11.content: Next on the list of important questions, where did you shrink at?
11.title: Where?

111.content:
You were visiting a big city in the Pokemon world, attending a field trip of sorts with your class from a Pokemon Trainer School. Keep in mind, this doesn't necessarily mean your ten. Most playable trainers in the games aren't ten... Anyways, back on topic! You and your class were heading towards a large science laboratory building in the city, that being the destination for this field trip... The building was in sight at this point, the group being lead there by the teacher and other adults in single file lines.

Within about one minute, you and the rest of the class arrive at the building, all going in... You see your teacher whispering to one of the women in lab coats working there, pointing to you as she was doing so... And looking around the main office, there were a few Pokemon in there as well... An Eevee was being fed some berries by one of the workers, an Elgyem seemed to be assisting in some experiments near the front desk, and a Skrelp was being examined by a worker near the back... A few students strayed away from the group to look at the Pokemon, but most stayed where the were...

You see your teacher motioning you over to her as she and the woman she was talking to walked into a room near the back... And of course you followed since it was your teacher... But as soon as you walked through the door, the woman in the lab coat sprayed you in the face with some kind of chemical in a Repel bottle... But it definitely was NOT a Repel. As soon as you inhaled whatever it was, you immediately began to feel dizzy, and soon passed out right there... But when you awoke, you received a shocking surprised... You'd shrunken down, now only about two or three inches in height.

As for WHERE you woke up though... You were still in the building, likely in a basement floor based on the lack of windows... The room seemed to be a mixture of a playroom, and a place for physical check-ups and tests. It was fairly colorful with a few toys around, as well as differently sized exercise equipment such as weights and treadmills that ranged from small enough for an Eevee to large enough for a Golurk. The same woman who you assume shrank you was sitting at a desk in the corner, seeming to be on the phone. There were also two Pokemon in the room as well. There was an Emolga happily playing with some blocks, and a Riolu currently using one of the small treadmills... As for exactly where you were during all of this? You were just kind of on the floor, in the middle of the room...
111.title: A city

11411112.content:
A sudden rustling in the bushes the mystery Pokemon had vanished into alerts you to the incoming danger, and you are forced to quickly duck into a small crevice in the wall, just barely big enough for you to fit into while sitting down. You manage to wedge in and still keep enough of a vantage point that you can see your pursuer come out of the bushes. What you see comes as something of a surprise to you.

         It had sounded like a much larger Pokemon, but what you bore witness to was a nearly, no, very humanoid looking fox that stood just under the size of an average man. It had a daintily small head, a slim yet shapely hourglass form to its body, and it had a lot long fur in shades of white, yellow, and maroon that draped from the Pokemon's body like a wizard's robe, and even from a distance it looked luxuriously soft and well-kept. The most noticeable feature of the Pokemon, however, were the giant ears it sported, and the two humongous, flame-shaped orange tufts of fur that poked out from them. Comparing that description to those you remembered from the Pokedex, you were able to identify the Pokemon as Delphox, the final evolution of Fennekin.

         The Delphox looked around for a second before stepping into the cavern you were sheltering in, drawing a medium-sized branch out of its cloak, scratching the tip against the fur and using the friction to catch it ablaze, holding what was now a torch in front of it to light its way. It looked around normally for a moment before raising its free paw and taking on a concentrated expression, its eyes beginning to glow a gentle violet. It didn't take much for you to realize that the Delphox was scanning the area using its Psychic powers, trying to find you. Panic began to well up in you and you looked about nervously, seeking some kind of escape route.

Maybe it was just the Delphox outside, but you had the feeling you weren't alone in this place... You began walking aimlessly through the dark cave, feeling around in front of you... The reason you were feeling around in front of you was just because you didn't want to accidentally run into a wall or anything... But eventually, your hands fell onto something... Alive... You stumble back as your hands touch the soft and furry object, and you hear the tell tale sounds of a Noibat. A pair of dimly gleaming lights suddenly appear above and ahead of you, and you realize that they must be the big yellow eyes of the Noibat reflecting what little light reaches this deep into the cave. It's too dark to see anything clearly, though, and you begin stepping backwards in fear of the Noibat suddenly lashing out at you without your being able to see it.

The two gleaming spots move around as the Noubat turns its head to try and see what touched it. After a few moments, a quiet yet high pitched screech echoes through the cave, and an instant later, the two gleaming eyes turn right towards you. It seems like the creature just used echolocation, and discovered where you are. You keep stepping backwards, not making any sudden movements as you try to back away from the giant Pokemon, but you can tell that it's approaching you. It's probably far too close to escape from, and it knows where you are despite the darkness.

You ponder your options. Stop moving and let it reach you--maybe it is just curious about what you are? Or, turn and run away--maybe you'll surprise it and it won't catch up to you.

11411112121.content:
Your legs feel like a coiled spring, ready to launch you blindly into the darkness — away from this creature. Through an herculean amount of force of will, you stand your ground and let the Noibat approach. Fleeing would just entice the Noibat to chase, you suppose. You couldn’t outrun it. Better to appear docile than to look like prey.
          Pit-pat-pitter-pat. The Noibat’s feet resound against stone cave floor as it came closer. In the darkness, all you could see is its glowing, yellow eyes. Now, they are inches away, trained on you. You could hear its high-pitched, nasally breaths whistle as it breathes through its nose. A humid, warm cloud of air envelops you as it exhalles from its mouth. With it, carries a strange smell. A bizarre mix of bad breath and fermented berries. The odor instantly compulses you to cough as you let out a tight-chested wheeze. You quickly recover, staving off further coughs with a forced cordial smile. To your surprise, you hear a voice, milquetoast and treble.
         “You...so small,” it speaks rapidly. Each word is a brisk high-pitched burst. “Funny! Not many...smaller than me.” In the darkness, you watch Noibat’s glowing eyes circle around you. Its irises quickly flit back and forth scrutinizing your form. A billow of a wind brushes past as the Noibat skirts around you. But still, you cannot see anything but the bat’s eyes: ghostly lanterns lit by a yellow flame, its slitted irises a black something rattling from within.
         “Yeah,” you admit nervously, “I’m not used to it either — being small and all.” To your left, you hear the crisp click of the Noibat’s claws as they rest themselves on the hard cave floor. The Noibat’s fur rustles as the bat Pokemon adjusts its unseen position. You pray that it’s not preemptively preparing to block your escape routes.
          “You always been small, no?” Its eyes immediately come close, far too close for comfort. They squint, examining you — slightly snuffing out your only light in the process. You hear the Noibat grumble. At least you think it’s the Noibat. It could its stomach. That’d be bad. You stop thinking about that.
          “It’s… a long story. To be honest, I don’t really know either but — you seem nice! We’ve already got a little camaraderie started, right? Your small, I’m… smaller. We could probably help each other out!”
With a hot puff of air from its nostrils, the Noibat’s head retreats. “I help you, I get what?” Its tone implies curiosity rather than indignation. “What do I get?”
          Your head instantly houses a whirlwind of thoughts. What do Noibat like? What do Noibat like? To your frustration, you can’t come up with any decent answer. Caves? Ear-scratches? How am I supposed to even reach its ears?? Your internal voice grows more desperate as your face goes bright red. You hope Noibat are colorblind.
         The Noibat clicks, clearly confused. “Did you not think of that?” Its funky berry-breath washes over you again. You mind fumbles for a response.
         “I, uh — you like berries, right?” You jabber out. It was something, at least.
         The Noibat’s eyes shift into an expression of pure confusion. “What? Yes — but—”
         “Yes! I knew it! I smelt it!” you announce with pride. The Noibat slowly blinks. Never before have you regretted a sentence more.
          “Little person, little...brain, maybe?” You hear a whistling whine of air traveling through Noibat’s nose as it sighs, exasperated. “You have no berries, anyhow. Why offer what you don’t have?”
         You didn’t really have an answer. You guess you could find them, right? Maybe? Either way, you’re gonna need confidence to sell this. You cross your arms and look up to the Noibat’s eyes, which were slowly donning the look of growing impatience.
         “Well,” you say in a slightly-deepened voice, “do you want those berries or not? You’re not gonna get anything lazing around in this cave. Honestly, I think the stereotype is true. You are blind as a bat if you can’t see I’m telling the truth.” The truth is, you weren’t. You have no idea what kind of berries Noibat like or where they’d be if you did know. You might’ve saw a patch of Pecha berries somewhere earlier…
The Noibat let out an annoyed high-pitch huff. It certainly didn’t like being insulted, but did it believe you?

          “You call me blind? You can’t see two-feet in front of you.” You feel a sudden tug from behind you as you are lifted into the air, presumably by the Noibat’s claws. You’re dangling in front of the Pokemon, its glowing eyes envelop your field of view — like two super moons in a too-small night sky. “You know what I see? Lies! Miltank-manure. All coming from you.          Noibat collects itself, lets out a singular composing cough (into its other berry-filled claw), and looks at you. “Of course… I’m still going to eat you! Your face was hilarious, though!” And with that, it brings you closer than you’ve ever been...and throws the berry in his other hand in its mouth. You glower at the bat as he chews loudly in front of your face. He’s clearly toying with you.

You can smell though, but the result is quite obvious: The same revolting combo of smells from when you first met the Noibat — nauseatingly sugary scent of berries (clearly Bluk, this time) and insalubrious bad breath. You hear the watery sound of traveling spittle as it sloshes around you and past the tongue. All of a sudden you’re lifted as its tongue raises you to the roof. You hear the distinct sound of the Noibat swallowing as some of the mixture is swept away and sent tumbling down into its throat.          The saccharine and repulsive mèlange you were in begins to shake stir as the Noibat had another giggle-fit.
         “Tee-huhuhu…” the Noibat obnoxiously laughs. Its... unusual giggle is loud and surrounds you, but is slightly muffled, “Now you know where the berries are! Too bad you can’t have any though...” The Noibat chuckles a bit at its own joke. “Oh, I’m sorry! You can’t see anything! No light! You’re blind! Isn’t that funny? Someone said that about me, once!” The Noibat erupts into full-blown laughter. The resulting waves and tides from within the Noibat’s stomach momentarily dunk you underneath the surface of the bat’s belly juices. Floating in the middle of the bat’s revolting stew, you tumble about as you completely lose all sense of up, down, left, and right. Your heart beats wildly — like shoes in a tumble dryer. The last thing you’d ever want is to drown in a manic bat’s belly.
          Fortunately, the Noibat composes itself. Now that the world is calm, you try to find your footing. You swim in an unknown direction until you bump into a soft wrinkled wall: the stomach wall! You’ve narrowed ‘up’ down to two directions. You take a guess on which leads up and begin to inelegantly paddle towards it. Question is, which direction did you really pick?
114111121212.title: No Bat is Gonna Believe That...

choices: You decide to get through one of the exits of the stomach
You decide to bid your time and wait for Noibat to eat something
1141111212121.content:
Choosing a direction, you swim, hoping you're not wrong. A few seconds later, your head surfaces, and you involuntarily gasp for air madly, filling your lungs with the acrid smell around you. It's unpleasant. It's breathable, but very unpleasant. It's better than not breathing and staying submerged in Noibat's gastric juices, though. "Come on, give me a break! Is this really how you treat a defenseless person?"

"Defenseless? I dunno. Being small doesn't mean you're defenseless, you know"

"What do you expect me to do at this size? I'm much smaller than you!"

"I dunno! Be smart, think of something? That's what I'd do if I was at your size! And not insult someone to their face, that wouldn't be bad either"

The more it mentioned your faux-pas, the more you regretted it. Maybe you wouldn't be in this situation if you had been more careful with your words. You swim to the wall, using a hand to stay there, to not drift back to the center of the stomach thanks to Noibat's movements. "Look, I'm sorry. I was desperate, I didn't know what to do. You have to believe me, I didn't mean harm!"

"Then you tried to fool me. Okay, that I didn't mind as much, it was funny to see you fumble, but you tried. It almost makes me want to see you make a fool of yourself some more. Too bad you're food now" it sounded indifferent to your fate, you couldn't find a trace of compassion in its voice. You swatted away a glob of chewed berry, it would be a problem if those stuckon you.

"I don't want to die, please help me! I'm sorry, okay? I'm sorry!"

You beg, gasping for air, talking until you have to breathe again. You plead like you have never pleaded before. If you can get it to listen, to give you one chance, maybe you won't die or be digested. At this point you have nothing to lose. You beg for several minutes until, with a huff of exasperation, Noibat interrupts you."Okay, fine, just shut up! You really are no fun, not even as food!" You hoped that mean you would get out soon. It didn't happen. Instead of pressing him on, you waited, hoping it had changed its mind.

Time passed. The warm melange around you got warmer and higher, the contents of the stomach churned, trying to drag you with it. You held onto the wall with all your strength, barely managing to stay in one place. The juices around you had slowly started to make you feel strange, like ants were walking all over your skin. Thankfully, Noibat's acids seemed to be rather slow, but you didn't doubt they would be lethal if too much time passed.Your eyes adjusted to the darkness. You couldn't see well, but after spending some time inside Noibat's stomach, now you could see the wall right in front of you, the surface of the liquid surrounding you, the mushy islands of chewed berries littering the place. You didn't know how long it was before you heard from Noibat again.

"You there? Did you die?"

"No! Still alive!"

"Fine. You know what? I'm curious. Survival of the strongest and all that, you know that? So I thought I should give you a chance to stay alive. What do you think?"

If it meant not dying, you were willing to do anything. You nodded, even if Noibat couldn't see you.

"Yeah, I agree! What do I have to do?"

"Prove you deserve to survive a little longer...by escaping! It's that simple. You get out, you don't die. You fail, you die"

"Escape?" Did it mean from its stomach? From its body? From the cave outside? You really hoped it was just from its body, because in your current state, it would take a miracle to escape the entire cave. "Fine, I will!

"A fair warning, because I'm fair despite everything: even if you get out of me, that doesn't mean I'll leave you alone, okay? Just saying!"

So even if you did get out of it alive, it held the right to keep playing with you to its heart's content. That wasn't a fun thought, but it wasn't like you had a choice. Deciding not to waste your breath replying, you start scheming how to escape.

The least it depended on Noibat doing something, the better. You had to do this with your own hands. What to do, though?
1141111212121.title: You swam up. Fresh(-ish) air, ho!

choices: Noibat realizes your method of escape! It begins to devise a way to stop you...
Noibat's thoughts are interrupted as it hears a rustle in the bush nearby...
11411112121211.content:
You rest your back on the wrinkled walls of the bat’s belly. Your right hand lays on the stomach’s rubbery walls; the other wades through the broth you’re floating in.
         How can you even get out of here? The voice in your head drips with a foreboding fear: the fear that your days might end by being this dolt’s lunch. It would be humiliating, although certainly unique….
         A sudden lurch, you’re thrown away from the belly wall and into the half-digested slop. Splat! Splosh! Your thoughts are most rudely interrupted. You’re barely under the surface — facedown. Of course.
         You stretch out your left hand upward. After travelling through the contemptible liquid and bumping into gluey clumps of who-knows-what, you feel your fingertips break the surface. The warm air is welcoming. Partially because your fingers can’t smell its detestable odor. When you resurface, you take a deep breath and wish you were more like your fingers. For a small moment, you think you have a moment of peace. That is, before you hear a distinct swallowing sound. Moments later, an abominable amalgamation of spit and berry nails you with a direct-splat.
         You glower as Bluk berry leaks out of your ears. You are not spending another moment in this deranged purple rat! You don’t care if you have to crawl all the way through his guts — as long as it's the way out!
         A wave of burning determination washes over you. That’s exactly what you got to do… You begin to turn the insane machination over in your head. He’s not going to let you up his throat or out his mouth. Not without a fight, anyway. And you don’t think you can take him… You silence your thoughts as the gravity of the idea hits you. Words can’t describe the inanity of your idea. However, the glorps and glops around you describe a more macabre fate. Your fate if you decide to remain idle.
         You close your eyes (out of habit more than anything — you can’t see anyway) and take a deep breath. Acrid air enters your nostrils and your mouth and your lungs. Unpleasant, but not dangerous. You hold it in, tight-chested. Then, you take the plunge. You dive beneath the stomach’s surface, a farrago of berries and bile, and swim downward through the mélange. Now that you are submerged, completely enveloped in an alien mixture, you are keenly aware of its strangeness. Too solid to be water, it reminded you of oatmeal — a lake’s worth of oatmeal. An eternal moment passes before your fingers brush against the bottom. You bring yourself closer, feeling the wrinkled lakebed to find the exit. It didn’t take you long.
         Your hands slide across a band of smooth muscle — in contrast to anything you’ve found so far. You hurriedly inspect it and find it to be ring shaped...and closed tight.
         A mounting pressure in your chest warns you that you’re on borrowed time. Without hesitation, you try and force your hands through the circle.
         To your surprise, after only a breath’s worth of work, the sphincter readily opens. Like air rushing out of a can of compressed air, the “water” behind you surges through. You are carried with the jet. Tumbling and spinning, lost among a stream of bubbles and semi-solid mush.
         Eventually, you eventually find yourself...somewhere else. You’re in a fleshed tube, cramped. Prone, your left arm in front of you. Your right arm presses to your side. Liquid (thinner than the stomach’s) fills half of tunnel. Fortunately, your head is above the fluid and you can breathe.
◓ ◓ ◓

         Noibat feels...funny. The purple bat rests within a Bluk berry bush. The sprawling, tangling vegetation completely obscures the Pokemon. Even the golden glow of its eyes cannot penetrate the foliage.
         “Belly…not good.” A two-pronged black claw reaches down to rub the lower part of the bat’s belly.
         “Not bad, either.” Noibat says with a huff as its stomach rumbles strangely. “But not good. Not bad, not good.”
         Noibat’s right claw slips through the green of the foliage surrounding it, its other claw continues to cradle its belly. Two moments later, Noibat’s claw bumps into a berry and fetches it for its master.
         The black-blue berry rests in its right claw. A dark mirror. The Pokemon’s image reflects from its smooth surface, slightly distorted, tinted yellow from its gazer’s scrutiny. Noibat appreciates it for a moment. Then, it throws it into its mouth, chews messily, and swallows.
At this moment, the Noibat feels a small push from within its tummy. A puckish grin slides up its cheeks like an unwoven thread. It thinks you’re protesting its Bluk Berry snack. Little did it know, the truth is much stranger…

Noibat puts a claw to its chin, thinking. Does it know?
11411112121211.title: Into the Depths of the Bat Cave

choices: ...it turns around, noticing you! Will it honor its deal?
114111121212112.content:
They say time flies when you’re having fun. They neglect to mention what happens when you’re not having fun: Time realizes it should be flying, but decides to call in sick. Then goes to bed, refuses to budge, and oversleeps. That’s how it feels, at least.
         In other words, it’s an awfully wordy way of saying that it feels like nothing is happening.
         You are still in the claustrophobic caverns of the Noibat’s digestive system. The fleshed tunnels are endless. The smell is horrendous. Time is meaningless. Everything feels identical. The intestines are ridged, tiny protuberances line the walls. The “water” level of the intestines has lowered a bit, but is present. Unfortunately, you’re forced to lay in the stomach-scented stuff, still.
         Every so often, the passage undulates and carries you forward. When this happens, the intestines compress a bit, pressing the villi against you. It’s an odd experience. Like being scrunched by spaghetti.
         The best indication that time, in fact, is still moving is the soundscape. You could hear the stomach grumble above (below?) its contents sloppily sloshing around. The Noibat’s organs babble in a tongue of groans and gurgles. Sometimes, you’d hear the muffled voice of your devourer. It sounds strangely booming. All the high-tones are dulled by the flesh surrounding you. Other times, you’d hear (and feel) it move. Organs would make a strange wet sound as they moved about the body cavity. You’d feel yourself move, too. The fluid in the intestines shifts, coating a once-dry side of your body. Sometimes, the tunnel squishes in as the Noibat moves in some odd position. That is the worst one...
◓ ◓ ◓

         Time passes, despite your earlier fears. You felt right arm press against a strange, smooth… thing. A ring? Ah, you remember. It feels like the exit of the stomach. Another exit? Your blear mind snaps to attention and you immediately try to force your way through. You snake your arm through the orifice, up to the shoulder. To your dismay, you do not feel the cool air of the cave. Only the warm walls from within the bat’s depths.
         Nevertheless, You push your body against the duodenum. Your shoulder goes through, your face begins to, before you begin to regret your decision. An abhorrent odor smites your nostrils with an unholy scent. You push on. Now, you’re halfway through. You brace your right hand on the wet wall of the strange tunnel and push yourself through. You undoubtedly know you must be in the Noibat’s large intestine.
         Fortunately, you appear to be the only tenant in the bat’s lower complex. Small victories, you suppose.
         The tube you’re in is larger. There is no liquid here, but walls are still wet and warm. You have enough space to crawl, no longer subjected to its internal’s sluggish pace. A fact you are most thankful for, given that you want to get out before things get in.
         As noted earlier, the smell is bad. Really bad. Horrid, repugnant — simply vile. It’s enough to make your eyes water. Although, they may be tears of joy, knowing that your journey is nearly at its end.
         You inch yourself through the Pokemon’s deepest depths. Up, down, and all around — the tunnels twist and curve but you cannot be stopped. You will escape.
         The Noibat does not make it easy for you. You quickly learn to fear the sound of a specific, rumbling grumble. It always starts behind you. Sometimes it starts small, its intensity quickly grows. You feel the intestines compress. Then, you’re in a wind tunnel. A noxious monsoon of heated air blasts past you in a nauseating storm. Even after it passes, it leaves behind a detestable scent, like irradiating fallout from a nuclear bomb.
         This...is not an exaggeration. What you would give to never have experienced this…
◓ ◓ ◓

         Noibat is enjoying a night’s walk in the woods near the cave. The sky is clear. The moon is full. The leaves on the trees above filter the descending moonlight, fracturing the white light into a speckled mosaic of light and shadow.
         It’s been a day since it ate the strange, small critter and it assumes they likely perished. A shame, it is. They were funny! Not as funny as Noibat, of course. But that is a high bar to reach!
         There’s a skip in its step: a half-walk, half-hop. The brief moment it leaves the ground, its wings do a quick flap before the bat lands gently on soft, cool grass. All the while, the Noibat makes a nearly-silent high-pitched whistle: echolocation.
         Noibat’s bouncing gait suddenly halts as the Pokemon stands stock-still, an unexpected pressure in its lower body. A familiar feeling, albeit oddly timed: nature’s call.
◓ ◓ ◓

         Inside, you are beat. Exhausted, smelly, and longing for freedom, you are unable to find the energy to continue on. Earlier, you arrived in a strange chamber, upside-down. Its exit is blocked off by a clenched ring. You know where you are.
         The moment you entered, Noibat noticed too. You felt its bouncy, fluttery movements immediately halt as you felt your surroundings momentarily tighten in surprise. Now, things are still. Your devourer takes demure, stiff steps. Suddenly, the world tilts and you feel your entire prison move slightly downward. Unbeknownst to you, the Noibat crouches. Its body is inclined, its legs spread apart, and its claws touch the earthen forest floor.
         Then, the Noibat pushes. Its purple belly flattens. Its round eyes close as it makes a thin treble squeak. In its innards, you feel the slick heated walls of the bat’s rectum squash inward — hard. You’re pushed downward, your face pressing against the tight opening, but not out. The bat’s belly relaxes. It takes a small breath. Then, does it again. The crushing walls return as you’re mashed by uncaring flesh. Yet, you’re still not free. Momentarily, the orifice in front of you opens and the intruding light blinds you. Freedom! So close!
         Noibat momentarily relents. Its clarion-like voice mutters through beleaguered breaths. Through the groans of its labored digestive tract, you catch one of its words: again. Your hostile environment renews its efforts to expel you as it squeezed and pushed you against the bat’s exit. The tightened walls of the rectum twitch as they are strained. Noibat’s groans reverberate through your bones as you’re squeezed like a tube of toothpaste.
         No luck. Again, it tries. No dice. Again — nada. Once more. Nothing! But then…
         ...Your head squeezes through! You’re met with the soft tufts of hair that encircle the Pokemon’s legs. The night air is frigid, but a welcome relief from the boiling depths of your former entrapment. Oh! And the light! You could almost feel the kiss of the moon’s soft glow.
The rest of you quickly follows, expelled with squawk from the bat above. You land on your back, the fall cushioned by the wild grasses. Your view is...interesting. You see the fluffy behind of an exasperated Noibat and a luminous circle of ivory amongst the stars. A rare sight: a double moon.
         But just as you gathered your bearings, you spot Noibat beginning to stand. Its wings spread, its claws dig into the earth beside you and…
114111121212112.title: The Full Tour

choices: It's around the same size than the Noibat
It's huge! Much larger than the Noibat
1141111212121121.content:
You froze once you noticed the Noibat was beginning to stand. With some luck it wouldn't see you if you stayed still, that's what you thought. With your heart pounding, you stared, not even daring to breathe in case it'd attract your tormentor's attention.

Only when the Noibat collapses you move. Looks like getting you out of its body got it exhausted. You don't feel bad, after all, it ate you and would have let you to perish if you hadn't forced your way out, so instead you stand up and run away as fast as you can. You definitely don't want to stay around, especially because the Noibat wasn't trustworthy at all. It warned you, even if you escaped it still held the right to play with you. That was something you wanted to avoid at all costs.

You run through the forest as fast as you can, navigating with difficulty through the tall blades of grass, climbing tree roots and hoping you'd put some distance between you and the crazy bat. After a while, you're very tired. You hope you're far away from the cave you encountered the Noibat in, although realistically, given your size, you can't be that far.

Even this short distance is better than being with the bat, anyway.

Gasping for breath, you look around. The night is clear, the moon is shining, the air is crisp and refreshing, but you don't feel safe being out in plain sight. Some Pokemon may see you. You didn't want to take any risks. Frantically, you examined your surroundings, stumbling upon something that could mean your salvation: a burrow. A cursory exploration proves it's abandoned. It's not a very good burrow for most Pokemon, it's narrow and goes deep into the earth before taking a 90° degree curve.

Although almost no Pokemon would like it, to you in your current state that burrow is heaven. You dive in, anxious for some safety. Once you're deep beyond the curve, you sit down, thinking about the situation. You're tired, cold, you smell exactly like anything that passed through a Noibat's intestines would smell like, and it doesn't seem like you can solve any of that except the very first one. Hoping the next day would be kinder to you, you fall asleep in the depths of the burrow, without dreaming at all.

When you wake up the next day it seems luck is on your side. The day starts much kinder to you. A voice you don't know echoes into the burrow.

"Hello? I know you're in there! You're a...a tiny critter or something"

You didn't dare to look who it was. It wasn't Noibat, that much was clear. The voice didn't belong to the bat. Despite that, it could mean danger, the owner of that voice saw you get into the burrow. the last night, apparently.

"Are you okay? Last night you looked like you were afraid for your life. I was — it got me worried. It must be tough to be so small. That's why I brought you gifts"

Gifts?

"Some food, and also some leaves if you want to be warm. Come on, it's rude not to say hello"

The thought of food and warmth is rather enticing, you must admit.

"I can smell you from here. You smell pretty — pretty bad. Is that to deter predators? Because I'm sure that'll work"

Cautious, you peek over the curve of your new home. The first thing you see is a few berries on the floor, as well as leaves. Looks like the Pokemon who is there wasn't lying. Having a friendlier Pokemon to rely on could be a good idea. That was why, after some thought, you decided to approach. You were pretty sure no matter what species it is, it'd be gigantic compared to you. By your current size you were sure you'd be easy prey even to a Joltik!

Judging by how you weren't immediately grabbed and eaten, it indeed was a Pokemon of a kinder nature than the Noibat. Once you exited the burrow, you finally saw the species. The species of the Pokemon that's trying to talk to you is...
1141111212121121.title: ...it collapses, enervated. Good-night Noibat…

choices: You both finish your meal in peace.
Your meal concludes, but Honchkrow needs to talk...
11411112121211211.content:
A startling sight! Resting upon a low-hanging branch, is your gift-bearer! A mantle of groomed black feathers drapes across a stout avian form. A white tuft of soft down hangs from its yellow beak. Atop its head is a fanciful hat of comprised of its own feathers. Peering from the dark shade of its hat, two half-circle eyes. There’s no mistaking it! The Pokemon before you is a—
         “Honchkrow,” it says unruffled. With a genial wave of a black wing and a tip of its similarly colored hat, the Pokemon greets you.
         When the gesture concludes, it looks to you.
         You stare back.
         A subtle look of worry graces the Dark-type.
         An awkward, pregnant pause.
         Honchkrow opens its beak, as if to say something, then slowly closes it after a moment of silent reconsideration.
         You begin to inch back into your burrow.
         Immediately, the black bird becomes ruffled. “H-hold up!” It says with a start. Its wings unfurl! However, its flusterment causes its feet to tie. Honchkrow falls backwards from its perch in a spinning black and red ball of frantically flapping feathers. The Pokemon crashes to the forest floor landing in a scant pile of pine needles.
         Whomp.
         You wince in sympathy. Calling the pine needles a “pile” might be a bit generous…
         It's now when you notice the Honchkrow’s more… peculiar gift. Outside the burrow and to your right (a couple of your steps away) is...a gigantic fork. Its silver sheen is dulled and stained.
         A shout from the pine needle pile:
         “The meal-trident is the gift! With it, you can eat like your larger brethren!” Honchkrow is currently bespeckled with little green pins as it meanders dizzily about, wings shuffling across the ground — looking for its missing hat. Looking up, the bird momentarily locks eyes with you, then breaks away. One of its wings rubs the top of its head.
         “W-well,” it says. Its voice is wobbly and imbalanced. “It might be a little big but it's the thought that c-counts, right?” The last thing you expected coming from the bird’s beak is a stutter.
         You shake off your confusion before you ask the bird, “...are you okay?”
         “No!” Honchkrow says. Then, its face lights up — red eyes awash in relief. It carefully reaches down to the ground and picks up its formerly-lost hat in its beak.
         “Ah, much better.”
         It flicks the hat upwards in a quick motion. The headwear flutters through the air, flipping and spinning and falling. It’s graceful in a strange way. It reminds you of the tumbles and twists of a Pokeathlon high diver’s descent.
         ...Then it misses Honchkrow’s head on the way down. It looks at you in embarrassment.
         It turns out — yes — birds can blush.
◓ ◓ ◓

         “...So, I was flying overhead — y’know doo-do-doo, flutter-flutter — and then I saw you! And when I got closer, I smelled you!” Honchkrow is sitting in front of you, its feet tucked neatly under its plumage. Wrapped in a vestment of warm green leaves, you are enjoying your first meal in a day-and-a-half (without the use of your newly-acquired “meal-trident.”) Honchkrow continued to prattle its beak before you interjected.
         “Why did you help me? Aren’t Dark-types usually, um, bad?”
         Honchkrow’s eyes break away, unusually interested in the ground. You could almost see the cartoonish bead of nervous sweat materialize. Feeling regret pang in your chest, you change the subject.
         “I don’t think you’ve ever told me your name.” you say.
         “Honchkrow!” it says, now invigorated.
         “That’s your name?”
         “Indeed.”
         “But that’s the name of your species!” you say, berry juice dripping down your chin.
         “Quite right.” it confirms.
         “Then is every Honchkrow called ‘Honchkrow?’”
         “Spot on.” The bird clacks its beak with a clap! “And every Murkrow is called Murkrow. It’s a big deal when you evolve. You get a new name. Takes a while to get used to. Sometimes you don’t even notice when Pokemon use your old name...”
         “Is there way to names apart, Murkrow?
         “Well, yes! Male Honchkrow names are pronounced Honchkrow. Females: Honchkrow.”
         You stay silent for a moment before saying, “...I don’t hear a difference.”
         “Well! Allow me to repeat — Honchkrow, Honchkrow!”
         “...”
         “…”
         “...So,” you ask the bird, “is your name the latter?
         “The former.” it replies.
         “...so you’re male?” You guess.
         “I knew you could hear the difference!” he triumphantly crows with joy. “You’ve got keen ears. That must be why they’re so big!” You decide to take his “compliment” in stride.
11411112121211211.title: Nothing to Crow About

choices: Allow him to eat you — with his BEAK.
Partake in his lunacy. You've been through worse...
Reject his plan. It's a horrible idea!
114111121212112113.content:
After finishing your meal, Honchkrow shuffles awkwardly before addressing you.
         “So, I waited until you were finished and c-comfortable with me before telling you this but — you can’t stay here.”
         You look at him, puzzled. What is he talking about?
         “I-in the den, I mean. A lot of critters have the same idea as you, y’know. They’d pop right in the burrow with you and since you’re so small…” He trails off and his posture slumps insecurly.
         “Look,” he says as his spine straightens slightly, “I wanted to show you that I’m not a bad guy — that I want to help you! And I can! I can fly you somewhere safer! B-but…” Honchkrow finds a frog in his throat.
         “But?” you repeat his last word.
         “W-w-well I don’t have a good way to carry you…” he peers downward at his wicked talons. The Pokemon shudders at the thought of you being sliced to bits in his grasp. “But that doesn’t mean I don’t have a way…” Honchkrow glances toward you, the bird’s blush returned. “I j-just can’t carry you on me. I c-can carry you in me…”
         You pray he isn’t suggesting what you think he is.
         “Like in your hat?” you suggest.
         “N-no. I drop my hat quite often. Every day, in fact. Sometimes multiple times a day…”
         “Are you really suggesting—”
         “Yes…”
         “In you.”
         “Yes…”
         “Where exactly?”
         “W-well...you’ve got two options.”
         “Did you really just say that!?”
         “And my belly’s got acid in it…”
         “You are not suggesting—”
         “No-no-no!”
         You stare at him, dumbfounded. He’s practically hiding behind his wingfeathers.
         Peeping from behind the feathery curtain, he says, “you don’t have to go there! I’m just really worried of what could happen if I do eat you, um…”
         “Orally.” You say with disgust.
         “Don’t say it that way!” He says flapping his feathers. “You make it sound so gross!”
         “It’s way less gross than what you’re suggesting!” You shout with indignation. Sighing, you look back at Honchkrow. He’s practically shrinking in embarrassment — and at the rate he’s going — he’ll match you in size before the minute is up.
114111121212112113.title: Corvid Convo

choices: A trainer on the ground. They're trying to catch him!
Honchkrow encroached upon the territory of a powerful Pokemon!
He was just trying to show off. Awkward...
1141111212121121131.content:
You see see Honchkrow peeping through a hole in his wing feathers, just big enough to catch a glimpse of his red-pupiled eye: a round ruby on a white saucer.
         “Yes, I c-can do that,” he says lowering his wings, no longer hiding — coming closer. He approaches cautiously. Right foot, left foot. Soon, they’re beside you; he’s above you. He looms like a dark tower: gigantic, imposing, and even a little sinister. But you know Honchkrow is a good Pokemon. He’d never hurt you. Yet, you can’t help but feel a little unnerved.
         You look up. His faraway head carves a dark silhouette into the night sky’s galactic canvas. The stars and the Milky Way are eclipsed. Their vibrant colors yielding to the bird’s feathery cloak of night.
         The star-shrouding shadow grows larger, Honchkrow’s beak coming closer. Color begins to return to his form. His feathers gain a shade of midnight blue, his beak regains its yellow: the color of jaundiced, aged bone. His maw opens. A color joins the palate: a deep wine-red that fades into a dark nothingness.
         Suddenly, his beak snaps shut — you not in it.
         “H-how do I do this? Do I just eat you? Like, peck you up? Would that h-hurt? Do you just walk in?” Honchkrow’s intimidation factor reset back to zero.
         “Open up; keep it open. I’ll just… walk in,” you reluctantly say.
         Honchkrow’s beak creaks open once more, suspended slightly off the ground but easy enough for you to step into. You approach the titanic beast. Your hand brushes the bottom, outside part of his beak — reassuring the Pokemon. He closes his eyes and breathes out. A warm wind, saturated and oddly-odored, whisks past you. It mixes with the cool night air before dispersing into the wood.
         You hear a ferocious sound: a strange rumbling growl. Honchkrow yelps, rising up and snapping his beak shut.
         “Sorry-sorry-sorry!” he cries.
         You’re confused before you realize: his stomach growled.
         “I didn’t mean to!” he apologizes fervently, “you’re not food! Y-you’re not food!”
         In response, all you could do is laugh. It’s ridiculous, darkly hilarious! You recollect yourself and find Honchkrow watching you, a bit abashed.
         “I think I’ll just eat you now…” he says opening his maw once more. You don’t resist as he slowly bends down, as your world grows warmer, and warmer, and warmer before it is dark — Honchkrow’s beak all around you. It begins close. You step off the cushy grass and onto the hard lip of his jaws. He tilts his head, no longer vertical. You fall onto the fleshed mat of muscle the lines the bottom of his maw. Sticky saliva coats you, getting in your hair and smearing itself on your face. A wet, fleshy strange thing lands on top of you. You deduce it to be Honchkrow’s tongue.
         “If it makes you feel any better,” Honchkrow mumbles, trying to move the least possible, but still manages to give you a good jostling, “you taste pretty bad.” With that, Honchkrow tilts his head up. Beak opening slightly, the last thing you see before being swallowed is the pale pocked profile of the moon.
         Gluk.
◓ ◓ ◓

         It’s been an hour since Honchkrow ate you, at least, you think it’s been. He’s flying now. Gliding on the night’s wind, every wing flap jostles his inner contents, slinging the sinful slurry — and you — in every which way. Fortunately, he’s a fairly steady flyer and can manage to stay aloft mostly on the updraft alone.
         It’s now when you recognize a curious thing. The belly juices don’t burn — strange. They don’t even tingle. Honchkrow’s stomach acids must be far stronger than Noibat’s, but yet…
         Abruptly, a shout — Honchkrow’s. Then, everything spins. Down is up, up is lost, left and right are meaningless. You’re submerged and emerge only to be submerged again. You’re weightless. Zero-G. Honchkrow must be falling!
         Honchkrow yaps a pitiful squawk as he flaps furiously, desperately trying to right himself (and keep ahold of his hat.) He looks down, tree-line fast approaching. Moments before he’d of crashed into a canopy, Honchkrow stabilizes and soars back into the skies. The cause of this?
1141111212121121131.title: Cravin' Craven Raven

11411112121211211311.content:
N-No! This isn't how it's supposed to go!

The plan was that he'd carry that small human somewhere safer, a helpful gesture that'd cement them as friends and also would make the human not be easy prey for any random Pokemon. Easy and nice, that was how the plan was. The jet of fire that crossed the sky, trying to blast him, didn't fit at all in that plan! It was very inconvenient, to say the least.

Honchkrow isn't a capable fighter, so his only choice is to make evasive maneuvers. In what may not have been an intentional move, Honchkrow dives down, loses control of his speed and flaps his wings to try to stabilize himself before he crashes once again into the pines and their needles. Honchkrow tries not to think of the possibility he's going to get covered in them again and manages to fly up in the brink of time. "I'm sorry, there's something going on!"

"What is it now?!" you ask from inside, slamming against the ceiling of Honchkrow's belly for the seventh time.

"It's one of your brethren, just that normal size and with a fire-type!"

A trainer, you deduce. You try to hold onto a wall to avoid being jostled around. With some luck this trainer is only aiming to knock out Honchkrow in a fight instead of capturing him, Honchkrow would be knocked out and all you'd have to do is wait until he recovered from fainting. Luckily for you, it seems his acids won't be dissolving you no matter how long you stay, so theoretically you could wait around for a very long while, the only problem being the boredom that'd befall you from sitting around with nothing to do other than wonder what Honchkrow ate hours ago other than the meal you shared with him.

You could easily endure that. The problem was the other possibility: the trainer capturing Honchkrow.

You weren't a Pokemon but you were currently inside of one. If the trainer captured Honchkrow, would you be sucked into the Pokeball too? You didn't want to find out! It was impossible it'd trap you to be associated with the trainer in any way, given how Pokeball technology didn't work that way, but Honchkrow was a different problem. If he was sucked into a Pokeball ad you were left behind you could be in trouble. To avoid that worst-case scenario, you hoped you'd be forced to come along, despite how much you disliked that.

And if only Honchkrow was captured, then you'd follow the trainer and try to reach Honchkrow, you decided. He was the only friend you had in your current state. You'd feel bad abandoning him.

"Try to flee!" you advised, getting showered with the mixture in the belly once again. Honchkrow flew in a circle, trying to reverse course and get away from the trainer on the ground. Desperately, he sped up, reaching a velocity he hadn't reached ever since a long time ago. It was liberating, he felt so fast and nimble, why didn't he fly like this before?

The hat falling off his head once again reminded him that was why. He couldn't hold onto his hat at those speeds. "Not again!" he squaked, trying to reach it, unable to do it before the hat fell between the trees.

"Did something happen?"

"My hat is gone!"

Again with the hat. "Can't you leave it there and just go away?"

"Never! My hat is my pride!" Leaving it behind was unthinkable! Without hesitation, Honchkrow landed on the ground, easily looking through the darkness to try to find the hat. It took him a moment to find it between the trees. Running and gripping it with his beak, Honchkrow flipped it into the air, miraculously catching it with his head with ease. He didn't have time to enjoy that lucky moment because that was all the trainer needed to find Honchkrow.

They approached slowly, a hand already holding a Pokeball. Honchkrow stepped back, fearing what could happen, until his back hit a tree. All around him there were a lot of trees, and although above the canopy was open, it was unlikely he'd be able to fly without being caught. "Go away!" Honchkrow shouted, opening his wings in what he hoped was an intimidating stance. To you inside his stomach that didn't sound too intimidating, you're already bracing yourself for what may happen now.

After what seems to be an eternity, the trainer makes their move.
11411112121211211311.title: A trainer on the ground. They're trying to ...

choices: Let you out right away! He has to apologize beak-to-face!
Take off. He promised to help and nothing will stop him now!
Try to forget any of this happened. You don't exist!
1141111212121121132.content:
“A-are you…” the big bird stops to recollect himself. He stands taller. He coughs into his wing. Then, he continues in a more confident voice, “you’re certain about this?” Honchkrow looks to you with eyes awash with anxiety. Truth be told, you’re not. But not-dying is pretty high on your priority list. Not-dying to painful acids even moreso. Compared to that, suffering this… indignancy ranks rather low.
         Honchkrow, blush in full flush, is raking his left claw through the dirt in a nervous tick. “I really, really don’t want to do this either,” Honchkrow says as he steps closer. He rests in front of you and brings his head low — you’re seeing eye-to-eye. “I don’t know if that makes you feel better. I only want to help,” he says softly. “I-I’m so sorry…” He stands up and turns his head away from you before his eyes can water. He’d rather perish before letting someone see him cry.
         You watch as his body pivots. His back faces you now. He takes a step back. A claw, dark as black oak, digs into the earth beside you — leveling the green grass with a soft crunch. Another step back. This time, his right claw. You hear the ruffle and shuffle of moving feathers as he adjusts his posture. His tail feathers loom over you. A cone of snow-white, tipped with blood-red down. You see him looking back, the brim of his hat half-obscuring his half-moon eye. Suddenly, you see him slip an ebon wing between his legs, down to the ground and face-up. His wingtips brush the top of the grass. They’re a gorgeous pattern of black and red. You never saw a bird’s feather this close before. You see each individual barb on every feather. It’s almost like his feathers have feathers…
         “Hop on my wingfeathers,” he says moving his prone wing slightly, “I’ll give you a lift.”
         For a moment, you falter. You see Honchkrow fluster. He begins to slump, his confidence draining. He made a new friend — and now he fears he lost them. He fears that they think he’s playing some sick game. That he wants this. The worst of it all: a small part of him, deep within — does.
         You’re on his wingtip, second from end and soft as cotton. Your avian escalator is lifting you to your destination slightly below his tail feathers.
         It won’t be too bad. Honchkrow thinks to himself. They’ll be okay; they’ll be fine. He reassures himself. Remember that time — long ago? When you were a Murkrow? You were...experimenting. There was this Joltik you... experimented with. The critter was...fine. Upset, violated — yes. It was a horrible thing...
         You hover inches away from the rear end of the bird. His shadow envelops you completely. Somehow, his feathers now seem to be darker than black. You wonder why you’re not moving. Is Honchkrow having second thoughts?
         You then notice a vile thing, enough to blanche your face and chill your bones. Emerging like an airplane from behind a dark storm cloud, something cylindrical, pink.
         ...But it felt...good. Honchkrow reminisces the feeling.
         Honchkrow is turned on!? The thought is sickening to you. You’re part of some sick fantasy. Nothing more than toy! Feeling angry and betrayed, you shout to him. “Honchkrow!”
         The bird snaps back to reality.
         “What is wrong with you!?”
         He begins to silently panic, feeling the blood drain from one head to another. A nightmare, come true!
         “Disgusting!”
         Honchkrow feels shame beyond imagining.
         “You really are an evil-type!”
         Honchkrow feels an uncharacteristic, broiling rage. A nerve has been hit.
         “Liar! Freak! I never should’ve trusted you—“
         Suddenly, the wing beneath you rockets upward, slamming you into the bird’s bottom. Your body lays flat across his rear, nearly lost amid a forest of black-blue feathers. You’re dazed, but unharmed. The impact was cushioned by his soft feathers.
         “My type does not mean I’m evil!” he cries, his acrimony granting him newfound confidence, evaporating his stutter. “And. I. Will. Help you!” You’re rubbed against his tail feathers as he clumsily tries to find his backport. His movements lack the dexterity or care he had shown earlier.
         You shout as you’re run across his black plumule. Fear overcomes all other emotions as you become keenly aware of how much larger the bird is to you. You’re helpless as you slip beneath the feathery surface. Your head comes across a strange, fleshed ring. It isn’t hard to guess what it is.
         Then, he begins to push you in.
         “I’m-sorry-that-I-ever-said-I'm-sorry-to-you-about -pushing-you-up-my-butt!” Honchkrow shouts, his words electric-fast due to a mix of adrenaline and pleasure.
         The slimy donut-shaped hole slips around your head. Its taut as a drum and does not give easily. But Honchkrow is determined and you no longer have a choice in the matter.
         You see nothing; you hear much; you feel more. His heartbeat sounds like a pair of shoes in a tumbler. You can hear it all around you. A primal sound, rich in bass. His organs groan as does he. Sounding from far away, you hear his beak chatter in orgasmic bliss. Constricting, mashing, tightening, the Pokemon’s rectum bears down on you as you’re forced ever deeper. The (thankfully clean) walls are slick, warm, slimy. They oscillate, growing tighter in bone-crushing pulses. Every time you believe they cannot be anymore binding, you’re proven wrong.
         Honchkrow feels the last of you slip inside him. There he stands, wing covering his bottom, his arousal fully arisen and in display. His beak is skyward and agape. A heart-melting full-body pulse of pleasure runs through him, starting from his rear and ending at the tip of his beak. He tenses and doesn't let up. It is enough to make his organs melt.
The, it happens again. And again. Honchkrow begins to rock back-and-forth, so lost in his fantasy that he forgets all about you. His body grows tighter, tighter, and tighter still…
         From within, you beat the revolting, ribbed walls that crush and squeeze with each of Honchkrow’s pleasure pulses. Soon, you can no longer move. You are completely binded as you hear the bird gasp and moan. Then, things grow tighter than they’ve ever been as Honchkrow stands, his feet apart, talons inward, wing over his privates — humping into his wing.
         Then, relief. Everything relaxes. Honchkrow clicks dreamily.
         A troubling storm cloud rolls over Honchkrow’s euphoric moment. His friend! Did he really—
         Back inside, you gasp for air but find only foul fumes. You cough, not even bothering to move or protest. Your entire body aches with a dull pain. No energy remains for you to lift yourself off the wretched floor. You hear Honchkrow’s voice reverberating through his bowels…
         “I-I-I… can’t believe. I w-wouldn’t…” Honchkrow dismays as he checks the sticky underside of his wing.
         “I-I-I'm s-sorry…” Honchkrow tears up, “I really am evil…”
         Does Honchkrow…
1141111212121121132.title: Fowl's Foul Haven Within the Raven

11411112121211211322.content:
Honchkrow is full of regret. With a heavy heart, he paces around, unaware of how much that's jostling you around in the deepest confines of his body. Luckily for everyone, he's too busy panicking to notice any sensations that may bring, and he has good reasons to be panicking! He just offended his friend very badly. The course of action now was clear: he had to apologize, maybe that way this budding friendship wouldn't be ruined forever. With that in mind, Honchkrow positioned his rear near the ground, intending to push out the tiny human.

Or should he really do that now? He promised he'd take the human away to a safer place. Wouldn't taking him out of his body now make him a liar? That would be worse than what he was now. At least if he fulfilled this promise, he could have something good to offer the human. That would help!

"We're leaving!" Honchkrow shouted at his rear. Inside him, you didn't hear him very well, but the feeling of weightlessness that covered you afterwards delivered the message clearly. So Honchkrow was already flying...you hoped it was to take you to a safer place.

------

You had no idea about how much time was passing, and that was because you were completely focused on staying completely still. Your muscles were cramped, and your entire body ached, but in your opinion it was a worthwhile sacrifice. The least pleasure you gave to Honchkrow the better, you thought. Knowing where you were, you knew moving could rub the sensitive walls around you, and after having witnessed by yourself just how easily Honchkrow was taken by the sensations he experienced, you didn't want to give him any reasons to keep you inside of him or do this to you ever again.

Not that you'd give him the chance.

At least you had a lot of time to think. Now that the horror of the situation was starting to pass, you could think in a more objective, calm manner, as hard as that was to believe. You evaluated your situation. You were still minuscule, far far away from the life you had before this entire nightmare started. The chances of you returning to normalcy were pretty much nonexistent. As proven by Noibat and Honchkrow, you were easy prey for pretty much every Pokemon in the world. The only things that could help you survive were your wits and your ability to get through disheartening situations.

You are pretty much doomed, weren't you? That can help you survive only for a while, you figure. You needed friendly Pokemon to be on your side. With an ally, your chances of survival would increase dramatically.

At first you had thought Honchkrow would be the friend you needed. He had taken the time to give you food, and also a fork. He gave you a fork! That was a nice detail, you had to admit. It was completely useless, but the thought is what counts. You were starting to like him, and then this entire problem with him happened. Although...he had suggested it as a way to help you. He had the best intentions.

"No, he didn't!" you shout, your voice echoing through the bowels. It didn't seem Honchkrow heard you. If he had the best intentions, he wouldn't have shoved you inside like this!

Those conflicting thoughts struggled inside your mind for a moment longer before you settled on a side once and for all.
11411112121211211322.title: Take off. He promised to help and nothing will ...

choices: Honchkrow lands right now. He's going to apologize?
You haven't arrived yet. You don't like the sounds above you.
114111121212112113222.content:
No. You're not forgiving Honchkrow.

Surrendering to your aching muscles, you shift positions, trying to knead as little as possible the walls around you. Your hands sink into the floor, you grimace at the sensations in your hands. "Ew" you mutter. Can Honchkrow feel this? Is he getting excited? You bet he is. He was treating you like a toy. So what if he said he wanted to help you? You don't even know if he was telling the truth! For all you know he's actually taking you to own you as his personal toy!

Noibat was awful, but at least the Noibat was honest about its intentions right away, and it was all because you made a mistake when talking to it. That had been your fault, you can admit that much. Honchkrow didn't have any excuse, you weren't going to overlook that!

Raising your head, you peer towards the direction the ring sealing you from the outside is supposed to be. Could you force your way through? Most likely not, and even if you could, you're in the air right now. You shouldn't even try. All you can do is wait until Honchkrow lands and lets you free, and once he does, you'll be running away as far as possible. With some luck you'll be okay.

"Uh, hello? You have been very quiet in there...you're still angry about what happened?" you can hear Honchkrow ask. You don't even bother answering. "You're still angry. I get it...look, I'm sorry. I dunno how to describe what I was thinking, I just...it wasn't that I wanted to use you or anything! You have to believe me"

You don't believe him at all. You gave him a chance, you had accepted to partake in the lunacy he had proposed, and he had betrayed your trust. For a moment you think of how it would have gone if it hadn't been for his unfortunate reaction. You'd have crawled into his rectum by yourself. Disgusted, you grimace. There was no reason at all you thought you'd ever do something like crawl into another Pokemon's ass ever again, but if by some unexpected reason you absolutely had to, it was going to be on your own terms.

"I'm sorry. I promise I'll apologize more when you're out. It's not too far, we'll get there in no time"

He wanted to apologize more...a small part of you wanted to believe him, but the rest of you stomped on it. You had made your decision.

-------

Time passed, and your mood soured more and more. You keep thinking back about how badly you're likely to do by yourself, and the constant smell around you doesn't lift your spirits at all. You feel like the stench's going to stick on you forever. Realistically you know it's something a few nice, long baths can get rid of, but right now you feel like you'll forever smell like you passed through two Pokemon's waste systems.

Which you did. You very much did. At least things can't get much worse than that, you decide.

"Are we there yet?!" you yell, your voice echoing into the bowels once again. This time it seems Honchkrow heard you.

"Yes, we're close!" outside, Honchkrow is flying as stable as possible, making sure not to lose his hat once again "You'll like the place, it's safe, there's plenty of friendly-"

"Just tell me when we're there!" you interrupt. Something about the way you said that tells Honchkrow you didn't want to talk at all, he whimpers pitifully and shuts up. Inside, you're glad. It's matter of time before you're out.

Everything around you feel different, though. It all feels slimier, somehow. It's nothing too bad, thankfully, but it does feel like everything's getting coated in preparation for...something. You can only guess what it is. You haven't forgotten where you are, after all. You hope Honchkrow arrives to the destination before anything gets anywhere near the space you're occupying right now. If any unwanted visitor from the rest of Honchkrow's digestive system creeps on you, you're definitely blaming Honchkrow for that.

With no other option than wait, you slide down the rectum towards the ring you came from, hoping it's not going to be long before you can get out.
114111121212112113222.title: You refuse to forgive Honchkrow

choices: “...in a rural PokeCenter. Only Pokemon are here right now…”
“...in my roost: an abandoned manor. Quiet now! I have roommates…”
“...somewhere. I don’t know… It’s better than the woods!"
1141111212121121132221.content:
The flaps of beating wings, the drum of a beating heart — the percussive rhythm of a sonorous orchestra: Honchkrow’s innards. The ominous gurgles and blurbles of his organs are akin to a rolling timpani. The shrill winds from outside: screeching woodwinds…
         A symphony most foul, indeed.
——
         You spend your time thinking of anything but the now. The past: Honchkrow’s misdeeds, your misadventures. The future: where is he taking you? How’s he going to take the end of your...‘friendship?’
         Just saying that word right now brings bile up your throat. Damn dirty bird…
         How did you even end up here…
——
         A feeling of creeping claustrophobia begins to arise. Pressing your hands against the rubbery and wet surface of the bird’s inner pipings, you push against the intestinal walls to make room. In response, the steady wingbeat outside goes a little offbeat. Honchkrow’s innards tighten slightly. You’re unsure whether it's in discomfort or…
——
         There is a gradual slowing, a feeling of weightlessness.
         A snap — like that of a whipped bedsheet, fluttering feathers, a sudden halt.
         Thump.
         A percussive whomp shakes your prison and sends shockwaves through your bones. Has Honchkrow landed?
Honchkrow sighs. You hear the great rush of air bellow above you, rushing from his breast and out his beak. Then, your surroundings jump as Honchkrow straightens and clears his throat with a glottal cough.
         “Well, I suppose that — um, we’re here.” Honchkrow blathers while looking down, under and past his wings: your general location. He waits for an answer. No response. He restlessly preens a feather. “Are you… still mad?” He says. He adjusts his footing and turns a bit, his eyes still locked on his behind. “I— uh, did a bad thing, yes. A very, very-no-good-bad-thing... But! I want to make sure you’re...okay. Y’know...alive. Not dead. So, yeah, that’s… um…say something, please!” He seems genuinely repentant.
         For a second, you feel a small twang of sympathy. Then a repugnant fluid oozes onto you from the ceiling. Whatever was tugging at your heartstring is yanked away.
         “I can’t hear you! You’re o-okay in there, right? Two taps for yes, one tap for no!” You hear the Pokemon’s heartbeat drum faster. “Wait, shouldn’t it be no taps for no? You can’t do much of anything if you’re out cold...”
         You fervently wipe off the ooze, and in the process, inadvertently tap the fleshy walls three times.
         “Three!?” the crow crows. “What does three mean!?” Honchkrow is panicking at this point. The birdbrain is no longer thinking. His thoughts are cloudier than the skies during an Alolan typhoon. Everything whirls and twirls as Honchkrow spirals chasing his own tail in hopes of — somehow — seeing what is wrong with you.
         ...But given that there is no light where the sun doesn’t shine, even you can’t see what’s wrong with you. That doesn’t mean you can’t experience it. You are pinned to the side of the Pokemon’s rectum by centrifugal force. It’s like those spinning top rides with the wheel in the center: the ones where you spin the wheel and the tops spin faster and faster until you’re sick and you regret everything. Except in this ride you’re fastened on the wall and it’s gross and squishy. And you can’t stop the spinning. And it smells like bird butt.
         All the while, Honchkrow is squawking incoherently.
         You’re granted the power to speak with Pokemon and the two clowns you’ve talked to were a sadistic vexatious Noibat and… Honchkrow. Truly, you’re blessed.
         “Stop spinning!” You shout as loud as you can, your vocal cords vibrating like a violently strummed guitar.
         By a miracle, Honchkrow hears you! He struggles to halt his momentum, tangling his feet and ends up hitting the ground with a solid clunk! Judging from sound of the floor’s timbre, you can guess it’s made of… timber: wood.
         You’re also thrown to the floor but yours is a bit more padded. You lay there, dazed, trying to think up a scornful name to call Honchkrow, but it seems you’ve lost your wit. Thank goodness you had a better handle on your lunch.
         “Oww…” Honchkrow groans, “hold on friend. Give me a moment to stand,” Honchkrow sucks in air in pain, “and I’ll get you out.”
         You feel Honchkrow slowly, clumsily rise to his feet. Everything swings from right to left as he tries to find his footing in off balanced steps. Clack, clack! His talons click on the wood floor. Through the ambient noise of the crow’s bodily gurgles and groans, you hear him take a great breath. His lungs, great industrial bellows, inhale. Hold. Then, exhale. Everything tilts, 45°: down. You slide slightly but are stopped by the grip of muscle. A push, an oscillation, drives you further. You are held tightly, a bit too much so. You find yourself roughly driven face-first into a tight orifice. Your right cheek is smeared against the tight ring of flesh but you are not pushed through. Honchkrow relaxes. The rectum’s grip relaxes. You are released. The big bird takes another big breath and strains once more. You’re seized for a second time, mashed against the bird’s tailhole. This time, you breach through. You’re blinded by the early morning’s light. Its color so vibrant: orange and yellow, you could almost taste it. It’s citrus-y.
         Honchkrow’s rear end’s tight embrace hugs your head as it slowly passes over. A few starts and stops and pushes later, you’re free. You plop to the ground, soaked in abominable, stinking anal fluid — but alive!
When your eyes adjust, you see Honchkrow’s beaked face above you and looking down. His black form a silhouette backed by brilliant sunlight.
         You can only muster a few words, “where am I?”
         Honchkrow replies, “you’re…”
1141111212121121132221.title: Nothing to Crow About

choices: Rattata was mirthful. A friendly companion!
Rattata was mischievous. Could be troublesome?
Rattata was displeased. Things would get rocky.
11411112121211211322211.content:
When you heard 'PokeCenter' you thought maybe you'd be able to get help from someone! If you had to be honest, you really preferred the help of humans instead of Pokemon. The two Pokemon that had "helped" you so far had caused you more trouble than it was worth. What was the point of being able to communicate with Pokemon when it led to you being inserted into the ir bodies?

Then came the rest of that sentence. One step forward, two steps back.

"Right. Can you leave me alone now?"

"Th-That's what I was going to do! I brought you here because you'll be safe here!"

"You said there are Pokemon here! How would that make me be safe--"

You didn't finish the question. Your very ereasonable concern was interrupted when, with a noise that almost made you jump out of your skin, something hit Honchkrow's hat, pulling it right onto one of the walls of the room you were in. The hat stayed stuck there, you were able to see what exactly was holding it against the wall: an arrow.

This had to be a joke! When you paid more attention to the arrow, you noticed it was a feather.

Honchkrow squaked, terrified, and clung onto the arrow, trying to get it off his hat. While he was pulling, you heard another voice, male, from behind you. The scraping of...claws? On the floor freaked you out, you couldn't turn around to check who it was.

"I told you to never come back here"

"I know, I know! I'm just passing by!"

"You're not staying not even one minute longer. Get out!" The last two words startled you, here was so much vitriol you felt yours was dwarfed by his! Apparently Honchkrow was getting on more Pokemon's bad sides too. Honchkrow, having finally unpinned the hat, put it on and fluffing up. Whether it wasn an attempt to look larger than he was or harmless you didn't know.

"I was bringing a friend!"

"I'll deal with whatever you're scheming. Now scram"

Honchkrow turned around and ran, extending his wings and flying through a window, disappearing into the sky outside. A tense silence followed, filling the place,. You felt someone's intense stare right on your neck, making your skin crawl. It was such an intense stare you imagined all sorts of Pokemon looking at you. What would happen? Had Honchkrow thrown you into the fire, instead of saving you?

"You have stared into space enough. Turn around." After a small pause: "Please"

Please? Alright, that was a bit encouraging. You did so, finally seeing who had shooed Honchkrow away.

It was another bird, much taller than Honchkrow. White, brown and green was all you could see, held tall by a pair of formidable talons and long legs. That was certainly an owl -- a Decidueye, if your memory was accurate. This was a one-in-a-million find! Wild Decidueye were unheard of where you lived! The owl aimed at you with one of his arrows for just a moment, before sighing and drawing it away. He probably judged you weren't dangerous at all.

You wasted no time in explaining your situation, although you omitted how exactly Honchkrow brought you there. The more you talked, the more something started shining in Decidueye's eyes. Sympathy? Once you were done, Decidueye crouched, looking at you with far more kindness than he showed Honchkrow.

"That pest took you here because he believed you'd be safe. I say that because I cannot help you return to normal"

"Really?" The bad news were nothing surprising.

"There has been no human in this area in a long time. If your intention was to get in contact with them, you're not finding them anywhere here" Where had Honchkrow taken you to?! You had to sit down, the weight of Decidueye's statement almost crushing you. "I can promise you safety, but I cannot help you"

"Then what am I supposed to do?"

"I don't know. I apologize, but I don't have the answers you seek"

It didn't sound like he held you any malice, but you didn't like that at all. "I don't know what to do anymore! I'm small and now I'm far from all of humanity. Why is this happening to me?!"

Decidueye tilted his head. "Again, I don't know. But as I said, if you don't mind sharing your space with a few Pokemon, you will be safe here. I can guarantee it"

Better than staying out there. You nodded, although not very happy.

"I thought you'd be happy. Hop on" Decidueye extended his wing, the tips lying right in front of you. Nothing to do but hop on. The feathers, so fine and with gaps it felt like they were made specifically for you to climb and hold onto. You held onto the feathers, entangling your fingers amidst the tiny strands that formed them, feeling your stomach fall down to your feet when Decidueye lifted you up to his face.

It seemed that, although he was willing to tolerate your presence, he had no idea how to be careful with someone as small as you. You hoped that wouldn't bring you trouble.

--------------

He definitely had no idea how to take care of someone as small as you. You were starting to have doubts he had even seen a human before. That was the only conclusion you could arrive to when you saw the berry right in front of you. The berry was of an intense purple, several times larger than you, and enveloped with a thick, dry crust you had absolutely no hope getting through of. Decidueye, standing right beside the counter you were on right now, stared at you expectantly. "So?"

"It's...big" you tried to think of the right wording to use. You feared you'd be too much of a bother for Decidueye to deal with.

"It'll last you for a while. These are my favorite, so I thought you'd like them"

You tried to dig your nails into the shell, unable to do a thing. "I think I'm not hungry right now"

"It's going to be interesting to take care of a human. I'd leave this to my assistant, but I have judged it'd be better for me to watch over you personally"

"What's this place?" you asked, looking around. The PokeCenter had been abandoned for a while, you could see a thick layer of dust all over everything. The machines, having stayed unused for ages, seemed like it wouldn't work anymore. Abandoned Pokeballs ere strewn all over the floor, a layer of grime in the corners of the lobby.

Decidueye spread a wing, showing everything in the room. "This is a place for travelers to rest at in their journeys. We have food, places to rest at, and guidance for any nearby place. I'm the one keeping it working" Was he...good at his job, then? His heart probably was in the right place, but maybe he was a little over his head.

"And you said you have an assistant?"

"I sure do. My assistant does all the errands and handles everything I don't have much time for. They also deals with the cleaning, but as you can see, they're not very good at that"

...well that explained that, at least. You hoped the asssitant would be able to handle you a bit better, Decidueye was starting to seem a little too unreliable to be a good caretaker. Having decided it was time to continue, the owl raised his voice. "Rattata!"

"I'm on my way!"

You heard skittering coming closer and closer! The sound of tiny claws grabbing onto acrylic surfaces got louder, until from a side of the counter you saw a purple, furry form arrive. Those large ears and whiskers definitely indicated that was a Rattata! The assistant sat on the counter, looking up at Decidueye with mirth. For a moment the grim, completely unwelcome thought that Rattata usually were prey for larger birds like the owl invaded your mind. Thank goodness they got along.

Decidueye gestured at you with a wing. "This human is going to live with us for an undetermined amount of time. You should introduce yourself while I go upstairs for a moment"

"Of course! I'll introduce myself and--"

With what you pretty sure was a smile -- hard to tell when the Pokemon has a beak! -- Decidueye pet Rattata's head, the little rat chuckling and stretching up to make it easier for their boss to pet them. "Good! Get along, will you? I'll return in a moment" with a flourish of his wing, Decidueye hopped on the counter, gliding across the lobby and towards the staircase, leaving you alone with Rattata.

You faced the rat, smiling timidly. "...well...I hope we get along!" you said. Handshakes were a thing for Pokemon? You tried, just in case, extending a hand. The rat stepped towards you, sniffing your hand, and stood on their hind legs, staring at you with attention, until their expression changed.

You knew right away how things would be like.
11411112121211211322211.title: Isolated From All of Humanity

choices: Rattata sneaks you into the guest rooms to pull a prank!
With a smirk, she suggests playing hide-and-go-seek in the courtyard!
She giggles, before shoving you inside the Wiki Berry Decidueye left for you!
114111121212112113222112.content:
At the flip of a switch, the Rattata’s friendly-yet-professional smile slipped into a mischievous grin. Their left paw awkwardly tries to clasp against your outstretched hand—but just as you’re distracted trying to maneuver your hand for a better grip—Rattata’s right paw swoops in for a boop on the nose.
