The surprise attack is gentle, but the sudden pressure causes you to fall back on your bum!

         “Keheheh!” Rattata merrily laughs. Laughter sounding like a chittering chipmunk, their paws reel back to his chest, resting against their chortling belly. “You’re the third in a row that’s fallen for that!”

         You dust yourself off as the Rattata regains their composure. “Sorry, sorry! Kehahah! I love doing that. Can’t help it!” Rattata holds out a paw to help you get back on your feet. You slap your hand on and with a grunt and pull, you’re standing tall. “Besides, introductions are for chumps! Laughter’s the window to the soul. You learn a lot about someone by the way they laugh! ...What does your laughter sound like?”

         You turn a little red. Not only from your ungraceful flop. But your vantage point got you an awkward eyeful of the particularities of Rattata genitalia. Good news: you can say with confidence that this particular prankster is female. And though it looks like the rat’s train of thought is a little squirrely, you don’t see any true malice. Only a veritable whirlwind of hasty, impulsive, impish energy. So, you do your best belly laugh! It comes out a little forced. But Rattata seems pleased!

         “Nice! Sounds a little hollow, though. Been through a lot, lately?”

         You nod. “The past days have been… something.” You don’t feel like getting in the details.

         “Oh! I think I get it. Mm-hm. Yes. You just need something to keep your mind busy!” Rattata falls back onto all fours, a small cloud of dust puffs from the dingy floor. It floats down, settling around you both as the dust particulates glimmer in the lights shining from the PokeCenter machines. With the dust swimming all over, you can’t help but ask, “if your job is to keep the place clean, why is it all… grimy and stuff?”

         Rattata hardly seems fazed. “I like it this way! I’m a rat, y’know? Kinda homey. Also, cleaning is boring. I don’t like boring. Can’t you tell? Am I giving off that kinda… aura? That—uh—not-into-scrubbing-floors-three-thousand-times-bigger-than-me aura?”

         “...Kinda?”

         “Good!” Rattata grins again. “I like you. It’s hard to get a rise out of you! Makes it fun. C’mon, let me show you around!”

         The tour around the center is a blitzkrieg. Rattata hops from one subject to the next, practically dragging you from room to room as she gushes about just about everything his little mind can conjure about the topic.

         “This is the rest area! We got a couple guests in there now, but they’re probably resting. We shouldn’t bother them… yet. Keheha!”

         “Ooo! Isn’t the courtyard great? No, no, no! Don’t step out into it you dolt! Admire, don’t inquire! It was originally a 'play park' for the littlest Pokemon in the center. Now all kinds of creepy critters are crawling up in those tunnels and slides!”

         “This is… the food court! Yeah, I know—real drab. It’s standard issue. White tables, boring benches, metal food stands. But the grub’s good! Berries, all you can eat! And plenty of that dry purple stuff Decidueye likes. Wiki Berry, is it?”

         Her frenzied tour leaves your mind in a whirl. Riding on the scruff of her neck, your eyes are swirling from all the bouncing around on her back. When it’s all done, you flop onto the ground. And the purple rodent scoops you up in her paws, holding you as if she’s cupping water.

         Your vision’s all sorts of blurry colors. But it doesn’t stop you from noticing a strange glint in Rattata’s eye. You saw it before: right before she booped you on the nose. It’s the shiny sparkle of mischievousness—the sign of the birthing of a naughty idea. Not malicious, but probably not quite nice!
114111121212112113222112.title: A Little Mischief Never Hurt!

choices: A different Pokemon comes to indulge in Wiki berries
Time passes. Decidueye still doesn't return. Is something wrong?
1141111212121121132221123.content:
This rat is a mischievous one, that much you could see. You being in this PokeCenter for an extended period of time meant you were going to be the target of a lot of her shenanigans, you know that. Still, you didn't expect her to start that so quickly. While you were still dazed from her movements -- why couldn't anyone here have any consideration for your diminutive size? -- she returned, still holding you in her paw, to the berry Decidueye had left for you.

"Oh, this is perfect. This is fate, you'll see"

"What's fate?"

"This berry! It's perfect!" and without further ado, she went to town with the berry. Her sharp incisors hit the hard shell, breaking through in matter of seconds. Another confirmation you'd never be able to penetrate it by yourself! Rattata, displeased, stuck her tongue out, she looked like she was going to spit. "Ugh, I have never liked these ones"

"I don't follow"

"Don't make any noise!" she said, lifting you towards the hole she had made with her teeth, a rectangular hole that went deep into the berry. For a brief moment you thought she had cracked it so you could try the pulp and finally eat, but instead, she turned you around so your head was towards her, and shoved you into the hole. It was tight, even for your size! Before you could see her expression of excitement, and then it all was replaced by purple, with only a small hole showing you the outside world! Your head and face was right at the surface, you could see outside with some effort. "Perfect. He won't notice you"

"Who?!"

"Decidueye! Who else?" she lowered her voice, whispering to you. "He's not going to resist once he sees two Wiki berries. He'll think I left them for him"

It didn't take you long for you to realize what she was planning. This betrayal...! She was planning to make you get eaten by the owl! You immediately started struggling, trying to worm your way towards the outside, like a worm trying to get out of a cocoon. "Are you crazy?!"

"What? No, you don't get it. This is normal for me. I have been inside Decidueye more times than I can count" That didn't really make you feel any better. "His insides are my own personal playground. I even got a couple objects in his stomach to make it cozier, but don't tell him that!"

"You can't be serious!"

"He doesn't like it very much, so it has turned into a game for me: come up with new ways for me to get into his stomach. No trick works twice! And I guess his belly is sensitive or something, because he always can feel when I'm in there before even a minute passes -- but once I'm in, he just lets me stay all I want"

You increased your struggling. "You're not afraid of being digested?!" Rattatas were prey for so many Pokemon! How could she not be concerned about that?!

Rattata shrugged. "His system is slow as molasses. It'd take me a day to start feeling the effects of acids. Sure, that means that being carried by his intestines takes ages, but--"

"You have gone all the way through?!" This was sounding worse and worse with every word.

"Only three or four times. The first time he was trying to throw me up, but instead it pushed me further inside him. It wasn't clean, but since then when I feel like it I take the long route out instead of crawling upwards" Rattata looks at you with admiration, her eyes sparkling with bravery. "I didn't think you would be interested in going that far! You must be as much of a daredevil as I am!"

Oh. So that was it. Not only she was mischievous, she also was an adrenaline junkie. Not a great combination, really. That explained why she was so fearless about the possibility of getting eaten by a creature that in any other situation could have been a predator. You sighed, feeling yourself drained of energy. This rat really could be exhausting. "That's not what I meant--"

"Really? Well, tell me if you change your mind. Now I better hurry!" Rattata disappeared from your line of sight, vanishing to parts unknown. Taking advantage of her absence, you started wriggling again, trying to get out of the berry before she came back -- or before Decidueye did, which would have been worse. During the process your face was smeared against the purple pulp of the berry, giving you a taste of it.

Rattata was right: Wiki berries weren't very good. You tried hard not to taste it ever again.

You hadn't done any progress at all when Rattata returned a couple minutes later, carrying what you recognized as two halves of a Wiki berry shell. She tapped one of them with a paw, the sound proving the halves were still as tough as ever. "Look at this. It took me so long to get the pulp out, but it's perfect" She set the halves on the surface, settling into one of them before grabbing the other and positioning it to close the berry, making sure her tail was inside instead of slipping out. The berry was barely large enough to accomodate her if she curled and made herself as small as possible. You hoped Decidueye would notice something off about it.

"Can we change our mind?" you asked.

"Aw, don't be like that! I'm giving you a tour of this place, and that includes a place I like. It's like a secret between you and me" her voice sounded through the berry shell, muffled by the hard material.

"This isn't really the kind of tour I was looking forward to"

"You know, I'm glad you're here" she suddenly said. "Everyone who comes here leaves shortly afterwards. Even Pokemon I befriend leave. So having someone else to share these things with...it's nice"

...what were you supposed to say to that? She sounded so truly excited, so truly happy to have you there, you couldn't bring yourself to say anything. Rattata continued, her voice sounding a little nostalgic -- or perhaps it just was the reverberation of her voice inside the berry shell.

"I'm looking forward to us having fun. There's so much we can do together. We can tend to the garden Decidueye has up in the second floor...we can play pranks on any guests that come here...we can go to the roof and watch the stars...I'll come up with everything I can to keep you entertained. Because if you're having fun, maybe you won't leave"

Ouch, that one hit you hard.

"So let's have fun!" you heard a tiny gasp. "Oh, I forgot! I'm supposed to be showing you around. I guess I should have a word or two about what's going on." you heard her clear her throat, before she started, sounding a little more professional than before. She wanted to give you a good impression about this, you guessed. "Decidueye's beak is merely the entrance to his body. Make sure to not get your arms or legs out there, because his spit sticks to your fur like glue! Oh, right, but you don't have too much of that. Then nevermind, but it still feels weird when the tongue touches you!"

Scratch that, it wasn't terribly professional either.

"We're going to be there for just a few seconds, so if you'll look around, you better do it fast!"

You smushed your cheek against the pulp, a little conflicted. Perhaps...you should feign excitement while being inside Decidueye's stomach? You were sure you weren't exactly going to enjoy being eaten by him, but Rattata seemed so earnest, so excited about this, it was hard not to say no.

Geez...
1141111212121121132221123.title: Just a Game

choices: “I got a shipment of luxury berries. And I really wanted to eat them…”
“I… met a special someone. And we... have a date…”
“There’s a rowdy guest I have to evict. And it might get violent…”
11411112121211211322211231.content:
Slimed in mushy, drippy sludge—you’re basically constantly sinking in gooey jam. Berry jelly squishes up your spread arms, plastered to the fruit’s inner shell lining. The shell is slightly softer on the inside, which lets you get a better grip to keep your head above the pulpy gush. The berry’s weird scent tingles your nose. It’s kinda like blackberries. But not quite. It’s got a bit more of that sweet-sour tang. And you swear, there’s almost a hint of… pineapple?
          Click. Click. Click. Decidueye is on the approach. His talons dance upon the hard floor as he walks with a steady, controlled rhythm. His pace is casual—unhurried as he checks on the duo he left behind.
          You hear Rattata whisper from beyond the fruity walls. “This is it!” She murmurs, “he’s coming, he’s coming!”
          And that he is. Peeking through the slit gouged in the berry’s shell, you see Decidueye. His round owl head is cloaked in the shadows of his grassy cowl. His circular eyes are near-perpetually half-lidded by dark eyelids. His brown irises encircle red pupils—almost glowing in the shade. His fluffy brown wings reach down for Rattata’s berry, brushing their feathers along its bumpy surface.
          “Two?” He hoots, “hooo, I can’t resist. It was hard enough giving one berry to the miniature fellow! There’s a bit taken out of the one down there, too. So they must’ve had their fill.” His beak parts slightly. A smile? “Oh well, more for moi!”
          Unable to peel your eyes away, you watch as Decidueye lifts the hollowed-out berry past his down-covered white body. He raises it to his hooked beak—which opens with an eager start. His avian tongue is slightly thicker than expected. Though it still has its trademark tapering form, it’s plump. It’s almost like a pillow squished into its form like Pillsbury dough. But while it looks comfortably soft, it isn’t anything you’d want to lay on. It’s absolutely slathered in gooey, sticky spit. Even for saliva, the foggy liquid is abnormally gluey. A thought comes to mind. Decidueye typically eat small rodents—and berries. Given that rodents are off the menu for this particular owl, that means he’s been subsisting on an entirely fruity diet. And his spit—it’s saturated with those sticky juices. Cloudy with fruit juice, you watch as long sticky strands glue to the berry’s shell. Thick mucousy ropes connect the shell to his mouth and tongue. The flabby organ washes over its surface, spreading thick drivel all over in a revolting film.
          Decidueye hums, squishing his beak into the gummy-yet-tough surface. As his beak closes, you see Rattata peek from her shell. Grinning widely, eyes squinted as bird drool squirts over her face, she sees her chance. She springs forward, skating along his tongue like a slip-and-slide. Her body shoots into his throat. And his eyes go wide. Before he can even squawk, he swallows. And the rat vanishes into his throat.
          His surprised eyes gradually drift into a look of annoyance. Talking with his beak full, he mumbles. “Oh, pellets. Blast her. I’ll finish the meal. I hope it splashes on her snout…” And with that, mashes the rest of the berry shell in his beak. Chewing it into a pulpy goo, he swallows it. Then, he looks to yours.
          You’re whisked up, floating high as your berry is cradled between his wingfeathers. His maw opens. Inside, purple berry residue slathers across interior. He tongue rises from the goopy purple waters, arcing slightly—poised to strike.
          Your berry is too big to fit in his beak all at once. So he tears into the front. The roof tumbles down as chunky gloop, the berry pulp gushing past his keratin beak. You’re swept along, riding the gelatin stream as your arms pinwheel backwards like mad. You gush onto his tongue, splatting as thick drool cements you to the plappy organ. Funky berry washes from behind, drenching you in a wave of foul goop. Decidueye’s beak is awash with odd scents. Sweet Mango Berry, sour Rawst. Even the nose-tingling aroma of spicy Cheri Berry wafts from his murky spit. But the gluey liquid is mostly sweet. It smells like candy. Which would be delightful if you weren’t covered in warm glue.
          Decidueye takes another bite. Pulp and berry globs flood his beak like a smashed pumpkin. You’re punched by the outpour, falling under his tongue as it smears around his mouth. It presses against the roof and sides of his beak, licking up all the sweet nectar. Dribbles of purplish spit cascade off the organ, plattering on you. The heavy weight of the cascade cements you to the floor, gushing in your ears and nose. After an entirely-too-long tasting, Decidueye washes his funky spit along his mouth. You’re picked up in the riptide, slushing over and under the drool-vovered organ as you’re rinsed in the washcycle. Old berry grime dislodges from his beak—flecks and remnants of his previous meals. The speckles of berry skin and pulp batter you while you ride up along his smooth tongue.
          Everything rocks backwards. Decidueye’s head tilts. Your tumble down his tongue, head-over-shoulders. You roll off his tongue. A flood of berry grime kicks you into his throat. The horrible conglomerate fills your mouth as the light snuffs out—Decidueye’s beak closed and out-of-sight. Each of his swallows jostles the slurry you’re housed in, mushing it up as you’re thrown around by the squishy, heartless walls. His digestive system is unsympathetic. You’re mushed into chewed berry. You’re treated no different than any other food.
          Decidueye’s throat mushing you into applesauce, your feet squish against a ring of flesh. Soft, but held tight. It yields after a few moments of simmering in owl spit and berry mush. The buildup of the owl’s meal pours into his stomach, carrying you along with the ride.
          Inside, it’s unlike anything you’ve ever seen. Even Noibat’s stomach. Here, multiple days worth of berries have fermented into a goo not unlike a melted taffy candy—like gooey Starbursts. Horribly sticky, it’s a rainbow-blend of every color in the rainbow, plus a few others. Blackish Bluk Berry spirawls amongst a conglomerate of pink Pecha and blue Chesto. Digesting in the soup, a paleish-yellow Aspear oozes a thick yellow secretion—as if it’s melting into gummy paint. But most surprising, is that you can see! The syrupy stuff is lit by a pendant of Mystic Water contained in a teardrop glass charm wrung around a familiar Rattata’s neck. Beslimed in thick taffy, Rattata’s fur twists into little dripping triangles of matted fur. Her original purple color is barely visible beneath the sticky, gummy layer of thickened berry slime. She’s a mixture of many colors, drenched in shiny, thick slop.
         Her paw splurts above the goop—another Mystic Water pendant. It glows blue.
         “Take it, take it, take it!” She chitters excitedly. You struggle to paddle over. It’s like swimming through molasses! But you get there. She sets it in the sap, plucks you up, and puts you aboard—letting you ride it like a raft.
          Looking up, you see there’s a couple objects floating amongst the goop. A couple balls, a hilariously tiny plastic Wailord. There’s even a soggy hammock! It’s sides are glued to the belly wall via natural berry glue, treated in order to resist digestion. It’s made of burlap and rests above the waves.
          “That’s where I sleep if I want to stay longer!” She chirps, viscid stickiness running over her cheeks.
The stomach jitters as Decidueye sighs, “oh, I should’ve known you were going to try that, my dearling. I’m assuming our guest is in there too…”
         “Yep!”
         “Um… yeah…”
         “Oh, no, no, no...” Decidueye puffs. His hearing must be good if he can hear both of you! “This is no good! Oh, Rattata! Of all days…”
         The sticky rodent looks confused—and concerned. “What’s wrong?”
         Decidueye’s beak chatters…
11411112121211211322211231.title: Sneaky Snacks!

choices: Decidueye runs into unexpected trouble at the worst time possible
Suddenly, the stomach groans. Seems you two are making it upset!
114111121212112113222112312.content:
Decidueye's words come slow, like he wasn't even sure why he was sharing that information with you two, but once he did, Rattata's face of concern changed to one of happiness. "No way! The eternal bachelor has finally found his match!"

"It's that big of a deal?" you asked.

"It sure is! Since I have known him I hadn't known he had interest in anyone that way. I once even asked him if the reason why he didn't have a lady in his life was because he preferred guys and then when he didn't answer I set him up on this blind date with this cute male Swanna that was passing by, and--"

"I believe you have said enough about my past romantic misadventures" Decidueye pretty much shouted, his voice reverberating in his insides. "My point is that you two shouldn't be inside me today! I won't be able to focus knowing there are two interlopers currently stashed inside me while I'm on a date"

You had to admit he had a point there, especially because you were one of those two interlopers. You had barely known each other for...what, an hour? An hour and half? Not really enough time to trust you with knowledge about his love prospects.

Besides, Decidueye sounded really uncomfortable. Even though he seemed to have been trying to make himself look imposing and a bit distant to you not that long ago, now he was rising his voice, flustered. "This is exactly why I don't like when you do that randomly! You don't know what plans I have when you decide to get inside me!"

You paddled towards Rattata through the thick berry muck, clinging to the amulet she had given you, having such a hard time advancing you thought you weren't getting anywhere. "You should apologize" you told her

"I know, I know. I screwed up this time. I'm sorry, Decidueye, I didn't know" at least she seemed genuinely embarrassed about this. "When's your date?"

"In a few minutes. Both of you, get ready to go up. I'm going to expel--"

"No you won't! Do you want to show up with signs you regurgitated a bunch of stuff right before your date? Not even a rat would be that untidy!" You had no idea if she was saying that because she really believe so, or because she didn't want to be forced to leave right after arriving.

"Then what do you suggest I do?"

"I don't think there's any other choice but to leave us here" you piped up. As you saw it, there was no way he could get both of you out before it was date time. While you weren't exactly eager to stay swimming in a melange of molten berries, you weren't going to get in the way of Decidueye's seemingly rocky love life. The owl seemed to have realized the futility of it all, because he sighed and groaned.

"Human, please don't make this a hobby too. I have enough with Rattata doing it"

"Trust me, I won't"

Everything around you shook. You guessed the owl was moving somewhere else. "You two better stay quiet and don't make a ruckus in there. I don't want to have to end the date because I get a stomachache"

"When have I ever caused even a bit of pain?"

"I remember the time you decided to try playing rock climber with the walls of my stomach. I'm sure my liver hasn't been the same since you clung to it from inside the stomach"

"I know! I learned my lesson back then" Rattata said, right while she was climbing the stomach wall towards her hammock. Was that painful incident when Rattata had hung that hammock from the wall? You had a feeling what Rattata had learned wasn't exactly what Decidueye hoped. She carefully got on the hammock, letting it sway like a boat suspended over the stickiest ocean ever. "Now listen here: you better make yourself nice and tidy for your date. You can't let this chance go, got it?"

"I wasn't planning on showing up dirty"

"Of course not -- but those white feathers of you better be so clean they'll glow in the dark. I'll be taking a look once I'm out after your date!" she joked.

You wished you could make yourself tidier. You were pretty sure you'd have berry juices and seeds stuck to you for the rest of your life, given how extensive this dunking was being. The liquids were swaying back and forth, gently taking you around like a piece of wood adrift the ocean, making sure you were getting familiar with all the sides of the roundish sac you were in.

"Hey, human" Rattata called for you while outside you heard noises that probably were Decidueye preening his feathers and leaves. "Psst. Come over here" You tried your hardest to ride the tiny waves, bumping into the plastic Wailord and finally reaching the side of the stomach where Rattata was at. She was holding onto the edge of the hammock, leaning towards you all she could. "How good are you at dates?"

"Well I'm no Casanova, but I guess I'm...okay?"

"What's a casanova?" she seemed confused. Perhaps Pokemon didn't have that concept.

"Sorry, human stuff. Anyway, why do you ask?"

Rattata's whiskers twitched. You watched a sticky drop fall from there to near you. "Decidueye isn't the most graceful 'mon ever. Knowing him, he's going to get all tongue-tied at the worst point. Since we're here, how about we lend him a hand?"

"Decidueye said we should be quiet"

"Decidueye says a lot of things. That doesn't mean we have to listen, if it's for his own good" she said. "So how about we give him a tip or two if he gets stuck?"

So she was pretty much asking you to help her play matchmaker. That was...

...well perhaps it'd be fine. Apparently it was a rarity for Decidueye to be in this kind of thing. It'd be such a pity for it to go badly. Besides, it wasn't like you had anything better to do. What else could you do -- count the wrinkles above the sticky mess all around you? "Sure, I guess"

Rattata grinned. "I knew you were fun. Don't worry, I want him to have a good date. I'll try my best to be of help -- between the three of us, there's no way Decidueye can't do well!"

You wished you could share that optimism.
114111121212112113222112312.title: “I… met a special someone. And we... have a...

1141111212121121132221123121.content:
With an outstretched paw, Rattata hoists you up and out of the goop. Splattering onto the canvas hammock, you and the berry goop form a puddle next to Rattata’s cream-colored underbelly. She shifts to the side, making sure she doesn’t roll over you, and lays lengthwise across the canvas. With her still dripping with berry gluck, it forms little rivers that cascade down the hammock. You’re able to resist being swept away into the slopping waters, shaking as Decidueye rushes to finish his preening. His stomach contents shuddering and swirling like an industrial vat of syrupy sugar, you hear Decidueye’s cool voice echo from above.
“The clearing. The one with the white and yellow flowers. Half-moon. Ohhh!” He mutters nervously, “I think I’m going to be late!”
“Calm down!” Rattata chirps, “it’s okay to be fashionably late!”
The gooey stomach slop jumps violently. You and Rattata are pressed to the soaked canvas as Decidueye jumps. “No it isn’t! That’s for parties! Dates, uhm, you’re supposed be on time, pronto!”
“Geez,” Rattata sighs, “he’s getting worked up about this.” She says to you in an aside. Her ears are low, but they spark right back up when she hollers again. “Don’t get nervous. Dates can smell your fear!”
“Eeep!” Decidueye finishes tightening his hood’s strings. “Alright. No fear. No nervousness. Nothing, nothing, nothing. No, no, no...” He chants before scurrying off out the room.

An open clearing. The starlight shines dim. But the bright moon makes the white flowers glow. A mild breeze passes through the trees, warming the cool night. The flowers sway in a hypnotic dance. A natural circlet cuts into the flower patch, like a clearing within the clearing. The dark canopy provides a nice private shade. And while the towering trees may seem imposing, the quiet sound of their leaves rustling in the wind? It could placate the heart of a rampaging Tauros.
Sitting amidst the flowers is a very nervous Decidueye.
“I… I don’t know if he’s coming!”
His nervous belly feels full of butterflies. But in truth, it’s only got two occupants. His stomach’s anxious churning kicks slop up to your perch. The stomach walls indent when Decidueye sucks in his belly, allowing the sticky waves to kiss the bottom of the hammock. When they recede, a long gum-like sticky trail of goo strings to your bedding’s underside.
“Decidueye—it’s okay! You’re probably early. You practically ran here…” you look over to the drenched Rattata, still dripping from the tsunami born from Decidueye’s haste.
“Half moon. The place with the yellow and white flowers… or was it the red and white flowers? Oh no! Am I in the wrong clearing…”
“No, big guy…” The stomach’s churning slows with the rodent’s words. “Give her a few minutes. Err, him?”
“Him…”
“Him!”
“A-hem!” Decidueye practically leaps out of his skin. You and Rattata fling off the hammock as if it is a trampoline. You make a noisy splashdown, instantly sinking into the berry sludge. Sticky and gross, you both look like you’ve been dipped in melted cotton candy.
A voice, barely heard from the outside, high-pitched yet proper and stiff, “this appears to be the one, Master Altaria. Decidueye. Male. Five-foot-three. Albeit, he fails to match your lofty descriptions.”
“That’s… thank you, Indeedee.” A wispy, shy sound barely breaks through Decidueye’s stomach’s barrier. It rings through the sweltry belly air like twinkling piano keys. “That’s him…”
“A-altaria!” Decidueye’s stomach goes hard as iron. It doesn’t even churn as he speaks. “I—I was waiting for—you’re not late—hello!”
You sigh. You’ve got a good feeling he’s going to need a lot of help…
Thick silence. Then—a giggle. High as bells, Altaria is laughing. “Ha ha! Sorry I’m… late. I would’ve flown… but… Indeedee can’t fly. And he’s… terrified of heights.”
“Oh!” Decidueye perks up, his fluttering belly bounces, swallowing you into the gloop. “I’m afraid of heights too! I can’t fly either! It’s cool to… not fly…”
Rattata erupts into laughter, despite being covered in berry goop. But just as soon as she’s begun, she shoots into a spitting fit. Some of gunk got in her mouth. “Ech. Keha~! Blech!”
You look at her in bewilderment as you hear the ploof! of Altaria sitting down next to Decidueye. Rattata gains a bit of her composure. “They’re both so awkward! They’re made for each other!”
“Um…” Altaria speaks, “Indeedee, can you… drop off the berry wine here… and the snacks and… leave?”
A lengthy respire, “My lord, it’s quite important that I don’t leave you unattended.”
“B-but it’s my date…”
“And you are a very important person. Imagine a ferocious Pokemon attacked. Now where would we be?” Indeedee’s stick-in-the-mud attitude is already grating. "You're safety is more important than your privacy. Besides, I have to make sure you're not 'mucking around' too much with the commoner! Ho ho! But with your current date, I won't have to be worrying about any illegitimate heirs."
Rattata bats away a goopy Wiki Berry and flashes you a look. The glint in her eye looks ever familiar. “This Indeedee's a jerk. We need to get 'em out of here! And I think I know just the way!”
Rattata swims over the rumpled wall and places a sticky paw on a gummy fold. She cups her other paw over her mouth and shouts, “You know Spirit Shackle, right?”
“What!” Decidueye whispers as softly as he can. Even inside him, you barely hear him.
“Don’t hit him with it! Glue his shadow to the ground and scurry off!”
“How in the world is that supposed to make Altaria like me!?”
“Well,” you say, “I think Altaria’s tired of having him chained to his ankle. He’ll might think it’s freeing!”
“Might!?”
“Who are you whispering to?”
“Ah!” You can’t see it, but Decidueye lifts his head out of his wingfeathers and rotates it 180 degrees.
“Eeep!”
“No, no, no! I’m sorry!” The owl apologizes, “I… should’ve waited ‘til we knew each other better before I did that!”
“You might nary know him much longer if you keep that up.”
“Ohhh…”
Rattata hisses into the humidity, “doooo iiiiittttt!”
Decidueye sighs, straightens his gaze, and…
Poof, poof, poof, poof! Lets loose a barrage of feathers into Indeedee’s shadow.
“Hey! What—”
Decidueye stammers, turning towards Altaria, “we, uh—”
“‘Gotta run!’” Rattata chimes.
“Got to run!” His fruity belly goop flings high as he stands with a start. A giggle, chiming, follows. When his belly becomes a chaotic mess, claws stomping on the ground as he runs, those small giggles become chiming laughter.
1141111212121121132221123121.title: A Sugar-Sweet Date (Part 1)

choices: Screaming. A familiar voice. Indeedee? But it sounds… tiny? Did he... shrink?
Gloppy gagging from above. Oh Arceus no… Decidueye…
The clack of two beaks embracing: Altaria is passionately kissing Decidueye.
11411112121211211322211231211.content:
Doused head-to-toe in fermented berry—and just drunken berry wine—you’re finally able to crawl back to Rattata’s hammock. She’s just as drenched. The canvas is too. But the waters have finally calmed. And Decidueye and Altaria are finally hitting it off. And fittingly, they’ve found a better place to rest: under the shade of a Pecha Berry tree. A fruit known for love with its heart-shaped form.
         “You’re… funny!” Altaria says with a twinkling laugh.
         “You’re, um…”
         “Fluffy!” Rattata shouts.
         “Have a great laugh?” You suggest.
         “...Fluffy.”
         You groan, expecting an awkward silence and palpable embarrassment. But instead, Altaria has a giggle fit. Geez, you’d think he’d run out of laughs by now…
         “People aren’t really funny where I’m from…” Altaria says, “they’re all so… stuffy.”
         Echoing in the distance, the soft cello-like sound of a Kricketune plays in the distance.
         “Ask him where he’s from, I’m curious.” Rattata wipes some goo off her ears and onto the stomach’s surface.
         “I know where he’s from!” Decidueye whispers, using Altaria’s interest in the faroff song as a distraction. “He’s from a chateau by the ocean, on the opposite side of the forest from the spooky abandoned manor. He’s a noble’s son. Sheltered… and all that.”
         You tilt your head. “I didn’t know Pokemon had nobility…”
         “Well,” Rattata says, “we don’t. Well, not really.But some Pokemon like to claim it anyway. Usually they keep a gaggle of surrounding Pokemon safe from predators. And in return, they, like, do stuff. Y’know? The boring stuff. The stuff like plucking berries but not eating them!”
         “Sounds… like our thing.” You say. It’s not too much different than kings and serfs. You hope the Pokemon version is a little more kind though…”
         As the night grows longer, Decidueye and Altaria down every goblet they pour. Each swallow comes with a great gush. The glug, glug, glug gives you a few seconds warning before cloyingly sweet red water douses the stomach. The tide grows higher, higher, and higher. Soon, your hammock becomes a raft floating amongst the waves. Bobbing beside you, their snacks. Pecha berries, plucked from the tree, are busy digesting into pungently sweet nectar. Crumbs of sweet bread crackers are scattered in wet bread chunks. They bounce into you on occasion.
         Rattata smiles, enjoying the sweet smell of good wine. You, on the other hand, are getting nervous. Decidueye has been drinking a lot of wine. And you’re no stranger to alcohol. You know what happens to someone who has too much.
         “Don’t puke… don’t puke…” you repeat on loop like a mantra.
         Suddenly, a shifting. Decidueye’s belly trembles. You fear the worst. And yet—you’re still surprised.
11411112121211211322211231211.title: A Sugar-Sweet Date (Part 2)

choices: "...n-n-n-no witnesses! Gotta eat you. Sorry, sorry, sorry…”
“...ransom! You’re coming with me! Err, inside me. Not in the beak, though...”
11411112121211211322211232.content:
It isn't long before a clicking sound reaches your ears. They wriggle. You hold your breath, gathering one last lungful of funny-smelling Wiki Berry. It… smells like sour blackberries.
         Click-click-click-click-FLAP! The sounds are talons, no doubt. But they sound oddly frenzied. Like a panicky tapdance. The pulp slurshes as you adjust your position, glueing your ear to the softer inner shell. The pulpy mess sticks to your body, filling the shell like the creamy yolk of a Kinder’s Egg. You hear a distant voice.
         “N-not here, not there! Gotta be fast, g-g-gotta be quick!”
         ...Is that...?
         “Ohhh, where are they? Decidueye’s probably stashing the little fella somewhere! Somewhere… dark! Spooky! Frightening!” Honchkrow’s nervous speech hits you with a shot of mixed worry and relief. He’s okay! That’s good. But, uh, what is he doing back here? Looking for you? He put you here to be safe! Judging from the nervous crackle in his throat, he’s probably having second thoughts about this place. Decidueye certainly wasn’t kind to him. But why? Is there… something darker about Decidueye that you don’t know? Or did Honchkrow pull a mean stunt in the past?
         “...Ooo! Berries!”
         ...That’s not good.
         “Um,” Rattata raspily whispers, “who is that? How did he get in here? Why does he sound like he’s got a Joltik in their tummy? When—” Rattata’s voice cuts off with a sudden mushy squish! as your berry’s roof abruptly collapses. You’re punched with G-forces as you’re whirled into the air, gravity pinning you to the berry shell wall. Juices oozing around you, you whip your head to the ceiling—getting an eyeful of berry mush in the process. You see the top-half of Honchkrow’s beak amongst the berry’s roof’s rubble. You light in surprise. Rattata had to take her time puncturing the hard shell. But Honchkrow did it so casually—like it was nothing! Apparently, he’s stronger than he looks.
         Peering out your fruity capsule, your heart instantly sinks. You’re in his beak. The curved roof above is a dark maroon—ridged and shiny as latex, wettened with spit. His pink slender tongue slithers beneath the cracked berry, plastering its gooey surface along the shell’s bumpy outside. You’re splashed in the face by a flood of saliva surging inside the fruit, pouring from above and below. The mucky, pulpy berry-and-saliva slushie spirals you around the snack’s interior. All the while, you’re protests are silenced from the (frankly disgusting) berry slush spurting into your mouth. Your stomach falls to your toes as you hear a crunch above. Honchkrow is chewing. The berry roof falls in chunks. You’re thrown out of the ruined shell, splatting on the bird’s tongue as he swishes his mouth juices around.
         “Hmm!” He mumbles, “not bad!”
         Chunks of pap and paste glob against your cheeks. The sticky mixture adheres to your exposed skin, twisting your hair in gooey knots. Squish! Squesh! Squash! The Wiki Berry is crunched into swallowable chunks. Each mastication splatters you in a sludge bomb. It’s like being pie’d in the face. Only the pie had a bomb in it. And it’s raining. So it all runs down in gluey chunks, flowing and squirting into absolutely everywhere.
         Honchkrow bobs his head forward. You’re thrown to the tip of his tongue, bashing into his closed beak before his chin bounces up like it jumped off a springboard. You float amongst the Wiki sludge before toppling onto the back of his tongue. Chunks of fruit shell barrel into you, pushing you past the point of no return. Your body slides along Honchkrow’s slippery tongue, slopping over its edge—plummeting into his throat.
         Glrrk!
         From the inside, his gulp sounds nothing like it would on the outside. It’s like having two sopping wet slabs of steak pound into your ears. Because frankly, that’s what happens. You’re crammed into his crushing throat. Mushed into a ball of viscous gluck and tough shell, you’re squeezed too tight to scream. Grunting and eeping, another harsh swallow contracts around you. Crow spit flows into your cramped chamber, lubing your up—causing you to slip and slide amongst the other bits of his meal. You’re mushed up against the food chunks, swamped in a blend of slurried spit. Painted purple, Honchkrow’s final gulp squashes you face-first into a band of muscle. Its doughy flesh molds around your face as the crow’s esophagus squashes in from behind—oozing you through as the passage kneads the pulpy mixture under your arms and between your legs.
         Your face breaches into the beyond, accompanied with a spurt of Wiki Berry. Inside, it’s nearly pitch-black. But alighting the rumpled, churning chamber—floating amongst the gloppy porridge soup of the bird’s belly—is a soggy clumping of Luminous Moss. Bioluminescent, the crow’s stomach is lit by its feeble green glow. The patch is broken up into smaller bits, each bobbing freely amongst the brownish-yellow gruel. Thick as oatmeal, it’s the result of your meal before: when you first met the big bird—and from his snackings before. Seeds melt into unrecognizable goo. Old berries are nothing but colorful mush, spreading throughout his paunch like colored dye in cookie dough. Streaks of batter are flung across the walls, flowing into the wrinkles between folds. Frothy bubbles align along the border of the soup, with thicker bubbles sputtering at the broth’s center.
         And then there’s the smell—it’s horrible. No two ways about it. It smells like crow vomit. Hot, reeking, digestion saturates the air as you’re helplessly thrust into the broiling belly air. You splat down into belly slime, sinking into sludge—only to be buried beneath the waves as Honchkrow’s rolling belly throws more slop atop your entry point. But survival instincts take over. You flail wildly as you flounder in the mush, breaking the surface as his stomach grumbles and moans.
         Outside, a faint voice, “hey! You’re not Decidueye!”
         The melange jiggles violently as Honchkrow leaps in surprise. “Ah! Who are—oh! You’re Decidueye’s helper!” His stomach sucks in with worry. You’re battered by a surge of slop as the bird’s heart beats fast. “I need to know: where’s the little one!”
         “Uh, they were in a berry. A berry that you ate. That’s in your stomach.”
         A pause. Honchkrow holds his breath. “A c-clever trick! You just want me to fly away before Decidueye gets back.”
         “No, you ate them. Why would I lie? I’m not a liar. You’re a flier—and a liar! Like, everyone knows that. You weird-o, beard-o.”
         “Grr,” Honchkrow growls, sending tremblings through the sludge, “y-y-you’re trying to buy time! I don’t have time—no time at all! I gotta… ahh…”
11411112121211211322211232.title: This Wasn't Part of the Plan!

choices: Honchkrow falls to the floor. Rattata's making him unable to fly!
He manages to start flying, hobbling a little
An arrow pins Honchkrow's tailfeathers to the counter. Decidueye found him
114111121212112113222112322.content:
When you heard him mumble that, you knew right away what Honchkrow meant. You had experienced it not that long ago, after all. "Stop!" you shout. "I'm here, I'm here! Leave her alone!" Perhaps if the crow realized she wasn't lying, he wouldn't make her undergo that.

But it was useless. It didn't seem Honchkrow could hear you. He either just couldn't, or he was too frenzied to realize you were right there. Either way, Rattata was doomed.

"Wait what? What's that supposed to mean?" you faintly heard. You really hoped by now Rattata was getting ready to run.

"I'm sorry, I'm desperate!"

"Hey! Stop that--you're gripping me so hard!"

"I just--stop moving and this will be done quickly!"

Oh no. He had caught her. You could picture the scene outside: Rattata trapped in one of his black talons, squirming and trying to escape but unable to. Honchkrow looking around with worry, trying his best to position himself to make it all easier for himself. Where was Decidueye? Did he really not hear the commotion going on down here?!

The stomach tilted backwards, you were thrown amidst a tsunami of gruel, towards the back of the stomach. The concoction all around you almost pulled you deep into it, but you were able to get out by clinging to the wall and using it as a guide to the surface. Once you surfaced, you coughed, trying to wipe that thick gruel out of your eyes.

"Wait, you're not going to do what I think you're going to do, right?!" you guessed she was looking upwards, at Honchkrow's back end positioned right above her. "I don't think I'm even going to fit!"

Oh. That was right. Decidueye was taller and larger than Honchkrow, and although Honchkrow wasn't exactly small, when you had gone in his system sometimes had given you quiet some bearhugs. Rattata was going to be almost immobilized. You hoped she was too big to be inserted.

"Don't worry, I have experience! This will go fine, it will!" you detected a hint of uncertainty in Honchkrow's statement. Even he wasn't sure if this would go like he hoped. Suddenly, the entire stomach moved downwards, forcing you to bounce in the air and splash into the soup, bits of moss clinging to you like velcro. It had started! Honchkrow was already trying to force her up his butt!

----

"Ow! Ow ow ow ow!" Honchkrow had regrets.

It was true he had done this before. Twice, in fact. First with a Joltik when he was still unevolved, and not that long ago with that tiny human. Both times it had been so...so enjoyable! It made him feel terribly guilty afterwards, but at the time it was great.

This time, though, it wasn't. Maybe it was the position Rattata was in -- she was trying to make herself as wide as possible -- what made it so uncomfortable, even painful. Honchkrow's vent had opened, enveloping her head very slowly to lead the way into his cloaca, but her paws were trying to get her head out, and didn't care it was stretching things a little too much. Any pleasure he could be getting was diminished by a lot of discomfort. "H-Hey, if you keep doing that this is going to take much longer!" he pleaded.

Rattata couldn't reply, her head already getting enveloped by the oily walls of the rectum.

"Can you even hear me? Uh...you can't? One knock for yes, two for no?"

The only response he got was more struggles. This wasn't going to work as communication! Seeing no more option, he kept moving downwards, towards the talon he was gripping her with, and tried to ignore the increasing urge to stop and reconsider. He couldn't reconsider, he was past the point of no return, as far as he was concerned! Trying to finish this as fast as possible, he pressed himself downwards, his butt hitting his talon. Once that was done and he had three-fourths of rat already up his rear end, he leaned forward, trying to use gravity to make her slip further inside.

It worked. Rattata slid in with a nasty sound, her back legs and tail disappearing into Honchkrow's vent. Oh, this was heavy. Too heavy. And his body was already giving him urgent requests to void his bowels, mistaking Rattata for something else. No, this wasn't going to go well! And it was making him unbalanced, to boot. He had some trouble to stay on his feet, flying was going to be a lot of trouble. He shouldn't have done any of this.

But what option did he have now? He needed to find the human, and Rattata was only going to, well, rat him out to Decidueye. After the welcome he got, he didn't want to see the owl again for a long time!

But first, he had to gather his strength. "I have to stop using that area for this kind of thing..."

-----

When everything had tilted forward, slamming you to the front of the stomach, you feared he had succeeded. All you could do was call for your new friend. "Rattata! Can you hear me? Are you okay?"

"I'm...urgh. I'm fine?"

Oh, she could hear you! Good. With a lot of difficulty you swam through the melange to the back end of the stomach. "I heard everything. Are you hurt?"

"No, I'm fine! I just...can't believe this is happening to me"

You could sympathize with that. You didn't have fond memories of having been in Rattata's position mere hours ago. "Don't worry, you'll be fine. Decidueye will help us"

"It's so--tight!" you heard a noise like Rattata was struggling to talk. "The walls are closing in--too many times!"

You hoped for her sake she didn't have to share her space with anything. That would make an already tight space even tighter. "Okay, we'll think of something. We should get Decidueye's help somehow. You know Honchkrow?"

"I...well, the owl always told me to beware them. I think it's because of this one"

"Why?"

Rattata had to take a few moments before she could answer. "You'll keep this a secret, right? I'm telling you because I trust you"

"Of course it'll be a secret"

"Decidueye is...well...this place? It's kind of a front."

"A front?"

"A front"

Oh. You caught onto what she meant. That meant Decidueye was, well...a criminal of some sort? Rattata continued. You imagined she was trying to push the walls away from her.

"It's nothing bad! We just are facilitators. It's true we welcome travelers, but some of the people that come aren't travelers. Some shady things can happen here, and Decidueye turns a blind eye to it. We get rewarded for it. It's--it's nothing too bad, I swear!"

You weren't sure you liked very much what you were hearing, but...well, you had to give some credit to that neither Decidueye nor Rattata seemed like they were bad 'mons. Just...willing to overlook stuff. It was bad, but it wasn't like Decidueye was shattering kneecaps or encasing anyone in concrete. Perhaps you could turn a blind eye as well?

If you had to. Not that you could do anything -- what would you do, stroll to a dangerous Pokemon and tell them to stop doing whatever they were doing?

"Okay, but where does Honchkrow fit in all this?"

"So, before Decidueye set this place up and before he even had evolved, he had a friend. I think it's this Honchkrow. Or Murkrow, I dunno. Decidueye told me he cut their friendship after the crow ruined a few of the things they were doing, and told him to never come close to him again. That's all I know"

Oh. You were starting to see why Honchkrow was looking for you. He had brought you here, perhaps hoping to rely on an old friend to take you in, only to be received with an arrow to the hat. Forced to leave, last he had seen of you was Decidueye aiming at you as well. He may have gotten worried Decidueye would hurt you because you had come with the crow.

It was all a misunderstanding -- and now, well, it sure had spiraled out of control. You slammed your forehead against the stomach wall, receiving a gurgle in response. What a disaster this was starting to be.

"Hey, can you s-stop reciting my backstory to yourself? It's starting to freak me out a little!" you heard Honchkrow said. He could hear her? She was further away from his ears than you were! You hit the wall with your forehead again, the rubbery wall almost giving you a headache. "Anyway, let's go. I have to--I have to leave before Decidueye sees me. And I have to think of a new plan to find that little one!"

Oh, great. You weren't sure if things could get worse, but knowing fate, it always could. You heard Honchkrow extend his wings, ready to fly.
114111121212112113222112322.title: Ransom

choices: You try to leave the manor
11411112121211211322212.content:
Honchkrow opened his wings, his head pivoting around. He seemed at ease now that he was back at this abandoned manor, and although you could see some nervousness in his movements, he was trying hard to compensate you for the rather bad experience. You weren't going to be deceived at all. You looked around, seeing that indeed, you two weren't alone. Most were asleep, a few were looking at you with disinterest, as if a tiny human among them wasn't that big of a deal.

There was a crowd of sleeping Pokemon lining the walls of the attic Honchkrow had landed in. A lot of Murkrow, a couple Raticate surrounded by Rattata, a few Salandit in a corner, alone. Other small Pokemon were further into the attic, you couldn't see them well. It was a surprising variety of Pokemon, and among all them Honchkrow was one of the largest.

Was he the leader? You found hard to believe he'd be the leader of any kind of flock, he simply didn't have the personality for that. He did say these were "roommates", not his flock. He was just one resident more of this group. That was good, if nobody in that attic was obligated to defer to him, then you'd have a chance to slip away without them bringing you back to him!

Honchkrow waited for your reaction, receiving a chilly stare in response. "Everyone here is nice, they'll leave you alone. Just in case you should stay away from the rooms in the ground flor, there's a Nidoking there. He's nice, but he's huge and you are not huge. What do you think?" Fretting and fearing you hadn't forgiven him yet, he stepped towards you, lowering his voice. "You're still upset? About what I did?"

"What do you think?" you blurt out, not feeling like softening the blow. Honchkrow recoiled, squaking at the vitriol in your voice.

"I'm sorry, I just wanted to help!"

"That wasn't helping, you were using me as your toy!"

"It wasn't like that, it was that you...you were..." Honchkrow blushed. He sure had a tendency towards blushing. "It was a sensitive part of my body, of course that happened"

You made a face of disgust. "I don't want to talk about this" The tense silence that followed your refusal to listen to him only made things worse. Starting to panic and not wanting to lose your friendship because of his actions, he flew into the air, hovering in circles above you.

"Wait here, I can fix things! I know, I'll bring back the food trident. We had good times back then, remember? It's a sign of friendship, so I'll bring it to you. Will that help?"

Of course it wouldn't help! A fork wouldn't compensate what he did! But now that you thought about it, that fork was left all the way in that den you had invaded. It'd take Honchkrow a few hours to retrieve it and return, and a few hours of advantage to get away from him could be your saving grace. Smiling eagerly, you nodded. "It'd help"

Happy there could be a chance to fix things between you, Honchkrow flew towards a window. "I'll be back soon, I promise!" he shouted while flying away. As soon as he was far away, you turned around, ready to make your move.

Luckily for you, none of the Pokemon around seemed to be interested in approaching you, instead sleepily looking in your direction. That was better than getting attacked. Getting quickly to the stairs that led down from the attic, you slowly start descending them. Your diminutive state meant descending a single stair was quite the ordeal, you had to gather all your courage to jump off the edge of each stair. Thankfully, your size also meant the fall didn't hurt at all, not that it made it any more pleasant.

When you got to the ground floor, you heard noises coming from the lobby. That wasn't the place with the Nidoking, was it? Now that you thought about it, Honchkrow had told you to not go to those rooms...the Nidoking was nice but large. Therefore, Honchkrow wouldn't suspect you were with him. With some luck you could ask the Nidoking for help and protection from the crow, and if things went south, perhaps you could return to the roost upstairs?

On the other hand, getting far away from this abandoned manor could be better. The problem was that you needed to put distance, and with your size that was going to take a while. Could it be the noises from the lobby could show you a way to get away quicker?

Considering your options, you take a decision.
11411112121211211322212.title: “...in my roost: an abandoned manor. Quiet no...

choices: You dream about your recent adventures
You're awoken by the Nidoking arriving
114111121212112113222121.content:
Right now your priority was getting away from Honchkrow no matter what. The problem was finding a hiding spot. You were a tiny human, Honchkrow was a Pokemon with pretty good eyesight and an interest in keeping you around, for reasons you suspected were not good for you. Unaware of Honchkrow’s sincere regret, you decided your best chance to get away from him would be two different options: either you hid in a place he wouldn’t ever think you’d be at, or hide in a place he’d refuse to enter.

If you played your cards right, you could hit both ideas at once! And what better to scare Honchkrow than a larger, more dangerous Pokemon? Surely due to your size it wouldn’t be as dangerous to you as it would be to him!

As long as you kept your distance, at least.

Your best option was right there, you decided. Honchkrow had said the Nidoking was nice, but you hoped he wasn’t so nice he’d just give you back. While you entered, you pondered if you really should let yourself be seen by your so-called new protector. Maybe it would be safer to seek refuge in his room without his knowledge?

It seemed like fate liked your decision. When you entered the rooms on the ground floor, you found out their owner wasn’t there. Good! This was your chance! Taking time to walk around without falling through the crevices on the floor, you examine the place.

A large pile of cloth and other soft things are piled against a wall. A bed? You take some of the cloth scraps, intending to keep the as a blanket and bed of your own. Not too far from there, there are many bones and a large slab of meat. All of those are much larger than you are, you shudder at the thought of finding yourself on the Nidoking’s bad side. If he could eat such large meals, then you would be no problem. At least that mean you wouldn’t be lacking in food, although you sure would like to cook it beforehand. You’d cross that river when you got there.

On the other end of the room there was a half-opened door, leading outside. Many scratches and gouges on the wood and stone of the walls showed a certain someone who passed through there often had quite the sharp claws. Great, as if you weren’t nervous enough.

Overall it was a basic room. Bed, food, protection against the elements, and from what you could see, a bathroom some distance away you didn’t intend to examine much. Everything was large, as expected of Nidoking. Thankfully, this all meant there were plenty of hiding places. Having taken some supplies, you searched for a hole on the wall near the floor, finding one near Nidoking’s bed. That would be good enough. Dragging everything inside, you piled your scraps of cloth in a corner of the tiny hole and settled on it, somewhat satisfied with your work. You didn’t like the thought of living here for months, but it was good enough to stay for a while. Better this than being with Honchkrow or Noibat!

After everything that had happened that day, you were so tired you fell asleep, even though you hadn’t been planning to rest yet.
114111121212112113222121.title: You seek the Nidoking

choices: Speak up. He knows you're here anyway.
Keep your mouth zipped! He can't find you if you stay quiet!
Book it. You're out of here!
1141111212121121132221212.content:
Thud.
         Crack!
         You’re awakened from your slumber.

         Old wood groans as it labors to lift an unfathomable weight. Measured, plodding footsteps pound the ground, growing more and more earthshaking as they march ever closer. You hear the clatter of a bone pile nearby as the jolting of the earth causes it to collapse.
         Never thought you’d say this, but you wish you were even smaller. So small, whatever is approaching would never see you.
         Across the room you see him — barely. He is at the very limit of your vision and illuminated by the dim glow of starlight that leaks between the cracks of the boards in the walls. His hide is of a rough purple leather bespeckled with spikes. His hunchbacked posture does nothing hinder his intimidating presence. In fact — it is exemplified, making him appear even more monstrous. But most of all, he's giant.
         You know Nidoking never stop growing. Most Nidoking rarely break 5'00", but the oldest just keep on going.
         A giant claw brushes against the wall with a sound like a hiss. Another lumbering step forward. Nidoking sucks in enough air for five men and lets it all out in a shuddering breath.
         "I smell you.”
         Your heart stops dead.
         “Don’t you know it’s dangerous here? Can’t see a damn thing anymore…" he says in a voice like a rumbling landslide. It's then you notice his milky white eyes, barely illuminated. He is blind.
         Nidoking clears his throat and speaks again, "come out! I don't bite. Trust me, getting stepped on because I can't see you is a lot worse than a little nibble." You wonder how he knew you were so small before it hit you: nobody is larger than Nidoking.
         Do you speak up?
1141111212121121132221212.title: Here Comes the King!

choices: He deserves it! Tell Nidoking about Honchkrow.
Nidoking seems a bit much. Keep to yourself. You just want Honchkrow away, that’
11411112121211211322212121.content:
You brush aside your apprehensions. Besides, he’s blind right? If things start getting dicey, run away. You’re willing to put good money that Nidoking wasn’t crowned for his chasing skills.
         Although you can’t shake the nagging feeling that there must be a reason Honchkrow fears him…
         “Uh...hey!” you say. Great opening.
         Nidoking’s head tilts slightly, one side towards the floor. “A puny voice? From the floor? Hmph, didn’t know we had a Joltik here. You must be new.” Before you can think to correct him, Nidoking steps to the side giving you a clear path to the doorway. “I’d recommend you leave. It ain’t wise for David to hang with Goliath.” He chuckles darkly, “You know how that story, one of them ends up dead. Now, I ain’t going to try and kill you, but accidents happen. All it takes is one misplaced step.” It’s obvious that Nidoking is trying to scare you — and it’s working. You're not going to correct him on how that story ended. But wasn’t he a nice guy, or something?
         “Well actually I was thinking about staying here—”
         “You what now?” Nidoking says incredulously. Uh oh.
         “For protection!” You quickly begin. “You’re big, strong, ...frightening but all-in-all you seem like a nice guy!”
         A moment of quietness. So quiet, in fact, that along with Nidoking’s hagged breaths and your own tumultuous heartbeat, you could hear the soft breaths of the sleeping Pokemon upstairs.
         Nidoking shatters the silence with his gravelly voice. “Was your momma a Taurus, bug? ‘Cause I smell 100% fresh bull crap.” Nidoking wrinkles his nose. “Among the other ghastly scents you’ve been cultivating. Take a bath sometime.” Clearly flattery won’t work. You try something else.
         “I’m just looking for a safe place!”
         “Ain’t one here, bug.” Nidoking says as his tail kicks a nearby bone, sending it skidding across the floor.
         “Fine. I’m looking for a place away from someone.” You swear you see a flash of an indiscernible emotion briefly flicker across his stony face.
         “Someone here?”
         “Sort've? He’s not here right now—”
         “But he lives...here?” Nidoking’s tone shifts into something more...not monstrous? Caring would be too strong of a word.
         “Yes—”
         “He messin’ with you?”
         “Well, yeah—”
         “Come.” Nidoking demands as he slowly reaches a hand behind him and to the ground, propping himself up so he could set his enormous weight down without shaking the entire manor. Now sitting, he points a single claw to a spot beside him. You oblige. Doesn’t look like you have much choice in the matter, anyway.
         “I don’t take kindly to bullies. We've got one rule: no browbeating.” Nidoking says as that indiscernible emotion momentarily crops up once more. Is he holding something back?
         Nidoking resumes. “Tell me who’s bullying you and I will take care of them. Nothing will happen to you, I guarantee.”
         You answer with an unsteady voice, “and what will happen to them? You’ll kick ‘em out?”
         Nidoking responds with a toothy smile and a glottal chortal, “they won’t be bothering you no more.”
         Another dark chuckle. “That’s for certain.”
         Do you dare give up Honchkrow’s name? He’s got what’s coming for him, but whatever Nidoking has in store certainly is no good.
11411112121211211322212121.title: A Chat With Royalty

choices: Honchkrow is too scared to say anything
114111121212112113222121211.content:
It was obvious Nidoking was already thinking of some rather unsettling thoughts. His voice and tone didn't foreshadow anything good for anyone you mentioned now. Nidoking didn't think kindly of bullies, that was for sure, and although you weren't sure Honchkrow fit that label entirely well, you doubted Nidoking would care to make a distinction.

For a moment you considered not saying anything. Then the events of not too long ago repeated in your mind: Honchkrow welcoming you while you were seeking for a place to hide, he deceiving you into accepting a proposal, with his reasons being quite perverse in nature - as far as you knew - and finally, your stay in the lower confines of his digestive system. You remember the humiliation, the slimy environment, his attempts to appease you once he finally let you go.

You barely kept yourself from saying his name. You were starting to get rather upset, but you also had to keep in mind Nidoking clearly was going to take action. Were you going to condemn Honchkrow to whatever punishment Nidoking had in mind, even though it could be too much?

Yes. If only because you knew lying to Nidoking was futile. He would know immediately you were lying. Better not to anger the giant Pokemon you're currently with. He said he wasn't going to kill you, but you sure didn't want to get on his bad side.

Nw you understood why Honchkrow had been afraid of someone who was said to be nice. Nidoking certainly was nice enough to be welcoming when he wanted, but the moment you made him angry with you would be a moment you'd regret bitterly. You quietly promised yourself you'd do everything in your power to stay on Nidoking's good side.

"Honchkrow" you said. A growl of acknowledgement shook you.

"That was not a name I expected. Despite the fame of his species, he always seemed to be quite the meek bird"

"I'm not lying"

"I know. I believe you. I will deal with him promptly, that I can assure you" you shuddered at the way he said that. Should you really have said anything about Honchkrow? You could have named Noibat and it wouldn't have been a lie. Too late for regrets, regardless.

The wait for Honchkrow's arrival was eternal. Nidoking had placed you on his head, beside his horn, where you sat down to wait. The more you waited, the more regret gnawed at you. At some point you voiced your concerns, but Nidoking shut you up with a rather blunt: "I believe I mentioned I don't take kindly to bullies. I can tell something happened to you, and although I'm surprised it was Honchkrow, I won't be deterred"

You sighed. "Thank you" you said without much sincerity. "Just please don't hurt him"

"What I shall do is none of your concern. Just trust me, you shall be safe from now on" he scraped his claws against the floorboards, leaving more gouges on the wood. "You should tell me what he did to you"

"I don't want to talk about it"

"It was that bad?" there it was once again, the sympathy in his voice. He must have gone through some rough experiences in the past, you supposed. "I won't force you to tell me, don't worry about that" You briefly wonder if he would even believe you. Maybe you're lucky he's blind and can't see you're a human. It makes this much simpler if he thinks you're a small bug.

Finally, the ear near you twitches. You don't notice anything, but Nidoking seems to have heard something, because he walks to the entrance to his room, and looks up the stairway. At the top, with a fork in his beak, was Honchkrow, looking around, undoubtedly looking for you and wondering where you were. "You" he said. Honchkrow squaked and turned around, passing the fork to one of his talons.

"Oh, h-hello! I hope I didn't wake you up!"

"You didn't. I was waiting for you. There's something we need to talk about"

You were hiding behind Nidoking's horn, but even from that point you saw how Honchkrow's eyes turned into pinpricks. "Really? Can it wait? I spent the entire day flying around, I'm not sure if-"

"If you know what's good for you you will come here right now" without awaiting reply, Nidoking walked back into his room, settling on the center. It didn't take long for Honchkrow to fly into the room, having decided making Nidoking upset would be a bad choice. You heard him swallow nervously.

"I'm here"

"Do you know why I'd like to talk to you?"

"H-Honestly I'm not sure why"

"Back then, when you and everyone else in your flock arrived, I made quite clear you would have to behave"

Honchkrow seemed to relax a little, he scratched his head with the fork. "Oh...has any of them been messing around? I will talk to them, I think I can-"

"I'm talking about you" Nidoking stepped closer. Honchkrow looked down, you had a feeling now he was starting to realize what Nidoking would be upset about. "I heard you have been treating a new resident in a rather unpleasant manner, to put it lightly. Is that true?"

"Unpleasant...I-I didn't..."

"I also have reasons to believe it's true. Do you have anything to say in your defense?"

"It's not like you're thinking!" he flapped his wings in a panic, inching towards the wall. "I was trying to help, I swear I was trying to help!"

"Then why was I informed your "help" has caused distress to someone?". You wonder if you should have gone into detail about what happened. It was true it was a rather nasty situation, but now you didn't know what Nidoking was picturing. If you said anything, how would Honchkrow react?

Luckily for you, it seemed Nidoking had enough of a cool mind to not rush into action without giving one last chance: "Honchkrow, until today you were a good guest. In respect to that I will give you a chance. Admit to everything you have done today. Everything. If you try to hide anything, I won't tolerate it. If you are honest with me, I will spare your life" you felt cold all of a sudden. He would have taken such a harsh action? You hoped that was just his way of trying to scare the wits out of the crow. "So tell me:

What did you do?"
114111121212112113222121211.title: He deserves it! Tell Nidoking about Honchkrow.

choices: Whether you like it or not, Honchkrow is beyond saving. Sleep the night away.
You don’t feel comfortable sleeping in this room. Seek another sleeping place.
There must be a way to save the oaf! Honchkrow would do the same for you, right?
1141111212121121132221212112.content:
“Oh, you see I— uh, well...um…” Honchkrow jabbers as the bird fumbles to create a coherent sentence. As his beak blasts nonsense, he holds his hat in front of him, nervously adjusting and fidgeting around with it. He avoids eye contact.
         Honchkrow trails off. A doom-weighted silence fills the void his gibberish occupied.
         He puts his wingfeathers to his throat and tries to clear it, his chest tight in fear.
         He opens his beak to speak; nothing comes out but a trailing whisper.
         He looks to you in desperation.
         He stares at Nidoking with terror.
         “I’m losing patience.” Nidoking rumbles.
         Honchkrow holds up a single feather as if to say one more moment, please!
         He swallows a breath of stuffy air like a dying fish flopping on a boat dock.
         He conscientiously returns his hat to its rightful resting place.
         He clicks his beak and—
         Nidoking is upon Honchkrow, fast as a Ninjask. An oversized claw snatches the bird by the neck and pins him to the ground in an wince-inducing blow.
         “You’re weak.” Nidoking says to the squawking bird that’s struggling, flapping, and kicking beneath his claw. “To think a flock would follow you: a leader without morals and strength.” Honchkrow reaches in vain for his hat that has fallen beside him.
         “I’m good! I’m weak! Yes— I-I’m good! I’m fine! Weak too!” Honchkrow stammers. “Touching a Dusk Stone that early? Level 6? Big mistake! You know the feeling! You did the same—”
         “Clam it!” Nidoking roars as he throw Honchkrow up and behind him with a brutal, primal force. Soaring through the air like a black comet, Honchkrow yelps in pain when he crashes into a wall. The impact shakes the earth like a mini earthquake as you clumsily try to back away from the impact site. The crash itself leaves a cloud of choking dust that slowly settles, cloaking the dark bird with a dusky layer of powder.
         “You need to learn to keep your beak shut before I break it off!” Honchkrow cowers in a little black ball. Nidoking takes his time to march thundering steps towards the trembling bird. You hear skittering and confused chattering from behind the walls and in every direction as Pokemon scatter in every direction away from this room. It seems everyone is now awake — and wise enough to stay far, far away.
         This is getting to be far too much for you.
         “Hey!” you shout at the top of your miniscule lungs, “stop it! He’s had enough!” You see Nidoking’s ears perk but doesn’t bother to acknowledge you.
         “Bird,” he says, voice simmering, “I’m going to make an amendment—”
         “You’re making amends? Thankyouthankyou!” Honchkrow sputters.
         “I’m making an amendment to my previous statement. I hate bullies and now — I hate you.” Nidoking reaches down to pick up Honchkrow. He fumbles at first but quickly corrects himself and clutches the crow by back, suspended at eye-level. Honchkrow has no choice but to look Nidoking in eyes and let his stinking breath wash over him and weave its way through his feathers.
         “I thought you were a well-intentioned fool. Now I know you’re a foul profligate whose ignorance inspires pity, which you abuse to your benefit.” Nidoking glares. “Or, perhaps, you’re simply an immoral idiot. I hope no one remembers you.” Nidoking shoves Honchkrow into his jaws.
         No! You remain speechless in horror while your mind screams. Nidoking stuffs his cheeks with your former feathered friend. Honchkrow puts up a weak struggle, exhausted from his earlier flights and recent beatdown. Adrenaline gives him the strength for a few frenzied flaps but he quickly tires and falls limp in a pitiable lump.
         Nidoking lowers his head parallel with the ground. For the brief moment he does this, slobber slithers down Honchkrow’s twitching body. Gravity slips the bird a few inches toward freedom but then Nidoking raises his head skyward. Honchkrow’s body slides down Nidoking’s mouth and into his throat like a fluid motion, like a greased up turkey in a slippery slide.
         You watch as Honchkrow, now an indistinct bulge in Nidoking’s purple neck, is compressed by the Pokemon’s powerful throat muscles. A muffled cry of horror (or is it pain? Betrayal?) is all that escapes the beginning of Nidoking’s digestive system. Soon enough, Honchkrow descends past his collarbone — and disappears. Not even a bulge graces Nidoking’s pale belly. Indistinct, muted speech emanates from within; muffled splashes and sloshes sound the crow’s feeble attempts to resist.
         You find the courage to speak.
         “You didn’t have to do that to him!”
         Nidoking tongue clicks satisfactorily. He pulls a feather from between his teeth and turns to you.
         “Do what to who now?”
         “Honchkrow!”
         “Hmm, doesn’t ring a bell.”
         A gurgling cry from within the Poison-type’s belly.
         “You just ate him.”
         “Did I now? Was it a bad egg? I only eat bad ‘mons.” He says "it" as if the word was poison.
         “Well yes—”
         “Ah, that’s why. I don’t bother to remember ruffians and rogues.” Nidoking does another of his dark chuckles. “Don’t you worry bug. This bad egg will be an omelette by the end of next night. By that, I mean dead. Digested.” Nidoking pauses as he holds a clenched claw to his face before letting out a toxic-stenched belch. “Please pardon my manners. It might only last to the end of tonight if it keeps getting on my nerves. Rest assured, it won’t be badgering anyone anymore.”
         “Isn’t that too much?”
         Nidoking...smiles? That’s the closest emotion you can gleam from the twisted shape of the Pokemon’s weathered maw.
         “You’ve got a big heart in that little body, bug. This bird doesn’t deserve it.” Nidoking’s expression saddens a bit, “I’m not even sure I deserve it. Go find someone else who does.” With that, Nidoking sits down and blindly reaches beside him. By happenstance he finds Honchkrow's abandoned hat.
Nidoking frowns. He takes two claws and casually rips the hat in half down the middle before resuming his search. He finds a femur of a creature unknown then chews on the bone absentmindedly, “feel free to sleep in my bed for the night. I will rest on the floor.”
         What to do? Is it even possible to convince Nidoking to spare Honchkrow’s life? Is it worth it to you? Should you heed Nidoking’s words?
1141111212121121132221212112.title: Silence Leads to Deadliness

choices: It's the Beast! Just a misunderstood Pokemon, thankfully
It's the Beast! And the rumors seem to be true!
The Pokemon continues walking, away from the clearing. Close call?
11411112121211211322212121122.content:
You don't have to think it much: you don't want to be near the Pokemon that ate Honchkrow right in front of you. You also didn't dare to say that to Nidoking's face, even though you felt he wouldn't try to hurt you. As soon as Nidoking fell asleep and started snoring, you got up from his bed, and walked to the door that led to the outside. The evening air was brisk, cool, cleansing. The moon was shining high in the sky. Honchkrow was gone, but Nidoking still existed in the manor. You didn't want to stick around anymore. With a heavy heart, you decide to brave the dangers outside. Rest in peace, Honchkrow. He didn't deserve such a fate, even though he had treated you so badly.

Entering the forest in the middle of the night was scary, but you gathered your courage and ran into it. You hoped to find a fallen log or any similar place to seek shelter in for the night, and when morning comes, you'd think of what else to do. A couple hours pass while you search for a good resting spot. The moonlight is bright enough to show you the ground of the forest, and thanks to it you're able to avoid any Pokemon in your path. That was the one good thing your size had -- it was easier to be stealthy.

Suddenly, you felt the ground beneath you tremor. An earthquake! You yelp and run to the base of a tree, but soon you realize it's not an earthquake. You can see many small Pokemon running through the trees, scattering in many directions, like they're...running away from something? A lot of Pokemon had to be running to make the ground shake like that! One of the Pokemon runs towards where you're standing, terrified, and hides behind the tree. They're so close you can see they're trembling and breathing quickly, gasping for air. You recognize the gray Pokemon as a Mincinno. "Uh, is everything fine?" you ask.

The Mincinno looks at you with surprise, not having seen you before, and shakes their head. "They're coming!"

"Who is coming?"

"The..the...you seriously don't know?" you inform them you don't know what they're scared about. Looking around like they expected something awful to appeal soon, the Mincinno gives you a hurried explanation:

"Around here there's a ravenous, hungry Pokemon that eats everything that gets in its way! Some call it the Beast, and I heard it's coming to this part of the forest!"

Oh. That sounded rather bad for you! You were small and certainly very edible to anything that wanted to have you as a snack. You hoped your diminutive size would make you unappetizing. You square up, trying to not look as fearful as you actually felt. "Okay, I see. How does this Pokemon look like?"

"...um..."

"What species is it?"

"I...don't know..."
