You stared at the Mincinno in disbelief. "What do you mean you don't know? Someone must have seen it!"

"Everyone who has seen it gets gobbled up, obviously!"

To you this whole hubbub about the Beast was starting to sound like a rumor, something blown out of proportion. "So you don't even know what you're running from? Couldn't it be just a random big herbivore or something?"

"It could be a predatory herbivore!"

"That sounds kind of contradictory" you said. This was starting to sound ridiculous. This Mincinno couldn't even confirm the fearsome, horrible Pokemon they were running from was a predator or anything like that! Mincinno opened their maw to explain more, but a noise like the crunch of sticks got its attention. It was so loud even you heard it. Something was clear: there was something coming your way. The Mincinno stepped back from the tree, brown eyes wide open, and started running away again.

"Hiiiide!" they wail, leaving you behind. Right afterwards, you heard the rustling of leaves. Something was right there! And you were standing right by a tree, in plain sight. A quick glance around showed no hiding spots, you had the bad luck of standing right in the middle of a barren clearing. You stood out like a neon sign, now that you thought about it. The rustling got even closer, you wouldn't even have time to run into the forest to hide!

In the few seconds that remained before the so-called Beast appeared, many thoughts crossed your mind. Maybe that rumor about the Beast was just that, a rumor. It was hard to think absolutely nobody knew how it even looked like! Rumors had its way of growing in size and twisting until it barely resembled how it started, it was possible this "Beast" was no more than a kind Pokemon who was getting slandered around. It may even not be a predator! For a moment the fleeting mental image of a Mareep so big it reached the treetops flashed in your mind. You basked in the amusement that mental image brought you.

On the other hand...what if there really was a reason to be afraid? What if that Beast indeed was a voracious Pokemon who caused a widespread reign of terror? You didn't want to think about Pokemon being devoured. True, it was an unavoidable part of life in the wilderness for Pokemon, but after witnessing Nidoking eating Honchkrow...it felt like a sore spot. It'd take some time before you could leave that particular memory behind.

Before long you can see a silhouette among the trees, getting closer and closer. Griped by a sudden fear, you start running across the clearing. Literally any Pokemon would be bigger than you, Beast or not! But given your size, you don't reach the other end of the clearing. You're standing right in middle of it, in plain sight, when the Pokemon steps onto the edge of the clearing.

...I hope I'm not doomed...
11411112121211211322212121122.title: Rumors

choices: You begrudgingly agree to lure the Minccinno out. Oof…
You refuse to help. Even if he swallows you, you might be able to help the bird!
You hastily propose another idea—something that pricks Furret’s interest.
114111121212112113222121211222.content:
A shadow slinks the shade and the underbrush, slithering along in twisting shapes and with frightening speed. You cautiously step back, watching warily as the mysterious ‘Mon makes their way closer. You suck in a sharp breath. The creature pauses. It heard you.
          What is it? What could it be? What do you do? Your mind scrambles to decide what to do, juggling a baker’s dozen of half-baked plans. When the shadowy creature erupts from the leafy foliage, exposing itself to the light, you gasp.
          It is not what you were expecting.
          Its body was long: tubular and snake-like; four small paws dot its underbelly. It’s covered in brown-and-tan fluffed fur—with pointed, triangular ears and oval eyes. Little brown markings scratch the sides of its cheeks, painting its face with whisker-like markings. The Pokemon, fully emerged from the underbrush, stretches its long, ringed, cream-colored tail and hones its black eyes on you.
          You recognize this Pokemon. It’s a...Furret? And Holy Smokes—it’s large!
          “Hmm. Mmm.” The Furret twines its body around you, inspecting you from every-which angle. Through the mammal’s silvery voice, you could plainly hear that he is male.
          “O-ho-ho! You are quite the specimen! I’ve never seen something like you before.” He snakes his head closer, meeting you at eye-level. You flick your eyes to your left and right. You see only fluffy rope. Furret has surrounded you.
          “Look, Mr. Furret—” Furret cuts you off with a loud obnoxious yawn. He doesn’t bother to turn his head, drenching you in the hot, humid air of his maw. The faint starlight shines just bright enough—letting you see the long, dark passage of his hungry throat, quivering from the force of the escaping wind. A strand of saliva, stretching from the bottom of his mouth to his pointy canine, pops in a splatting ‘splosion of spittle.
          Furret recomposes, watching you wince—sprinkled in saliva. “My, oh, my. If you weren’t so fascinating—uniquely captivating—I would’ve gobbled you up already.” Your heart plummets like a rock. Your breath cuts short. Please, let me go! You plead silently in your mind. I didn’t even know Furret could eat meat...
         Furret gives you another look-down. “Although, besides you being bite-sized, there seems to be nothing else interesting about you.” The slim-bodied Pokemon casts you a casual look, but lurking behind it was something clearly villainous—a look you never could’ve imagined coming from such a normally-cute critter.
         “So, why shouldn’t I eat you?”
         “Don’t eat me!”
         “Ah—yes! I shouldn’t eat you because you told me not to eat you. Really changing my mind, Snack.”
         You race to respond. “I’m too small! Why bother eating little-old-me?”
         Furret sighs impatiently. “You’re saying that eating nothing is better than eating something?” The Normal-type harrumphs. “I would’ve thought your pea-brain could concoct something half-decent. Ah, well. Bottoms up.”
         “H-hey!” You sputter. “I’ll do anything!”
         A fang pokes from the corner of his lip. “Those were the exact words I was looking for.”
         You blanche. This isn’t good.
          Furret plops his head into the grass beside you, nearly flooring you with the impact. His cheek smushed up to his face, he looks at you with fake sorrowful eyes. “It’s so hard being a predator. I don’t have claws, horns—none of that pizazz. I’ve got to rely on wits to catch my prey, you see? I know it’s hard to understand—for you especially—but some of us can’t get by being simpleminded lamebrains.” Furret smirks sinisterly, face still pressed to the ground. He flushes the look away, locking back into sad-face mode. “I’m really hungry and sad. Can’t you tell?”
          “Uh…”
          Furret burps—just a small one. He opens his mouth just enough to let a black-and-white Fletchling tailfeather flutter out from his mouth. The smell that creeps from his maw bespoke a foul fate.
          “Mmm. I forgot about them.” Furret admits with the amount of care of someone noticing an untied shoelace. “Anyway, I want those Minccino. They’re fast, but wondrously naive. Lure a few out for me. Tell them it's safe. Then I’ll let you go. Maybe.”
          You gawk at Furret. Your disgust is plain on your face. “I’m not tricking those Minccino into being your supper!” Furret clicks his tongue.
          “Well, I suppose I could just snack on you instead.” You try to back away, but find your back pressed against a fuzzy wall as you nearly vanish in the monster’s hairs. A scary-sounding grumble rumbles from deep within Furret’s stomach.
          “You know, I think that Fletchling might still be kicking in there.” Furret says, grinning as he watches you squirm in discomfort. “Key words: might be. Not quite sure. It could just be their ghost trying to give me indigestion.” Furret laughs cruelly as a sick revulsion pools in the pit of your belly.
          “Who knows!" Furret says. "If you’re not up for this job, maybe you can play the hero and save the poor birdy!”
          With Furret casting you in dark shadow from the moon’s glow, you make your decision...
114111121212112113222121211222.title: The Cruel Beast

choices: You manage to think of an idea to escape
You're too late! Fletchling expires before you can think
Furret is still hungry. Another Pokemon joins you and Fletchling
1141111212121121132221212112222.content:
The tailfeather lying near you only brings something very familiar to mind. Looking at Furret, for a moment you flash back to Nidoking and Honchkrow. There in front of you was a large Pokemon who ate a bird and was now presumably digesting it. The memory fades right away when you realize Furret is worse: Furret wasn't eating a Pokemon who had hurt you. Furret was asking you to go fool a few innocent Pokemon so he can feast.

"No! I'm not helping you!" you yell. You're surprised by how loud your voice can be.

Furret gives you the good ol' puppy eyes. "Why not? That's the circle of life, 'mons eat other 'mons"

"This isn't just eating for food, you're...eating for fun, or something! That's just wrong, you can't do that! Are you even supposed to be eating meat?!"

"Rattatas are a staple food in any self-respecting Furret's diet, if you're wondering that"

"Okay, fine, but this is far more than any random Rattata" you glare at him. "You have been eating so many Pokemon they're all scared of you! You're evil!"

Furret's ears went flat on his head, while he stared at you bemusedly. His face slowly got closer to you. "That was quite the speech. If only you were as big as your morality seems to be, you would fill me up for days" You hadn't expected to convince Furret to change his ways, but it made you shiver with fear anyway. "I guess this means you're not helping me. That's fine"

"...you're not letting me go, are you?" your shoulders slumped.

"Do me a favor and get digested. You can do that much for me" he says before lunging at you. Having some of Furret's body behind you, like a predatory snake cornering you, there was no place for you to run. Before you can even blink half of your body is enveloped into Furret's mouth. The tip of his tongue hits your face, slobber slathering you, before your world turns upside down. Suddenly you're airborne, making a flip in the air, Furret's open maw underneath you. Not only he was going to eat you, he also had to be tossing you in the air like the prey you were now! The world freezes for a moment before you freefall, straight into Furret's jaws.

The impact is like hitting a very wet trampoline. Instinctively you try to grapple what you hit -- the tongue, you realize belatedly, but you can't do it, it's too slippery for you to grab.

"By the way, if that Fletchling is still alive, say hi for me. Don't worry, you're so small there's plenty of space for you two!" Furret says, giving you a good jostle with his tongue. His gentle-sounding voice contrasts with the nasty intent in his words, so much you have to wonder how he can be doing this and not feel grossed out with himself. This time you manage to grab onto the tongue but, Furret sensing you had done that, you're lifted high until you crash against his hard palate. Not wanting to be smothered between the tongue and the palate, you let go. That was your mistake.

As soon as he felt you had let go, Furret tilts his tongue backwards, funneling you towards his throat. You slide while you're still dazed, your body scraping against the rough papillae underneath you, until you fall into the gaping pit of the throat. You barely notice the esophagus cradling you, carrying you deeper into the Furret's body, until you feel your feet touch something. That something slowly opens up, giving you access. A strong, acidic and foreboding smell envelopes you even before you enter the stomach -- clearly the chamber is hard at work right now.

"No way..." you mutter, once your head crosses the threshold and you fall. You expect to crash into a pool of acids, but instead you fall onto something else. You blearily touch around. This feels like...feathers. A lot of very wet feathers. What it means hits you immediately when you remember you're not supposed to be the only resident in Furret's stomach right now.

You sit up immediately, your heart beating a hundred miles per hour. You can see...not very well, but you can faintly see, your eyes adapting to the darkness. The walls of the stomach are moving a lot, stirring the stew, and Furret's walking does that as well. Furret didn't even say a word to you. You're just a bitesized prey for him. Beneath you there are a lot of gray feathers, and you're somewhat glad to find out it's not a pile -- it's a body. A feathered body, Fletchling. You get onto your hands and knees and crawl in direction of where you see the head is. Thankfully, Fletchling's head is over the surface of the belly juices. Their eyes are closed, and their beak is half-open.

"Hey. Fletchling! Come on, you'll be...fine!" you whisper, unsure if you should raise your voice. You don't want Furret to hear you. "Fletchling!"

No response. No, no, please don't be dead! you plead. You don't even know Fletchling, but your empathy is making you worry for their sake. You didn't do a thing about Honchkrow. Now you were in a similar situation, and to tell the truth, you didn't want to make the same mistake. Not if you could do something about it, for someone who is innocent!

You put your ear against the soaked feathers of Fletchling's back, trying to listen inside. You want to find out if they're still alive! There, you hear it: a heartbeat. You feel your own heart on your throat when you realize Fletchling's heartbeat is way slower than it should be. Their breathing is also very labored.

Fletchling is on the verge of death. You don't want to find out how things are like underneath the surface of the acids. The mental image of a corroded bird grips you, you hope the fact Fletchling is alive means they haven't suffered much physical damage yet.

"Don't worry, I'll help you. I'll...think of something, I promise" you whisper, patting Fletchling's back. How careless of you, promising such a thing. Merely breathing the air inside Furret's stomach is painful, you feel your nose tingling. It's bothersome, but it's a reminder you're in the middle of a sac of acid.

There's some space around. Fletchling is small, there's enough space to accomodate at least six of them. You can see the pool of acid extending from wall to wall, greenish liquids that sway and make waves. You really don't want to fall in that -- you survived Noibat, you hope that means you're hard to break down. Still, you sure would rather not to find out the hard way if you're more vulnerable than you think.

That was your situation now. A daunting task laid ahead of you, and you...you had to think. Think! How do you save not only yourself, but also a bird? Even though Fletchling is small, they're still many times your size! At least it seemed you had an advantage: Furret wasn't bothering to keep track of what was going on in his stomach. Your predator's cockiness was something you hoped would continue happening.

Now it's only a matter of think something to do, and fast...!
1141111212121121132221212112222.title: You Have a Place in the Foodchain

choices: You’re surrounded by Furret’s scat, entombed in his large intestine.
You’re strewn on the ground, the sun in your eyes. Furret is looking down at you
You’re on a foul-scented fleshy floor. The heat is sweltering, the smell: rancid
11411112121211211322212121122222.content:
Sailing on your feathery boat atop a gloppy sea, you flip through your thoughts like a well-tossed flapjack. The pitter-patter of Furret's steps along with the slithering of his long, noodly body cook up quite the storm. The slop sloshes side-to-side, slathering the walls of his belly with acrid slush. The stomach itself undulates, ever-moving, churning the chemical vat below. Flecks of slurry are flung into the air and dribble back down in acid rain. All the while, Furret’s belly keeps on making the horrible sounds of digestion. Glorp, glop, slorsh… Glip, glap, grumble...
         The acidic fumes are overbearing, setting fire to your nostrils. And the heat—by goodness the heat! It’s boiling! And the humid, sweltering air presses down on you as a 100lb weight, making you feel like Atlas: holding the weight of all the world on your back.
         But the heaviest burden of all is that of Fletchling's. If you can't think of a way out of here, they're going to be nothing but goo. Just thinking about it makes your blood run cold!
         But how in the world are you going to get out of here!?
         Going up is impossible. And you don’t even know where to begin in making Furret have an upset belly. You even consider taking the… scenic route. But you’re not sure if Fletchling could fit! And even if they could, how would you push them in there?
That left only one option.
         “Hey! Furret!”
         No answer. The muck of his stomach burbles like a hot mud bath.
         “Furret! I know you can hear me!”
         Still no answer. In the dead silence that follows, you hear Fletchling wheeze a raspy rattle. Your chest is instantly gripped in an iron vice. No, no, no!
         “Please, Furret! Come on! Listen to me! Just—”
         Abruptly the stomach seizes. The formerly-cavernous space quickly crunches in, surging the marshy, quaggy sea up over your head. The digestive soup swallows you, the entire chamber now squashed to far-too-small size. You bellow in the broth as the wet muscled ceiling forces you under the tide, mashing you against the bird Pokemon’s sodden-down chest. The vile belly juices slather your skin and plaster your hair. You try to form words, pleadings to Furret, but your words are lost in the soup.
         And then Furret releases. His stomach sags back into a relaxed position. You flop back onto your feathery liferaft. You can’t help but cough and sputter, racking your lungs and rasping your throat. And throughout it all, one thought is on your mind:
         He did that on purpose!
         You reclaim your breath—just in time to shout one last pleading to your devourer.
         “I don’t know what I have to do—what I have to say! Just save Fletchling! I’ll do anything!”
         The moment the words leave your mouth, you already regret it. Especially when things get far too quiet. The rapping of his footsteps silence—Furret stops. All you hear is his breathing, great bellows of wind, and the all-encompassing drum of his heart—distant thunder. Your own heartbeat begins to pound in your ears as your mouth goes dry and your throat grows tight. The gurgling and growling of his stomach grows ever-louder in the silence.
         Squalid waves crash into you again as he stomach tilts to the side, sweeping you and Fletchling away. The bird tumbles in the stew, spinning and flopping. Rolling over limply as they are lapped by beating waves, Fletchling’s peeps a half-conscious squeak as they toss and turn. You grip the bird’s feathers, bleached by the digestive acids, and hold on for dear life. You’re dunked under the waves as Fletchling flops. The sheer force of the waves threatens to peel you off, but by luck, you manage to hold on. Now on the former side, now floor of Furret’s gut, you smush yourself against the bird’s down as you watch the tumultuous waters of the predator’s stomach settle.
         At last, a silky-smooth voice drifts through the hellish air. Along with a… spattering of water?
         “Ahh~.” Furret sighs with relief. “Was holding that in for a while…”
         Your face grows beet-red. He can’t be—!
         The gush-and-splatter of liquid slows to a trickle before Furret’s stomach pitches back to its original orientation, mopping you along with the contents of his belly. When the dust settles, you’re back where you started—only a little more humiliated.
He… he didn’t hear me at all… You feel your heart drop like an iron ball. We really are nothing but food to him…
         It would be lying to say you didn’t cry. But because of your black thought:
         I don’t know how to save them. You look down at Fletchling. They’re barely moving, but you don’t even know if they’re alive anymore. It could just be the bobbing of the waves.
         And then, you hear a noise. A burbling, gurgling, draining sound that reminded you of a shower drain. You didn’t connect the dots until you notice the slop level slowly lowering. Furret’s belly-stuff is leaving.
         You gaze into the dark pool, then back at Fletchling. There’s nothing you can do…
         You don’t remember plopping into the slosh, but next you knew, you find yourself in the middle of it all. An inescapable force sucks you downward, drinking you deeper to the bottom of Furret’s sloppy belly.
         Down,
         Down,
         Down.
         You plow through well-digested muck as you submerge, head-first, the blood rushing to your head. The tingle of acids prick your skin the same way Pop-rocks fizz in your mouth—a harmless feeling, but an unnerving one. A great pressure bears down around you, as if you passed through an unseen porticule. And shortly thereafter, you’re in free fall: ejected from duodenum behind. You’re sputtered out with a gushing of sludge, plummeting toward the ground like someone’s spat up drink. And when you land, it’s in roily water—filthy and yellowed.
         You burst to the surface and greedily gulp stained air. Little tubes cover the passage for as far as you can see. The hideous fluid plashes against the protuberances as the passage slightly writhes, stirring the broth within. All the while, the wibble-wobble of Furret’s now restarted gait causes the entire tubing to rock like a baby’s cradle.
         And as if you couldn’t feel any more horrible, Furret begins to softly hum an upbeat tune, filling the small intestine with its mirthful melody.
         The flow of belly slop behind you starts to diminish. One breath later, it stops. You’re all alone in the depths of the meat-eater’s tubing.
◓ ◓ ◓

         You’ve never felt crappier. Moving through Furret’s depths is, to put it simply, the opposite of fun.
         While you travel through him, the horrible creature continues to do what he does everyday. He lounges, bounds around, sings some songs, but worst of all—he hunts. Every time he pounces, pinning some poor Pokemon to the ground—you feel like your soul is being ripped in half. You can still hear them…
         “No!”
         “Get awa—”
         “Help!”
         You didn’t know what was worse. The sudden, lurching halt of their voice or the sound they made when they plopped into his belly…
         And when sleep calls for you, you don’t resist. You simply want to be anywhere else right now. Seconds later, you pass out—floating in the intestinal stream.
◓ ◓ ◓

         And when you peel open your eyelids, a new day, where are you now?
11411112121211211322212121122222.title: Furret's Foul Belly

choices: You go with Mincinno to meet their group
You decide go find a strong Pokemon to fight Furret
114111121212112113222121211222222.content:
You're not sure how long you slept, but soon you feel something shining on your eyes. You cover them with a hand, the rest of your senses slowly catching up, until you hear the singing of birds and the whooshing of the bird. None of that sound remotely how you expected Furret's insides to sound like, and they were so bright, to boot! When you open your eyes you see why: you simply aren't in Furret's body anymore. You're outside, lying on the floor, on a rock. The sun shines through the canopy above.

"About time you woke up. I was starting to wonder you had died inside of me"

That voice...you turn your head around, glaring at who it is. There's Furret, head lying on the rock, staring at you with his round eyes. If it wasn't because you felt so much revulsion towards him, you'd think he was pretty damn cute. "What do you want?!" you yell.

"Nothing! Right now. I should be the one upset here, you couldn't even get digested like I asked you to. You're serious about not wanting to do anything for me" Furret sighs. "But I'll deal with that later. Right now I have other things to do"

"Yeah? Like eating half of the forest's population?"

"It's called having a varied diet, snacko! So I thought I should stick around to give you a word or two before I leave for now" Furret sniffs you for a moment. "Oh yes, this worked. You smell just like me"

Unsure what to expect, you give yourself a cautious check. Indeed, you have a rather unusual scent on you. It reminds you of one time you stuck your face onto a stuffed Pokemon plush toy you once had, just that much stronger. It's nothing close to how you expected to smell after having passed through Furret's digestive system. "What...how did you do this?!"

"Do you really want to know?"

On second thought...maybe not. A series of unpleasant scenarios cross your mind, ranging from the harmless to the humiliating. You decide ignorance is bliss. "No, thanks. Now what?"

"You do whatever you want to do, I don't mind. I'll find you later through my own scent. Could be tomorrow, or in a week, or maybe in just a couple hours. I dunno. And when I do...we can mess around some more" You don't want to know what exactly is Furret's concept of 'messing around'. You're sure you won't have any fun. "You turned out to be the most interesting thing in a while, what with not being digested and also being so small. I figure there's more stuff we can do together"

"I don't want to do anything with you!"

"Aw, but it's like we're pals now! Or at least I'm counting you as one. Just maybe ranking lower than the rest" What a honor. "I'm leaving now. Don't die, okay? I hope to have some fun with you later!" he says as a farewell, running among the trees. There goes Furret, to continue wrecking terror through this area of the world.

All you can do for a moment is glare in the direction where Furret left. He didn't even say a word about any of the Pokemon he had eaten before and after you, all he cared about was getting to have fun with you later. Somehow, you had risen above the rank of 'prey', and into the dubious rank of 'pal'. Rage and frustration boils inside you, you shout a few profanities, letting steam out. For a while all you do is stomp around on the rock, until you feel all the energy leave you.

Maybe...maybe leaving the abandoned manor was a mistake. You're in a lot of trouble now. You're not sure you'd be able to find the manor anymore.

"...umm...are you...done?" a meek voice asks you. You turn around, startled, and see a Mincinno. Is that the same one that had warned you about the Beast? "So that's the Beast? He looks...less scary than I expected..."

"Yeah? Well let me tell you: the rumors are true. He's eating 'mons left and right"

Mincinno would hide behind their own tail if they could. "I knew it! I knew it was true! But...you survived? I know you did. I saw Furret...uh...let you out?". You're glad you were sleeping when you were expelled from his body. "And then he took you and went to wash you off. I'm not sure it's good he's interested in you"

"I'm not going to accept it just like that! There must be something I can do!" you're so full of frustration you're seriously considering revenge. The horrors of Furret's stomach could only be understood once you witnessed a harmless Pokemon get digested inside. Now that you think about it...Fletchlings and its evolutions aren't common in this part of the world, no? Maybe you could find one and tell them what Furret did. You ask Mincinno if they know about them.

Mincinno's brown eyes light up. "Not too far from here there's a red tree! That's where Talonflame and Fletchling live in their nests. They're siblings, Fletchling is the elder but you'd never guess because they never wanted to evolve. Why do you ask?"

"You think this Talonflame would want to talk with me?"

"I...guess...? Talonflame is kind of...super protective, though? So if you talk to them...try not to let them get attached to you"

Super protective, huh. Good! As you saw it, if the Fletchling Furret ate was Talonflame's sibling, then that big falcon would have a reason to go after Furret. It'd be justice, you think. All you wanted was for someone to go after Furret and give him what he deserved! Surely the forest had to have strong Pokemon who would want to take action against Furret!

All you had to do was find one.

"Wow, when I look at you you look just like a tiny little human" they say. Looks like your size makes everyone around here think you're just a human-looking bug, you guess. "Why are you asking? Are you...wait, I know what you're thinking!" Mincinno gets closer, climbing the rock to get close to you. "You want revenge because Furret ate you!"

Naive as Mincinno was, at least they were somewhat observant. "Something like that"

"No, no, you shouldn't! That's not going to end well for you or for anyone! Please, don't do that!"

You clench your fists. "There must be something I can do! Look, in the time I was inside Furret I'm aware at least four Pokemon got eaten. That's just wrong!"

"I-I-I guess...but instead of going after him you could...maybe seek safety?"

"Safety?"

"Yes, other Pokemon you can stick with. Hey, why don't you stay with my group?" Mincinno suggests. They sound so earnest you can't bring yourself to reject such proposition immediately.

"You mean other Mincinno?"

"Oh. Oh, no, not really...I'm not part of any of those. A few friends and I travel around and...generally try to not get in anyone's way. They're all so cool, you'd love them" Mincinno extended a paw towards you. "You wouldn't ever guess what they are!"

"I don't know if I should..."

"It's...better than going after Furret, right? And maybe if you stick with us he'll think twice before coming for you again. Just...please, please join us. For your sake, so you're safe!"

You feel Mincinno is begging you so you wouldn't go down the probably dangerous path of revenge, instead of because they think you'd be safe with their group.

You had to make your choice.

You could either do everything in your power to get somebody to fight Furret, you were sure you could find any Pokemon who'd want to do it. Talonflame seemed to be your best option, thanks to their possible relation to Fletchling and because you knew where to find them, but you were sure you could pick a direction, walk, and find a strong Pokemon to fight Furret.

Or you could go with Mincinno and try to forget your desire for revenge. Stick with Mincinno and their friends, hope for the best, and dread the moment Furret decided to find you again. You'd be safe, but the threat of Furret playing with you again would still be present.

You take a deep breath, weighing your options in your head with a clear mind. You're not entirely sure if you're making the right choice, but you tell Mincinno what you want to do.
114111121212112113222121211222222.title: Unwilling Association

choices: Nab a spot in line. Let's hope Smeargle is feeling understanding today...
Sneak around back. Don't let anyone see you!
Hitch a ride on another Pokemon. Ask around or sneak on yourself!
1141111212121121132221212112222222.content:
You scratch the back the back of your head and breathe through your teeth. You don't know how to say this....
         "I really can't go. I want to—but I can't." Mincinno's eyes grow a little wider, a little darker. They look so worried...
         "A—are you sure?" Mincinno peers at you, their face half-and-half above and below the rock. "It's really, really dangerous out there! Like—a lot! There's creepy critters, monstrous monsters! And, uh, the Beast!" The twinge in their voice tugs at you. You really don't think she's kidding around!
         You bite the inside of your cheek. "I know. But if I don't go, things are just going to get worse." You take a deep breath. "And what if he comes for you next! I don't think I could ever live myself if I let that happen."
         "Well—I have my friends!"
         "I'm sure the Pokemon he ate had friends too..."
————

         Minccino had reluctantly pointed you in the direction of Talonflame's roost. You packed up your non-existent belongings and hurried off into the forest—but not before saying your goodbyes to the teary-eyed chinchilla.
         You weave between blades of grass, clamber over wood chips and stumps, and rush into the underbrush whenever you hear the stomping footsteps of a giant Pokemon nearby. With every footfall, your heart leaps in your chest. Your bones rattle with thunderous vibrations. And whenever those gargantuan creatures crash their stompers right in front of you, inches away, you whisper a silent prayer under your breath. If they see you, it's over. Even if you survive another 'Mon's digestive system, you'll be lost—with no way compass to point you the way toward the fire bird's nest.
         Fortune smiles upon you. Every scary-sounding creature clomps away, you not daring to leave until their stompings echo into nothing. You confidently heed Minccino's directions, stowing your unease over the possibility of you being lost. The clawed tree, the half-leaved bush, the sky-scraping pine—yes! These are the landmarks Minccino told you. There's no question: you're on track.
         You slap away the leafy fingers of the brush, peeling them apart to reveal a magnificent sight. A great oak, with a trunk thicker than a Machoke's neck, and with branches that extend far and wide—with a million rustling leaves. Looking up into the orange evening sky, you see that the oak is home to a great menagerie of life. Just from a glance alone, you see Rowlet, Burmy, Pidgeotto, and even a Noctowl just rousing from its slumber. You make your way closer, in awe of the picturesque sight.
         But you stop. You notice a something strange.
         Stationed near the base of the tree, its body massive and powerful, is a grumpy-looking Stoutland—male. Resting on his belly, he keeps a half-lidded eye out. And in front of the great creature is a single-file line of Pokemon, waiting patiently, looking up at the Pokemon atop Stoutland's back.
         It's a Smeargle. Speaking with a high-class cadence and affected accent, he addresses the first 'Mon in line: an overcast Cherrim.
         "Good evening, good Cherrim."
         "Hello..." the Grass-type mumbles.
         "You wish to enter, yes?"
         "Mm-hmm..."
         "Would you mind showing me your identification mark?"
         The Cherrim slowly peels through the veil of their petals. Painted on the downcast body of the Pokemon is a small scribbled mark—inked in the same color as the Smeargle's paint.
         "Very good. Welcome home!" Smeargle waves the Pokemon on; the Cherrim waddles behind the oak, out of view. Where did they go? You think to yourself. Is there a passage behind the oak? Does it lead into the trunk? Under its roots?
         The next Pokemon in line walks up. It's a Metapod.
         "Good evening, good Metapod."
         "Mmmph."
         "You look as if you want to enter. But from a cursory look at your body, I don't see your mark." Smeargle clicks his tongue rudely.
         "Mm-mph."
         "Well then, I'm sorry to say I cannot grant you passage. The exit is that way."
         "Mph!"
         "You had your mark as a Caterpie? And your shell is covering now that you're evolved? How unfortunate! You still don't have a mark, though. Run along, now."
         "Mhm-mm."
         Smeargle huffs, losing a bit of his cool. "Look—if I let you in, any schmuck without a mark is going to want to come barging in. And if one of those unknown Pokemon happen to be a predator, every one of the Pokemon in this tree is suddenly in mortal danger." Smeargle puffs his cheeks. "And also I would be out of a job. Now get out of here before I order Stoutland to detain you! Trust me—it won't be pleasant!"
         At this, the Metapod blanches and quickly hops their way out of line.
         As Smeargle greets the next 'Mon in line, you rub your chin in thought. You don't have an "identification mark", but you could always try to snag a spot in line and try to convince Smeargle to let you in—or even just to send a message up to Talonflame!
         Or your could try and sneak around back. That Cherrim had to have went somewhere, given they couldn't fly. Problem is, you'd be blindly searching the place without an alibi of if anyone questions why you're there...
         Or maybe—just maybe—you could hitch a ride on another Pokemon! You could ask them or sneak on yourself. Either way, all you need to do is avoid Smeargle's watchful eye. It doesn't look like Stoutland's paying all that much attention, anyway.
1141111212121121132221212112222222.title: The Queue: Your Greatest Obstacle Yet

choices: A modest nest on a branch, made with twigs and fabric
A birdhouse, large and almost empty
A hole in the tree, other Pokemon living there too
11411112121211211322212121122222222.content:
You're not risking them seeing you, you decide. That's just getting yourself into troble gratuitously, and frankly, you really don't think anyone here would give you a lift. Not if it meant getting caught by Smeargle. No, you decided it'd be better to sneak around back. There had to be a way in, no? You stepped back away from the queue, deciding to walk around, no matter how long it took you.

Twenty minutes later, you were close to the other side of the tree. You couldn't see the guardian dogs anymore, although the queue was still visible. Slowly, you walked out of the underbrush, ready to approach your target and seek an entrance.

You barely had walked half a meter when you heard the sound of wings, and then something pushing you roughly back into the underbrush. You roll ungracefully until you stop into a pile of leaves, dizzy and with all sorts of aches.

"Be careful! You could be seen if you step out there!" a voice, way louder than it had any right to be, startled you. You rub your head, looking up at whatever kooky 'mon had decided to make your life a mess.

Literally any Pokemon is a giant when compared to you -- and this one was no exception, but you could notice it wasn't one of the larger species. While you were smaller than even one of its talons, the bird wasn't as imposing as, say, Honchkrow. Chatots weren't really what you imagined when you thought about intimidating birds, and maybe that was what got you to relax quicker than you usually would. "You saw me...?"

"Of course I did! What are you trying to do?" it asked. They didn't sound upset, just curious.

You consider for a moment how much you should tell. "I'm trying to visit someone in there"

"And you don't have a mark?" they asked. You couldn't discern their gender, their voice made it rather difficult. You admit you don't. Chatot flaps their wings. "That's no good! If anyone catches you you'll be kicked out!" Nothing you weren't aware of already, really. You were about to stress how important if was for you to enter the tree, when Chatot added: "So let me help you. I can help you!"

"You...you can? How?"

"We bird Pokemon can go in anytime we want. Getting checked is like a code of honor thing!" That made some sense to you. Smeargle didn't have any way to check any flying Pokemon that didn't land and go into the queue, you guessed. "I can take you straight to the treetops!"

"And you...you don't mind that?"

Chatot laughed. "Of course not! You're so small and so strange. You wouldn't harm anyone" It seemed Chatot was naive, but they weren't wrong, and this was your best chance to get in there. You didn't have to mull it for long before you accepted. "Now I just have to carry you somehow up there. You're too small for my talons, so..."

Oh. There it was coming. After your experience with Honchkrow, you were kind of expecting this. What was it back then? Be gobbled up, or be shoved into the bird's butt? Better cut that short and make your choice right away, you figured. After what happened with Honchkrow, you weren't looking forward to getting involved with any bird's cloaca. Time to get eaten! You open your mouth.

"...I guess you'll have to get on my back"

You frown, confused. "Wait, really? That's an option?"

"Sure! It's from here to the treetop up there. That's just a minute or two of flying, you should be able to hold onto me that long! Right?"

"R-Right, I just..."

Chatot tilted their head, a bit puzzled. "Were you thinking of a different idea?"

"No, not really" you said immediately. You weren't going to give the parrot any weird ideas!

Climbing up Chatot's back was harder than you both thought it'd be. They had to position themselves into a rather uncomfortable position so you would be able to climb onto their tailfeathers, right to the base of the longer feathers forming its tail. Slowly, you manage to climb upwards, grabbing feathers much larger than yourself, pulling yourself upwards. Once you were close to the parrot's neck and you were holding as strongly as you could -- holding onto those feathers was almost impossible, admittedly -- you decided it was time to fly.

"Don't let go!" Chatot said to you, starting the flight. You almost fell right away, swooped away by the wind, but you held onto the feathers at the last moment. No wonder you had to be stored inside the bird for longer distances! This was incredibly dangerous! The treetop got closer and closer, until you and your feathery carriage flew right into it, entering a maze of branches and leaves you wouldn't be able to explore by yourself.

None of the other birds paid any attention to Chatot. Good! You'd be fine, it seemed.

"So who are you going to visit?" Chatot asked, gliding through the branches. You tell Chatot you planned to talk to Talonflame. Chatot look around to orientate themselves before saying: "Oh. You're late. Talonflame left the tree just a few hours ago"

"What?"

"They said they had something to do, and vacated the place! Too bad"

You were too late. Getting into the tree would have been pointless. You risked this...you even managed to find a way in...and it was moot now. Disheartened, you go silent. Your silence must have spoken volumes about how downtrodden you felt now, because Chatot said:

"Since you're here why don't you hang out with me for a while?"

"Huh?"

"You're here and it's not like I have many pals to be with. And you look like you need a pal too. What do you say? Want to hang out?"

"Chatot, I..."

"I have a huge stockpile of nuts, like you wouldn't believe it. Do you like nuts? I could give you as many as you want!"

Chatot sounded so friendly, so welcoming, you just couldn't say no. Telling them to take you down to the ground...it'd feel like you were turning your back on a Pokemon that wanted to help you out of the goodness of their heart. You would have patted Chatot's back if you weren't worried about falling down. "Yeah, I'd like that"

"Awesome! Come on, my home is right there. You'll dig it, it's--it's not amazing but it's home. Look, can you see it!"

"No, I can't" All you could see were blue feathers you were holding onto, and black feathers upwards, from the parrot's head. Chatot landed on a place you couldn't see, you were so glad to not be flying anymore. At least this time you were outside the avian Pokemon instead of inside.

"Welcome!" Chatot shouted while you descended from their back. While you were getting down, you finally saw what kind of home Chatot had.
11411112121211211322212121122222222.title: Helpful Chatot

choices: Smeargle doesn't find you. Lucky you!
Smeargle finds and takes you -- but doesn't inform Stoutland
11411112121211211322212121122222223.content:
After seeing how Smeargle refused to even give Metapod the benefit of doubt, you're pretty sure he wouldn't hesitate before telling you to scram. You cannot expect him to be lenient, you figure. Sneaking into the tree or...wherever they're going is tempting, although you're worried about Stoutland, in that case. Smeargle was busy making sure everyone had their marks, Stoutland wasn't doing much. There was a chance he'd see you trying to get in, and the jig would be up.

Getting a ride seemed to be the only sensible option, even though...you could be caught by both Smeargle and Stoutland, but you'd be passing right in front of them without them being none the wiser. In a way it had to be safer. You're not even sure if what you're thinking is logical -- the growing nervousness is skewing your thoughts somewhat.

There aren't that many Pokemon awaiting entrance, only five. You take a good look at them and decide to approach the one you think is least likely to try to make a meal out of you. The Bunnelby was staring forward at the tree with bored expression, the tedium of having to go through a familiar process everyday is obvious. You approach, unsure how to even ask such a favor, but you have to do it.

"Excuse me?"

The Bunnelby's ears swivel around, trying to locate where the voice came from. Only when they look down they see you. The rabbit's face scrunches. "Yes? What's up?"

"I want to enter the tree but I accidentally washed my mark off. Can you help me go inside?"

"That's a very obvious lie. Smeargle's paint doesn't fade at all"

...just what was that paint made of, then? You pinch the bridge of your nose. "I don't mean harm, I just want to visit someone who lives in there"

"Then ask that someone to tell Smeargle that you're allowed inside! I'm not risking getting in trouble with the guards because of you" with an exasperated huff, the Bunnelby turned their head around and refused to acknowledge you further, despite your attempts. Was Smeargly really that bad? Apparently so. It was likely everyone else would react similarly. Quickly, you return to the underbrush, reconsidering your plan.

Asking someone nicely wasn't working. The other option...was to hitch a ride without that Pokemon knowing.

--------

The sky above turned from a nice orange into a beautiful purple by the time a Pokemon you could ride appeared. You had discarded many options so far. Most of the Pokemon trying to enter were unevolved, and therefore were small. True, to you they were giants anyway, but them being small meant there were less ways to hide. How could you conceal yourself into an unevolved Pokemon's fur? Even with your size you'd be visible enough.

There, a viable Pokemon to hide on, a species you had never even heard before, but you didn't care about such details right now. A blue chameleon-like Pokemon crawled forward, moving rather slowly. Good, with how slowly it moved you'd be able to get on it. Carefully and as stealthily as you could, you reached the creature, throwing yourself onto one of its hind legs. You already have a plan.

Climbing a moving Pokemon is tough, but its rather low speed when moving works on your favor, and it's even easier when it has to wait on the line. The chameleon doesn't seem to notice you at all, even though you're grasping its scales as strongly as you can to keep pulling yourself up. You're glad you're not too shabby at rock climbing, it made this much easier. Soon you manage to crawl onto the Pokemon's lower back, taking a breather. All around you there's just blue scaly skin, and in the distance there's the head, still looking forward, the Pokemon unaware there's an interloper currently lounging on its lower back. Once you rested enough, you decide to get into your hiding spot -- there were only two Pokemon between the chameleon and Smeargle, you had to hurry. With that in mind, you turn around to face your target: the Pokemon's curled tail.

It's not the best hiding place, but you figure it'll help you go unnoticed -- and also won't be a problem to get off it later. You don't want to alert the 'mon you were riding it, after all.

You stay on the center of the tail, making sure not to deviate at all. It's not too difficult, thanks to your small size there's quite a distance between you and the edges of the tail. You get on all fours and start dragging yourself up the tail, to the point where the tail curls on itself. Slowly, you wedge yourself into the curl, turning around and pushing yourself on your rear until you can't go up any longer. All around you is just blue, and a rather thin sliver from where you can see the outside. It's official: you're hidden.

The wait isn't long. It takes just a few minutes before the Pokemon walks to where Smeargle and Stoutland are waiting. You relax, thinking it'll all go fine. The chameleon's scaly skin is surprisingly soft, and the sections of tail above you aren't pressing on you. You congratulate yourself for the comfy choice of hiding spot.

"Good evening, good...Stoutland, which one was this?"

"Sobble" Stoutland says. It's the first time you hear him say a word since you have been around.

"Right, Sobble. Good evening. Please show me your identification mark, if you may?"

"Um, right" another voice joins the group -- Sobble's, you figure. An approving hum could be heard, Smeargle seemed satisfied.

"I see you're a visitor. Welcome once again. Go ahead--"

"Wait." Stoutland stops Smeargle and Sobble before any of them can finish the conversation. Suddenly he sounds alert "Something is off"

"What? The mark doesn't lie"

"It's not that. There's some kind of scent in the air here"

There's silence for a moment while you hear someone take a deep breath. "You're right. It doesn't seem familiar"

Right then, you realize with horror what they could mean. Furret. Furret had ensured you'd have his scent. Surely your scent was lingering in the air, and now it was getting the guards' attention. Dang it! Even when he wasn't around, Furret was causing you trouble! Why did the guards of the tree have to be dogs? Why couldn't it be something without a good sense of smell?!

"I'm sorry, did I do something wrong?" Sobble sounds rather worried, almost like they're about to cry.

"Smeargle, I have seen this Pokemon many times before. They don't have any sort of malice. Even if there's something wrong it can't be their fault"

"I know, I know. Geez." said Smeargle. "Stoutland, keep guard for a moment. I'll handle this. Through the sliver you were able see the bark of the tree, as well as dirt. All that is gone. All you see now is white fur -- Smeargle was right beside Sobble. "Listen, you have done nothing wrong, don't worry. No crying, last time you cried near me I had watery eyes for hours. You'll be fine"

"What's going on?"

"I dunno, that's what I'll find out. Don't worry, it's routine and we'll be done right away. Follow me" he said, leading Sobble to a side, away from everyone else in the queue, at least having the decency not to badger a Pokemon right in front of others. All the time you have been holding your breath, like you're afraid Smeargle's sharp hearing would detect you that way.

You really, really hoped Smeargle would fail to find you. You hoped he would think they were wrong, or that the scent came from somewhere else in the forest. It had been a while since you felt so nervous. With bated breath, you hear Smeargle start looking for anything odd on Sobble.
11411112121211211322212121122222223.title: Infiltration

choices: "I suppose I can make an exception..."
"That scent... Are you with that criminal scum!?"
114111121212112113222121211222222232.content:
"It's right here..." the beagle hushly mutters. Sniff. Sniff. "Whatever it is, wherever it is, it's—ah ha!" Your curled-tail enclosure leaps, Sobble hopping in surprise at Smeargle's sudden outburst. You're careful to keep yourself steady, propping yourself against Sobble's soft scales.
Smeargle clears his throat with a one-two cough. "Ahem. Sobble."
"W-what?" You feel a nervous tremor wrack the shaking Pokemon. Your eyes remain glued on the curtain of white-tan fur standing right outside the small crease of the chameleon's tail.
"Would you mind unfurling your tail?"
No! Oh no!
You're helpless as the teary Pokemon obeys. The blue spiral you're wrapped in begins to roll itself open. The sliver of light rapidly expands, bathing you in cool blues and purples of the nightime air. You cling to Sobble's scales as you're lifted high in the air. Dangling from the rounded, deep-blue tip of their tail, you're flipped upside-down as Sobble's tail completely unfurls—presenting you at its tip. You're splayed out on its surface, belly to the sky and eyes locked onto an inspecting Smeargle, looking down from above.
"Ah! The culprit reveals themselves!" He sniffs once. Frowns. "We're quite in luck that our smelly little criminal forgot to bathe themselves."
"Hey!" You blurt, standing up. You're tempted to smell your armpit. But you don't. Because that's stupid.
Smeargle lowers a paw down to your height. He waggles his digits impatiently. "Hop on, now. Chop chop!" You throw out your arms and plead to Painter Pokemon.
"I know this looks—really—bad. But—"
"No 'buts'. Hop on."
"Look at me! I'm a tiny human! Aren't you surprised?"
"Criminals come in all shapes and sizes."
"Not this size!"
"Quiet!" Smeargle bellows. The blast of sound knocks you on your butt—and causes a certain blue chameleon to start sniffling out of fright.
"Look what you did!" Smeargle furrows his eyebrows, giving you a mean look. "You made Sobble cry."
"I didn't do that! You did!" Smeargle blows hot air out his nose, dousing you in the fumes.
"Enough!" He shouts before picking up his paw and hovering it over you like a claw in a crane game. You're about to scurry away, but fail to kick yourself into gear; Smeargle pinches you between his paw. You flail your arms, trying to slap away his digits, but find your blows are cushioned by his coarse fur. He brings you up between his eyes.
"You are rude!" Smeargle waggles his paint-coated tail in your direction. "And rude criminals are the worst! Crook-Pokemon like Nickit and Murkrow at least have charisma—charm! Sniff, sniff. You even smell a bit like a Murkrow!"
"I'm rude!? Go pick on someone your own size!"
"Shut it!"
Sobble's sniffles become tears.
"Oh no—ah—Sobble! You're free to go!" Smeargle starts to rush away before Sobble's eye-watering tears wet the beagle's peepers. "And you, speck, are in so, so much trouble!"
Smeargle scampers along, you dangling between his pinchers. The quickly cooling evening air whips you with windchill as you swing in the breeze. Looking ahead, you see Smeargle round the trunk of the tree. Stoutland stands sentinel at the head of the line. Only a few Pokemon remain—waiting for passage.
Hearing the plap of Smeargle's footsteps, Stoutland flicks his eyes toward his partner before swinging them back to the queue. "Found 'em?" The dog gruffs.
"Found them. They're an indignant, mouthy little thing." Smeargle slows his pace, walking up to the hound. Stoutland gives a single guffaw of a deep chuckle.
"They need to be detained?"
"Ohhh yes." Smeargle lowers his eyes towards you—and smiles smugly. "Modus Operandi C: Colo Edere."
A gruff chortle causes the hair around Stoutland's mouth to lift up. "Bad egg, eh?"
"Very." The poisonous way Smeargle chews his words causes your gut to drop.
Stoutland grunts. "Put 'em up back. Poor bugger."
You struggle, kick, and cry out as you continue to dangle in Smeargle's grasp, swinging to-and-fro like a tiny pendulum. Smeargle tromps over to Stoutland, humming a private melody to himself. He's happy, you think. Why is he happy!?
You're question is answered when the beagle finishes his journey to the big, blue-brown coated guard dog. He circumnavigates the ginourmous creature, holding you close to Stoutland's indigo fur—causing you to skip across his coat and be exposed to his crude dog-like scent. Abruptly, Smeargle pulls you away and holds you at his white-furred hip. You look up at your captor. Smeargle opens his mouth and closes his eyes, smiling as he makes an announcement that curdles your blood and stands your hair on end.
"Stoutland: lift you tail—if you'd please."
You spin your head toward Stoutland. You can't see his face. You can only see his planet-sized behind, dressed in a forest of deep blue fur. The tuft of his tail lay limp, but at the behest of Smeargle's words, it lifts—parting his tangled, wild wool and revealing a pudgy mass that brings bile up your throat. Dust and dirt cling to the edges of dark, fleshed hole—or at least you hope it's dirt...
Smeargle swings you up to his face. "You could've had a cozy cell." Smeargle seethes. "But you had to make Sobble cry. Besides—you could've got them in deep trouble. Your stink almost barred him from going inside. Do you think that they could survive out here at night?"
You punch the air, taking out your frustrations at a target far out of your reach. "You're just looking for excuses!"
Smeargle rolls his eyes. He flips you around, turning you to face Stoutland's derriere. He drops his paintbrush tail, letting it drop to the floor, and places his free hand on the lower back of his partner. He brings you closer to the horrible prison. Stoutland's musk swells to near-unbearable levels. You wriggle and worm, but it's useless—you're going in.
You're centimeters away. A foul scent brews from within. The frightful gurgle of his organs are clearly audible.
Smeargle positions you on his thumb.
"Wait! Don't—"
He pushes you in.
The horrid bundle of muscle squelches over you, the normally taut flesh yielding to Smeargle's intruding thumb. You're pressed against the disgusting flesh, rumbling with Stoutland's suppressed, grumbling moan. The cool night air is gone—replaced with nauseating fumes and torrid heat. Moist flesh hugs your face as the evil pudge of the dog's asshole embraces you in a vile hug.
The beagle's thumb relentlessly pushes you deeper—until the crook of Smeargle's paw catches Stoutland's behind, unable to venture further. Smeargle has pushed his thumb up to its root: enough to imprison you deep in Stoutland's tract—with no way to escape unless the big dog wills it. Slimed with colon juice, baked by heat, and abused by the dog's colon walls, you're thrust into a miserable cramped space. A sickening stench invades your nose, causing you to let loose a wheezing gag. Smears of brown horribleness stain the walls. You try to crawl away, avoiding the scattish rump scraps that gum the folds of Stoutland's rectum.
You bounce as the dog's intestines twitch and quash, the big dog straining—trying to hold his pleasure and keep his professional composure. You hear the dog release a fat sigh. "Sorry y'all had to see that. Only the real bad folk get sent there. Don't know what they did—but you bet they deserved it."
No you didn't! You're innocent! Smeargle just seems to have a real bee in his bonnet for "criminals."
You strip yourself off the grimy colon floor, your face red-hot. This is disgusting! How long do you have to be in here!?

The last Pokemon in line—a Swellow—shows her mark that's painted on the pale underside of her wing. After a hasted verification process, she's approved. The Swellow immediately takes to the skies, but not before flashing the pair a mildly disgusted look.
"And—that's all of them." Smeargle says with a relieved finality. "Hoppity Hoppips, that was a long day..."
Stoutland harumphs. "You're telling me." The great hound rises to his feet and stretches his legs, back arching—rear in the sky. "I'm damn happy I was laying belly-down when you stuck 'em in. Popped something embarrassing..."
Smeargle pats the dog's fluffed side. "Hush! Look: another visitor!"
"Hm? Oh. Two, actually."
You're broiling in the fetid heat of canine bowels—surrounded by the sickening odor of dog shit. The dog's bowels pulse rhythmically, timed with his heartbeat. Large clumps of scat lay deeper within, but you're able to stay far far away from them—thank Arceus.
Breaking through the musty swelter of his shitpipe—a voice. Your veins abruptly fill with ice.
"H-h-hello..."
"Ah! A Mincinno! You have your mark, yes?"
"Y-yes..."
"Excellent! And your friend there?"
"They don't have a m-mark. Th-they're my g-guest..."
"Guests aren't typically allowed. They either have their mark or—"
"Don't worry," a silvery, male, oh-so-horribly familiar voice chimes, "I'm their best friend. We had a wonderful meal just a little while ago. I introduced myself to her friends and we got quite close. Poor things, they're very sick. And If I don't meet a special little birdie Mincinno told me about, well—" Furret pauses.
"I'm afraid they'll just melt."

You suffer in Stoutland's fetid bowels, heart in your throat, waiting for Smeargle's response...
114111121212112113222121211222222232.title: Dog Days

choices: Suddenly, something sweeps down from the sky: Talonflame
Furret escapes right away, much to Mincinno's horror
1141111212121121132221212112222222321.content:
You exhale with relief when you hear that, and immediately regret that, coughing while filling your lungs with vicious air. At least Smeargle was as much of an impenetrable wall with Furret as he was with you. You breathe shallowly, thinking about the situation.

Obviously Furret found Mincinno and most likely is forcing her to get him into the tree. You're not sure what he stands to gain picking a fight with a bird that's likely strong enough to give him a good fight, but him reaching Talonflame can't be good. Right now you're more concerned about Mincinno, though...

...too bad you're currently trapped in a guard dog's colon! That seriously limits your options, there's little you can do when all that's around you is a tube of filthy, greasy walls. There's only one thing you can do, you realize: plead. Plead to Stoutland to do something.

You get on your knees, weakened by the heat and the unpleasantness, and smack the wall with a fist. "You...Stoutland, you have to listen to me! Don't let him into the tree! Mincinno is in danger! Please, listen to me!"

Mincinno's reaction to Smeargle's refusal to let Furret in was of despair. She cried with horror, approaching Smeargle and pretty much clinging to one of his legs. "P-Please, I invited him to...to spend the night because he really needs it. There must be something I can do!"

"Aw, it's not that big of a deal. I'll return any other day" Furret said, nonchalant. "Too bad about your friends, I hope they get better"

"Wait, don't leave, I can do this!" Mincinno shouted at Furret, who had already turned around to leave. "Smeargle, he's my guest!"

"Guests need to go through a process before they get accepted and are painted with a mark. I know you haven't been here in a while, but that's the policy" Smeargle shrugged, seemingly not having noticed the urgency of the situation. "We can get that started tomorrow"

"I need it tonight!"

While Mincinno begged, Stoutland felt a little voice coming from deep inside him. Ah, that tiny thing Smeargle had found sneaking around. The big dog had been about to tune out from that when he noticed the voice in his innermost depths wasn't pleading about being let out, or anything similar. Stoutland stepped away discretely, unnoticed by everyone else.

Every time you hit the wall, the flesh quivered, but you didn't know if the dog was feeling any of it. You were shouting as loudly as possible, trying to overcome the noises that saturated the tunnel you were in. Was Stoutland even listening to you? "...can you even hear me? Arceus, if it turns out I'm shouting at the void I don't know what I'll do..."

"You shout loudly, for someone so small"

Good, Stoutland heard you. You step away from the wall. There was no time to waste. You shouted everything you knew about Furret. How they had eaten so many Pokemon, how they were feared by anything small enough to be prey, how if he got into the tree, everybody inside could be eaten by him.

You also lied, saying you had tried to sneak in so you could warn Talonflame about an imminent attack by Furret. It was a lie you could get away with, thankfully -- besides, if it helped make them take the threat seriously, it was worth it.

When you were done, nothing happened for a moment. You just stood there, right in the center of the tube, staring at the depths that led into Stoutland, nothing more than wriggling walls, rancid air, and piles of waste far, far away in the distance. You awaited for Stoutland to say anything.

"Fine. We will have to do something about that"

That made you so happy you may as well be standing on a field of fragrant flowers, with lots of sunlight all over you. It was the best news you could have heard in a while.

It was a rather unsettling accusation. That speck was claiming Furret was a dangerous predator and that if he got into the tree everyone inside would be in danger. That Furret was looking for Talonflame. Really? If that so-called dangerous predator was going to pick a fight with Talonflame then it wasn't too smart, but if everyone else in the tree was in danger...

"If it turns out you're lying, you'll be in so much trouble" Stoutland turned his head around and whispered to his backside, thankfully without anyone noticing.

---------------

This had been a long and stressful day and Smeargle wanted nothing more than go retire to his home. But noooo! Now he had to deal with this mess. The whole day he had to stand around and sit on Stoutland's back and check the marks for hundreds of Pokemon. It wasn't a hard job, but he took it so seriously it was stressful.

At least the tiny human was novelty enough. For a moment Smeargle's thoughts wander to the tiny human he had inserted up Stoutland's rear, as it was their agreement when dealing with those who got mouthy and put anyone in the tree in danger. That small human deserved it, no doubt. Mouthy idiot, getting Sobble involved...

Still, Stoutland always enjoyed that modus operandi a bit too much. Smeargle briefly wondered how it felt to have something crawling up your rear like that. It was a thought that crossed his head every time Stoutland imprisoned someone like that, just around a dozen times a year.

Shaking his head, he focused his attention back to Mincinno. He had been about to tell her she could go in but Furret wouldn't, when he turned his head to look at Stoutland, who was staring at Furret. His partner seemed...wary. "Anything wrong?"

"We could let him in through the entrance for visitors"

Smeargle got alert. The 'entrance for visitors' was their moniker for a dead end in the forest, against a cliff and in the opposite direction to the red tree. They led serious threats in there to be dealt with before being locked away. If Stoutland was suggesting such a thing, then this was a serious situation. "If you say so then that's fine"

"Oh, thank you, thanks!" Mincinno sounded so grateful, unaware this wasn't what it sounded like. Furret was standing there, tail swishing from side to side, having read the air and noticed the guard dogs were tense.

Furret nudged Mincinno. "Lead the way, my friend!" he said, excessively cheerful. Now that Smeargle was alert, he started to notice something was very wrong. Stoutland had to be right.

All the Pokemon walked into the forest, Mincinno to the front following a trail, Furret following just a few steps behind, and Stoutland and Smeargle on the back. Smeargle was on Stoutland, lying with his chin on his partner's head, fiddling with his paintbrush tail. "So do you plan on telling me what's freaking you out about him?"

"You didn't notice anything wrong?"

"...Mincinno is real desperate, now that you mention it"

"That speck I have in me right now has been yelling a lot"

"About how they want mercy and to be let out, I guess"

"No. It's about Furret. They say he's extremely dangerous"

Smeargle almost hit his own face with his tail. "And you believe them?!"

"They say Furret has been eating 'mons around, and that one of them may have been from the tree. They say Furret may want to attack Talonflame"

Crap. When put like that, there was no way Smeargle could just ignore any of that. The safety of everyone living in there was his priority, after all. He had to take the human's warnings as if they were true. There was no way he'd apologize, though. Trying to get into the tree like the human did was reprehensible, he had been justified in treating him like that.

The entrance for visitors was just like usual, a semicircle formed by the rocky face of a cliff, trees standing so close together passing through them would be impossible, and open sky above -- and the guard dogs at the only way in and out. Furret tilted his head. "Is the entrance a tunnel?"

Stoutland advanced very slowly, ready to pounce at any moment, while Smeargle stood on the trail, intending to block it any way he could. "You have one chance to tell us what's going on" said Smeargle. Furret said nothing. "Did you think we're stupid? I dunno what you threatened Mincinno with, but there's no way we're letting you into the tree!"

"...that's too bad. You heard them, Mincinno, you can't blame me now"

It was clear there had been a threat of something. As much as he hated to admit it, the human had been on the right. Even worse, this meant once this was dealt with Stoutland would have to let the human out of his system. Hell would freeze over before Smeargle admitted fault, though.

Oh well, first he'd have to deal with the problem right in front of them: they needed to incapacitate Furret before locking him away. Stoutland was strong, and although Smeargle had far less strength, he was too large to be eaten and wasn't really in any danger -- although he'd stand aside from any fighting. The only one in serious danger here was Mincinno. They had to finish this before Furret did anything that could harm her. "Stoutland, knock him out!"
1141111212121121132221212112222222321.title: Looming Threat

choices: Stoutland stirs awake not too much later.
Stoutland blearily wakes up. It's sundown. Has he been out for nearly 24 hours?
Stoutland pops awake. He tilts his head. He can't remember any of the past day..
11411112121211211322212121122222223211.content:
A booming thud pounds your ears, Stoutland slamming his paws to the ground outside. The stocky hound is getting into a fighting stance; his feet spread, shoulders raise, and his head lowers. A growl brews in his throat.
         Inside, your knees buckle as the dog rapidly shoots forth, flying forward in a wild charge. You slap a hand on a greasy wall, searching for a handhold to brace yourself as the dog's bowels jump up and down in his ferocious stride. The crash of his stomping on the ground sends a shockwave through the squishy flesh of his bowels, causing them to ripple and shake. You can only last a couple seconds before you collapse to your knees, one hand pressing against the quavering floor. Your legs wobble as you try to unsteadily rise to your feet.
         But then Stoutland hard swerves left. An invisible marionette string tugs at your back, flinging you through the fetid air and splattering you against the right of the canine's colon. Centrifugal force pins you to the slime-soaked side. Every inch of your body feels like it's held by heavy lead. You try to lift a hand—and you do so. Trembling and shaky, your hand tries to peel yourself away—but your pitiful strength makes that impossible.
         Stoutland stops. You're unshackled from the wall and sent hurtling to the grimy floor. Your body makes a horrible fleshy plap as it flops onto the ground. Bones aching, stomach queasy, you struggle to your feet once more—but then Stoutland flashes to the right. Dodging an attack, maybe?
         Either way, you find it impossible to find your footing. As Stoutland and Furret engage in an unseen—but not unfelt—battle, you're tossed around the place like the world's most ill-loved ragdoll. You're grimy, bedraggled, and smell like you just got finished rolling around in dog sh—
         SLAM!
         Stoutland is swept off his feet from a particularly powerful attack. You're sent hurtling in another unfun flight. You squish into the colon's abhorrent roof and stick there, your body held tight by intestinal lubricant. As Stoutland clambers to his feet, you begin to fall, gravity pulling you down. Strings of the stuff connect you to the ceiling as you slowly descend before snapping. You fall like a miserable meteorite, crashing into a quaggy, squishy earth.
         Stoutland growls. You hear Furret.
         "Oh, and here I thought someone your size could've been a challenge!" His smug voice pierces your prison and fills you with ire. "It's a shame, really. If your stuffy friend here was a little bit smaller, I think I would have myself a victory snack."
         A faint protesting voice. Smeargle? You listen closer. You barely hear him. "Get up, Stoutland! Get up!"
         Furret continues. "Although, I am quite stuffed. And once I'm through with you, I won't be needing little miss Minccinno over there." He hums. "You really are the perfect size. You like the taste of chinchilla?"
         A powerful growl booms through Stoutland's body as he suddenly springs upright. Without pause, he plows his body into the monologuing ferret in a brutal Take Down.
         "Waaugh!" Furret cries. You say the same thing, flying and splattering once more.
         Pound!
         Whomp!
         Thwack!
         Smash!
         When it's all over and done, you're more slime than human—and you're seeing quite a lot of stars...
         Suddenly, you hear a horrible sound—outside: retching.
         "Blourgh..." Furret gags. "Hurk..."
         And then, a disgusting splattering sound. Two heavy thuds sop onto the grass.
         "Nooo..." Furret moans, forlorn. You hear Stoutland's heavy steps as he approaches the recovering Pokemon and stomps his heavy pad on his now-empty belly.
         "You're... under... arrest." Stoutland breathes heavy between his breaths, barely conscious after the recoil from his desperate attack. You feel the blood of his crazily-beating heart pulse through the echoing catacomb of his body. You feel your prison wobble before you feel yourself fall. One second later, you're thrown up high as Stoutland crashes on top Furret, spirals in his eyes.
         "Get him off!" Furret wheezes as he wriggles around, his tail writhing around like a wiggling cat toy. "He's... really heavy..."
         A small pattering of feet. To your surprise, it's not Smeargle. Minccinno approaches.
         "You are bad!" She shouts, holding back tears. Furret groans, annoyed.
         "Yup. I'm bad. Great observation, Sniffles. Your friends were delicious, by the way."
         A sharp smack rings out like music to your ears.
         "Ow!" Furret yelps. "Did you just slap—"
         Another resounding smack. Then another. And another. Despite having having literal bowel slime dripping over you like syrup on flapjacks, you smile.

         It's been one hour since Furret's arrest. After Smeargle sped away for backup, he returned to find Furret unconscious—a beaming Minccinno standing beside him, her pain-giving paws cutely slunk behind her back. Her friends were resting on the grass, drenched in belly juices.
         You're still in Stoutland's bowels. The big 'Mon still hasn't woken up. He's very clearly still alive. His heart still thumps, his organs still grumble. Worst of all, his intestines didn't get put on pause. The dog crap that once lurked far in the twisting abyss of his colon steadily grows closer. His busy bowels pounded it into an indubitable log. Its stinking fumes are already starting to fill the passage with its horrible stench.
         For the better part of the hour, you tried to pry your way free. Lodging your hands into the folds of the dog's arse, you pull and pull—but it's stuck tight. You look back at the clay-like mass and a shiver runs down your spine.
         "How much longer is he going to be out..." You mutter into the stinking air. The dog’s guts burble as a breeze of fart-ridden air wafts into your wretched chamber.
11411112121211211322212121122222223211.title: Battle of the Bowels

choices: Accept. It won't be that comfy, but fine
Refuse. You have the option to say no, so you say no
Suggest an alternative he'd be interested in
114111121212112113222121211222222232111.content:
You press yourself against the sphincter blocking your way, trying to put as much distance between the ever-approaching bunch of crap and you. You really hope you're not going to be there when it enters the rectum, you calculate it won't be more than a couple hours before it does. Did Furret hit Stoutland that hard? You sure hope not!

Thankfully, you're lucky for once. Everything around you trembles when the big dog stands up, shaking his head. He aches, but he's fine. He awoke just in time to see Smeargle return once again, Mincinno and her friends aren't anywhere to be seen.

"About time, big guy. Mincinno is in the tree, and I just finished making sure Furret is taken away and those he had eaten are on their way to Sanctuary"

"Sanctuary is rather far away" Stoutland said, strethcing his legs.

"They were in Furret's stomach for a while. They're okay, but it'd be good to get them some attention just in case." You're really glad to hear that. Against all odds, Mincinno and her friends are safe. "Now we have to deal with the human"

"The human...?"

"The speck. It's a small human" And since they had warned them of the danger, there's no option but to let them go. Smeargle approaches Stoutland's rear. Your entire world turns ninety degrees, your heart soars when you realize what it means: it's time to exit.

When Stoutland's anus open you don't waste time to jump down through it, exchanging the stench of the bowels for the fresh air outside, without even noticing you'll fall into Smeargle's cupped paws. When you land, you look at the beagle's face, just for a second before he forms a fist. "Hey, I'm free, right?"

"What are we going to do with them?" asks Stoutland. For a moment there's silence. You thought Smeargle had already decided what to do, the silence makes you uneasy, until...

"I'll take care of this. Don't worry about it"

-------

You didn't expect Smeargle to bring you to his home inside the tree.

When Smeargle opened your fist after a bumpy ride, you were surprised to see a small-sized place, looking like it was exhaustively carved into the tree's wood. There even is crafted furniture, and the floor has several splotches of paint -- paint that dripped from Smeargle's tail, you figure. It's a modest place to live but it seems rather comfy.

Why did he bring you here?

"Okay, get a bath before anything else. You really need it" he said, bringing you a wooden bowl with water. You didn't hesitate to get in there and start removing all the filth you had accumulated during the day. It's cleansing, you even feel Furret's scent finally leaving you. It feels like you're removing shackles off yourself. You're free!

Once you were done, Smeargle once again took you in his paw, enclosing it around you. When he opened it again, he was lying down on what seemed to be a couch, and he placed you on his torso. "Turn around" he commands, grabbing his paintbrush tail. "You better not move. With your size there's only one try"

"Wait, you're going to give me that mark you were looking for?"

"You got a problem with that?" You certainly didn't. Soon Smeargle was painting on your back, the tip of his tail sketching a rather complicated mark on you with his paint. "I'm the one in charge of security, if I say you're allowed in then you are"

"So that's why you brought me here"
