How long would it take you to traverse so much of his guts and reach Honchkrow? It could take you hours! Maybe even days -- or not, you guessed, but it would be a rather long time before you made progress. You wished you had climbing gear, in case any slope or wall proved to be too much for you to handle.

There was the other option of entering through the king's mouth. He could easily swallow you, but then there was a big problem: his stomach. Any contents inside would be like a lake to you. Would you even be able to dive to the bottom? Diving through Noibat's stomach had strained your lungs, this would be almost impossible.

You really hoped Honchkrow's survival and anything Nidoking could tell you about the human who went through your same fate would be worth it.
1141111212121121132221212112323.title: The Big Favor

choices: The plan works! Honchkrow passes a bit further along!
Nidoking’s bowels clench hard, dislodging and rocketing Honchkrow towards you!
Honchkrow… goes the wrong way and is flung deeper: to the stomach.
11411112121211211322212121123231.content:
Honchkrow needs saving. You need answers. And, despite all you’ve witnessed, you’re not going to let two Pokemon die. A grim determination sparks in your breast. Soon, it blossoms into a burning valor.
         You can do this!
         You stick your hand in. Regret.
         An awful warmness and a sickening sensation assaulted your hand as it slipped in with a repulsive squishing sound. Your fingers wiggle inside, tickling wet flesh that writhe in reciprocation. Your hand glides deeper as if it had a mind of its own, drawn in by slipperiness of the lizard’s backport. Now you’re up to your elbow as the muscles inside ripple and twitch, coaxing the foreign object to head ever deeper.
         “...Can you speed things up just a notch?” You can feel the rumble of Nidoking’s voice through his pliant flesh. “The faster this is done, the less memories for the both of us.”
         You sigh and do as he asks. You wedge your other hand in, prying a miniscule opening for yourself to slip into. You see two pink walls, slick with slimy lubricant: the king’s inner tailhole — the final barrier sealing his innards from your reluctant invasion. A world-destroying odor leaks through and threatens to devour your soul.
         You press on anyway. You shove your head in and are met with a execrable combo of overpowering heat and monstrous stench. The result of their sinful synergy is so unpleasant that it’s comparable to a hell — it feels as if the fumes could burn your skin to the bone. Darkness yields to light as your miner cap reveals secrets best left to the shadows. A behemothic tunnel of horrid flesh breathes with life of its own, shifting, oscillating, and stirring as it continues to serve its fetid purpose as the end of Nidoking’s abhorrent system. The soppy and slimy sounds of muscle-on-muscle saturate the foul-smelling hellscape, conducted by the steady rhythm of a bass-rich heartbeat.
         You go deeper. You wriggle your way in, carving your way through an ocean of flesh. The circlet of muscle chews around your waist like toothless gums. An all-encompassing groan besieges you as Nidoking’s tail arches and lifts as his anal muscles clench. You’re effortlessly swallowed. Sucked in like a slurped noodle.
         You are ejected onto an organic floor with a splat: prone. You brace your hands against the colon, giving you the support to stand. Nidoking's innards are gigantic. The intestinal ceiling looms above, shiny from its coating of foul fluid. Veins and arteries dance along the cavern’s surface, painting a twisted pattern of muted red and blue. You see the passage curves downward but that’s all you can discern before your light dissolves into darkness.
         “Best of luck,” Nidoking’s voice booms as if he were the voice of Arceus itself. “And thank you.”
         You take some steps forward. The sound of your bare feet slapping against the organ that is now your earth echoes through your mind. There is no doubt in your mind now. You left your old world behind. Now you are at the mercy of a world of meat. So small, that if Nidoking hadn’t helped put you in himself, he would never know you are there.
         Nidorous air, the poison filtered but the stench remaining, burns your nasal passages like acid. Yet, you soldier on. You broil as you venture deeper, down the bend of the rectum and up an incline that would be slight if you were not the size of an ant. You struggle to clamber over. The intestinal floor, slick with natural lubricant, causes your hands and feet to skate across the glossy plane. Only by finding handholds in the wrinkles and ridges of the king’s flesh are you able to surmount your first trial.
         You’re greeted with soul-crushing revelation: you only passed the rectum. The incline goes on for far longer, its true distance obscured in shadow. Now you are in the large intestine. Your journey is far, far from over.
         For you, this is like climbing a mountain. You toil through the night, or at least you assume the night. Your skies are sunless. Daylight does not fall — only revolting slime. The only way you know it is still night are the baritone snores of Nidoking.
         Just as you pull yourself into a fold in the monster’s flesh, you feel everything move. Turning, rotating — Nidoking is flipping himself over in his sleep. You hold on to the intestinal wall for your life as the entire world works against you. You can’t let go! All your work will be undone! All of your blood, sweat, and tears as you toiled — wasted. You can’t! You can’t!
         You let go, plunging into the darkness as you witness hours of work evaporate.
         You plummet. Your slam into the soft wall and splatter into slime. Gravity peels you off as you descend further until your descent is halted by the colon floor. You’re back at the beginning. But you’re not beaten — not yet. You got to stand before a distant, familiar, and dreadful rumbling fills you with despair. Nidoking’s great organs groan as you watch a rapid contraction speed towards you, carrying a malodorous payload. He farted. Even filtered, the miasma poisons your soul.
         May Azelf grant you strength….

◓ ◓ ◓ ◓


         It’s almost been a day. ...At least you think it’s been that long. You remember the grueling ordeal that was making up for your lost progress.
         You remember being assaulted by fumes, heat, and all the evils that fester within the deepest depths of the Poison-type.
         Worst of all was when Nidoking awoke. The belabored groans of him and his tummy alike fill your ears with a deep rumble. His thunderous, quaking steps rocked the world, wobbling his innards and bouncing you every which way as if you were trapped in a bouncy, inflatable castle during an earthquake. Your tiny calls for help failed to reach even Nidoking’s sensitive ears. It’s clear: nothing was ever meant to live here.
         But somehow, you made it. Nidoking fell asleep again and that was when you made most of your progress. You scaled the twisting internal mountain, against all odds. Now — you see it. The entrance (or is it exit?) of Nidoking’s small intestine. The ginormous sphincter lays tightly closed but you’ve come too far to be stopped.
         “Alright birdbrain,” you mutter, “you better be thankful…” You scale to the sealed opening of the orifice and force your way in. You groan as you’re squeezed by its stauch grasp and mashed by its unyielding muscle. Enveloped wholey, surrounded by pink crushing walls, shrouded in darkness, the light of your cap blocked. For a moment, you fear you’ll be stuck there forever — blind and binded with only the grumblings and groans of Nidoking’s organs for company. After what seems like a forever-and-a-half, you breach through.
         You fall into another fleshed tube: Nidoking’s small intestine. Landing into a tickling barrage of threadlike villi, you’re held aloft like a crowd surfing rockstar. The horrid stench of the colon abates greatly, much to your relief. Little fluid exists graces this part of the intestine. Either Nidoking’s anatomy differs greatly from Noibat’s or Honchkrow is a darn good plug.
         The intestines are winding, far more than the colon. Much to your relief, you find that villi’s presence to be an invaluable climbing aid. You trek through the living forest of villi, combating the natural flow and peristalsis of the intestines. A fire reignites in your belly. You are not going back the way you came. Not without a big bird in tow.
         It’s impossible to say how far you traveled. You could’ve traveled halfway, a quarterway, you could’ve even been right at the end of the monarch’s royal tract. Distance is unfathomable and time doesn’t exist. All you know is that you knew you arrived at your destination when you saw a big black taloned foot emerge from the darkness. It’s Honchkrow!
         He’s stuck fast, the loathsome tunnel suctioned around his form like an air-tight bag. To your relief, you notice his feet kick and his tail sway slightly, brushing the roof of the cavern. He’s alive, even if he might be wishing he wasn’t.
         “Hey Featherbutt — it’s me!” You shout at his, well... feathery butt. Instantly the bird’s struggles renew.
         “Mm-mmph!” The crow hails you.
         “Listen up: this is going to be weird… but I’m going to get us out.” You whip out your electrical rod and set it on the intestinal wall. “It’s probably going to take a while so, uh, hang in there!” You activate the tool…
11411112121211211322212121123231.title: Nidoking's Chagrin Within the Intestine

114111121212112113222121211232311.content:
The entire reason why you're inside Nidoking's guts was because his skin impided the electricity from reaching his organs. Now that you were inside the organ itself, you definitely could see everything was squishier, much wetter, and hopefully much easier to zap. If this didn't work, you were ready to just lie down and curse everything and everyone. Crossing your fingers for a favorable result, you activate the rod. Sparks shine at the end, spreading through the wall. The reaction is immediate all around you. The walls contract, compressing Honchkrow and making him try to protest, a weak whisper being all he manages to say. He can't even do the "mm-mmph" noises from how tight it is. Thankfully, you being so small, you don't experience the contraction of the walls.

With your light, you see Honchkrow start moving. Relieved, you extract the rod. "This will work! We'll get out of here!". You tell Honchkrow. You climb one of his talons, clinging to it like it's a lifesaver in a tumultous sea. "Don't worry, I will keep everything moving". It was a promise you intended to keep no matter what. True, the return trip would also take a while, given you had to lug the crow with you, but the fact this was going well was enough to lift your spirits.

Honchkrow must have felt you get on his foot, because he doesn't move as much from there on, or at least you hoped it was because of that instead of because the constant compressions knocked him out. That was just as likely, you had to admit. Maybe that would be for the better. Less resistance would make this easier.

Just like Nidoking had feared, although the intestine kept moving its oversized contents along, Honchkrow did get stuck a few times along the way. Every time you leaned and stuck the rod into the wall, activating it and forcing the muscles to do their job. You were glad Nidoking was currently asleep, the sensations you and Honchkrow were causing couldn't feel good at all. Despite that, to you it felt almost like a leisurely ride down a river. The sounds of sloshing and gurgles close to you contributed a lot to the impression you had of this.

If it wasn't because you were inside a creature and in the middle of its digestive system, you almost would find this pleasant. Alas, the reminder you were currently getting something unstuck from Nidoking's guts was always present.

By now you had lost track of time. You had no idea how much time passed when you saw in the distance the sphincter that divided the small and large intestine. Now that there was a much larger object about to pass through it, you hoped it would be enough to coax it to open far more than it did when you were trying. "Okay, you'll have to stay completely still, birdbrain" you advised.

"Mmmmph?"

"You'll have a little bit of freedom in just a moment"

It was like a slow-motion collision. The talons hit the sphincter, but the round hole did not budge. You were forced to ascend up Honchkrow's leg until you reached his thigh. This wasn't supposed to happen. Maybe you'd have to use the rod here too? You extended the rod forward in that direction, with enough bad luck it slips through the pinprick hole on the sphincter. Having received something, the muscles snatch the rod off your hands, passing it into the colon. You're left without it. "Oh, come on!" More of Honchkrow is pressed, until you yourself experience it as well. The sphincter hits you, pressing you against the feathers behind you. You have wet flesh against one side of you, and soaked feathers on your other side. It's by far one of the most unpleasant sensations you have experienced.

It's a battle to see what will yield first: Honchkrow, or the sphincter. Luckily for you - or perhaps unluckily, later you'd ponder - there's a build-up of liquid following Honchkrow. The pressure of not only the crow's body, but also the day-old stomach contents Honchkrow kept blocked from going through, forced the sphincter to open violently, finally letting you and Honchkrow go inside, fast like a cork. You're thrown off Honchkrow, falling to the spongy floor while the bird twists around, trying to adjust his position.

You barely had time to shake your head when something enveloped you. It was like thick tar flowed over you, like treacle of a rather unpleasant acrid color, the former stomach contents pooling at the start of the colon, ready to start being processed. You can't move, and you're on borrowed time. This can't be how it ends for you! You were still trying to get out when something scooped you out, tossing you a safe distance away from the pooling sludge. Trying to get as much of the fluids off yourself, you see Honchkrow saved you.

The crow had managed to turn around, his head in the center of the colon. Nidoking was right, there really was a lot more space here. "Are you okay?" it asked, genuinely concerned. You nodded. Honchkrow wheezes: "It stinks it here!"

"What are you waiting for? Start crawling!" He didn't need to be told twice. Much to Honchkrow's chagrin, there was still a constant trickle of sludge leaking through the ileum, the sludge level raising more. After letting you get on his wing, he tries his best to worm his way through the colon, with you clinging to him. It was no wonder Honchkrow could get stuck, his usually fluffy feathers felt like they had absorbed a lot of stuff.

There was a lot of effort from Honchkrow, but he only managed to crawl for a short while before collapsing. "I can't-I can't keep moving! I'm exhausted!" he complained, slumping over. You sighed, resigned. The intestine would have to finish the job for you both, you guessed. And so it did, albeit at a glacial pace. "So...so now what?"

"Now we wait"

"Do you think it'll be for long? This place, it...it reeks! It's worse than the stomach!"

You weren't in mood for inane comments, especially not after having been in this exact place for quite a while already. "You know what this place does, don't you? Of course it's not going to smell like a bed of roses"

"W-w-wait, that's bad, right? We entered with something but that doesn't mean we'll get out with it, right?" You didn't answer, strangely numb to such thought. Waste leaving alongside you and Honchkrow would be one disgrace more in a list that was already long. Still, you hoped Honchkrow's crawling had outrun that sludge enough to give you time to get out.

"Let's just hope Nidoking lets us out first thing in the morning. Less likely his digestive system is done with his food if he does"

The conversation died, until it restarted when Honchkrow asked something you didn't expect:

"Was it...was it like this when I pushed you inside my butt?"

"Pretty much" you lied. It had been bad, but this was worse, you judged. Honchkrow's beak clicked, he seemed to be on the verge of crying.

"Oh, Arceus, I'm sorry, I'm so sorry. I had no idea it'd be this bad". You appreciated the apology, but you didn't acknowledge it. "...listen, when I offered to carry you there, I really didn't think of you as a toy"

"I know what I saw, Honchkrow"

"I know! I just...look, it made me remember something I did when I was just a Murkrow". Honchkrow then started explaining how that similar situation, retouched to make that Joltik sound much more willing than it actually was. You listened, not having any other option, and although it all had a lot more detail than you'd have liked, it was a bit of a relief. Honchkrow hadn't intentionally used you, it was an unfortunate coincidence. You patted Honchkrow, distant and aloof.

"I get it. Let's just forget that ever happened"

"I'm really sorry, if I can do anything to compensate you..." he wiggled, an idea coming to mind. "Wait, I could be your bodyguard while you stay in this manor!"

"...I doubt anyone will mess with me if they know I have Nidoking's favor". Besides, you didn't have much faith in Honchkrow being a good bodyguard. The crow didn't give up:

"Then I'll be your...your vehicle? Yes? Yes! If you ever need to fly anywhere I'll take you"

That was more appealing, you had to admit, with one condition: "I'm not letting you eat me in any manner. Think of a way to carry me that doesn't involve being inside you"

"I will, I'll think of something! But...does this mean we're friends again?" you looked up. Through the light from the helmet you saw Honchkrow's hopeful expression. There wasn't even an ounce of hard feeling, just an eagerness to please. Even though you were partly responsible for him being inside the inner pipings of a toxic lizard thing, he didn't seem to care about that as long as you forgave him.

It did tug at your heartstrings, you had to admit. You thought for a moment. The groans and sloshing of the crow and you being moved constantly filled the silence, until you answered:
114111121212112113222121211232311.title: Apologetic

choices: Honchkrow wriggles and squirms — and manages to force your way out!
Honchkrow is beat, but you feel gravity shift. Nidoking woke up!
Honchkrow succumbs to his weariness. This won’t be pleasant...
1141111212121121132221212112323111.content:
Clinging to the mired down of Honchkrow’s chest, you don’t really have a choice but to look the bird in the eye. Despite the sweltering heat of Nidoking’s internals, you feel a certain — different — warmth bloom around your heart. For once in who-knows-how-long-now, you feel… fine!
         “Alright beak-for-brains, we’re friends again,” the words hardly leave your mouth before Honchkrow attempts a half wriggle, half belly flop out of joy. With the confined space you share, it looks more like the bird did the worm.
         “Ca-caw!” Honchkrow crows, “This is the best day of my life!” You look around you. You take a sniff. It clearly isn’t yours.
         “...You’ve got to have better days then this one, Honchkrow.” You say. Your face turns wry as a suspicious-sounding bodily gurgle rolls past your ears.
         “Nope! Well— ah, maybe! The day I met you! It was like this, except um...uh...” a blast of foul-smelling air blows past you, disturbing your fleshy enclosure as the world rumbles with the sleeping lizard’s accompanying satisfied groan.
         “...Except everything.” You finish. Honchkrow silently shuffles forward. Hopefully he’s staying quiet out of agreement and you didn’t ruin your friend’s “best” moment. Although, Nidoking seems to be trying his damndest to ruin it too. Honchkrow is doing his best to crawl along, fast as he can. But the purple lizard’s guts, sensing a new heavier object in the colon, continually squeeze Honchkrow with a relentless and mindless ardor.

         Honchkrow shuffles forward through the never-ending tunnel, his feathers soaked with stink. By now, his beak began to clatter again. A bit ago he was chronicling a tale of how his tail feathers once caught in one of the manor’s doors, leaving him stuck for hours. Now, you have no clue what he’s talking about. You tuned out long ago. One word, however, rang loud and clear.
         “Aaaah!” Honchkrow cries as the wall close in on him again. Their cruel grip pushes the bird forward, his form sliding around a bend and getting smeared with intestinal juices. Another wave of peristalsis knocks the wind out of the Dark-type as he’s thrust forward once more.
         And then you’re upside down — the both of you.
         The colon walls lock your feathery vessel in place with a slimy, powerful grapple. Suspended in air, Honchkrow hangs above an abyss. Your weak light petters out long before it reaches the bottom. All it reveals is the glistening walls of Nidoking’s colon tightening and loosening, ebbing and flowing...
         You hang from Honchkrow’s neck, your fist full of the soppy strands of his down.
         “Honchkrow!” You shout, “are you okay?”
         “I’m fine!” Honchkrow croaks, reluctant to replenish the air he lost with the choking reek of Nidoking’s interior.
The body of the Poison-point Pokemon takes its sweet time to pass you two along. Meat and senseless tissue do not care to accommodate you — for they are used to passing refuse and, to Nidoking’s callous body, you are nothing different.
         Contractions press you further as if you’re toothpaste, plastering you with the unforgettable scent of Nidoking’s musk.
         How long can this go on..., you lament in your mind. The horrors Nidoking’s body has put you through, all while the king himself sleeps unaware of your current torture. He certainly knew it would be unpleasant, but you’re sure his mind could never of conjured the detestations his body has subjected you to. With uncanny timing, you hear dull scratching coming from beyond the pipings of the Pokemon. Nidoking is scratching his belly-plates in his sleep. It’s rather petty of you, but you hope Nidoking isn’t having nice dreams.
         “Owww...my head...” Honchkrow interrupts your thoughts, “all the blood is rushing to my head…” Honchkrow gags as he inadvertently tastes the air (if you could call it that), “I don’t feel so...good…”
         A pang of worry hits you in the chest. Are the toxins getting to Honchkrow? Or has he just been hanging upside-down for too long? A small bit of your fear is abated when your light reveals the long-awaited bottom of this hell-hole. You light up as you remember early on you had to scale a great vertical segment of the intestines. That means…
         ...You’re almost free!
         Eventually Nidoking’s colon deposits the blackbird down onto the intestinal floor. You never have seen a bird look so happy to be on the “ground.” Despite the twinkle in Honchkrow’s eyes, he still looks rather green between the gills.
         “I… think now’s a good time for naptime...” Honchkrow mumbles with a tuckered sigh.
         “Buddy,” you say with a firm, but caring, voice, “I need you to crawl just a bit further. We’re almost out!”
         “Just...five minutes…” Honchkrow begins to rest his head on his soaken, stinking feathers. An frightening sound bounces from the intestinal walls behind you: a squelching, yucky, mucky sound accompanied by gurgles and groans.
         “I don’t think we have five minutes, Honchkrow!” Your dire tone temporarily snaps the avian out of his dreamy stupor. “And even if we do, we’re not going to risk it!”
         “Risk what? What’s behind…” Honchkrow trails off. “Oh.” He says as he promptly begins to scuttle through the dark tunnel: the final stretch toward freedom.
         And in what feels like no time at all, your light reveals your way out of this horrid place. Barely illuminated, the tunnel of flesh tapers to a comparatively small point. A tight ring of muscle, much like the one blocking the path to the small intestine. It was your entrance, now your exit. The smallest pinprick of light shines from the outside, penetrating this place of filth and sorrow.
         A week ago, you’d be uncertain of what you’d say the happiest moment in your life was.
         You’re pretty certain you know what it is now.
         A tenacious flame flickers in Honchkrow’s eye as he summons the last of his energy to crawl forward. He doesn’t stop until he is an inch away from the disgusting bundle of flesh.
         He squawks with the last of his energy and all of his breath, “Nidoking!” All that replies is the gurgling of his internal symphony.
         You join Honchkrow in protest. “Nidoking!”
         No answer.
         No, no, no! You’re so close. You can’t go out with his…
         ...
         ...You can’t even bear the thought!
         “Honchkrow, get us out of here!”
         You look to Honchkrow and notice the bird is nearly about to collapse from exhaustion. But yet, the fire in his eye still burns — dimly…
1141111212121121132221212112323111.title: Partners in Slime

11411112121211211322212121123231112.content:
It was no secret Honchkrow was exhausted by the ordeal. Not only he had flown for a long time in a round daytrip, he didn't even have time to rest before he was shoved into the cruel, uncaring digestive system of their host. Since then he had been struggling almost nonstop in one way or another, and in the time he wasn't, he was being pressed from all fronts by powerful, unforgiving muscle.

You and he knew he deserved a lot, but that didn't mean he had to like or want worse. To you, he had long ago received more than enough punishment. To Honchkrow, he had learned his lesson back when Nidoking demanded answers. "Listen to me, if you don't get us out, we'll have a bad time in here" you press on, wishing you could do more to help. Why couldn't you be bigger?!

"I-I know, I'm trying my best!" almost feverishly, Honchkrow inches forward, until he's pressing his head against the gateway to your long-expected freedom. Over and over, he headbutts the unyielding muscle, trying to force his way out. It wasn't working at all. Every attempt tired him out more, until he collapsed in a heap. You couldn't believe it. Everything you both had done, it would fail at quite the crucial time... "I can't move anymore"

"How are you feeling? Is everything okay?"

"I'm fine, I just am...so tired and sleepy..." he says blearily. "It has been a long couple days, you know, buddy?"

"I know, I do, but this isn't the time to rest!" not when the gurgles behind you were getting closer. You pat Honchkrow. "One last attempt?"

"...you know, you're very small. I bet— I bet I could get you out! I just would have to open this enough and..." the bird coughs. Nidoking had said the crow would resist better all the poison and fumes, but you were pretty sure extending the stay for too long would take a toll on Honchkrow's system. Yet despite that, he was trying to get you out, even if it meant he'd have to stay inside for longer. You were grateful, but you didn't like the thought of abandoning Honchkrow inside for who knew how long.

"No"

"No? W-What do you mean by no?"

"I'm not leaving you here. We're getting out together" as if to punctuate your will, you kick the unrelenting sphincter. Touched by your solidarity, Honchkrow headbutts the flesh again, even pecking at it. That seemed to be somewhat more effective, if only because of how uncomfortable that must have been for the king. Everything shifts around you, the tissue contracts, it all feels like the world's going topsy-turvy when the entire environment moves. Behind you, the gurgling stops miraculously. You cling onto Honchkrow while the behemoth containing you wakes up. "Nidoking!" you shout. As expected, your voice doesn't reach him. Honchkrow's cawing is deafening to you, but maybe Nidoking could...?

—————

The first thing Nidoking noticed when he woke up was the strangely pleasant feeling of emptiness inside of him. The day before he had spent the entire day with a constant weight inside him, always sending pulses of discomfort. Several times he had feared the tiny rescuer would fail or even lose its life. The thought of something happening to the maybe-not-a-bug was harrowing. It had no fault in anything that happened! Now that all sensations were gone, he felt like a new Pokemon.

At least until he noticed the weight didn't go away, instead it relocated. The moment of surprise turned into subdued elation. It had worked! The bug was extremely capable, this was a feat! And then came the urgency of having to let them out. His body had its needs, and among them was not keeping inside the refuse. What would usually be routine was extraordinary now, as now instead of refuse it would be a very-much-alive Honchkrow. Thrilled for your success, Nidoking hurried to the bathroom, slamming the door open and settling against a wall. A cracked toilet nobody ever used, the large clean pile of sand and gravel that would usually receive his needs, and a chipped bathtub were the only objects left. Almost crawling, Nidoking settled on the pile of sand. First he decided to check on the passengers inside of his rear: "Is everything in order there?"

"Let us out!" he heard Honchkrow's voice.

"How's your friend?" even though Nidoking had great hearing, he couldn't catch anything you said. Part of him feared something happened to you.

"We're both okay, we just want out of here now!" An understandable request, he judged. Satisfied everything was okay, Nidoking started the laborious task of getting the crow and the bug out. He still couldn't believe this had happened, but a promise was a promise: he wouldn't harm a feather off that stupid bird's head, out of respect for the most-likely-not-a-bug.

—————

Inside, the contractions had gotten stronger. Honchkrow felt like he was once again in the middle of the small intestine, while you held onto the feathers and kept your stare at the obstacle in front of you. You feared the contractions woul push nearer whatever had been following you. Thankfully, instead of that, the anus started to open. Slowly at first, you see it widen. A circle of sand greets you. "We did it..." you say with a whisper, already feeling the cold air entering your location. Few times in your life you felt so free and looking forward to something. Honchkrow's eyes are shining, again with unshed tears, forgetting the almost bone-shattering pressure enveloping him. Slowly, he's pushed outside.

You see the rim of the tailhole go over Honchkrow's head, red and pale pink being replaced by the more vivid color if Nidoking's skin. Lucikily for you and your friend, your prolonged stay inside Nidoking covered you in a rather slick coating, letting you pass easier than it usually would be. There's still some trouble when Honchkrow's midsection gets stuck, he tries to propel himself forward and all he manages is get a wing out, making it flap around wildly and smacking Nidoking's tail a few times.

"Watch what you're doing. Stop moving before I make you"

"Nidoking, no" you say firmly. Nidoking growls but yields, resuming his efforts to get Honchkrow out. More and more of the bird's body slides out until the legs are left inside. By then Honchkrow can get himself out, he smoothly gets his talons out and rolls around, covering himself with sand and gasping for air.

"Freedom! At long last! I'm alive!" he yells, ecstatic. You are thrown off him, falling onto the sand heap, and you stare upwards at the king, who is turning around to face you. He looks rather embarrassed, you figure if he wasn't blind his eyes would be full of shame.

"That must have been a harrowing ordeal for you" he says.

"You have no idea. Let's not do it again". Nidoking eagerly agrees, and turns his head towards Honchkrow.

"You're lucky you have this human on your side" he says. You gulp. The gig was up, apparently. Your silence says more than Nidoking thought it would. "I wasn't certain, but I figure if it wasn't true you would have said something already. Now I see why you demanded that of me". He talking to you about the past, he meant. "A promise is a promise. See me when you're ready" with those parting words, Nidoking left the bathroom, stomping towards his bed. You and Honchkrow are left alone on the sand pile, to gather your strength.

You had earned a hard-fought victory. You toss the gas mask off your face and take off the helmet, taking deep breaths. To your side, Honchkrow didn't seem to be too bad. His feathers were covered in muck, sand, and slime you hoped he would manage to get off himself, but overall intact. Now he was staring upwards with relief. "Now what?" he wondered.

You sure knew what now. May as well get done with this now. It was true whoever went through your past situation didn't survive to tell the tale, but you hoped there could be something that could indicate how to return to normal.
11411112121211211322212121123231112.title: A Miracle

choices: You accidentally drop the camera while running
11411112121211211322212121123231113.content:
For a moment you thought this could end well. It had been a close call all this time, but you really thought right at the last moment there would be a miracle that'd save you.

Those hopes are dashed when Honchkrow collapses. "Honchkrow, no!" you plead. "We have to keep going!"

"Sorry, I'm sorry, I just am...so tired..." he said, right before falling asleep. He even dares to start snoring softly. You stare at him, powerless, until the ground underneath you shakes violently. Oh. Right, something was coming. You really needed to be on safer terrain.

—————

You certainly hoped it wouldn't come to this. You had climbed Honchkrow's prone body, settling on his back. It was a tad callous to use your newly-reconciled friend as a raft in what you were sure would be an unpleasant situation, but it was far better than being amidst the incoming matter. It all trickled inside the rectum slowly, like a extraordinarily slow avalanche. When it started, you just took a glimpse at the earthy bunch of solidified sludge, like a mass of many balls of mud, before you decided to turn off the lights. Some things are better not seen.

Honchkrow stays asleep, unaware of what was going on. You hoped he was having pleasant dreams, at least. The refuse lifts him off the surface of the rectum, the mountain of waste mercifully keeping Honchkrow up instead of enveloping him. You stayed on your friend's sleeping form, waiting with a patience that surprised even you. Maybe it was resignation, knowing there was nothing you could do right now.

Time passed. You tried to sleep, but the stronger stench, having increased by the feces all around you, kept you awake. Exasperated, you sit up again and turn on the light on your helmet to survey the situation. Everything you could see was halfway-full by a large field of waste, reaching from side to side of the living tunnel. There was no way Nidoking wouldn't feel any of this when he woke up. That was your only consolation, that when the king woke up, your stay would be cut short. "At least one of us can't see any of this" you say, Honchkrow still sleeping peacefully. You were about to turn off the light when something shone in the distance, a glint of metal, the light having bounced on the surface of whatever it was. It was some distance away, too far for you to get there by staying on Honchkrow. Even though you didn't like having to get off Honchkrow, you decided to get off and retrieve that object.

You never thought you would ever do something like willingly stepping on the compact remains of Nidoking's food, but you were now. It was surprisingly solid, a fact you were most thankful for. At least you wouldn't sink into it. You tentatively step forward, finding it easy to walk on, until you reach the object you had seen. It was surrounded by fish bones, it was possible Nidoking had eaten a fish that had previously eaten the object you were now trying to get. You grab it, trying to touch as little as possible the surrounding matter, and push it out with an audible squelch. "Oh, gross", you mutter, turning in your hands the object. It was a camera. Would it even work now? Curious, you managed to turn it on.

It worked. The camera turned on, the battery still worked. Wouldn't this mean it had been shrunken somewhat recently? The photo function was busted, so instead you checked the photos and videos on the memory card. The most recent one confirmed it was from a week ago. A video of a person, presumably a hiker, walking through a landscape similar to where you were before you were forced to hide in Noibat's cave. It wasn't the same, but it was similar enough you wondered if it was a coincidence. The video continued until the person holding the camera turned around, their attention caught by something. They immediately started running. All you see is a flash on the lens of the camera before it falls to the grass. The angle is awkward, but you see the hiker running away. The image, though, shows incredibly large blades of grass. The camera itself was shrunk. You were rather glad the person didn't undergo that same fate.

The video stayed on that position until everything shook, something was rather close to the camera. The camera is picked up by something you can't see— a Pokemon, definitely. You hear a voice. "It's so small!" Had that Pokemon caused the camera to shrink, or was it just a bystander who had approached? It sounded pleasantly surprised, but not like it was seeing something like this for the first time. The video cuts off, the Pokemon may have turned the camera off. You feel a sudden burst of joy.

This was invaluable! A lead onto your situation! Somehow your current disgrace had turned out to be a blessing in disguise. What were the odds this camera would still work, that it would be eaten by Nidoking, that it would survive the onslaught of strong acids and a trip through this digestive system, that it would reach you because you couldn't get out in time, that you could even see the camera in the first place among the large amounts of shit filling everything? If you and Honchkrow had managed to escape, it was possible you would have never found out this was here. Nidoking's memories would be of use to you, indeed, but now you also would have a more tangible lead. Maybe Honchkrow or Nidoking would know where the place in the video was, or maybe even what Pokemon's voice that was.

Your elation stopped when everything around you gurgled and contracted. For a moment you feared Nidoking was once again going to pass gas, but instead the place changed. Everything tilted, a groan resonated from far above you. The heartbeat that had always been present during your stay inside Nidoking intensified. The king had woken up.

—————

Like you had predicted, Nidoking immediately felt the heavy load inside him. The king yawned widely, standing up and trudging slowly into the bathroom like it was his routine. His mind didn't make the connection between the weight in his rectum and you and Honchkrow until he was almost on the sand pile. Any sleepiness vanished instantly. Nidoking touched his lower gut, hoping what he was feeling was the crow and nothing else, but no, focusing on the increasingly urgent sensations deep inside of him, it felt like there was more than just the bird. Nidoking's heart saddened.

"That poor human". Nidoking couldn't imagine how unpleasant the situation inside must be for you. He had to make up for this somehow. Knowing you'd like to be out as soon as possible, the king opened the faucet of the chipped bathtub, starting to fill the tub with some water. He had a feeling you and Honchkrow really would want a bath.

—————

The change was very noticeable for you. You fell on your back, splashing and leaving an indentation in the waste, you clutched the camera against you. No way you would lose it! Some distance away from you, the commotion seemed to have woken up someone else as well. Honchkrow moved weakly, raising his head with closed eyes. "Huh? Is it...is it time to fly already?"

"It's time to leave!" you said, struggling to stand up.

"We're leaving already? Wait, why does it smell like something died in here..." apparently Honchkrow was still in the middle of snapping out of his dreams. You shakily stood up, only to be thrown off your feet again when the walls contracted. A squawk from Honchkrow indicated he was fully awake now, having noticed what was going on. Any potential discussion was extinguished when, slowly, the tunnel filled with light. Ahead of Honchkrow, the anus had opened, illuminating the sickeningly red insides of the rectum and all the crap filling the place. Luckily for you, you were rather small, so the walls didn't compact you against the surface, you still could move somewhat. The waste train was now going to leave the station. You tried to run to Honchkrow.
11411112121211211322212121123231113.title: A Different Miracle

choices: You try to hitch a ride on Floatzel
114111121212112113222122.content:
While the thought of possibly having a fearsome Nidoking as an ally that'd keep you hidden from Honchkrow was nice, it didn't change the fact he resided in the same abandoned manor Honchkrow lived in. It could be matter of time before Honchkrow found out you were there, and then would he try to retrieve you? He did do some drastic stuff that involved carrying you in parts of his anatomy you didn't want to think about. There was a chance he'd try to do something drastic to take you.

Better to avoid taking risky chances and just get as far away as possible. You run towards the lobby, away from the rooms in the ground floor. Even if whatever was making noises in the lobby wasn't useful, the main door should be there. It'd be your way out! It takes you a few minutes to reach the lobby, and indeed, the main door was wide open, showing a stone path that leads into a forest. You could hear the sound of water rushing outside. A river! Better not to fall into the water, you weren't sure how well you'd be able to swim in a current.

The source of the noise was an explorer -- a Pokemon rooting through the wodden planks of the floor, trying to pry some of them up. Looking for a way down? You took a good look at the explorer. Orange fur, twin tails, a sac that resembled a flotation device...Floatzel? Wary but deciding taking a risk could pay off if it meant getting away from Honchkrow, you approach. The more you approached the more nervous you felt. You couldn't tell what this mustelid's personality is like. Would it be kind, or would it look at you as a toy like pretty much all Pokemon so far had thought of you? As much as you didn't want to admit it, the odds of you ending inside its stomach was higher than zero.

Holding your breath and trying not to show how nervous you were, you stepped closer, not bothering to mask your steps. Despite your size, the Floatzel heard you coming. Alarmed, it raised its head, turning around and curling into a ball in a defensive stance. That was a good sign, the less aggressive it was, the better. "Really?"

"Really what?"

"Are you what Honchkrow brought?" slowly, Floatzel uncurled and crawled towards you, until its snout was mere inches away from you. Gusts of wind pushed you back, even its breathing was enough to push you off-balance. "I thought he'd have found something cool, but it's just a small human?"

Part of you was offended at that. Since when was a human dozens of times smaller something to not even be intrigued about?! Floatzel snorted, looking around as if expecting something else more interesting to appear. "Usually he brings stuff from far away and hides it around. It's like hunting for treasure! But never before it was a human"

"Can I speak now?" you interrupted it, hoping to get a word in. Floatzel's eyes widened, and he shut up. "Listen, I need to get away from here. I don't want to be anywhere near Honchkrow"

"Really?" the orange mustelid sounded surprised. "I heard it's not so bad up there"

"That doesn't matter, I don't want to be here! Can you help me?"

Floatzel's tails swished from side to side, it was considering your request. "What do I get in exchange?" The question made you shudder involuntarily, it reminded you too much of that Noibat. You had answered this question incorrectly, one thing led to another, and you got eaten. You weren't going to repeat the same mistake this time!

You opened your mouth to admit you didn't have anything but were willing to listen to proposals or something when a scrapping noise echoed from the rooms not too far from you. Someone was coming! Floatzel turned its head at the direction of the sound, fur standing on end, and then got on all fours. "Good luck" it said to you before bolting towards the front door. Not having expected your potential savior to just leave you behind like that, you stood there for a moment, flabbergasted, and snapped out of it once the urgency of your situation struck you again.

"H-Hey, wait! Don't leave me here!" you shouted, running. Floatzel, having heard you, stopped in front of the steps that led to the front door, his head on level with the floor. Was it hesitating about leaving you behind? Heartened, you sped up as much as you could.
114111121212112113222122.title: You try to leave the manor

1141111212121121132221221.content:
The Floatzel had stopped, you were sure you'd reach it in no time...or so it seemed before you were tackled by a Pokemon. The impact forced the air out of you, the Pokemon and you rolled away from the entrance, behind a wall of the manor. In the entranceway, Floatzel looked back, trying to see you, but since you made no attempt to signal to her you were still around --- something partly to blame by you reeling from the force of the impact, it left the place.

You didn't even notice that happened. By the time you gained enough of a semblance of strength to realize your situation, Floatzel was far gone, and you were already deep into a new and disquieting situation. You were face-down on the dusty floor, flakes of dust bigger than yourself surrounded you. Even if you wanted to stand up and move, you couldn't, because a black, scaly paw was holding you down. You could see two of the digits near your head, and the weight of the paw over you. What was more, whatever was holding you down was currently smelling you, with remarkable enthusiasm, if the sounds were anything to judge by. You felt a snout pressing on you in intervals.

A strong, thick smell of smoke had invaded your nose. That must be the breath of the Pokemon holding you down, you realized. "Hey, please don't hurt me!" you plead. You'd feel calmer if you could at least see what kooky Pokemon is bothering you now! From behind you, a rather raspy voice mumbled:

"Hurt? No. I'm not hurting you. No worries"

That was a weight off your mind, if not off your back. After a couple minutes more of enthusiastic sniffing, the Pokemon backed down enough for you to turn around and take a good look. It wasn't hard to identify it as a Salandit. Its purple eyes were focused on you with a mirth you found a tad disturbing, and its tail was slowly wagging back and forth. It was pleased, for some reason. "How nice...well, I think I should get going"

"Wait! Not yet. Please."

"I really have to go"

"I heard what you were talking. You know, with that orange Pokemon. I'll help"

"...seriously?"

"Can't get you away from here. But I'll keep you safe. Promise" its pupils widened a little in what you interpreted as sincerity. You were going to say no, but before you could even say a word, the Salandit had grabbed you in his paw, and this time it was running back upstairs, babbling all the time while it climbed up to the beams holding the rooftop.

"No worries. You'll be okay. I promised" it stopped for a moment to nudge you with its snout. "Salandit, nice to meet you"

"Lik-Likewise?"

--------------

The next hour went by in a flash. Salandit had introduced itself once you were set on the thick wooden beam. It had said it was male and had arrived to the manor since not that long ago, and that he was just getting settling in. You had barely stepped away from him when he dragged you closer, surrounding you with surprising care, and patting you on the back of your neck with its large paw. Everything was rather overwhelming, and the fact the Salandit was so much bigger than you didn't help. At least he was very friendly and willing to help. If you didn't know better, from the way he was leaning against you, and the way he was looking at you with a joy you don't remember in anyone looking at you before, you'd think he had a crush on you!

His tail curled around you in an affectionate embrace.

The Salandit liked you. Somehow, you had gained the affection of a male lizard much, much bigger than you. Your life was turning out to be a mess.

His conversation was easy to follow, even if it was peppered with short sentences. Salandit narrated to you how he had ran away from his group for reasons he didn't want to talk about, and that this manor was like a haven for Pokemon who need shelter. He promised once again with him you'd be safe, and that he'd do everything he could to keep you happy. You couldn't detect any kind of ill-natured intentions on him, even if you certainly didn't reciprocate his feelings, you at least could be certain he was truly invested in your safety.

By now he was happily lounging around in silence while you leaned on his tail, staring at the beams of daylight that were starting to creep from slits on the roof. While this wasn't going at all like you thought it would, it wasn't really too bad. A companion who cared about you would be nice, and you made sure to tell Salandit that.

"Thanks. Told you you'd like being here" he replied with a smile that looked a tad creepy for you. A Salandit's face wasn't really made for expressions that weren't sly, apparently. You were about to reply when a flap of wings announced the arrival of someone you knew, a couple beams away. Honchkrow.

The crow was looking downwards, trying to find you with his excellent eyesight. While you were looking, it hopped around. You felt your blood run cold, that bird was certainly someone you'd rather not to deal with every again. Over you, the Salandit had placed his head over you protectively, staring intently at the Honchkrow.

You knew it was matter of time before Honchkrow looked in the Salandit's direction and saw you, and you really didn't want that to happen. You had to get out of sight right now, but how to do that? Where could you hide that Honchkrow wouldn't be able to ever see you?
1141111212121121132221221.title: You're tackled by a Salandit!

choices: Salandit swallowed. Let’s hope he brings you back up soon…
Salandit high-tailed it out of there! Does Honchkrow give chase?
Honchkrow opened his beak and plead, “Wait!”
11411112121211211322212211.content:
You looked every which way for a hiding place, careful to not make any unnecessary movement that could have alerted the crow. One wayward glance, and he would have seen you. The gig would have been up.
         There were surprisingly few places to hide in the rafters of a half-decayed manor. Behind a beam, maybe. However, you were too far away and your short, little legs would have made it an odyssey to get there without being detected.
You have to hide somewhere close by. But there was nothing. Nowhere to hide!
         …
         ...Except Salandit?
         ...
         ...No, that’s a horrible plan! You’ve endured the front of one Pokemon and the backend of another and you’re not going to—
         ...
         Fine! In your head, you shout so loudly you were surprised your ears didn’t ring. There wasn’t another place to hide. You were going to be found eventually unless you were hidden. Although Salandit was doing a decent job shielding you with his hands, he was also doing a great job looking suspicious as heck. Even Honchkrow would have noticed something amiss with the reptile’s behavior.
         You catch Salandit’s attention with a hushed siblant whisper, “Hey! Can you hear me?” Salandit’s razor-thin pupil shifted toward you. You continued, “this isn’t the best plan. It’s barely a plan at all—but I’ve got a plan.” You took a moment to gather your thoughts. The lizard waited patiently. How were you even going to propose this?
         “Hey, uh, I need to hide in your mouth.” Salandit shot you a strange look.
         “Do you want to die? Not safe. Not at all.”
         “This isn’t safe! I’m going to be seen. It’s really obvious that you’re hiding something—no offense…”
         Salandit meekly looked to the side, then back at you, “sorry…," he said, "don’t want to upset you!” You’re about counsel him before the ruffle, shuffle of fluttering feathers interrupted—along with a familiar voice.
         “A-ha! I found you!” Honchkrow exclaimed as the bird flittered down towards you. You didn’t even have time your mouth before Salandit opened his. His flame-orange tongue barreled into you as the muscle crashed into your location between the lizard’s hands. Stuck in its sticky grip, you didn’t resist as Salandit reeled you into the confines of maw.
         As you laid in a saliva-drenched cavern, darker than night, the air faintly smelling like burnt wood—you can only imagine the bewildered look on Honchkrow’s face as the bird squawked madness.
         “You ate them!” the Pokemon shrieked. Salandit stayed silent. But from the quivering on his tongue, you felt like he had something to say.
         “S-spit them out!” he demanded. “Open you mouth!”
         You slipped across his tongue as your “devourer” shook his head to-and-fro.
         “I’m warning you! I’ll...make you!” Honchkrow didn’t sound entirely confident but when a great force flung everything, you and Salandit both, backward—you knew Honchkrow meant business! You were catapulted into Salandit’s palette and were held there by gravity: Salandit must be belly up. Gravity righted itself as Salandit’s head faced his aggressor. You were still fastened to the top of the Pokemon’s mouth but you did began to slowly drip down along with a globule of spit.
         Tongue free, Salandit spoke. “You’re bad! Go away! Or I’ll swallow!” This wasn’t going well….
         “You wouldn’t!” Honchkrow squeaked.
         “Would!”
         “Then I’ll... I'll make you throw them up!”
         “Not if I run!”
         “I-I’ll catch you!”
         At this point your weight caused your liquid-y bindings to snap and sent you plopping down onto Salandit’s tongue. At once, his end of the bickering stopped. The fang-lined opening of Salandit’s carnivorous cavern shut fast. Your old friend Darkness came to greet you again.
         A dreadfully long moment came and passed. Breathing Salandit’s smoke-tinged breath was starting to make you dizzy. You wished that your new lizard friend would make up his mind so you could know if it was time to resign yourself to another Pokemon’s belly….
11411112121211211322212211.title: Squabble Gobble

choices: Honchkrow steps off Salandit. Some relief!
114111121212112113222122111.content:
Honchkrow was serious. Having fallen on Salandit's tongue, you waited, listening and hoping Honchkrow would yield and just leave you alone. Unlikely, but hope is the last thing that dies! And you also didn't want to fall into another Pokemon's stomach. Once in Noibat was plenty bad, repeating the experience was a bad thought.

All of your hopes were dashed rather quickly when Honchkrow stepped forward. He was trembling slightly, but he felt he had to do something, all for the sake of the human! He still had yet to apologize and make sure the human didn't hate him. Salandit, being completely on your side, just knew he had to keep you away from the corvid. Which was why, although he hesitated a lot, decided to just make the inevitable happen. He planned to run away as far as he could, and in his opinion the movements would make you fall down his throat.

If you were doomed to be swallowed then it'd be on his terms.

You gasped when the muscle underneath you shifted. "W-Wait!" you pleaded. It all went too quickly for you to react. Everything inside the mouth tilted, and soon you found yourself enveloped in Salandit's throat. Given his position, you were forced down a bend, until you were grasped by the esophagus, inexorably being pulled down into the depths of your new friend. The smell of burning wood and of smoke intensified the deeper you went, like you were being dragged into a forest fire, until it was the only thing you smelled.

Outside, Honchkrow squaked with panic when he heard Salandit swallow. "No! You can't do that!"

"Already done!"

"Spit them, now! If something happens to them I dunno what I will do..." he begged. Salandit blinked, feeling a bit of pity for the crow, but what you wanted was priority -- leaving aside that you didn't want to be swallowed in the first place. Compromising on that issue was necessary. Still, if you wanted to be away from Honchkrow, then he had to run away. While Honchkrow restlessly paced around, Salandit quickly turned around and started running as fast as possible on the ceiling beams.

Inside, you were done descending down Salandit's gullet. You were starting to get used to the smoke smell, until you fell into a larger chamber. You had finally arrived into Salandit's stomach. While you fell you anticipated the splash against juices, like it happened inside Noibat, but instead you fell onto spongy floor, bouncing once and splashing onto a very thin layer of slime. Looking around you, you sigh, relieved. The stomach was mostly empty. All around you there was nothing but empty space and wrinkled walls. You guessed anything Salandit had eaten had already gone ahead down the intestines, mercifully leaving the stomach empty for you. Lucky you!

As soon as Salandit got his feet on the ground he started running forward, as fast as he could. Behind him, Honchkrow flew through the air, pursuing with speed. Not too far from there there was a crack in the wall. If he could get in there, he'd escape from Honchkrow! A safe place! Just a couple meters more! Right before Salandit could get into the wall, a talon gripped him, stopping him on his tracks. Honchkrow had caught up.

"Spit them up, quick!"

"No!"

Honchkrow pressed down with the talon, pressing on Salandit's back. The lizard gurgled, feeling the pressure. It was a tad hard to breathe, but he refused to let the human go if it meant being captured by the crow. Salandit really feared for your safety! "If you don't, then I will...I will get them out myself!"

"You don't even know how to do that!"

"I will...I will get my beak in your throat and pluck them out!" he bluffed. That was impossible, but he hoped Salandit wouldn't realize that. Unfortunately for him, Salandit did realize and refused to budge. Maybe pressing a bit more would make you pop out Salandit's mouth? Honchkrow pressed again.

Inside, you were feeling the pressure too. Lying down against the hard floor of the beam and with Honchkrow pressing on Salandit, the ceiling of the stomach descended until it reached you. The stomach compressed further, enveloping you in an uncomfortable embrace. It was like everything was trying to squeeze you, you found it hard to focus. What was happening outside? You placed your hands on the floor of the stomach and tried to get some space, but it wasn't working, Honchkrow was just too heavy for you to do anything. Giving up, you collapsed, only hearing Salandit's labored breathing and Honchkrow's threats. You were confident Honchkrow lacked the malice to really harm anyone on purpose.

The dense air tinged with smoke, the pressure on you, and the rather oppressive heat made you feel woozy. At least I'm not getting digested... you thought groggily
114111121212112113222122111.title: Pressure

choices: Salandit was talking to what sounded like another Pokemon. Hopefully friendly?
Gagging noises. Seems things were looking up, Chuck….
Everything seemed darker? Tighter? You were not in the stomach anymore….
1141111212121121132221221112.content:
Just as your vision was beginning to blur and your consciousness was slipping to sleep, Honchkrow let up. The formerly-unrelenting pressure vanished instantly. Both you and Salandit wasted no time to gather your breath. With you in his stomach, situated between his great lungs, his breaths sounded like a squall. Meanwhile, the smokey air tickled your throat coaxing you to cough briefly.
          On the outside, Honchkrow outstretched his wings trying to make himself look as big as he can be. “See!” He said, standing strategically between Salandit and the oh-so-close crack in the wall. “I mean business! Big business! Let them go, let them go, let them go!” On the wooden beam, Honchkrow had resorted to hopping in a fit.
          “No!” Salandit sputtered, still trying to regain his breath. But as he was about to add some poison to his words, he noticed the glint of moonlight creeping from the decayed skeleton of a window. Another escape…
          Granted, it was a bit away. He’d have to hop three beams to get there. The alternative, however, was to stay here. And that was no good.
          “Look there.” Salandit said pointing his snout to a random dark corner.
          “I’m not that stupid!” Honchkrow said. “That trick is older than Relicanth!”
          “Uh,” Salandit stammered. “Shiny jewels there?”
          Honchkrow sighed, a little hurt over the assumptions of his intelligence. He craned his neck down until he was beak-to-face with Salandit. “My eyes are on you! Can’t take them off! Not for nothing!”
          Salandit stared for a moment.
          He promptly knocked off Honchkrow’s feathery hat.
          “N-no! No!” Honchkrow fumbled as he hat fluttered to the floor. The bird practically fell head over talons as he struggled to retrieve his fallen hat. Salandit took this to escape. He scrambled across the beam and rocked his body as he judged the distance he had to leap. He jumped and landed with a perfect 10.
Though your experience differed a bit. You too were flung through the air. Except you careened through the air, clearing a path through the smoke, and splattered onto the lizard’s stomach’s wall. As you slid down the slippery, slimy wall of the belly, you hoped that was a one-time thing.
         Unfortunately, your hopeful expectations were dashed as you were flung into the air twice more, bouncing about belly walls like a flea performing in a flea circus. Things quieted down briefly as Salandit was perched on the ledge of his escape, peering down to see how far he would have to fall.
         He looked back to see Honchkrow finishing brushing off his hat, his beak going wide in shock as witnessed what Salandit was about to do.
         “Farewell, featherbrain! Thhhhpppt!” Salandit stuck his tongue out mockingly and blew a raspberry. He then jumped aiming for a (hopefully soft!) bush adjacent to the mansion. As he sailed through the air, he could hear the indignant words of the bird behind him.
         “I am not a featherbrain!”
         To you, everything was in zero-G. For the brief moment you two were airborne, you closed your eyes and awaited the inevitable landing.
         Salandit plompf’d into the bed of the bush. You plopped onto the bottom of his belly and bounced a few times more. When things were still, you let an exasperated breath. No more, you say!
         “Sorry!” The lizard apologizes. “Must run now!” Salandit sprinted off as fast as his legs could carry him. In his speed, centrifugal force drew you to the back of his belly but, thankfully, you were not pinned to it. Salandit didn’t say anything in his frantic scurry. The only sounds he made were of his beating heart, labored breaths, and the ever-constant plip-plap of his footsteps.
By now you were starting to get used to the strange, smokey air of the Salandit’s body. Harmless embers flitted about, lighting the bellyspace like fireflies. It was dim, yes, but the atmosphere is almost tranquil. It was an evening fog, the last of the sun’s light filtered through murky smoke. The burnt-wood-smell bestowed a rustic touch. Closing your eyes, you easily imagined a burning wood stove awaiting you in homely--with a promise of a home-cooked meal. And the heat! Once nearly unbearable, now relaxing: sauna-like. The sounds of Salandit’s body morphed to those of the forest as you were swept up in your fantasy.
         It was so nice, you just felt… a little… sleepy….
         …
         …
         When you awoke again, something had changed. But what was it?
1141111212121121132221221112.title: Belly Run

choices: Salandit manages to throw you up
11411112121211211322212211121.content:
You heard voices. One was a much muted voice you didn't recognize yet, the other the Salandit in whose stomach you were in right now. You shook your head, holding onto the walls of the stomach to get your bearings. The stomach seemed to have less smoke than before, possibly having been exhaled at some point. Thankfully for you, there was still nothing else in the stomach, so you had it all for yourself. "What happened?" you ask, deciding to make sure Salandit knows you're awake.

The effect was immediate. The stomach tilts ninety-degrees, Salandit must have gotten on his hind legs. "There they are. They're awake"

"Who are you talking to?" was it someone in the manor? No, that couldn't be it. Salandit had been running, by now he had to place some distance between the manor and wherever he was now. You were rather relieved, you had to admit.

"Friend. I dunno what to do to help you," Salandit admitted. He liked you, but you were a bit more of responsibility than he was used to. He didn't feel like he could handle you alone.

"Is it someone I can trust?"

"Of course," he sounded very sure about it. You relaxed, leaning against the stomach walls and listenin more. "Human inside me. Ate them to keep them safe,"

"Again, are you sure you did that to keep them safe? You know what happens in stomachs"

"Human not food!"

"Okay, I understand. I won't say that again." you heard the other Pokemon say. You frown, focusing. For some reason the voice sounded familiar, but you were having a hard time remembering who it was. High-pitched, teasing...for some reason the more you listened to that voice, the more nervous you felt. You insisted, asking Salandit who he was talking with.

"Noibat. Best friend"

You felt like you were about to faint again. No, that couldn't be possible! It couldn't be that, after everything you had gone through, you had returned right to the first Pokemon you had met since you shrunk, and not only that, it was the one Pokemon you would have liked not to see again. Even Honchkrow had shown some friendliness towards you, the Noibat was only bad news for you. "Can we leave? Please?" you hope the answer will be yes.

"Let me show you to Noibat?" at least Salandit was asking.

"Don't ever do that!"

"Why do you need the human's permission? Come on, I want to see!"

"You won't hurt them." That wasn't a question, that was a demand.

"Of course not. Why'd I do that?"

"Salandit, please, don't show me!"

Your protector didn't even reply. With a sudden lurch, the stomach contracted, pushing you closer to the sphincter that led to the esophagus. You yelped, not having expected such a strong movement. This was as good as a reply, though: Salandit trusted Noibat and was willing to show you to them. Maybe it wasn't going to be so bad, who said it had to be the same Noibat that had eaten you before? There had to be million of Noibats all over the world. This had to be a different one.

On the other hand, a Noibat had eaten you, and you had almost died. It was an experience you weren't willing to forgive. Maybe you shouldn't take your chances.

Clinging to the slippery walls with all your strength, you manage to crawl in the opposite direction. Noises like retching filled the chamber, proving Salandit was serious about getting you out of his stomach. With strength that surprised even yourself, you managed to cling onto the stomach walls despite Salandit's best efforts. He was straining so much to squeeze his stomach, trying so hard to get you out, he had to take a moment to rest.

You decide to use that moment to your advantage. If you could do something to make sure you wouldn't be shown to the Noibat...

"What's taking you so long?" the other voice said. Feeling the disguised malice in its voice, you looked around, hoping for anything that could be of help. Not too far from you there's the way into the intestines. Salandit's efforts seem to have loosened it, it's halfway open. In a flash of inspiration that surprised even yourself, you dash towards it, pretty much diving into the open sphincter.

You land right after it, in a tunnel that's far more cramped than the stomach. You make sure not to advance much, though. Your idea was to stay far from the stomach's reach. As long as you were in Salandit's intestines, he wouldn't be able to throw you up. Just in case you stayed near the sphincter you had dived through.

The plan was that you were going to stay there until Salandit gave up, or at least until you could explain you didn't feel comfortable at all getting shown to the Noibat. Anything that could give you some time would be good! Or at least you hoped you were safe...

It depended on how stubborn Salandit was about showing you to Noibat.
11411112121211211322212211121.title: Not Someone You Want to See

choices: You manage to cling onto the tongue
1141111212121121132221222.content:
You were very relieved Floatzel stopped to wait for you. To you the time it took to reach the front door was like an eternity, and to Floatzel it was even more. It kept looking around, expecting a flock of Murkrows to come and attack, or for there to be an ambush. Why did this small human have to be so slow?! Seeing how antsy Floatzel was starting to be, you ran faster, doing a leap of faith when you reach the end of the topmost stair, closing your eyes and extending your arms forward. You expected to crash into Floatzel's fur, you were ready to hold onto it as hard as you could while your newfound helper ran away.

"What are you waiti-?!" you hear Floatzel start yelling and suddenly shut up.

Strange sensations you didn't expect happen when you land. Instead of coarse and short fur enveloping you, you crash against something slimy and wet. When you open your eyes you only see red, not because you're upset, but because the surface you landed on it is of an intense red and pink color. Looking up through the dim illumination around you, you see ridges above you, and white spires surrounding you. It doesn't take you long to realize what exactly happened: you landed in Floatzel's mouth. This was something you didn't need right now!

Floatzel snapped shut its maw out of surprise and, still fearing an attack from any of the residents of the abandoned manor, started running towards the river. It went there to search for treasure and got out with a tiny human in its mouth. This wasn't what it had expected, but it couldn't complain that much. The only thing it could complain about was the taste of that human. It was horrible! "You taste awful! Where have you been?!"

"I don't want to talk about that!" you shout, feeling guilty, holding onto the tongue. Floatzel's talking jostled you around, the sound of its voice was deafening. In moments like these you seriously reconsidered your choices. Why did your life have to be like this now?

Luckily for you, Floatzel wasn't going to spit you out just like that, even if having you in its mouth was a rather unpleasant experience. Like it or not, it had to carry the human away. "I'm going into the river!" it said, confident in its swimming skills. Inside, you were in no condition to ask him not to. It wasn't like you had any better suggestions. Having some trouble holding onto the tongue because of how slippery it was. To try to get a better grasp, you crawl upwards, a bit towards the throat. It was a risky move, but in your mind the plan was clear: stay away from the teeth, stay away from the throat. If you managed to stay in the center then you'd be okay!

With a splash, Floatzel dives into the river, you can hear the water rushing around you. You can't see well, but you're sure some water leaked through the lips and teeth. "You know how to swim, right?" it asked you, surfacing for a second. More water splashed into the mouth when he talked.

"Kinda, I just don't know if I can swim in a river because I'm small" you explain, a bit uneasy at the water trickling around you. Behind you, you can hear it trickling down Floatzel's throat.

Floatzel swam, taking another chance to resurface when it judged it was safe to. "Then you can't stay around here. I'll leave you on a dry place" it says. Being used to not worrying about the level of water, a wave gets into its mouth.

To the mustelid it was nothing. To you it was a tsunami of water. The water hits you with force, you feel your fingers slipping from the tongue. Panic grips you while you realize the danger you're suddenly into. Frantic, you try to cling back onto the tongue.
1141111212121121132221222.title: You try to hitch a ride on Floatzel

choices: Never give up! There must be a way to get you out!
Floatzel thinks you’re a goner. You’re on your own...
11411112121211211322212221.content:
A single imperative thought screams through your mind: don’t let go!
         Holding on to Floatzel’s slippery tongue is chief of your concerns. You really don’t want to think about what happens if you let go of the bumpy, slimy muscle. This is hard. In Floatzel’s stress and focus its tongue is taut, slippery, and slimy as a mossy river rock.
         Moments before now, no light passed through the mustelid’s lips. No water either — besides the spittle that called this dank, fishy-smelling cave a home.
         That was, until, the pearly white gates opened.
         Light and water stormed in. By going flat as you could, you braced yourself — body pressing into the alien surface of the tongue.
         And yet, it had not been enough.
         Back in the present, the encroaching wall of water barrels into you, peeling your fingers from their ever-tight grip, and flushes you away with its forceful current.
         Tumbling back feet-over-head in a reverse somersault, you slide across the slick muscle, pocked with pipiliae. With no time to spare, you barely manage to halt your descent by hugging the back of Floatzel’s tongue. A torrent of water washes over and past you plummeting into the abyss below.
         Abruptly, a horrid gagging sound. The pillar of muscle kicks back like a wild horse. You’re lifted higher and further back than you’d ever wish to be. River water violently returns from the depths of Floatzel’s throat.
         It’s coughing up water!? You remember: Floatzel is a mammal. It can’t breathe water!
         Meanwhile, Floatzel’s tongue hefts you to the fleshed ceiling. Water surrounds you in a suffocating shroud, held there by Floatzel in a concentrated, teeth-clenching effort to not gag and spit out the weasel-creature’s tiny passenger.
         Your situation is red; you’re trapped betwixt a rock and a hard place: being crushed against the Pokemon’s hard palate — or tumbling into the dark abyss of their gullet.
         Floatzel then tries a different approach: swallow the water, not the little one.
         Everything tilts up. Water flows downward, trying to drag you with it. Despite both your and Floatzel’s best efforts, it succeeds. Slipping from the mustelid’s slick tongue, you are pulled into the athirsting throat. It snatches and swallows you as it would to any other food.
         On the outside, Floatzel feels the little mote on its tongue slip away. Momentarily, its eyes go wide in surprise. Then its face quickly shifts into one of vexed half-moon eyes and a exasperated frown. Soberly, Floatzel thinks:
         That's how I lose them?

         Walls of hungry flesh drag you deeper into dark depths of Floatzel. Wet muscle shoves your sodden form deeper. Water surrounds you. Air is nowhere to be found. You can only hope that there is something breathable deeper within.
         Just as your lungs begin to ache, you hear the bubbling flush of water released as esophagus opens and ejects you into the eager stomach. A sweltering heat and a pungent fishy aroma hits as if you slammed face-first into fish-market stall in the middle of sultry July.
         Then you fall — into the foul gruel that lay fermenting in Floatzel’s gut. You cannot see in the darkness. However, your intimate contact with the otter’s belly-brew imparts vile sensations your eyes could never infer.
         Rising to the top like a cork dropped water, you struggle to stay afloat through Floatzel’s bouncing swimming-motions. Your efforts are successful because, regrettably, this isn’t your first rodeo.
         Floatzel! You shout over the slopping of an ever-shifting stomach, can you hear me?
         Under the river surface, Floatzel halts its movement, closes its eyes, and listens closely. Its ears perk as a curious sound tickles its ears…
         ...It’s Floatzel’s stomach growling.
         Palkia’s pearls, Floatzel thinks, that little buddy got themselves in a fine mess.
         Floatzel is not particularly hard-hearted, but does it believe it’s even possible to save you?
11411112121211211322212221.title: Wash Down the Wittle One

choices: You're swept into the intestines alongside the Light Ball
114111121212112113222122211.content:
You had to wonder what you did to deserve everything that was happening to you. Had you insulted a cosmic entity? Did you bring upon yourself something’s wrath? Was the universe simply into messing with you? There had to be some sort of explanation as to why you were once again inside a Pokemon, and by no fault of your own, may you add. While you moved with a lot of difficulty through the contents of Floatzel’s stomach, you kept thinking about that, but even thinking was difficult when the mixture around you was so difficult to move through.

You had just reached the wall when it curves towards you, it smacks you right on the face. Instinctively, you grab onto it, letting yourself be pulled against it. “Are you there?” you hear Floatzel’s voice ask. You shout as loudly as you can:

“I’m okay, but I don’t think I’ll be okay for long if you don’t get me out soon!” you shout, lying a little. Although you were presently covered by Floatzel’s gastric acids and countless bits of fish, you felt more like you needed a bath, not like you were burning and melting. You sure weren’t going to complain about that.

“Hang in there! I will get you out” it promises. “Just wait until I get home. It’ll be easier for me to help you once I’m there!”

“I’m not too sure about that”. What exactly could Floatzel do over there that it couldn’t do right where it was now?

Floatzel prods its belly again, as if it was annoyed you doubted it. “Trust me on this one, I know what I’m doing!” and as if there was no ground for discussion, it started swimming as fast as possible. You held against the wall of the stomach for dear life.

What followed were some particularly anxiety-filled minutes.
