Not only the walls of the stomach were much more slippery than the tongue you had been grabbing not that long ago, you also kept hearing the sloshing of the stomach contents a few inches beneath you, and the fishy smell was starting to get you dizzy. How was it possible the fish smell filled the air so much?!

To Floatzel’s credit, it really didn’t take long for it to stop. The otter crawled out of the water and into a burrow, shaking the water off and rooting through a chest of trinkets. It liked to collect stuff, the more uncommon the better. There had to be something it could use to get that tiny thing out of his belly! And in one piece, hopefully. While it was searching, it came across a round, small sphere, of yellow color. A Light Ball! Testing it, he enveloped it with his paws and peeked through them. The ball was shining rather brightly, so much he could see every detail of the fur covering his paws. “Are you still okay?”

“I am. This stopped moving so much” you said, relieved.

“I have an idea. While I work, here, I have this for you” it said before putting the Light Ball into its mouth and, with some hesitation, swallowed it. The ball went down its throat rather quickly, so in no time you saw light enter Floatzel’s stomach. You couldn’t see the source, but it entered and crashed into the fish soup, sinking to the bottom.

“What’s that?”

“It’s something I found once. I thought you’d like to have some light in there instead of just darkness”

It was a rather considerate thought, but it didn’t exactly make you feel better. The stomach was now filled with light, allowing you to see every inch of the place. You never thought you’d see so much detail of a Pokemon’s stomach, yet now you could see everything. The contracting walls, the slime rolling off everything, the rather large and expansive stomach that reminded you just how small you were. Almost touching your ankles was the contents of the stomach, a beige liquid that looked like quicksand and undoubtedly had that consistency too.

Some things were better unseen, you figured. “Thanks” you said quietly, not very grateful about it. Luckily for you, Floatzel didn’t notice, focused on its idea. “Although now that thing is stuck inside you as well”

“I’m sure I’ll get it back one way or another. What’s important is getting you out”. At least it had its heart in the right place. Several minutes more passed before you heard the sounds of gulping above you. “What are you doing?” you asked. There was no response except more gulping. The answer to your question was obvious when, from the entrance sphincter on the other side of the stomach, a string appeared. “Grab it!” you heard Floatzel’s voice.

“That string?”

“I’m gonna pull and get you out. Get ready!”

It was a good idea! Better than being trapped inside Floatzel for a long time, at least. Intending to swim to the string, you let go of the wall and fell into the syrupy mixture in Floatzel’s gut.

As if that was what its system had been waiting all along, the whole stomach shook. Floatzel bent over, a pang of discomfort coursing through it. Inside, you saw everything contract violently, and then beneath you there was a rather gross gurgling sound, like someone had removed the plug of a bathtub and was emptying the contents now. “No, not again!” you said, trying to swim faster, against the current that was threatening to take you. If you could reach the string before it was too late...!

The light in the stomach dimmed, caught in the current that was leaking into Floatzel’s intestines, and floated inside. Great, you thought bitterly. Now if you failed to reach the string, not only you would be into another creature’s intestines, you also would have enough light to see every inch of the rest of Floatzel’s inner tubes. Making one last desperate push, you extended your arms, the string touching the tip of your fingers.
114111121212112113222122211.title: Never give up! There must be a way to get you out!

choices: ...a weird glade with big, but normally small, Pokémon. Maybe an answer's there!
...a cave at the peak of a nearby mountain. The Xatu there knows everything....
...ruins in a swamp right around here. Lots of weird stuff — maybe it can help!
1141111212121121132221222112.content:
No sooner did your hands brush against the rough twine of the string did you grab ahold. Your grip so tight your knuckles turn white and your nails dig into fibers of the string. Your momentum causes you to swing, stirring the broth of the weasel’s belly like goop in a cauldron. Yet, you hold on — as if your life depended on it.
         ...Technically it didn’t, really. You survived this before. But you’re not going through it again. Not if you can help it!
         On the outside, Floatzel feels the tug of your weight. Immediately it begins the process of reeling you up and out and back into the daylight. It feels a tickle in its throat as the string sidles on upward.
         Inside, you’re being pulled in two different directions. Like siblings fighting over a toy, Floatzel tries to pull you up as the whirlpool in its body drags you down. Floatzel triumphs over its own body as you’re lifted from the watery clutches of its gut. Soaring through sultry skies, you’re tugged towards the exit, former entrance. You slam into the esophageal sphincter. The collision isn’t gentle but as you’re not down there you don’t care.
         After a brief moment of resistance, you breach through. Darkness returns. Throat muscles grab you like clenched fist and haul you skyward. Gravity shifts. You’re sideways. Floatzel is on the ground, hunched over — gagging. Its esophagus presses against your ears with each heave. The squelching of moist muscle, Floatzels’ awful retching, the faint burbling of its belly below — all perfectly interlocked in a horrid organic rhythm.
         At last, you spy the glow of light peeking behind the hump of its tongue. Daylight rushes to greet you and you’re momentarily blinded. You’re out of the throat — upside-down now. You spill over its tongue and fall past its cage of glistening teeth. Now in freefall, a trail of drool tailing you, you’re caught in a soft paw before you can hit the ground.
         “Eyuch,” the Pokémon clears a phlegm-full throat. “You’re still kickin’, right buddy?”
         You lift your arm out of the weasel’s sticky slobber and manage to give a thumbs up.
         It gives a weary chuckle. “Ghost-type’s haven’t got you yet…” It turns around and stretches out a paw toward a menagerie of items nearby. It pulls out a Silk Scarf. It cleans you with delicacy and a dexterity you did not expect.
         “You look a lot more Normal!” It says with a toothy grin.
         “Not sure if I really feel it...,” you sit up and look Floatzel in its kelp-green eyes. “Thank you.” You end your words with an exasperated sigh. As you breathe in, you find the rich earthy scent hits you with a curious nostalgia. Maybe the burrow is so home-y that it reminds you of your home….
         The Water-type sports a kooky grin.
         “‘Spose now is a good time as any for introductions! The name’s Floatzel!” It extends the tip of a foreclaw towards you. For a handshake, maybe?
“I...would have never guessed.” You shake the weasel's claw. Pokémon naming conventions, man…
         “So, Mr. or Mrs?”
         “Neither!”
         “Huh?”
         “Ms.”
         “Oh.”
         The weasel sets you down on the dirt floor, next to a dilapidated novelty Poké Ball. Looking around, you notice Floatzel amassed itself quite a collection of odd goodies. There’s a bit of everything. Ranging from kitschy Pokedolls to practical Full Heals and revives — there’s a pendant of Mystic Water too! You even see the sparkle of a Comet Shard! That’s worth pretty good money!
         “How did you get all this stuff?”
         “I found it.” She says flatly.
         “Is this the I found this in someone else’s pocket type of ‘found it’ or—”
         “Not like that! I’m not a thief. I’m…” Floatzel holds for dramatic effect, “...an adventurer!” She proclaims with wide outstretched arms.
         “Adventurer?” you say surprised. Not the answer you were expecting. You always thought of adventures as… a people thing. Not a mantle a Pokémon would take up. “So, where exactly do you “adventure”?
         “Everywhere! Under the waves, in abandoned buildings — it’s amazing what things humans leave behind!” Floatzel picks up the deactivated Poké Ball next to you and pops it open, studying the many mirrors inside before clicking its tongue — seemingly in disapproval before setting it down.
         “So — how’d you end up pint-sized? Your folk’s usually a little bit bigger.” Floatzel scratches behind its neck. “And not as chatty. It’s weird having a two-way conversation a human. Refreshing, for sure!”
         You tell her the usual answer: you don’t know.
         “...So you wake up one day, smaller than a pine needle, and you haven’t got a clue why?”
         You nod.
         “You know, adventurers often work as part-time detectives…” Floatzel chimes with a wink. “‘Detective Floatzel.’ It has a nice ring to it…”
         “You’re going to help me?” Your face lights up. A Pokémon who isn’t a total weirdo wants to help you? Sign you up! “You’ve got any ideas?" You say excitedly. “Leads?”
         “Uh, well — no. Kinda’ve? You see, there’s this place…”
1141111212121121132221222112.title: Escape Ropes and Weasel's Words

choices: Ask any big Pokemon you find
11411112121211211322212221121.content:
A glade where small Pokemon are bigger than usual? It sounded tangentially related to your current situation, at best. You were smaller than usual, not bigger. Something must have shown your discontent, because Floatzel hurries to offer other possibilities. "If that's not convincing, I know other places! You know how Xatu is said to see the past and the future? I know where we can find a Xatu. There are also ruins in a swamp not too far from here, and ruins are known for their strange artifacts. I myself have found quite some treasures in ruins before"

You appreciate her effort, you really do, but those two also sounded like they were a long shot. That about Xatu was closer to myth than truth, as far as you knew, and mystical ruins were more fiction than reality. Floatzel sighs, a tad annoyed with you. "Look, you can't expect answers to be found easily. I said I'd help you, the only thing I ask is that you don't turn your nose to my suggestions"

"I'm sorry, I didn't mean to offend you" you say. She's right, you have to make a choice or else you will have zero chance of returning to normal. You won't get anywhere unless you take the plunge! After a moment, you consider the options. That glade...it's a fact Pokemon are larger than they should be. Maybe there's something in there that will make you larger. "Can you take me to the glade?"

"Of course I can! It's two hours away, and I don't think many Pokemon who don't live in there know about it. We won't be bothered by anyone"

That was a bonus. Less chances of someone you know seeing you. True, you knew a grand total of two Pokemon, but it was something you wanted to avoid, anyway. The course of action was set, you were ready to depart. Floatzel, though, insisted leaving the next day would be better. It'd give them more time to prepare. "Adventuring isn't something you can do recklessly" she said. You had to admit she was right.

That night, you asked her to tell you more about the glade. Floatzel curls on the ground, reminiscing about when she had seen that glade for the first time. She was a novice in her hobby, and had stumbled upon the glade. She hadn't stayed for long, deeming it too dangerous, but right now? It was important to go back! "It's surreal. Pokemon that wouldn't even reach my hip would tower over me. One of them saw me, but it was like they were normal Pokemon, just bigger than they should be"

"So how dangerous is it?"

"For your size? I'd say you'd better stick with me or else you'll have a hard time" she adds, with a cocky smirk. "I'm pretty sure I saw a few Pokemon who were so big they could eat me. Can you believe that?" You couldn't. The mere thought a Pokemon could be that big was mindboggling. "Anyway, the air feels so clean, and even though I could see the sky over my head it felt like I was in an entirely different world. It was so weird"

"What do you think is going on in there?"

"I dunno. Maybe it's another world, for all we know. Everything is normal size except the Pokemon, so it's not that different from the rest of the forest" That was a relief. At least it was a confirmation you wouldn't be getting even smaller by being there.

------

Departing from the burrow felt bittersweet. It was only for a night, but it felt like such a nice place. Floatzel had talked and shown you her treasures, you'd have loved to stay for a little longer, but she was eager to return to the glade. "I can't believe I'm going back!" After some discussion, it was decided you'd hold onto her fur. After what happened in her snout, you weren't willing to risk it again, and she agreed wholeheartedly.

The trip to the glade was uneventful, thankfully. You sank into Floatzel's fur while she ran through the forest. The ride was bumpy, it was one of the few times you were glad to be so small because it meant the fur kept you on your newfound friend. Floatzel recommended not to talk during the trip, so most of the ride was you battling the dizziness of being on what felt like a living rollercoaster from how much she moved.

At the start of the second hour of traveling, Floatzel reached a fallen tree. The insides had been hollowed out, it was a rather narrow passageway. Although she as larger than the passageway, her shape allowed her to sneak inside, even though it was a tight fit., so tight the bark pressed you against Floatzel's skin with no room to move. The pressure went away when Floatzel emerged at the end of the tree, into the strange glade she had been talking about.

It did feel like a weird place. The air was clean but there was this constant feeling of dream-like calm, like nothing would ever happen. The sky overhead had a very intense blue, with no clouds at all. The trees looked very real and healthy, more than you remembered the forest on the other side of the dying tree to be. Even the dying tree you had came through was covered with moss and dew.

The glade was rather beautiful, and from the looks of it, further than the glade the forest went on. You wondered just how far this anomalous place went to. "So what's the plan?" you asked. Floatzel stood on her hind legs, sniffing the air around.

"We'll look for a Pokemon and ask for help"

"Really? Just like that?"

"Someone must know something"

"And if they're hostile?"

"Then we run away, of course. No point in fighting" she reassured you. "Not everyone is out to get you" You knew she was right, but it was hard not to feel paranoid when you were tiny and the Pokemon you were going to stumble upon now would be larger than they should be. You wondered if it was limited only to small species, or if those that were already large would be gigantic now.

It sure wasn't a soothing thought.

"Now, where to start..." Floatzel considered the options, discussing them with you. "Let's find a Pokemon, but what'd you prefer? Should we approach any Pokemon that's bigger than usual, or should we try to find a normal-sized Pokemon around here?"

This glade was bound to be teeming with anomalous Pokemon, so finding those would be easy. A normal-sized one was a nice thought, you had to admit.
11411112121211211322212221121.title: Strange Glade

choices: ...spits you out onto the grassy ground!
...shoves you toward the back of his throat!
...splutters you off in a loogie as far as Dedenne can!
114111121212112113222122211211.content:
It isn't too hard to find a "big" Pokémon. Only moments after your search begins, it ends! It's pretty hard to not notice the unmistakable rotund form of a Dedenne peeking over the horizon—a lazy sun. Its black ears peep over the tall grasses like an inquisitive Watchog. Its belly rises and falls as the Pokémon snorts and snores in its afternoon nap. All the while, normal sized Dedenne sleep on and by the 'mon.
         The creature is massive! Double — no! Triple? Can’t be! It must be quintuple—fivefold—the size of its brethren! Floatzel admires it for a moment, before taking her time to stroll on closer — it's not going anywhere.
         "That Pokémon's an electric mouse, right?" Floatzel says, a twinkle in her eye.
         "I think so?" You reply.
         "Like Pikachu?" A tooth peeks through Floatzel's gums as she tries to hide a growing grin.
         "I guess…"
         "So, you could say that Dedenne is…"
         "...Are you really—"
         "...An absolute Chu-net?"
         "..."
         Despite it being midday, you swear you hear a lone Kricketot chirp. You decide it’s best to shun Floatzel’s joke with silence. You take up residence behind her neck, propped between her flotation device and cushioned by her super-soft coat.

         Soon enough, you and Floatzel stand by the Dedenne. Snorts, snuffles, and snores of many a ‘mon become the new sounds of the glade — overtaking the birds and the whispering wind. A cartoonish bubble crops from the nose of one of the smaller Dedenne, sleeping on the larger one’s tail. It grows and shrinks, timed with its breaths before it pops — startling the critter awake!
         "Waaa{s ize:2}agh!" The Pokémon's black oval eyes dart around, looking to its still sleeping kin before settling on Floatzel. "Oh! A Floatzel! Hi! You're far from the river. Whatcha doing here?"
         "Solving a mystery and helping a friend. And big boy here," Floatzel points a back-claw to the jumbo-sized rodent, "may be the key to the puzzle."
         "But... puzzles don't have keys," the Dedenne frowns, whiskers drooping, "they have pieces." Floatzel blinks.
         "...They’re a piece then."
         "They’re awfully big to just be a piece."
         "They’re a big piece."
         "How big is the puzzle? I can't imagine finishing a puzzle with pieces as big as—!" You notice the Dedenne focus on the back of Floatzel's neck: your general location. "Hey, I think there's a Flabébé on your neck, miss!" You dig yourself a bit deeper into her fur as Floatzel quickly adjusts her position to face the small Dedenne head-on.
         "Yeah," she tries to laugh it off casually, "sometimes I give small Pokémon piggyback rides. It's, uh, thrilling."
         Dedenne's eyes sparkle. "Can I have one?"
         "No."
         "Aww."
         "Steering this raft back on-course, can I talk with Jumbo? I've got something to say about the small hu—" Floatzel's eyes balloon as her words halt like a skidding train. She catches herself. "—utiefly. A Cutiefly. They're a Cutiefly." She finishes. The small Dedenne raises an eyebrow, but curbs it's inquisitiveness just this once.
         The little creature clambers up the plump mountain. At the summit the small Pokémon springs upward, using their cream belly like a springboard, proclaiming, “wake up, big guy!” They land softly back onto the furred trampoline and bounce away as the big Dedenne stirs, and yawns, and stretches their limbs—nudging the surrounding Pokémon away.
         “Mmm… hello?” The big Dedenne yawns once more and smacks their lips drowsily. Their voice sounds like a Snorlax's. Er, what you'd imagine a Snorlax's to sound like anyway. Definitely a dude, though.
         “Hey big fella!” Floatzel greets, “up and at ‘em!” The giant ‘mon groggily rubs his eyes and attempts to sit up. All the other Dedenne scramble to get out of the way and vanish into the tall grasses.
         “Ah!” The monumental Pokémon grins ear-to-ear, “a visitor! I haven’t seen you before!”
The Pokémon seems so jolly! He honestly doesn’t seem to have a bad bone in his body! At least, not from the ten seconds Floatzel spent with him.
         Eh, you think, might as well make myself known. He’s going to find out soon enough anyway. You slide down Floatzel’s yellow floatation device and find a perch by the side of the weasel’s neck.
         “I’m Floatzel: outdoors-mon, explorer, and experienced misadventurer,” Floatzel holds out a paw—expecting a handshake. She’s quite fond of those!
         Dedenne’s whiskers twitch before erupting in a full-on belly laugh. “Handshakes? Bah! We don’t do those here! Here’s a good ‘ol fashion Dedenne greetings!” Before Floatzel can protest, Dedenne hunches over and gives Floatzel a great, big lick!
         When you saw Dedenne’s face close in and his fat tongue emerge, you had just enough time to think two words before relinquishing yourself to its sticky embrace:
         Again, really?
         After you’re dragged through and off Floatzel’s fur and as you’re ferried away through the air, approaching the cavernous reaches of the Fairy’s mouth, you try to peel yourself from the muscle’s grasp—but it’s futile. The last of the outside world you see is Floatzel, coated in slobber and bearing an empty-eyed look of shock.
         Locked behind a gate of lip and fang, situated atop a slimy and sticky tongue, you don’t even have time to scramble to your feet before light rushes in once more and the muscle beneath bounces and moves. Hot air, incubated within the Dedenne’s deepest depths, rushes from below as you’re flung about. Dedenne is speaking.
         “Eyuck,” Dedenne says, “I think I got some of your hair on my tongue. One sec!”
         Floatzel snaps to attention. “No! Don’t—”
         Inside the mouse’s maw, the enormous tongue pushes you around and about the Dedenne’s closed mouth, swishing you through his saliva and giving you a full tour of dark chamber. Then the muscle scoops you up—along with an ocean of spit and…
114111121212112113222122211211.title: Face-to-Face With a Fat Fairy

choices: You wake Dedenne up to ask questions
1141111212121121132221222112111.content:
In your experiences so far you knew once you entered a mouth, you'd end in a stomach. If you had a moment to prepare yourself, you're resign to the imminent swallowing that'd lead to the belly of another Pokemon.

You didn't have a moment of respite, though. Dedenne's tongue moved you around in his mouth at blinding speed, not even giving you the time to notice what was going on. You saw blurry colors. White, pink, red, and black mixed together in a dizzying trip that made you feel like you had been through in a washing machine. All the saliva you were being tossed with only increased the similarities to that metaphor.

Surprisingly, the spit didn't drag you towards a waiting throat. Instead the mouth opened and you were thrown in the air at fast speeds. You barely had time to notice you had left the hot cavern you were in, replaced by air that felt cold. The impact against the grass stunned you, you just laid there and made a quick inventory of your body. Nothing broken, thankfully, but that was too close. Everything aches.

"There we go, that's better. Where were we?" you vaguely hear Dedenne's booming voice. You hadn't recovered yet when someone lifted you. The cream-colored fur enveloping you told you the identity of the Pokemon who had you now.

"Are you okay? Can you hear me?" Floatzel cradles you in one paw, anxiously checking you all over.

"Thanks, Floatzel..."

"You're okay! I'm so glad!" She had gotten so worried when she noticed you had been swept by Dedenne's tongue, but in her opinion what happened to you was better than being swallowed. Much better!

All Dedenne could do was stare quizzically at Floatzel until she finally calmed down enough to explain the situation. Dedenne's wide smile got smaller when Floatzel described how she had brought a small human, and that they had gotten all the way to this glade to try to find a way to return you to normal. "So wherever this human comes from it's not like here? Some bigger -- or smaller -- than others?"

"I'm pretty sure they're not" Floatzel said, not knowing at all.

Dedenne asked a couple more questions. By then you had recovered enough to sit up and talk. Part of you was grateful at Dedenne for not swallowing you, you had to admit, so you were patient and explained you had no idea what had happened. "So can you help me? Please, anything that could be of help could be good!"

The fairy's ears twitched. "Nope. I don't have the slightest idea"

You sighed. Figures. "How are you so big? We saw the other Dedennes, they were much smaller"

"I dunno. I just grew like this since a few years ago!" he said cheerfully. You frowned: you sure didn't have years to wait! "I do remember something weird happening back then. Maybe that'll be of help?"

"If it's weird it's a clue! Weirdness is what we need" Floatzel pressed on. "What kind of weird was it?"

Dedenne pointed upwards. "One day a flying human vehicle had passed above. It was all on fire, and a box that fell from it exploded in the air. Whatever was inside the box broke and fell all over the forest, maybe even more than just the forest. Since then several hundreds or like a thousand Pokemon grew more than usual" he nodded, pleased with his good memory. "Is that useful?" You weren't really sure if it was, but there indeed was a chance there was some causation there.

"Yes, very useful! But if it was years ago then we can't do anything about it" Floatzel said. At least they knew a little more now! Dedenne, noticing neither you nor your mustelid friend were very enthusiastic, laughed rather loudly.

"I know what to do. Look at this" from his whiskers, sparks of electricity spread all over the place. For a moment you felt tingly but it didn't seem to affect you any further.

"What was that?" you asked, curious. Dedenne pounded his chest, proud.

"I gave a signal to my fellow Dedenne! They will bring here some of what fell down so long ago. There were so many small pieces to this day Pokemon keep finding them around" Those were good news! Sure, the odds you'd be able to get something useful from the pulverized remains of whatever happened back then were astronomically low, but at least he was being helpful. You thanked him profusely. "No need to thank me! Just have some patience. I hate to admit it, but we Dedenne aren't known for focusing for long on a task" he winked like he had said a very good joke. "I suppose you two will stay for dinner?"

-----------

Nobody could say Dedenne wasn't welcoming. That was a great dinner. Floatzel and Dedenne ate so much you were sure Dedenne got rounder than usual and Floatzel fell into a food coma five minutes after eating. You had a rather generous share of food too, but you had been so nervous from the way they were shoveling food into their maws you made sure to stay kind of far from them.

"They're taking longer than I thought they would" Dedenne commented, his tail swishing across the grass with impatience. "I'm sorry, maybe I should have gone myself"

"No problem. It's not like I have any place to be right now" You sure weren't going to stray far from Dedenne or Floatzel, that was for sure.

"Then let's have a good night of sleep!" Dedenne proposed, curling in a ball. "Come on, little human, sleep a little"

"I'm not sleepy" you said. It had barely been sunset half an hour ago, you were used to going to sleep much later. Dedenne smiled at you, yawned widely and settled in for the night. You laid on Floatzel, staring up at the sky until you heard Dedenne's snoring. Great, he snored. That wasn't going to help you sleep later.

An hour passed while you waited around. Underneath you, Floatzel slept placidly, satisfied. Dedenne had uncurled, stretching and turning over and over until he found a comfortable position. It was like the entire forest had gone to sleep, the only sounds you could hear was a breeze passing through the leaves, and the faraway sounds of bug Pokemon. It was a peaceful night.

But there was still no sign of the Dedennes. Given how it was night, you judged it was unlikely they'd arrive so late. They likely would be here the next day. A possible clue, so close yet so far! Or perhaps not so far? Dedenne was right there --- a very large Dedenne who had been affected by something. You got off Floatzel and approached Dedenne.

From up-close, Dedenne was a behemoth. Usually a Dedenne would be much smaller, this one was even bigger than Floatzel! To think it had grown along the years...but perhaps you'd be able to find something? Such a drastic, unnatural change surely had to leave traces of some sort. You ran your hand over Dedenne's fur, letting it sink until you touched skin. Dedenne didn't react at all. You didn't have to wait until the other Dedennes returned, you decided. There were two options available to you right now:

Maybe you could explore Dedenne's body. There could be traces or clues on him that could tell you what you were dealing with. He was asleep right now, so you pretty much had free reign to do whatever you wanted. You frowned, a tad uncertain. Right now all you were thinking about was examining the exterior of his body, but if you found nothing then what would you do? You didn't feel like examining his insides...but maybe you'd have to if you found nothing. Or if you found anything that could indicate you'd have to enter him to find out more. That'd make it necessary too.

The other option you had right now was interrupt Dedenne's sleep and interrogate him. The fairy was a rather jolly Pokemon, he wouldn't be upset if you woke him up, but what would he be able to tell you? You didn't know. You just knew you had to do something tonight.
1141111212121121132221222112111.title: Lucky Break

choices: Dedenne grows in size a little more
Dedenne has an upset stomach now
1141111212121121132221222112112.content:
When you heard Dedenne thought you were some of Floatzel's fur you were relieved. That had to mean you'd be spat out, as that's what anyone would do with hair or fur in their mouths. You struggled to stay afloat and conscious, trying to be ready for impact, but then you felt everything moving in the opposite direction you expected. "Wait!" you yell when all the spit and you moved towards the throat, already opening to receive you. Right before you were swallowed, all you could think was that you hoped Dedenne's stomach would be hospitable enough not to make you float around in digesting food.

The feeling of weightlessness catches you. The throat squeezes the ocean of spit and you, mercifully keeping you on top, while it all descends with frightening speed down Dedenne's throat and esophagus. It's all happening way too quickly, not even giving you a moment to catch your breath, while you plunge down into the depths of the giant rodent. The sphincter to the stomach opens with an audible sound and you fall through, bouncing on the side of the entrance and falling towards a side, free from the saliva that made the trip along with you.

You expected to splash on gastric juices and food, or on spongy tissue if Dedenne's stomach was miraculously empty. You certainly didn't expect to fall on a surface so hard you were stunned. Trying not to black out from the impact, you crawled forward, dizzy, until you felt safe enough to stand up.

The strangest mix of sensations was invading all your senses. The smell was odd: a combination of nuts, herbs, something that really resembled cinnamon, and vomit. It was like you were smelling very acidic peanuts. It wasn't unpleasant, but you didn't want to keep inhaling it for too long. The stomach was faintly illuminated, like a slight electrical current was underneath the stomach lining. The gastric soup was sparkling underneath the platform you were on, you could see bits and lumps underneath the surface, undoubtedly food being processed. Finally, you seemed to be on a metallic shard of something. You examined it, finding grooves and reflecting material. It took you a moment to realize what it was:

You remembered having seen this texture in a book, it was the inside of a Pokeball. This wasn't the only shard in the stomach. In the faint illumination you could see dozens of smaller shards embedded onto the walls of the stomach, metal and plastic inserted into the tissue. You recognized the color of the plastic: this was from one of those novelty giant-making Pokeballs from a region you don't remember right now. Could that be the explanation for Dedenne's size? There must be shards all over Dedenne's digestive system. Hoping to get shards as proof of what was happening, you decided to take a couple more, in case you got separated from the shard you were riding. Trying to row the shard to the wall, you start paddling as much as you can with your hands.

-----

"Why's this happening?!" Floatzel shrieked, frustrated, while she tried to tackle Dedenne. She had to get the human out of the mouse, The large Dedenne didn't expect that, he had been saying how it was so unusual to see Pokemon from the river, when Floatzel slammed onto his abdomen. It wasn't as effective as Floatzel could have hoped, he barely staggered. Instead he put a hand on Floatzel's back, surprised.

"Something wrong? Did I say something I shouldn't have?"

"You have to spit them out!"

"Who?"

"Wait, I don't even have thread right now, and even if I had, it wouldn't be enough...there has to be a way to solve this," Floatzel said to herself, ignoring Dedenne. All he could do was keep watching in confusion. He had been about to ask Floatzel to explain when he felt a sudden tingling sensation coming from inside him. The tingling sensation increased very quickly.

-------

Floatzel's attempt to help you hadn't gone unnoticed to you. Her attack on Dedenne's abdomen had hit lower than the stomach, but it had been enough to rock the sack you were in. Waves formed, moving the shard around. A couple others fell into the mixture, a hundred shards still into the walls. You held onto the grooves of the shard you were on, until it crashed against the wall.

"Oh no!" you hoped it didn't hurt Dedenne. The stomach reacted immediately to the impact, you could just watch while the effects made themselves known pretty quickly.
1141111212121121132221222112112.title: Dedenne's Insides

choices: Floatzel succeeds, you reach the peak
11411112121211211322212221122.content:
Xatu, Xatu...if you recall correctly, that's supposed to be a Psychit-type bird who can see into the past and the future at once -- or at least that's what the rumors say. It wasn't likely it was the literal truth, but if that species did have some foresight, then this Xatu Floatzel mentioned should be of help. You nod when Floatzel says that. "I'd like to talk with that Xatu. How far away is that mountain?"

Floatzel grins, takes you delicately, and walks outside of her den, holding you high so you can see. "Do you see that mountain over there?" she pointed at a mountain that was just a couple hours of distance away. "That's the one" The mountain was rocky, with trees all over the base, but the higher you looked, the more barren it seemed. The peak was barely visible, you were sure you could see something that seemed to be snow. That was a rather tall mountain!

"Have you gone up there before?"

"Me? No, I haven't. But I'm confident in my skills. We'll be fine!" she reassured you, the way she exclaimed was dripping with confidence. Still, that was a really tall mountain, and if it got colder the higher you went...you couldn't avoid being worried. Not only for you, but for Floatzel. She didn't seem particularly ready for colder climates.

-------------

Floatzel and you left the den at dawn, ready for the new adventure of going up the mountain, you holding onto her neck, right beside her flotation device. Walking through the trees, Floatzel seemed to be in a rather good mood, until you both got to the parts where the trees stopped and the rocks and moss increased. From there on the trip would be much more difficult. Floatzel looked up at the peak, and psyched herself up: "Alright, are you ready? This is going to be steep"

"It's not like I'm the one walking on this place. I'm more worried for you than for myself," you admitted. Floatzel seemed rather flattered for your concern, she patted your head and back of your neck with a paw. You weren't sure you liked when she did that, it made you feel like a pet.

"Aw, are you worried? It'll be fine, this isn't the first time I come to a mountain?"

"Really?"

"Really. When I was younger I used to play around here with a friend. We used to climb around because he wanted to be strong. I think he left to go to faraway lands, but I'm sure some of that strength we got back then is still in me. I'm prepared"

She knew herself better than you knew her, if she said she was ready then you weren't going to doubt her. You got comfortable between her flotation device and her fur. "Alright, let's do it. Be careful"

"Careful is one of my qualities, friend, it's part of being an explorer," she boasted, jumping high and grabbing onto a jutting stone. The arduous climb towards the peak of the mountain had started.

---------

You trusted Floatzel's survivalist skills, and she clearly knew what she was doing. You could feel it in her movements, in the way she stepped on every trecharous part of the path with confidence, even though she crossed a lot of narrow ledges and frightening-looking chasms.

Despite that, you felt something was wrong.

The sky overhead had gone cloudy, and when that happened, the temperature was reduced considerably. Floatzel's face had flashed concern, she stopped for a moment, surveying the sky. "It...doesn't look like the clouds are going away," she said. You felt the muscles beside you tremble very, very slightly. She was cold.

"Should we go back?"

"No, I refuse. This isn't like I had planned, but we have come too far to retreat. The peak is just a few hours away," she said, determined. Fire of bravery burned in her eyes, you hoped that fire would keep her warm in the increasingly colder weather.

The more time passed the more obvious it was this was very taxing for Floatzel. Her movements were still very energic, her steps firm and nimble, but the trembling you felt through her neck had increased in intensity. The stronger her tremors got, the more guilty you felt. She was doing this for you, she was almost to her limit because of your situation. Floatzel was truly a friend you could rely on.

You just hoped it wouldn't lead to she being harmed.

Floatzel looked up, frost falling around them. "Look, there's some frost. We're close"

"Maybe we should camp or something--"

"No. If we stop moving we'll be in more danger. We don't have a way to keep warm," she declared. She wasn't wrong. "We have to reach the cave at the peak, that's our best bet"

"Okay," you said. You pressed yourself onto Floatzel's fur, like it was going to transfer some of your warmth to her. Her neck and the flotation device had protected you from the cold, you were nice and toasty.

"As a thank you you should befriend a Floatzel when you return to normal. Have one as a companion," she said lightly. That was something you were actually considering. Still, your return to normality was still far away, and it wouldn't happen unless Floatzel reached the peak.

You just hoped she'd succeed and reach the caves.
11411112121211211322212221122.title: Perilous Climb

114111121212112113222122211221.content:
Even experts have a breaking point. The best laid plans run into snags, something goes wrong, something doesn't go as expected.

Floatzel's shivering was increasing to worrying amounts, so much you were actively being moved around by the contractions of her muscles. The fur all around you was starting to have bits of frost, and the flotation device felt cold as ice. For the first time, even in your cozy spot, you were starting to feel the cold. You could only imagine how Floatzel felt.

"...I have to keep going. You won't last long...out there in the cold," she mumbled, walking forward. Her steps were growing tired. You raised your voice:

"You don't sound well at all! Maybe we should go down the mountain for now!" even though you said that, she ignored you completely. You silently cursed the clouded skies -- ruining Floatzel's efforts like that.

The cursing turned into fear when Floatzel collapsed. It was sudden, one moment she was going on all fours to grip the barren rocks better, the next she was falling onto her belly. "Floatzel?" you called. You got no response. "Floatzel, say something!" she was alive, you could hear her breathing when you put your ear against her neck, but falling unconscious at a time like that was very dangerous. If she got any colder...

The thought of your friend dying made your heart jump to your throat. You got on top of her flotation device on her back, jumping up and down to try to get her to rouse. "Come on, you have to stand up! You're...you're close, don't give up!" It was useless, though. She didn't even twitch.

Guilt invaded you. You felt this was your fault, she had wanted to help you and now she was going to freeze to death on a mountain. You should have asked her for other options. You should have suggested she should get something warm to carry. There must have been something you could have done! Even though the cold was a real danger for you too, you didn't fear for your life, you were more worried for Floatzel.

There wasn't much time for pity. A big shadow enveloped the area, barely visible on the dirt and moss. At first you thought it was the clouds above moving and covering everything even more, but the sound of something landing beside Floatzel dispelled that notion. You looked up.

It was a bird. A frighteningly large bird, covered with what seemed to be a steel armor of some sort, frost caked on them. Black feathers peeked from between some of them, you saw large and bright red eyes on the head. The wings were covered with steel, and so were the rather sharp-looking talons. There were very few places without steel, just the holes for the eyes, the beak, most of the legs, and the underside of the tail feathers and its base. You had never seen a Pokemon like that one before. It reminded you of Honchkrow, as it was clearly a corvid of some sort.

What frightened you the most was that, even if you were normal size, you were sure it'd be at the very least two heads taller than you. Where did such a large bird come from?! "...please, help" you pleaded. "We need help!"

The bird opened its beak. A boisterous voice emerged, clearly a male voice. "Don't worry, that's what I'm here for! Believe it or not, I have been watching you for a while already. I feared your orange friend here would collapse!"

"...wait, you could see me from up there?" he didn't seem surprised about your presence. If it ever was, then it already had time to convince himself he wasn't seeing things.

"Of course, my eyes are second to none. I don't know why you're so small, but that's not what's important right now. I, Corviknight, shall take you under my wing for protection!" he patted his chest with a wing, lowered his head and whispered. "Metaphorically. What I'm actually doing is taking you both to get medical attention. That's my job, I'm a scout"

Corviknight. Interesting name. "Medical attention...?"

"I believe you humans call such places 'hospitals'. It's a place where Pokemon get attention for all sorts of problems, from the most pedestrian illneses, to the more injuries, to those of a more..." he cawed in what seemed to be an attempt to clear his throat. When he spoke, he seemed a llittle bit flustered. "...of a more private nature. Reproductive problems and all that. Not my field!"

"...right..." so in general it was a place where Pokemon got help for medical problems, and now this large bird was going to take Floatzel there. Good! Just what you needed, for once! Corviknight positioned himself over Floatzel, like a mother hen to a chick, giving her some of his warmth. Then, inclining his head, he gazed at you with curiosity.

"I must say, your size is unusual. Would it be inaccurate to say you're afflicted by a medical problem too?" Maybe being shrunk was a medical issue, now that you thought about it. You nodded. "Then you shall be a patient too. Your case seems unusual, though. I mentioned I'm a scout, I scout for both patients and workers"

"Okay?" you weren't sure where he was going with this.

"You're smaller than even the smallest Pokemon I have ever seen. I won't beat around the bush: your help would be immensely useful! Sometimes there are cases that need some sort of smaller help. We used to have a few Joltiks who did the job, but they fit in less places inside Pokemon than you'd think"

Oh. Now you were starting to see where this was going. "You want me to work at the Pokemon healing place you work at...as a helper?"

"To be frank, I don't think we have seen a case like you before. You may not recover your normal size. But wouldn't it be a nice life? Doing your part to help other Pokemon? In exchange, you get warmth, a home, and our company. It's not a bad trade"

It was too much to consider at once. Here you were climbing a mountain with Floatzel, to try to get you back to normal size, and then she falls unconscious, a giant crow tells you you may be tiny forever, and then offers you a job as a medical assistant whose job would be crawling inside Pokemon to help. No, you needed time to think about it. No way you could give an answer right away! "I'll consider it," you say. "Right now all I want is Floatzel to be okay"

Below Corviknight, Floatzel twitched. His warmth was helping. Corviknight examined her face carefully, seemingly satisfied with what he was seeing, and turned his attention at you again. "She will be fine! I will carry her now that she's not in a dangerous state anymore!" he claimed, and once again lowered his voice and head towards you. "But...there's an issue"

"What is it?"

"You."

Being called an issue felt a bit insulting. "What do you mean?"

"I cannot carry you like I carry Floatzel. I can grab her easily and carefully, but you're too small to be gripped by my talons"

"I could ride on Floatzel--"

Corviknight squaked with indignation: "Absolutely not! I cannot condone the risk of you falling down! No, I have to ensure you'll be carried safely, and this is an urgent situation. I wouldn't usually suggest this, but there's no more option:

I must carry you in me!"

You feel a chill down your back you're not sure has anything to do with the weather. "Like inside your armor?"

Corviknight pecked the plates over his belly. "These are fused to my plumage, I'm afraid. There's no space, and if there were, you'd be crushed by my muscles. That won't do"

“Are you really suggesting—”

“That's right”

“In you.”

“Correct”

“Where exactly?”

“You could say you have two options.”

“Did you really say that?!”

“And my belly’s got acid in it.” he finished with a look of concern. All you did was look at him with disbelief.

"So this is what deja vu feels like..." you mutter. You remembered having a very similar conversation with a different and smaller crow, just a couple days ago. Now you were in a similar, but more urgent situation. Crud.

"Is there a problem?"

"Corviknight, you're asking me to either get swallowed or to get into your ass"

"The correct term is cloaca, human. A cloaca receives both solid and liquid waste--"

"That's not the point! I'm just..." you sigh. "It's not like I have a choice to not go. Damn it. My life has spiralled out of control. I just want to feel like I have some control in my life"

Corviknight looked at you with sympathy. Slowly, he got off Floatzel, walking to a flatter part of the terrain. "I understand. It isn't much, but if it helps, I'll let you go inside me at your own pace," he said, folding his legs and loweing his entire body to the ground. Corviknight positioned his head against the rocks, ready to open his beak if you approached it, and made sure the open part of his armor at the base of his tail was low enough for you to go under it and crawl into his vent. You appreciated his willingness to do this at your own rhythm -- he was showing much more consideration than Honchkrow did.

That was the moment you knew you could trust Corviknight with your life.

Now you had to make a choice so he could depart and take Floatzel to get help and rest.
114111121212112113222122211221.title: Guardian Corvid

choices: Corviknight abruptly careens down. He shouts, “Sorry human! Someone is in troubl
You feel a resounding thump as Corviknight touches down!
Corviknight gently flutters down. “Sincerest apologies, human. I must eat…”
1141111212121121132221222112212.content:
After your “experience” with Honchkrow, you are understandably slow to approach another bird’s butt. You swiftly decide that you would rather risk the dangers of the frontdoor than the unpleasantness of the back. But knowing you’ve survived the belly of two Pokemon already, you’re put at ease—as much as one could reasonably expect of a person about to be willingly gobbled.
         You trudge atop the arctic surface of the snow-shielded ground. The red eyes of the Corviknight watch you warily, monitoring your progress. Watching carefully to see if you’re having any problems—like a dutiful sentinel.
         You begin your ascent up the cool rock, placing your hands on its frozen surface. With a grunt and a grimace, you pull yourself up the edge of the stone. The rest of its surface is smooth and shiny, almost like a polished mirror. It’s icy, but your low weight prevents you from slipping. Corviknight’s armored face stands before you. He waits with the stillness of a statue and the patience of a saint.
         “Please, approach at your leisure.” The metal bird’s voice is strong, but not pushy. You don’t need encouragement, however. Floatzel is freezing! The faster you bop yourself into the bird, the sooner Floatzel can get help! You push yourself towards Corviknight, skating towards his black beaked face. And before long, Corviknight dwarfs the world. You slow approach, the last of your momentum bops you into the tip of his beak, to which you gently bounce back.
         As the great bird’s beak creaks open, the hot air that harbors within escapes. You’re washed with the warmness of his breath, fragrant with the scent of birdseed and iron. His black tongue is outstretched and fills the bottom of his beak like a carpet of putty. The back of his throat descends into a dark cave whose unseen depths are only left to your imagination. Listening closely, you could hear the sounds of his stomach escaping from the abyss. The whining gurgle from within escapes like the wail from a prisoner in their cell.
         Corviknight’s caw abruptly snaps shut as he begins to speak.
         “I sense your fear, human. Your choice of travel is bold—but I will ensure your safety!” Corviknight opens his beak once again, but not before bestowing you a few last words. “Do not let your vexations overtake you.”
         You take a deep swallow of arctic air. You’re ready.
         You clamber up the lip of Corviknight’s beak and plant a foot on his soft tongue. It wriggles slightly in response, but the armored avian wills it still. You have been granted passage.
         Enveloped in his maw, the light outside dims as his beak seals. The white mountain’s brilliance narrows to a slit before it narrows into nothing. You are in a hot and humid inner world. The sounds of the whistling winds outside are silenced. Now the powerful sonorousness of Corviknight’s breath replaces it. Deeper within, you can hear his great heartbeat rump-a-pump away.
         You hear a sticky sliding sound as Corviknight’s tongue lifts up. Simultaneously, you sense your center of gravity shift as he begins to tilt his head up. Soon, your stable footing vanishes. You begin to slide down his gluey tongue as you approach the black hole of his throat. Corviknight’s head is now completely vertical—and you are shunted into the clutches of his throat.
         Corviknight is a caring fellow—who forged himself an iron will and is a master of self-discipline. But even he, swallowing as gently as he can, cannot quell the hungry clutches of his gullet. His esophageal muscles cram you downward with the strength and dispassion of an uncaring lord. The wet meat mashes with primal, mindless instinct—and despite the hot flesh pressing against your skin, you feel that whatever smidgen of will Corviknight’s tissue possesses, it’s colder than his steel armor. Before, you’ve only been swallowed by a bat and a weasel-otter. Now it’s extremely apparent you’re in the gorge of an alpha predator. Despite Corviknight’s clear friendliness and passion for life, you’re made keenly aware of your place in the food chain.
         You’re propelled forward, passing through a tight ring and expelled into a pungent-smelling sack. You splash into the mushed-up remains of…something as you plunge underneath the semi-solid surface of the bird’s internal pool. You flip and twirl in the mush before finding your orientation. With squeezed-closed eyes and a wrinkled-shut nose, you swim to the surface, allowing the goo to slide away like water off a duck’s back. You take your first breath in a forever and find it stained with an acrid odor. The previous scent of birdseed is omnipresent too, but it’s now soured and wry.
         Corviknight’s voice shakes the contents of the mud-like pool around you.
         “My most sincerest apologies, valiant human. I had filled my belly to prepare for the day of work ahead. But I fear my gluttony has conferred you a maltreatment most foul.” You feel the great mucky lagoon slosh back-and-forth as Corviknight struts along—likely toward your unconscious friend. “I will carry your friend to the safety of Sanctuary.” He does another of his half caw, half cough throat clears. “Ah—and I’ll try to keep the flight steady and smooth. It must be… very gross in there.”
         He is most certainly not wrong.
         “It’s not… the worst I’ve been through.” You admit. As repugnant of a place this is, nothing will beat the squalor of Honchkrow’s cloaca.
         After a brief moment of silence, Corviknight clears his throat once more. You and the goopy stuff lurch upward as whatever is blocking the crow’s throat gets ripped away. “Apologies—force of habit.” And without another word, you feel Corviknight shift his weight around as he grips Floatzel before launching off into the sky with a flap of his wings.

         True to his word, Corviknight’s flight to what he called “Sanctuary” is smooth and stable. The Pokemon glides along with the winds, flapping his wings only when needed—and even then, minimizing the jostle as much as possible. You got splashed around some, sure. But it could’ve been a lot worse. For most of the flight you just soak in the mire of his belly. At the start of your journey, your vision is completely obscured by darkness—leaving only your nose and your ears to paint a picture of your surroundings. But as your journey continued, a peculiar thing happened. You began to see, ever-so-slightly. The darkness was still oppressive, but you could barely make out the rumpled walls of the crow’s belly, the murky soup of his earlier lunch, and the slow churning movements of his stomach at work. The smells of his internal broth still are an offense to your nose, but you grow used to it. And somehow, the scent of digesting birdseed only grows stronger. In a strange way, it reminds you of the collection of birdhouses your grandmother used to have. The kind that drew all the bird Pokemon from all over—of many different colors and sizes. The old memory brings you comfort as you sit there, reminiscing and letting the hours melt away...
1141111212121121132221222112212.title: Black Beak Banquet

choices: You notice the end of his “safety string” melting in Corviknight’s belly juices.
You grab ahold the bug and prepare to be hoisted out of there!
You hear a familiar draining sound coming from the bottom of the crow's belly...
11411112121211211322212221122122.content:
You’re jostled from your thoughts as everything jumps as Corviknight hastily decelerates. You feel you and your literal bird cage touch down on the ground with a hearty pompf!
         You hear Corviknight’s voice, “Ah, Mistress Audino. Please take this young Floatzel to warm bed and treat her to some tea. She has warmed up and is beginning to come to. Tell her that her friend is in safe hands.”
         A chiming voice answers, “yes, Corviknight!” As you hear a puff of labor from the Normal-type as she presumably hefts up Floatzel and carries her away. You lurch as Corviknight takes off once more, flying to another part of the facility. No more than a minute later, you touch down. The contents of his belly settling with a splash and splosh.
         “Corviknight!” You shout, hoping to break through the layers of flesh that separate you. “Is it time?” You don’t even have to specify for Corviknight to catch your drift.
         “The moment I’ve been dreading,” Corviknigh rumbles. You feel the stomach sway side-to-side as the bird begins to walk. “Valiant human, are you familiar with bird Pokemon? Corvids, to be specific.”
         You mutter, “more than you could ever imagine.”
         “Splendid,” Corviknight chirps. “Than you are aware we cannot vomit.”
         You go pale at his words. “Does that mean—” Suddenly the sludge-filled chamber you’re in bounces with Corviknight’s laughter.
         “No! Heavens, I hope not! We’re going to send someone down there to help.”
         “Help me get out?” You feel your heart rate slow down.
         “Indeed. We’re sending our good fellow Joltik down there to help. He will string up a rope of spider silk, journey inside, and rescue you from my dark depths.” Corviknight gives a small crowing chuckle. “And treat the good bug well; it’s his first time on the job.”

         You wait in Corviknight’s churning belly broth for about ten minutes as your practically count down the seconds. Corviknight humors you with some small talk, distracting you from the other unpleasantries of his stomach. You’re in the middle of a conversation over your preferences of medieval swords and shields (which you try to desperately feign interest and knowledge of the subject) when your chat halts and Corviknight addresses someone unseen.
         “Greetings, Joltik. Is our brave spelunker ready to undertake your first quest?”
         A voice, nearly imperceptible, responds. “Why are you calling it that! Don’t call it that! When have you ever called an assignment a ‘quest?’ And 'spelunker?' Gross!”
         You could almost feel Corviknight smile from down there. “It’s just a light joke, Joltik. Your job is as serious as any other.” The muck you’re settled in is washed forward as the body of the massive crow tilts. He must be opening his jaws for Joltik.
         Moments later, you hear a swallowing noise. And after that, you spit-soaked bug plops into your goop-jacuzzi. He doesn’t waste a second before willing his fur to glow a bright incandescent yellow. He looks at you with all four of his blue eyes.
         “Wow. You really are a tiny human! Y’know I used to worry about being stepped on by you all?”
         “Um,” you say. You’re not sure how to take his words.
         “Yeah. I feel that. Big mood.” Joltik says. “Anyhoo, I’m gonna get us out of here. Grab on. Gently, please. Too rough, and I'll zap ya.” Joltik gestures towards his back with a flick of his head. He bobs up and down, floating in the messy substance that surrounds you both.
         You begin to swim towards the fluffy bug when…
11411112121211211322212221122122.title: Bug Buddy

choices: You sacrifice yourself too. You stay with Joltik
You wish Joltik good luck. You cross the sphincter
114111121212112113222122211221221.content:
Swimming through the contents of Corviknight's stomach is difficult. It feels like swimming through quicksand, and in the faint light of Joltik's incandescence, you see the color is close enough. Joltik tries to move towards you, but he doesn't seem to be a very good swimmer, you do most of the job, until you finally grasp the bug's side. Joltik, although bigger than you, is not that big. Your head reaches his eyes' height. It's comforting to be with someone who is almost as small as you.

"Get up there, this is gonna be a ride," says Joltik, sinking a little in the mire to make this easier for you. You grab the fur and hoist yourself up, soon getting to Joltik's back. "Hang tight"

"Sure." there's spider silk looped around Joltik's midsection, so much there's plenty for you to grab, You get your fingers through it, grabbing some of the silk. Much to your surprise, some strands snap under your fingers. That's odd... you thought these were supposed to be tougher than this. A sudden bad feeling invades you. "Joltik, can you turn on the lights a bit more?"

"I guess?" Joltik's fur gets a little tingly, and soon there's more light, enough for you to see around clearly. Corviknight's stomach is large and with a lot of birdseed in it, halfway digested, thanks to all the time you have been there already. You ignore the contracting pouch and focus on the silk. What you see makes a knot in your throat -- the strings seem corroded. You look up, see nothing, and instead notice the safety string is lying against the wall of the stomach. Acidic liquids are dripping on it.

"The silk is breaking down. We have to get out now!"

What you saw fills Joltik with urgency as well. Hurrying as much as he can without jostling you -- a distressingly small speed -- Joltik starts backing up, crawling up the wall by holding the string. Joltik manages to get halfway in direction of the esophagus sphincter when you hear a soft snap.

Next you know, you're splashing in Corviknight's belly juices, with Joltik's light weight above you. It's enough to hold you down for several seconds before you swim away, and when you surface, you hear Joltik is shouting at Corviknight. "--it broke, I see it all dissolving!"

"I still have silk in my beak and throat. Can you reach it?"

"There's none left in here!" he could make more, but without a place to tie it into... "You're the senior here, what do we do?"

You hear the flap of wings outside. "This is unfortunate, but looks like I have no choice. I shall undergo surgery"

"WHAT?!" Joltik shouts surprisingly loudly for a little guy his size. "No, no you won't!"

"It'll be the easiest way for you and the human to get out. The Leavanny will need an hour or two to prepare, but--"

"Don't, please don't! We'll think of something" Joltik pleads. You voice your agreement. Corviknight didn't deserve to undergo such a procedure for your sake. The matter settled, you crawl on Joltik again. He's completely soaked in spit and digested birdseed, but it's still comforting to be on him. "Okay, we need to think of something"

"What about other Joltiks?" you suggest. Everything around you grumbles and shakes, the symphony of Corviknight's body at work is just so loud.

"I'm afraid we have a shortage, human! The one with you is the only Joltik around. That's why I was offering you a job" Corviknight explains.

"E-Enough! Corviknight, please rest. I'll handle this, I promise." you feel Corviknight settle down to wait for you and Joltik to get out. If only the raven could just throw you up...! A couple minutes pass, both of you are thinking as much as you can. Joltik is floating around, letting the stomach's movements push him all over the place. "What a first outing..."

"You just joined them?"

"I arrived a few months ago. There was a lot to learn and memorize before I could start," Joltik says. "My dad and my grandmother and many other generations helped here until they evolved, so it was my turn to do the family tradition. They wouldn't have let this happen to them..."

Oh no. Your bug friend wasn't feeling confident about his job choice. You hope patting Joltik's head isn't too bold, because you do so. "Being inside Pokemon isn't too bad," you tell a white lie. "I have been inside others before this one"

"Really? But you're still alive! I mean..." he looks around. "You know Corviknight's acids are real strong? But you're still intact! You humans are made of tough stuff. I had to get covered in all sorts of things to stop acids. Anyhoo, how did you get out?"

"One time it was like with the spider silk, just that it didn't break. The other time..." you look down towards the surface of the birdseed goop. You very faintly see the outline of another sphincter beneath it all. "...I had to wait for nature to take its course"

"Oh. Ew." Joltik shudders underneath you. He didn't seem eager at all about such option. Big mood. "Let's leave that for plan B. Or maybe even plan C. Any other ideas?" you didn't say anything. Joltik turns his head to look at you. In his eyes, you see so much concern your heart melts a little. "Corviknight has helped me since the start. Honestly I'd rather crawl travel through his guts than let him be under surgery because of me. Please...we have to think of something..." to be honest, you also didn't like the thought of Corviknight doing that.

"Just so you know, I ate at dawn today. If you take too long I'm afraid my body may push things along before surgery preparations can be finished. Can I contact Leavanny already?"

"No!" both Joltik and you shout at once. Corviknight didn't try to convince you again, but his point was clear: take too long and his body would take the decision for you. Suddenly, you get an idea. "Corviknight, you should get on a high place! And then you should tilt your body so the esophagus entrance is closer to us. That way we can crawl up and get the silk in your esophagus!" you propose. Joltik nods with enthusiasm. It could work!

The weightlessness of Corviknight taking flight submerges you and Joltik in the acids for a moment. Outside, Corviknight settles high on the roof of the facility, and slowly tilts his body forward, gripping the edge of the facility with his talons. Slowly, the tide carries you forward. You're hopeful!

Until everything just rushes ahead and slams onto the upper end of the stomach. It all is immediately submerged under a pond of digested birdseed. "It's the shape of his stomach," explained Joltik. "The way out is going to get covered as soon as he tilts enough for us to get there"

"Then don't tilt so much. Corviknight, tilt back!" It takes a few minutes, but between the three of you you finally get the right inclination for the esophageal sphincter to be available. The problem is that it's up an almost ninety-degree climb, too high to reach. "I really thought this would work..."

"It still can. Kinda," says Joltik. Clumsily, he reaches the wall and tests it -- the bouncy and soft wall keep oozing slimes. Joltik can barely get his footing. "...I thought so..." he says. For a moment you thought he'd give up, but then he jumped onto the stomach wall. You hold onto him while he, very slowly, climbs the wall towards the sphincter. You can feel the strain of his bug muscles underneath you, you fear that in any moment he'll lose footing and tumble down into the stomach contents.

It didn't happen, though. With a last effort, Joltik slams a foreleg through the sphincter, forcing it open and eliciting a caw of discomfort from Corviknight. You did it! Joltik's foreleg trembles. "What are you waiting for? Go"

"Wait what?"

Joltik doesn't seem able to smile, but you feel it would if it could. "I won't get a grip enough to get myself out of here, but I thought I should get you out"

"Get me out...?" Then you understand. Joltik had tested the wall and found it was impossible for him to climb it well. Despite that, he had made an herculean effort to make a climb he wouldn't benefit from, all so you'd have a chance to go out. These Pokemon were truly invested in others' safety. It made you feel awfulyou couldn't reciprocate with ease. "But what about you...?"

"I'll be fine. I won't get digested, and I'll think of something else"

"I still can get--"

"Will you can it about your surgery? I'll try anything but that!" Joltik shouts. You feel him slip, until he's hanging by the foreleg in the sphincter. "If I don't think of something I'll just go down the intestines. It's no big deal." he closes his eyes. "I'll...just think of it as a lesson in bird digestive systems"

You doubt he'll last much longer hanging from the entrance to the stomach. You look behind you, through the opening. There's a corroded spider silk some distance up the esophagus, but you think you can reach it. Then you look down at the bug who had come to get you and was pretty much sacrificing himself for your sake.

Apparently the main trait in this Sanctuary place was sacrificing yourself for others. Pretty fitting for a medical center. Corviknight was willing to go through a procedure for you and Joltik's sake. Now Joltik was trying his hardest to get you out cleanly even if he couldn't. Such goodhearted Pokemon...

You take a decision.
114111121212112113222122211221221.title: Stranded

choices: He’s safe, floating on ahead of you. He looks a little disgusted, though.
...He’s gone! You can’t see him! Oh no, is he still in the stomach?
You hear a splash as Joltik crashes into the soup behind you.
1141111212121121132221222112212211.content:
“What are you waiting for?” Joltik whines.. His many eyes are scrunched in concentration. His leg that’s latched on to Corviknight’s esophageal opening quivers, his muscles slowly failing to keep their grip. But you look down at the bug, his fur matted with the bird’s digestive juices—the once vibrant yellow soiled—and give him a solid, steadfast look.
         “I’m not leaving you.”
         Half the bug’s eyes open in strained shock, “no! I’ll be fine! Go!’ He weakly kicks his abdomen up, trying to convince you to leave, as he slowly begins to slip down. You make your choice clear. You let go of the bug’s fluff and plummet back to the bottom of the crow’s belly.
         You glop into the slop that awaits you. Under murky water, you can hear the indistinct, shrill cry of disbelief and surprise as Joltik watches you sink under the surface. Moments later, he lets out a defeated yelp as he loses his grip and tumbles down into the mushy, mashy semiliquid—joining you beneath the surface. Even beneath the squalid tide, you can see his four eyes morph half-lidded into an expression of why??
         You reply with a wink. As much as he wants to hide it, you can see the deep appreciation in his eyes.
         You two, bug and human, break the surface. Joltik sputters something out his mouth as you try and smother your disgust with a smile.
         “Why didn’t you go!?” Joltik grills you. “You could’ve been outta here! Tonight, you could’ve been sleeping in a bed instead of slop! All you had to do was jump!”
         You feel everything shake as the bird outside adjusts his position slightly, shifting in worry. “Is everything alright in there?” The rumble of Corviknight’s voice disturbs the liquid-filled chamber like a miniature earthquake. A serenity suddenly drapes over Joltik’s face.
         “We’re OK, Corviknight.” Joltik eyes you wearily. “The freshie is just real big on the ‘no ’Mon left behind’ thing.”

         It’s been about half-an-hour since Joltik’s arrival. You pass the time chatting with Joltik and pacifying the bundle of nerves that is Corviknight. At the moment, you’re trying to relax—resting your back against the squishy wall of his gut.
         “Perhaps—”
         “No, Corviknight. We’re fine! If I hear you suggest surgery one more time I’ll… spit in your belly.”
         “Joltik, you know that’s unsanitary. Chapter 1, Section 12 of the PMM-V?”
         “...I know! That’s how mad I’ll be if you mention the ‘s-word’ again!”
         A rolling chuckle sends rippling waves through the stew you sit in. “I’m sure you could give me quite the bellyache.” Corviknight seems to have lightened up—at least a little bit.
         “Yup, you know it!” Joltik responds, kicking his legs through the muddy solution in order to keep himself afloat.
         “Although I must warn you: I have a hunch that an upset stomach will be far more unpleasant for you than me, given your whereabouts.” Another deep chuckle.
         Joltik begins to mutter, “at least he’s jolly again.”
         Corviknight hums loudly to himself. “And I’m afraid if I continue to be a worrywart, I really will have an upset stomach.” The crow swallows a deep breath and sighs. “I’ll never stop worrying, but I must quench my fear—at least a little. For your sake.” He caws and chuckles again. From where you are, you can hear the great drum of his heart slow down considerably. It seems the good bird finally got a hold over himself. Joltik swings his look over on to you. His look of exasperation is so plain on his face, that you’re surprised that it isn’t written on it.
         An oh-so-familiar gurgling, draining noise burbles up to your ears. You know it well; any possibility of doubt over what it is rinses away as you notice the muck level lowering. You spy Joltik’s expression of worry as he realizes what’s happening.
         He says in a small voice, “I don’t want to go down there…” It hits you. The bug is afraid. He kept up his mask of confidence for this long, but now it is starting to crack. You swim over to the bug, fighting against the riptide that desires to pull everything to the depths of the Steel-type.
         “Joltik, we have to go.” You say with an intrepidness even you didn’t expect. “If we don’t go now, that antacid stuff you soaked in is going to wear off.”
         “I…” Joltik falters.
         “You’re going to be food if we don’t go now!” Joltik winces at the bluntness of your words, but when his eyes pop back open, the fire of a reluctant determination burns behind them. He dives.
         You follow.
         Instantly, you’re snatched by the undercurrent. You pulled along with the digested gluck, praying Joltik is going along with you. You swirl and spin as you’re jostled along with Honchkrow’s food as you’re sent past the duodenum. You dare to squint open your eyes, but the murky subsurface prevents you from seeing anything but clouded waters.
         Suddenly, you’re shunted into a narrower tube. You flop into a river of the belly’s former contents as more mixtures spills from behind you. You float to the surface and inhale the humid, sultry air of Corviknight’s internals.
         You look around. Is Joltik with you?
1141111212121121132221222112212211.title: You've Got a Friend in He

choices: You wake up in the large intestine
You wake up in the small intestine. Joltik isn't with you
11411112121211211322212221122122111.content:
It doesn't take long for you to see the light coming from Joltik. It's a little bit ahead, thankfully he's floating in the current. You hurry to swim towards your bug friend. Once you reach him, you grab his behind and climb to his back once again. "Here you are," you say. "I'm glad you're safe." He doesn't reply to you. You say something else: "Good thing you float, too"

"...I'm sorry, I just need a moment"

"For what?"

Joltik turns his head towards you. He does look a little disgusted. "This was supposed to be a simple extraction assignment, something that's going to be routine. Now I'm floating in the intestines and I'll be pooped out later." Joltik sighs. "It's not how I imagine my first assignment would go"

You grimace a little. He's right, it's not exactly a pleasant thought. "Look at the bright side: you'll succeed at the extraction, it just...won't be from the end you expected"

"Because you refused to leave when you had the chance!" he said, but then added: "But I guess it's fine. Misery loves company?"

"You said it"

The current around you slows down gradually, until the formerly strong torrent you entered the intestines with was reduced to a more leisure pace. Mangled seeds and oats surround Joltik and you, fresh from the stomach. Everything shakes for a moment, until you hear Corviknight's voice coming from right in front of you. He must be talking to his belly plates. "If I'm not mistaken you both must have left my stomach already. Are you both okay? Is everything intact?" Once you confirmed you were fine and unharmed, Corviknight exhaled. His heartbeat sounded relaxed. "Good. I'm sure you'll be pleased to know you won't be in any danger from now on"

"It just will be gross?" Joltik asked. You were sure that was a rhetorical question -- one Corviknight didn't answer. Avoiding the topic, you noticed.

"So now what?"

"Joltik, valiant human, my body is a carefully calibrated machine. I have established an efficient routine, so you have nothing to worry about. My body will take care of everything" Corviknight returned to his home in the facility, a rather large nest with a neatly measured feeding trough to a side."I see the sky is turning red, meaning by now my morning meal left my stomach. You'll be in my small intestines until around 2AM, when you'll arrive to my large intestine. From there it's six hours more before you reach the end of my digestive tract, before the...the daily voiding of bodily residues at noon"

Voiding of bodily residues. What a wordy way of saying 'shitting'. Joltik and you exchanged a glance. "You're going to make an exception to your routine and letting us out earlier than that, right?"

"Why, of course! I wouldn't let you two stew in my rectum for four entire hours. I imagine going there is unpleasant already," he said before starting his evening meal. You heard the sound of seeds and berries splash in the stomach right above you.

So you got a timetable established. It didn't really matter to you since you didn't have a way to tell time, but you filed that away in your head anyway. Looks like you and Joltik had a long night ahead of you.

"You said you had gone through something like this once. What did you do to pass the time?"

"Try to sleep and be scrunched by my predator's guts"

"That isn't happening to us." He was right. The walls of Corviknight's small intestine weren't even touching you. You chalked it up to the size difference -- Noibat's 1'08" size and Corviknight's 7'03" were too different. "Any ideas to pass the time?"

----------

Somehow, counting villi was almost akin to counting sheep, if sheep emitted gurgles and squelching instead of bleating. Joltik and you were trying to do something else other than stare ahead into the endless-looking fuzzy tunnel of Corviknight's intestine, and the result was that you were both idly counting villi to see how high you could go before losing track of the number.

"3064983..." Joltik mumbled underneath you.

"1632. 1633" you counted, feeling drowsy. The sounds of Corviknight's body at work were oddly calming, if you had to be honest. Maybe it was because you were inside someone you trusted, but it didn't feel like the stressful situation you had the last three times you were inside a Pokemon. You felt the large crow flying around, 'making a last round' before ending for the day. It may have been because you were getting steadily lower into the avian body, but you felt the impact of him landing resonate through the tunnel more than you did before.

"I'm about to retire to sleep. Status report, Joltik"

Joltik lifted a leg, a strand of thick goop sticking to it. "It's almost time" Between the three of you you had agreed a plan of action: as soon as the goop thickened enough, Joltik would try to get ahead as much as possible to avoid getting stuck in fully digested food.
