Corviknight had insisted you and your bug friend had to stay a healthy distance ahead of the meal that had received you, because -- in his words -- "Things can get real vile if you stay in the middle of that". You didn't doubt that.

"I suppose I'll hear from you both in the morning. Don't worry, I'll take the day off to make sure your release doesn't happen away from the Sanctuary." Joltik looked guilty when he heard that. You imagined Corviknight wasn't the kind to take days off at all, and now he had to because of this. "Good luck. May my body treat you well" Soon the breathing slowed down, and the heartbeat acquired a steady rhythm. Corviknight had fallen asleep. Only the gurgling and constant contractions of the intestines around you continued like normal.

Joltik tested the state of the food again. "I'd say this is thick enough. Let's go." you made sure you were gently grabbing Joltik's fur, and the two of you trekked over the slime towards the front. It was going to be a lot of effort, and all of it was going to be done by your bug friend, while you coasted along on his back. "You should catch some zzzzs"

"You sure about that?"

"I'll have plenty of time to rest once we're out. Or once we have to play the waiting game for Corviknight to let us out," he guessed. "Sleep, I'll take care of this".

It was real tempting. You didn't want to, but...the lullaby of Corviknight's organs, the warmth around you, the soft, fuzzy bed you were lying on...it would be nice to sleep. But you couldn't, not when you had to keep Joltik company. Trying to keep yourself awake, you decided to continue counting villi. What number were you at...? Drat, you'd have to start from zero again. One, two, three, four...

You barely reached fifty before you fell asleep.
11411112121211211322212221122122111.title: Not So Bad When There's Company

choices: You find past meals along the way
The path is clean...ish. Could have been worse
114111121212112113222122211221221111.content:
Birdseed, sun, and the sound of wings. Through the foggy haze of your dream, you once again remembered your grandma's birdhouse collection. When you visited you liked to watch the avian Pokemon from the window. Most were small, but sometimes larger ones appeared. Today there were a lot of crows, for some reason. With what seemed to be medieval armor on. Curious about those bird Pokemon, you exited the house, walking towards the birdhouse they were gathering around. You heard noises coming from inside, you entered without much hesitation. You were instantly blasted by an oppressive heat and a stench that almost knocked you out. Just great, you must have wandered into the shed where your grandmother kept the fertilizer. Not wanting to be there, you turned around and exited the birdhouse, but the smell remained.

The pleasant dream vanished away, replaced by the far less nostalgic smell of scat. You opened your eyes, falling to your knees and coughing for a while. It was pretty bad! There still was a faint smell of birdseed in the air, but now it was far heavier with other things, with a stench that threatened to overwhelm you. It takes you a few minutes to gather your wits.

As if the smell wasn't confirmation enough, the wide space all around you proved it: you had arrived into Corviknight's large intestine. You were on the upper part of a slope, and down you could see a large pool of congealing substances, right in front of a ring of tissue. It seemed you were right at the start of the colon. You looked around, wondering where Joltik was, and find him a few steps away. You stagger towards him, trying your hardest to get used to the stench.

Joltik was staring down the colon, as far as his light could reach. The ribbed tunnel ebbed and flowed, inviting you to walk further. You reached Joltik, and pat his side. "Are you okay? Is the smell too bad?"

"...I don't have much of a sense of smell." You sure were jealous of that. It felt like you were never going to get used to the bad air. "It's just that I keep remembering some unpleasant things from my training. It makes me dread going forward"

"Really?" you paid more attention to the tunnel ahead. There were a few thin rivulets of white liquid on the walls, and in other places white powder. Greenish round pebbles littered the way. It...wasn't entirely clean, but it wasn't too bad.

Joltik stepped away from the white liquid. "Most birds, um...they don't have a bladder. Their bodies move liquids upstream for some more absorbtion before it all flows down again for expulsion. In other words, this is...pretty much urine from Corviknight's cloaca"

What a joyful thought. "Oh." If "fun facts" like those were going through Joltik's head you definitely understood why he was so hesitant to continue on.

Joltik gingerly walked forward. "I fear things may get nastier the further we go"

"I suppose there's a risk, but it'll all be over later. We'll be out of Corviknight in just a few hours" you said with more aplomb than you actually felt.

"Then let's get walking. We still have to leave that behind," Joltik glanced at the pool of digested birdseed that had arrived shortly after him, and quickened the pace. Joltik's words kept echoing in your head. Nastier, huh. Could Corviknight have broken his routine even further and tried to make your trek easier by emptying his bowels? Routine was a poweful thing. Although reliable, Corviknight seemed to have been busy with many other things. He may not have thought about that.

You'd find out the deeper you went.
114111121212112113222122211221221111.title: The Anticipation of What's Ahead

choices: "I know that look! That's your I-wanna-work-face. Let's go for a walk, instead."
"After eating that little bit of food? Absolutely not!"
1141111212121121132221222112212211112.content:
There is a saying that no great journey is complete without greater adversity.
         What a load of crow crap. Thank Arceus things aren't as bad as you had feared.
         Joltik is your torch, bringing light to a writhing cave that had only known darkness. His weak glow alights the yuck-stuff that once lurked in the shadows. Thin streams of white flow down the walls like a trailing raindrop on a windshield, oftentimes congealing into a miniature pool on the filthy floor. You spy Joltik very carefully sidestepping as much of the dregs as he can. Teetering and tottering, trying his best not to tumble into his coworker's waste, Joltik finds great relief in that he can mostly avoid dipping his tips in muck.
         You follow in his footsteps. And since you have two less legs than your not-so-jolly co-operant, you're able to stay pretty clean too. That's not to say everything is easy. Corviknight's intestines wrap around his internals like spaghetti around a twirled fork. It isn't long before you find a bend that towers above you like steep cliff face. Climbable, certainly. You have mountain climbed once or twice. Same principle here, really. You just gotta put your hands in the right place. But in here, finding a bad handhold means slapping your hand in crow poop. That's a mistake you are not making.
         All the while Corviknight's sleeping heart steadily beats away. Mixed in with his heartbeat are content coos from the crow, snoozing away—his worries of the world put on ice. His murmurings and chirps saturate the tunnel—almost as much as stench. As you worm your way around a particularly large clumping of waste pellets, you can't help but wonder. Corviknight is in dreamland. He's happy. But he's also unaware: of you. His dreamscape would certainly be a nightmare if his mind is filled with thoughts about your fate. But in this brief moment, he's checked out of reality. Right now, he doesn't even know you're here. He might not even remember you exist.
         A shiver runs down your spine. For a moment, you feel alone.
         But then you see Joltik: squeamishly surveying a pile of Corviknight's refuse. You realize: you're not alone. Joltik risked everything for you. And if you weren't there to spur the bug to move to the intestines…
         Another shudder. You stop that thought-train dead in its tracks.

         The morning sun is shining. At least, you assume so. You haven't a clue of the time, but when you heard the crow drearily rouse awake and stretch his wings—compressing the intestines a bit and shifting things around, sending an unfortunate Joltik tumbling into a small clump of white-brown-green scat—you could wager a guess. Now that the big guy is awake, he doesn't waste a second before bending a beak underwing to address his lower guts.
         "Joltik, Human, I dearly hope everything is okay."
         Joltik looks at you with half-lidded eyes. "You tell 'em, Champ."
         Your couple second delay in answering prompts Corviknight to quickly jab an addendum. "Human? Joltik! Please, please respond! My digestive system is perfunctory, meticulous—ruthless. It could've grinded you to goo, buried you in refuse! No! I dread to think! The clutches of sleep, dragging me into a pleasant dream as my friends were snuffed out within me! O' woe! Great souls, perished alone—dark, afraid; within—"
         "We're okay Corviknight."
         Corviknight stands stock still. Even the undulations of his bowels seem to momentarily freeze.
         "Oh." He says. "That's relieving to hear." You wonder if giant metal-clad birds can get visibly flush.
         "Um," Joltik pipes up, "You weren't serious about the whole 'my guts could grind you into goo' thing, right?"
         The ground beneath you moves in time with Corviknight's uncomfortable shifting. "It may have been an exaggeration." Joltik furrows his brow(s).
         "Uh, you sounded awfully confident that your guts really could do that!"
         "It would bring me great relief if you could cease to remember my outburst." Joltik keeps prying.
         "Is it because you're embarrassed or because that's something you can really do!"
         "...Both."
         "Uh huh."
         "Theoretically, at least."
         "Gotcha."
         "Admittingly, I am unsure. Does this fact bring you solace?"
         "Yeah. Now I know I only have a fifty-percent chance of your bum crushing me into goo."

         You both continue your travels as you rummage through the deepest depths of the bird. You two quickly learn to adjust your pace with the sway of Corviknight's step. The big corvid seems to be walking somewhere. Where, you don't know. To be honest, you wish he stopped. But you don't have the heart to show him your mind.
         You hear a voice from outside.
         "Howdy, Corviknight! How do you do?"
         "Greetings, Mistress Audino." Corviknight greets her. At the moment you're sitting beside a tuckered-out Joltik resting himself on the foul walls. Honestly, you're thinking about petting him. But you're both kinda icky and you're unsure if he'd find the gesture patronizing. Instead, you take your time to observe your surroundings. Things got a little worse, that's for sure. More white urea finds its ways in the rivets of his bowels, mixing with the ever-present waste. It isn't all-encompassing, but there's noticeably a bit more "stuff" than when you first entered.
         Audino's chiming, bell-like voice rings. "Mind if I eat breakfast with you? You always eat alone..."
         "Of course."
         "And take your time, this time!" The Normal-type puffs. "You're always in a rush! You need to slow down. You're in-and-out faster than a Farfetch'd who stumbled in a soup shop!"
         "Well, Mistress Audino, you see I'm quite—"
         "Eat." Audino demands in a twinkling voice. "Slowly."

         Suddenly you hear the clamoring of a rather jubilant Joltik. "Yes! Yes! Yes!" The sounds of the Pokemon's celebratory spark echo from around the intestinal curve in front of you. The passage runs up at a 45-degree angle before bending right and out of sight. Joltik scurries closer to you and pokes his head from over the edge.
         "We're almost out!" He practically sings his words. Despite the bits of filth that accumulated and stained his coat—not to mention the discoloration from the corvid's belly acids—you've never seen Joltik happier. Granted, you've only known him for a bit.
         Joltik looks to you, eyes shining "I see it! The way out!"
         You never climbed faster in your life. And lo and behold, you saw it. The passage dips down once more. A horrid blend of everything you've seen thus far pools within the trough-like chamber. At the end of it all, you see the vent: your wrinkled gateway to freedom.
         But for now, you're staying on the high ground.

         Corviknight feels a subtle tickle in his backside. Worry sprouts in his red eyes. He knows you're at journey's end. He stands abruptly.
         "Mistress Audino, I beg your forgiveness but I must leave immediately." Corviknight says stiffly.
         Audino huffs. "Not on my watch, mister! You haven't eaten half your oats and you haven't even warmed your seat." You groan hearing the Pokemon's words. The sour smell wafting from Corviknight's waste is making your head dizzy…
         "But—"
         "No."
         "Miss—"
         "No!" Audino pouts something fierce. "Everyone here knows you're the hardest working bird in Sanctuary and I will not allow you to spend your one day off acting like you've got someplace to be." Corviknight shrinks under Audino's gaze. She points to the wicker basket of oats Corviknight was eating out of. "Take your time."
         Corviknight gives her an imploring look. When Audino does not relent, he gives a defeated sigh and begins to finish his breakfast. Slowly.

         "So, uh, yeah," Joltik yammers, "this is happening now." You match Corviknight's exasperation with your own. You faintly hear the crunch of the oat-and-seed meal in Corviknight's beak, the squishing of his gulping, and the splash the masticated remains make when it reaches his gurgling tank—hungry for more.
         "Looks like it…" you say. You swear that if it things take too long, you're jumping on Joltik's back and telling him to go and force your ways out.
         But then Joltik says something you didn't expect. "I'm kinda glad this is happening. He doesn't take care of himself. Always worrying about others." Joltik looks wistfully at the exit. "Kinda wish we were a half-hour earlier, though."

         Corviknight gobbles the rest of his meal, beak low, before looking up expectantly at Audino.
         "Mistress Audino?"
         "Yes?"
         "Am I free to be dismissed?"
         Audino hums nonchalantly, looking upwards and tapping a finger to her cheek.
"Hmm…"
1141111212121121132221222112212211112.title: Traveling Through the Knight

11411112121211211322212221122122111122.content:
Corviknight considers himself a rather courageous bird, but right now he sure doesn't feel like it. Audino is kind, but forceful, very forceful. Not only that, she's also someone he greatly respects and wants to please, and even if she wasn't, his cordiality and desire to help makes him not want to rudely turn his back to her to go seek a spot he can finally deposit the passangers he has inside. It's a struggle, battling between the need to help you and Joltik, and the need to listen to someone he respects. His armor had never felt so heavy ever since the day he had evolved, and so hot, too. He couldn't sweat, but he knows he'd be sweating buckets right now if he could!

Inside, his apprehension doesn't go unnoticed. His heartbeat has gone rapid, so much you can feel the vibrations through the wall you sit and lean against of, and the passageway you're in keeps contracting sporadically, in a way that feels unnatural. You feel bad for him, even though you want to be out as soon as possible.

"...is there something wrong?" you hear Audino ask. "Your face looks like a Meowth got your tongue"

"I'm fine. I simply need to take care of something," Corviknight says. He's struggling a little to keep his growing unease out of his voice. Audino notices, she frowns. For a moment she stares at Corviknight.

"...I see what's going on" That's unlikely, you thought. "You asked for a day off, but I'm rather certain it wasn't out of your own volition. Someone asked you to do so." Not entirely inaccurate, but not true either. Joltik seems a little bit worried about this. "You're trying to leave and, once you're out there, you'll work as if it was any other day."

Joltik sighs. "She knows us all too well." Apparently if this were any other situation, Audino may have been right in the money.

"Who is she exactly?"

"Mistress Audino is our leader, but she works along all of us. They say she's as old as time."

Corviknight looks down, ashamed. "That's not true." he says.

Audino pats his chest. "You're hardworking but at this pace you'll burn down under the stress of working. You have to rest and try not to overexert yourself, darling, this isn't good for your health. When I heard you were taking a day off I was very happy, but then I was worried you wouldn't take it quietly. I see my fear was accurate."

"...I'm not sure what to say, Mistress Audino," Corviknight says quietly.

"You don't have to say anything. Here, I want you to take a walk with me. Just give me a minute to get a couple things and we'll go"

Corviknight looks around. A few Pokemon were coming and going, but it was a calm day at the Sanctuary, nothing that'd require Audino to stay around. "But what about Sanctuary?"

"Oh, we'll be fine. We both aren't the only competent 'mons around," she said proudly, pleased, and left the dining room, saying she'd be back shortly. That was the chance, Corviknight thought. He could step outside, get you and Joltik out of his rear end, and be back inside before Audino returned. If he hurried enough he could even apologize profusely to you two for the wait. The large crow had barely stepped away in direction of the outside when a voice called him.

"Excuse me! The knight bird!"

Near you, Joltik slammed the tip of one of his legs to the floor with frustration. "Another interruption?!"

"No, wait, I want to listen." you said, having recognized the voice. Floatzel. The crow also recognized her, so he walked up to her.

"Yes? Have you rested well?"

"I have. Listen, I know you saved my life. I couldn't talk to you along the way, but I wanted to thank you"

"It's no problem! That's what I live for," he boasted, looking carefully at Floatzel. She was in a far better state than the day before, she didn't even have a cold. In fact, she was rather full of energy, raring to go out there and do whatever she wanted. "But be more careful in the future when hiking up the mountains. That was quite dangerous"

"I know," Floatzel said. That was starting to be a sore point. The mention of that brought her to why she wanted to see Corviknight, though. The entire time she had been incredibly worried about the human she had been carrying, and although they told her you were in good hands, she couldn't stop worrying. Did that mean you had almost frozen too? Were you hurt? Floatzel gestured Corviknight to come closer and lower his head, and once he did that, she whispered to him: "I was with...with a very small friend. How are they?"

"They're perfectly well! Despite how I found you, they were healthy and unharmed. In fact, right now they're in the company of one of our bugs. It's routine." he struggled a little to tell half-truths.

Floatzel exhaled, relieved. "Thank you, thank you so much. I hope they're getting a VIP treatment!"

Joltik scoffed, keeping back some laughter of disbelief, while a mound of crow poop brushed you while passing before tumbling down into the growing slop at the rectum and cloaca. This was all as far as it could get from VIP treatment. Corviknight didn't even have the heart to nod at that. The otter didn't notice, she just thanked him again and left towards her room, she still had to rest before she could be let go. Which was good for you, you thought, she wouldn't find out your current location.

The tunnel around you contracted while Corviknight hurried to the entrance, intending to go outside. You held the urge to slam your head against the incredibly gross wall when Audino's melodious voice could be heard.

"I'm ready!" she had returned, carrying the basket again, with a blanket and other things. "Let's go. It's such a nice day, perfect for a day with no work. Aw, don't make that face, this will do you good. Come on, let's go!"
11411112121211211322212221122122111122.title: Corviknight's Day Off

choices: You decide to still seek a way to return to normal
114111121212112113222122211221221111221.content:
You think it's good you can't tell the passage of time. It'd drive you insane.

Until not too long ago Corviknight had walked in a manner that wouldn't jostle those in the innermost parts of his body, out of consideration towards them. Now, thanks to the uphill walk Audino and Corviknight were having, you were wishing you could ask the bird to fly. The tube swung from side to side, like an amusement park ride, with the movement of the crow's legs. Joltik, being the bug he was, managed to cling onto the wall with some effort, avoiding most of the movement, but you were out of luck, sliding from side to side of the edge between the colon and the rectum, like a skater in a half-tube.

Outside, Corviknight was feeling every move you were forced to make. It was like a constant tickling sensation right underneath his feathers, just three inches above his vent. He mentally apologized over and over, and tried not to move too much during the walk. You could see his vent twitching and contracting, it was pretty obvious he was itching to release you and everything else, but simply couldn't.

"I see you have been walking a bit stiff for a while already. Your legs are part of your body too, you shouldn't rely only on your wings," she chimed. Corviknight used to be so eager to walk, apparently he wasn't anymore, she thought.

Inside, you tumbled down the incline and fell into his rectum, crashing against the latest pile of crap that made the fall. The mass stopped your descent, but it still was pretty unpleasant to get so acquainted with the bird's waste. Telling yourself this wasn't Corviknight's fault, you got away from the poop, climbing the slope again, to where Joltik was waiting. "That looked nasty"

"I don't want to talk about it"

It took a couple hours to arrive to where Audino was taking him, but when they finally stopped, Corviknight felt calmness when he saw where they were. In front of them there was a large expanse of soft grass, dotted with flowers and berry trees, as far as the eye could see. Several rocks made small plateaus, a stream of water crossed the place. The air was clean, invigorating. The idyllic landscape almost made him forget about his worries -- he recognized where he was.

The wistful look in his eyes didn't go unnoticed to Audino, who had spread the blanket to sit on it. "I thought you'd like to come here." Slowly, since he still had the presence of mind to remember Joltik and you would want reprieve, he approached, folded his legs, and settled beside Audino.

---------

The air was far less invigorating inside the avian large intestine. Even though you had been in such area of Corviknight for hours, you still weren't getting used to the awful smells, especially when more and more of the cause of it was getting piled right where you could see it. The urea dripping slowly from a hole you could see from the ceiling hadn't stopped, either, and the volume of the revolting mixture had been increasing very slowly, the shore being mere millimeters away from you.

Despite all that, you were calm now.

Having nothing to do but wait, and having stayed awake the entire night -- half of it carrying you on his back -- Joltik decided he needed a nap. He had approached you and turned into a fuzzy ball near you, and it didn't take long before he settled right to your side, lying his head and half of his body against you, a very slight electrical current making you tingle. He was sleeping placidly, like he was back home. You liked to think it was thanks to you, it was obvious Joltik really liked your presence.

You had never been particularly appreciative of Bug Pokemon, but you were growing rather fond of Joltik.

You laid your head against the wall, staying still as much as possible, not only because Joltik was using you as a pillow, but also because of the conversation outside.

"Do you remember this place?"

"It's been ages, Mistress Audino." he remembered that place very clearly. It was like a secret grove, hidden away in the mountains, untouched by humans and Pokemon. A long time ago, Audino had taken him there, the day after he had joined Sanctuary. To tell the truth, Corviknight had completely forgotten this place existed. Coming back was like a dream.

Audino smiled. "Back then you were such a young bird, even shorter than me, and if I may say it, quite rude. I brought you here so you could see my favorite place, and you had in your eyes that same awestruck look you have right now.

Look at yourself now, you're so tall my neck hurts when I look up to you, and you have turned into quite the gallant Pokemon"

A drop of white liquid fell on your head. You still didn't move at all. You felt like you were intruding in a meaningful moment, and you feared moving too much would break the spell and make Corviknight go away.

"It hasn't changed a bit since the last time you were here, has it?"

"Not at all..." he sounded so melancholic. You swear you could hear his voice strain. Surely he was teary-eyed.

"Corviknight, I just wanted to tell you how proud I'm of you. I'm not the only one, we all are very proud of you. You're so hardworking and caring, and a wonderful friend. Frankly, if you had some medical knowledge, you'd be perfect to be my successor someday. Alas." Audino put a hand on the connection between Corviknight's leg and his body. That was as high as she could reach from where she was. "But don't go learn medicine just because I said that. You're perfect as you are"

"Really...?"

"We all appreciate you so much, and everyone who joins Sanctuary adores you. I don't think you know how much they look up to you"

So that was why she was so insistent. She was very concerned Corviknight was overworking himself, and wanted to take a moment to tell him how much he meant to her and everybody else -- and to stop being a workaholic because that wasn't good for his health. He felt a knot in his throat, he didn't know what to say other than thank you. It was nice to know he was appreciated.

Audino looked up at the sky from between the trees. "My, compared to yesterday it's turning hot. I say it's time for lunch. Would you like a bite, Corviknight?" Eating was the last thing in his mind right now. He shook his head. "Okay, but you should start eating three small meals a day instead of two large ones. That'll be healthier for you"

Three meals...eating lunch...suddenly Corviknight whipped his head skywards, trying to find the sun. There it was. Rather high in the sky. What it all meant hit him immediately: noon.

As if on cue, the entire tube you were in contracted almost painfully. The walls mashed you forward, throwing Joltik and you to the floor. You saw the rectum twitch and compress. The sludge you could see was more solid than liquid, and now it was all making its presence known to Corviknight. It was a sensation he was familiar with, and he knew immediately what it was. Excusing himself, Corviknight bowed his head. "...I'm sorry, I have to take care of something"

"Of course, go ahead. I know you wouldn't leave me stranded in the middle of the mountains," Audino winked, having ensured that way he wouldn't go work on his free day. A bit surprised at her clever craftiness, Corviknight hurried away. He had to look for a spot to deposit everything.

On the way, he apologized over and over: "My most sincere apologies, Joltik and human, I'm so sorry. It wasn't my intention to leave you inside me for so long -- and at a time like this! I'm so mortified you must be..." he couldn't bring himself to say with words the state of your surroundings. "Hold tight, I'll make something to cushion your departure," he said, starting to work on a nest of sorts once he found a secluded enough spot.

Inside, everything was quivering in preparation for release. Not wanting to get too close to the rest of the waste, you stepped back and looked down to the other side. There still was some crap coming your way, but most of the meal you had fallen into a day ago was already awaiting release in the rectum. That was one concern less.

"...you know, she's right." Joltik suddenly said. You hadn't noticed he had been awake for a while already. "We all like Corviknight. You...you're not holding this whole thing against him, are you?" he asked. "You know this was all out of his control?"

"Of course I don't"

Joltik nodded. "Good. By the way, welcome to our team"

You looked away. "I...I'm still not one of you guys..."

"But you will be, right?"

It was very tempting. You had a very large friend in Corviknight and a much smaller one in Joltik, a place to be at, and something to do, even if it wasn't a profession you really were looking forward to. If you couldn't return to normal, then this was a good as it could get.

But what if there was a way to return to your normal size? That question still existed.

Joltik looked at you expectantly, so you finally took a decision.
114111121212112113222122211221221111221.title: Appreciation

choices: Sneak to river, wash off, and attempt to follow Corviknight and Audino.
Venture on ahead and try to make it back to Sanctuary yourselves.
Hide here and wait for Corviknight to return.
1141111212121121132221222112212211112211.content:
“Joltik,” you say to the soiled bug, “I’m… not quite sure…”
         Joltik immediately grows crestfallen. His black pupils begin to wiggle as eyelids droop into a sorrowful expression. “I… getcha. You don’t have to, really—”
         “...But I’m making the choice anyway.” You slap on your serious face and lock in your answer. “I’m staying.”
         You see a spark of joy flitter behind his glass-blue eyes. His little mandibles open in surprise as his matted fur suddenly stands on end: shooting up due to excited burst of static electricity. “R-really? You’re staying? In Sanctuary—with us!?” He raises his thorax in the air and wriggles it in excitement. “Woohoo! Yeah!” Joltik whoops in thunderous joy. You couldn’t suppress the smile snaking up your face if you tried.
         “This is the best moment of all time!” Joltik proclaims to the denizens of Corviknight’s bowels. But just as he’s coming down from his happy high, his oval eyes become round and his pupils grow large. You open your mouth to ask what’s wrong when a contracting wave of Corviknight’s bowels surges past. The undulation sweeps the ground from under you, sending you plapping to the grimy floor. Before you could even mutter a curse, you find out what made him go wide-eyed. A mass of bird poop, carried by the undulations of his intestines, plows into Joltik and sends him reeling into the foul cesspool. Before he can gather his bearings, Corviknight’s rectum collapses violently as he begins to rid himself of the accumulated scat. The small opening above the pool unleashes a deluge of pale horribleness. You wince so hard you think you fear your face is going to stick like that.
         Another ripple wracks the crow’s colon. Barely keeping your balance, you peer down into the rectum. You frightfully scan for Joltik, but in your rush you can’t seem to find him. You only see the pit of filth, semisolid and absolutely vulgar.
         “Joltik!” You shout as one more undulation flows past. Your heart leaps through your chest as you see the manure level rapidly drop as Corviknight’s machine-like system voided the waste with frightening efficiency. Only a couple seconds have passed and almost all the waste is entirely expulled. Once more, you risk a glance behind you. Nothing’s behind you: only the filth-streaken walls. You come to a heart-pounding realization: if you don’t jump now, you’re not coming out until noon tomorrow.
         You never made a faster leap of faith. You rocket from your perch like a tensed-up spring. Your arms spin in circles as you legs dangle, hurtling through the heavy rotten air. As you fall, eyes watering, you vaguely hear the muted sounds of Corviknight’s waste splattering upon the ground. And of course, you’re fast approaching the tailend of the moat of scat. You wish you could say something cheeky about this being a “crappy” experience—or some such—but you haven’t a moment to think before one last contraction bears in, mashing you in midair. You’re propelled forward by the muscles careless movements. As you near the mucky abhorrence, you shut your eyes and plug your nose. You’re fearing the worst.
         But fortune smiles upon you (for once.) The disgusting scat ahead of you is voided milliseconds before you collide into it. The sweltering, oppressive internal heat of the bird is swapped by the cool pastoral air as you pass through the opening of Corviknight's vent. You dare to open your eyes, gritting your teeth and powering through the sun’s burning sunlight. You see that you’re still sailing through the air. You catch sight of the pile of Corviknight’s waste waiting below and desperately twist yourself to the left, hoping to nudge your trajectory out of the danger zone. Your fortune continues to be true and you bellyflop in a pile of grass and leaves with a puff.
         Your landing is cushioned by the knight-raven’s jumbled-together nest, but the impact still knocks the wind out of you. You lay there, dazed, when a great shadow eclipses the sun and a greater voice speaks above.
         “Ah! The human’s okay! But Joltik—where’s Joltik!? Joltik!” Corviknight shouts the world’s loudest strained whisper. It’s only matched by the world’s tiniest wail of disgust.
         “BLEEEECCCCHH!” You hear the plop of something erupting from Corviknight’s remnants. “Get me out! Get me out! Get me out!!” Joltik bawls. Corviknight panics, hopping in place, dancing in confusion.
         “I don’t know what to do! My—ah—ahah!” Corviknight snatches a twig with godspeed and begins to try and fish Joltik out. “Grab on!” Corviknight says with muffled words and a full beak. Joltik doesn’t waste a precious second before scurrying over and latching onto the stick with all four legs. Carefully depositing the pint-sized Pokemon in the clean grasses, Corviknight relaxes and holds his head in shame.
         “I am repentant beyond calculable caliber.” Corviknight chokes. “I can’t express how horrible I feel having forced you into this mess…” You look over to Joltik, who's looking quite shell-shocked at the moment, and decide that it’s best if you do the talking.
         “Don’t beat yourself up, Corviknight.” You say. “You tried to help. You did everything you can. If it wasn’t for you, Floatzel and I would’ve been ice cubes.”
         Corviknight lifts his head slightly. “But I had to ability to prevent all of this! If only I had underwent surg—”
         “Don’t you dare say the ‘S’ word!” Joltik suddenly snaps from his stupor. Even Corviknight looks at him with surprise.
         “Well,” he says, “it fills my heart with joy to see you both okay.” He coughs quietly and lowers his voice a bit more. “But we have another problem. I’m on an outing with Audino and I can’t leave her!” He swivels his head quickly from Joltik to you. “And her dainty little nose is going to sniff you out if the wind so happens to blow vaguely in her direction.”
         Joltik wrinkles in worry. “So what are we gonna do?”
         Corviknight ruffles. “You could say you have two options.”
         You look at him in abject disgust.
         Corviknight stare back horrified. “No, not those options! These are different options. Options that do not involve putting you in me.” Corviknight calms himself. “There’s a stream near here. Go there, wash off, and follow behind me 100 paces back. Audino and I will be leaving soon, and you will tail our trail.”
         “Alright,” Joltik says, “and what’s the second option?”
         Corviknight rumbles in thought. “You two could always go on ahead. Joltik! Are you aware of Sanctuary’s position from here?”
         “Nada, coach.”
         “Hmm... Well, try to follow alongside the river. It’ll be slightly longer journey, but you’ll find yourselves close enough to Sanctuary you’ll be able to find your way back.”
         “Or…” Joltik begins. “We could stay right here and wait until you walk back Audino, and you fly here to pick us up!"
         “Do you know how long you’ll have to stay here! How dangerous that would be?”
         You pipe in, “and walking back ourselves isn’t dangerous?”
         “Well…” The corvid trails off. “Fine! Do whatever you wish.” He looks over his wings hastily. “But I must really get going. I fear Audino is growing suspicious!”
         The yellow bug points himself toward you. “Y’know, I’m not cut-out for this decision-making stuff. I’m gonna leave that up to you.”
         So, what is your choice?
1141111212121121132221222112212211112211.title: Out the Bird, In the Sanctuary Club!

choices: A Pokemon for Joltik to feast on!
1141111212121121132221222112212211112211.content:
You were going to be the one making a choice. While you didn't like how you got the responsibility thrown on you, you couldn't back off. You had to decide. "Uh, I think we should get going. If we stay around Audino could find us and that's going to be hard to explain"

"Are you sure about this?" Corviknight wondered.

"Surely we'll be fine if we mention we work at Sanctuary. Nobody would harm 'mons who work so everyone is healthy" you were inclined to agreeing with Joltik, mostly because you wanted to believe that was true.

Since he had to return to Audino, the large bird had no choice but to allow this. After again giving you instructions to follow the river, he flapped his wings and flew some distance away, to where Audino was still waiting. You were on your own.

Once you reached the river, Joltik and you decided to take a pause to wash yourselves up -- or more like you scrubbed all the filth off Joltik once you were done with yourself. Joltik was barely bigger than you but it still took you a while because you wanted to do a good job, erase any trace the both of you had passed through that bird's digestive system. The only hint such a thing happened was the discolored fur on Joltik. "That's much better!" he sighed with relief. "Are you ready for the trek back?"

"I sure am. Let's get going"

-----------

Going downhill was easier than you thought it'd be. Your size wasn't nearly as big of an obstacle as you thought it'd be, Joltik and you managed to walk at a good pace. The very peaceful and unhabitated grove Corviknight and Audino had stayed at was soon left behind, replaced by a mountain that was definitely the home to countless Pokemon. You could hear the noises of unknown Pokemon wandering around, thankfully nothing engaged you.

"When you can zap something's insides they tend to not prey on you" had said Joltik at some point. You were glad your friend had a way to defend himself, at least.

Still, despite how well the trek was going, the distance was the biggest problem. That grove had been up a mountain, while Sanctuary was at the bottom, and you were pretty sure the path you were taking wasn't the shortest one. It was matter of time before the both of you started feeling the effects of the walk.

"I'm hungry" Joltik mumbled. You could faintly hear his tummy rumbling. "I haven't eaten anything for almost an entire day..."

Although you knew Joltik would never do such a thing to you, for a moment you were glad you were far too big for the bug to eat. "That's going to be a problem." You were trying very hard to ignore that you were hungry too, having eaten nothing for far more than a day. Last you ate was before Floatzel and you went to climb a mountain. You were surprised you still could walk!

"Do you have anything to eat?"

"Clearly not! I'd have offered you food if I had any"

Joltik stopped, looking at your head. "You have hair. Maybe there's some static in it. Mind if I...?" Static? Ah, right, you remember hearing something about this species consuming static. You weren't going to miss any static electricity on you, that was for sure. Once you told Joltik that, his mood seemed to brighten a little. "Alright, sit down and don't move. This will take just a moment!"

"Okay..." you obey, sitting down.

"This is going to be really weird for you, I guess, but thanks anyway" That wasn't really what you wanted to hear! But it was too late, you had accepted to provide Joltik with whatever static you had on you.

Joltik approached you slowly, moving until he was right beside your head. It was really odd to be seeing your friend's head from the ground, an expanse of yellow fluff. The mandibles were at the front, very visible given your position, and right behind them, a rather unpleasant-looking hole. How many had seen a Joltik's mouth from so close? You weren't sure it was much of a honor. The bug positioned his mandibles right against your scalp. You didn't feel anything, but it really was weird to have the tips of the mandibles brushing against you.

The process took just a few seconds. "You full?"

"No, not at all. There was almost nothing on you" Joltik said sadly, stepping away from you. "You have almost no fur, any Pokemon with fur on them would have so much static on them..."

You weren't exactly eager to approach a random giant Pokemon, even if it was for Joltik to feed. "Can't you eat anything else? Like...grass? There's plenty here"

"Of course I can eat food! If we find berries we will be just fine. You look pale, they'd be good for you too"

Great. A reminder you weren't looking too great right now. "Let's see what we can find around here" you say, looking towards the side. Looking for food would mean going away from the river you were following, but surely that would be no problem, right? You should be able to find it again and continue your trek. Right?

...you really hoped so.

Joltik and you wandered away from the river, going towards other parts of the mountain. You kept your eyes wide open, scanning the area to see what you could find. Anything that could feed Joltik would be nice. You didn't really think much about food for yourself, you were more worried for your bug friend.

It took a while, but soon you stumbled upon a solution
1141111212121121132221222112212211112211.title: The Journey Back

choices: Another Pokemon has entered the cave
114111121212112113222122211222.content:
You had faith in Floatzel's skills, but it didn't stop you from worrying. If something happened to her because she's trying to help you...you don't know what you'd do. Floatzel keeps going, while you start feeling the bite of the cold from your vantage position. All the time you're crossing your fingers, pleading silently. 'Please don't fall, please be okay, you can do it', you kept repeating.

Every minute seemed eternal because you kept feeling like Floatzel was about to collapse from the cold. That was why, when Floatzel suddenly hastened her pace, you knew something was up. "There's the cave! We're here!" she said. The burst of relief you felt was unlike anything you had ever felt in your life. She had done it!

Floatzel wasted no time in getting into the cave. Above you the peak of the mountain loomed, like an ominous guardian, and the inside of the cave was illuminated by a large collection of crystals, both growing from the walls and seemingly brought from somewhere else. Floatzel slumped over against a wall, taking deep breaths. She deserved a break, after all the effort she made.

"Visitors?"

From the depths of the cave came a Pokemon. You peered from over Floatzel's flotation device, immediately noticing that Pokemon was definitely not a Xatu. It wasn't even a bird. That was a bear, black and white, almost touching the roof of the cavern. The shoot in their mouth was the confirmation you needed, you remembered hearing about a Pokemon that had that. Pangoro.

Pangoro stopped, surprised. "...you?"

"You!" Floatzel shouted, elated. Without warning you, she bolted forward, running on all fours until she leaped at Pangoro, clinging onto his torso and mushing you against coarse white fur. "I thought you had gone far, far away!"

"I have been here for a while. Xatu lets me stay while I train in the area."

"You should have told me! I'd have come to visit you!" You knew you were definitely missing something here. Floatzel, remembering you were there. Carefully, she took you on her paw, showing you to Pangoro. "Human, this is my friend! I told you about him, we used to play when we were younger!"

Pangoro got his head closer to you to take a better look. He was so close you could see his eyes amidst the dark semicircles on his face. "That looks like a human, and a very small one at that."

"It's a long story," you say. Floatzel clearly trusted Pangoro, if she was showing you like that, so you decided to trust him.

Floatzel and you explained your situation, although you didn't go into much detail about your unfortunate trips inside Pokemon. All you did was mention it had happened and that you had come out of them alive -- you wanted him to know you wanted to return to normal, and that you and Floatzel thought Xatu could help. That was the important part, you remarked it over and over. Pangoro listened patiently, sitting on the floor of the cave. Once you were done, the bamboo shoot in his mouth moved around while he chewed on the end, before he reached for a rather colorful and tiny crystal lying nearby. "Xatu had to fly somewhere and should return in a couple days. That said, I believe I know what happened." He showed the crystal. "Have you seen these before?"

"No, never"

"Xatu says these crystals are full of strange energy. When the crystal breaks, the energy is liberated, and if it reaches any being nearby..." he pointed at you with a claw. "...this happens."

Finally, an explanation! "Okay, what's the solution?"

"Time. The effects are temporary. The bigger the crystal, the more it'll last."

"It's been a few days already"

Pangoro exhaled noisily. "It must have been a rather large crystal, most likely underground. There's nothing you can do but wait for the effects to wear off" This brought you a lot of happiness. You didn't have to do anything, just wait for the energy to dissipate! But you had quite the curious feeling: that there were still many, many days of having a small size ahead.

Floatzel took the crystal, looking at it with curiosity. There was a glint in her eyes you weren't sure you liked. "You said the effects are temporary?"

"A crystal that size should make the size last from eight hours to one day"

"Interesting...!"

Pangoro stood up, beckoning Floatzel and you towards the far end of the cave. There you could see a rather cozy fire, and a fluffy couch. "Since you two climbed this mountain I think you should rest for a while. Human, if you'd like to, you could talk to Xatu when she returns." May as well do so, since you were here, you decided. Floatzel put you on one end of the couch and curled on the other end, pleased as punch. With a toothy grin, she beamed at you.

"I told you everything would be fine! We got up here, and now you know you'll be okay!"

"I should have never doubted you," you admit.

"And I got to see an old friend again!" she glanced at Pangoro, who had gone to make sure the campfire would last for a while longer. "You know, he and I were about to be more than friends, but then he decided to leave. Now look at him..." she winked. "He has turned into quite the handsome 'Mon, hasn't he?"

You looked at Pangoro and shrugged, noncommital. You sure didn't know how to judge a bear's supposed attractiveness. Still, you were grateful for his help. Content, you laid on the couch, soothed by the warmth of the cave and the softness of the couch.

You don't know when exactly you felt asleep, but now you're waking up. You don't feel particularly rested, so you deduce you have been roused by something. Soon you know what it was: voices. Rubbing your eyes, you jump from the edge of the couch to the rock floor and slowly approach the source of the voices.
114111121212112113222122211222.title: Reliable Old Friend

choices: Pangoro positions his hand against his rear, like Floatzel said
Pangoro moves his hand somewhere else, Floatzel was bluffing
Pangoro moves his hand to the ground, having second thoughts
1141111212121121132221222112222.content:
You can see Pangoro and Floatzel beside the bonfire, talking. Their voices are quiet, most likely out of consideration for you. From where you are you can see Pangoro is sitting on the ground, with Floatzel sitting on his lap. You barely manage to glimpse a shiny, colorful object in one of her paws -- the crystal Pangoro had showed you earlier. "...eight hours should be enough."

"I'm not sure about this."

"Oh, come on! Try to see it as I do: this could be the adventure of a lifetime for me. How many Pokemon can say they have been inside another, without being prey?" You feel your blood go cold when you hear that. Floatzel isn't saying what you think she's saying, right? Pangoro glances towards the couch. You're not sure if he noticed you're not there anymore.

"The human didn't seem to have liked it at all."

"I can't blame them. They didn't ask to be small, or be eaten by anyone. That's the difference, I want to go through this willingly. I'm a explorer, and now I have the means to go into uncharted territory." Floatzel clutched the crystal. "But honestly I wouldn't dare to do this with anyone except you. I'm doing this only because I'm with you. I trust you."

You're rather sure that underneath the black and white fur on his face, Pangoro is blushing. "Really?"

"Of course. What do you say? Will you let me?" you waited, hoping Pangoro would refuse. He did seem hesitant. "Imagine it, Pangoro. I could enter your mouth, and then I'd jump down your throat into your stomach with a perfect 10 landing."

"Hm." Pangoro gulped involuntarily. Floatzel continued:

"Or maybe I could go into you through the other end." She tried to grab Pangoro's butt, but from where she was sitting, all she managed to do was put her paw on his hip. "You have quite the great ass, did you know that?"

"That's very daring of you..." Pangoro sounded intrigued, much to your disappointment. He was letting himself be convinced of this madness!

Floatzel smirked. "Or, if I'm small enough, maybe I could try some...bolder entrances..." Pangoro inhaled sharply. You didn't see it well but you're almost certain she just brushed his crotch with her tails, the implication quite clear. You wanted to go there, tell her to change her mind, but your own curiosity kept you rooted where you were standing. You wanted to see where this was going. "I could even try your nose, or your ears."

"You have given this a lot of thought already."

"I guess I have," she admitted. No wonder she had seemed so interested in the crystal. "Pangoro, you're like...like a big, furry cave system, and I want to see what's inside it. You're the only one I'd feel comfortable doing this with. But of course, if you don't want to accept, I'll understand," she smiled. "At least you listened to this crazy idea I had."

Pangoro was silent for a moment. You held your breath, hoping to hear a negative response. There was no way Pangoro would accept being the host for Floatzel's curiosity, right? "Fine. I'm willing to do it." You held back the impulse of shouting into your hands. You couldn't believe this! "But what the human? They'll want to know where you are"

"Oh..." For a moment you see guilt on Floatzel's face. She shakes her head, steeling her resolve. "Just tell them I went down the mountain, and that I'll be back after a while. I don't think they'd approve of what I'm doing--"

"Obviously I don't!" you didn't notice you had actually yelled that until the Pokemon turned their heads towards you. Spurred by the surprise in their faces, you stomp towards them, indignant and baffled. "I can't believe you're actually thinking of doing this!"

"I knew you wouldn't get it..." she murmured. "I just want to go where no Pokemon has gone before, that's all"

"Floatzel, it's not fun to be inside another living being. Take it from me, it's not nice at all."

"I know that! Look, I'm prepared. I just want to give it a try. The crystal is temporary, I'll be fine"

"What if something happens to you? It can be dangerous inside a Pokemon!" you argue. Pangoro's shoot moves from side to side of his mouth while he mulls what you just said. "I almost got digested, remember?"

"My fur is rather dense and I'm sturdier than you think," she replied.

Pangoro put a hand on Floatzel's head. "They're right. This is dangerous." Yes! you thought, hoping Pangoro had changed his mind. When he looks at you you know he wasn't done talking. "I'm not letting you unless they come along."

"What?" Floatzel sounded so disappointed. Ignoring her, Pangoro addressed you.

"You have experience inside Pokemon and you got out of them alive. You said that earlier. I want you to help her be safe."

Your immediate thought is to reject that, but then you saw Floatzel and her expression of complete determination. You knew: she'd sneak inside Pangoro later if you refused to come. Either you went with her right now, or she'd go by herself later. Besides, you owed Pangoro a favor. You could repay it by keeping Floatzel safe -- and not only that, you also wanted her to be okay. She's your friend, after all.

Sighing, you nod. "Alright. I'll go with her."

Floatzel's face showed both surprise and frustration. Looking at you with disapproval, she stands up, managing to reach Pangoro's ear, and whispers into it. Pangoro nods, hems and haws, and finally stands up as well. "Let's get this done." he says. Agreeing, Floatzel steps away from him, holds the crystal with both of her paws, and snaps it.

The effect is almost immediate. You have to avert your eyes at the sudden onslaught of light, but when you look again, you see Floatzel. She's just as small as you are. Floatzel looks around with interest, marveling at the sight around her. "This is amazing! Pangoro, you hear me? I'm ready!"

Pangoro's ears twitch while he puts his clawed hand on the ground, palm up. Floatzel wastes no time getting on it. You follow her reluctantly, climbing the paw, until you manage to get to the surface. Floatzel is already waiting, sitting on the pad of his palm. Once you're with her, Pangoro raises his hand, until it's to his chest level.

"Human, this is your last chance to change your mind," Floatzel says, and leans toward you with a sly smirk. "I already told Pangoro where I wanted to go."

"Yeah?"

"I have decided to explore the insides of his butt."

You groan. For a moment you wonder if your presence is precisely what made her take such a decision. You look at Pangoro. He has a carefully neutral expression. "Are you serious?"

"Oh yes. Pangoro is going to get his hand close to his anus, and then we will climb into it by ourselves. Can you picture it? We will make our way into Pangoro's ass!" she grins toothily, and then you realize what she's doing:

She's trying to make you decide to not go. She knows you're not eager to go inside Pangoro in the first place, so she decided to go into an area she imagines you'd like to avoid. You weren't going to give her the satisfaction: "I'm coming along anyway."

Floatzel snarls, and raises her voice somewhat. "I'll let you know Pangoro is infamous for being unhygienic!"

"Excuse me? That cannot be true!" Pangoro sounded rather offended by that. Floatzel must have been rather desperate if she resorted to slander.

"And-And did you know bear stool is as goopy as syrup? If you step on it, you'll sink right to your neck. Gross, ain't it?!"

"Now that I know isn't true at all. The bamboo sometimes makes it all so dry I get constip--"

"I said I'm coming along!" you shout, cringing at the excess of information Pangoro just gave you. Gathering all of your courage, you face Floatzel: "I'm not changing my mind no matter what you say. I'm going with you, and that's that."

Floatzel huffs, staring at you carefully for any signs you were wavering, but you refused to let any doubts show on your face. Not when it meant losing face. After a few seconds of daunting staring, she sighs, admitting defeat.

"Alright. I never thought we'd do this together, but since you want to come..." she looked up, at Pangoro's face, and settled on the pad of his palm. "I'm ready. Get us to the entrance point."

"Let's go." you agreed. Pangoro sighed, but it had to be done. With a swift move, he moves his hand.
1141111212121121132221222112222.title: Explorer Fever

choices: Pangoro’s colon is clean—for a butt, atleast.
Before you could get a glimpse, the Light Ball flickers out.
11411112121211211322212221122221.content:
Cradled in his careful claw, Pangoro moves his paw downward. You mumble near-silent grumbles as you pass by his mountainous white belly, flying past and behind. You flank behind, leaving behind the forest of white belly hairs before moving under the shadow of his black fur cape. The warmth of the fire is replaced with that of Pangoro’s body as you hover around where the two tones of his fur meet. The pleasant smell of firewood mingles with another. You’re close enough now that the panda’s scent prickles your nose. It isn’t a bad smell. It smelled like a freshly-groomed animal—a natural musk with an earthen detail. You aren’t particularly moved by the scent, but when you turn your head to Floatzel, you catch her swooning—breathing deep with closed eyes and relaxed shoulders—awash with nostalgia and amour.
         You watch as Pangoro takes a knee, his massive weight sends a rippling shockwave through his fur. He follows it up with the other before resting his left hand on the cave floor, propping himself up in a three-point stance. He continues to crane his claw lower, hauling you to the “entry point.”
         Pangoro’s black bottom is all you can see. You feel your belly do a little leap. You realize Floatzel wasn’t completely insincere.
         Floatzel picks up your growing apprehension. “Having second thoughts, are we?” She slaps on a casual look as she cooly looks away, “you’ve still got a chance to back out!” She says quietly, almost mockingly. "I won't judge. If I were you, I wouldn't want to go up Pangoro's stinky behind either."
         You wipe away your trepidation. “I’m not leaving.” Floatzel responds with an exasperated sigh and a click of her tongue.
         The sky is now black, enshrouded in Pangoro’s cloak and painted with the furs of his butt. You both are sent closer—the musk of his scent growing stronger—until you could reach out and grab one of the countless hairs of his pelt. Hiding behind the ebon thicket, lurking abaft the panda’s asscheeks is the sight you’ve been dreading: the Pangoro’s puckered exit, your entrance.
         His paw lifts you a little higher, inching closer to the dark band of muscle. A gasp of disgusted fear claws up your throat and nearly breaks free, but you grit your teeth and chew it back down. You will not let your disgust get the best of you! You can’t wimp out now!
         Floatzel saunters up and past you, speaking with a slight waviness in her voice. You knew it isn’t from fear. “O-oh my…” She whispers through her teeth. She steps forward onto the tip of Pangoro’s paw, reaching out a paw of her own—gently resting it on the ursine’s tailhole. Pangoro breathes sharply, the pudgy muscle recoiling slightly.
         “Settle down, Pangoro…” she says with an unmistakable sultriness. Is she really getting her jivvies off to this!? Somehow, you find that more disturbing than upcoming trek into the panda’s butt. You turn your head and gag. Floatzel doesn’t notice.
         With a dextrous slip of a paw, Floatzel slides her hand inside. Pangoro tenses, careful to not clamp down on Floatzel’s paw. After a tense moment of stillness, Floatzel smooths her limb in up to the shoulder. She flicks her head back to you.
         “It’s real nasty in there.” She says. “You’re gonna hate it. Trust me. 10,000%.” You might’ve taken her words more seriously if she wasn’t blushing brightly behind her cream cheek-fur. When she sees that you’re not budging, she turns away and faces the bear’s exit once more. She sticks her other paw in, prompting a small groan from Pangoro, and bravely shoves herself in. You follow with repugnant curiosity as Pangoro grumbles a deep belly-moan as his tailhole tightens, nibbling on Floatzel’s body as it slowly draws her in—her twin tails spinning in excitement. You bite your lip as you walk closer, watching as her friend is drawn deeper inside, slipping past the bundle of black flesh. Soon, she’s nearly consumed. Her tails stop spinning as the asshole’s flesh clamps down upon them before slurping them in like two orange noodles.
         Now only you remain. Staring down at Pangoro butt-to-face, you roll your shoulders and pump yourself up. It’s gone beyond making sure Floatzel stays safe in the wretchedness of Pangoro’s innards. Now, it’s personal. You are not going to let her psych you out. You would never hear the end of it!
         You’re there: balancing on the tips of Pangoro’s mitt and engaged in a staredown with his wrinkled eye. You don’t look away as you stick your hand in. His flesh molds around your hand, slickening it with sweat. You let out an uncomfortable grouse as you reach further and further, your fingertips brushing the innards of dungeon never chartered. You follow in Floatzel’s footsteps, pushing your other hand in, gripping the twitching flesh as its owner breathes deeply. Your arms are slick and wet and warmed with a steamy heat.
         But you won't back down.
         You press your head against the flesh as it peels apart, making way for the shape of your head. Pangoro’s musk grows to an oppressive level, his masculine scent now commixed with scent of his scat. Slick flesh slides over you as you draw yourself in, aided by the spasms of Pangoro’s shivering exit. You go in, cautiously and slowly, reluctant to go blindly into the abominable darkness. You feel the tissue around you quiver as Pangoro spits a sudden gasp as his asshole squashes in, a sharp surge of pleasure runs through the panda’s body. The contraction squeezes you in an unrelenting bear hug, smearing the oily flesh against your skin, before devouring you too.
         All is dark. All is smelly. You press your hand against the squishy ground as you attempt to blindly stand. You wave your dominant hand ahead, groping in the darkness—searching for your friend as the odors that have been stewing in Pangoro’s colon commit a full assault on your senses. Pangoro’s deep, pleasured breaths fill your ears as his mammothine lungs struggle to catch his breath. The warm, wet ground you’re on rises and falls with his gasps as the big fella sucks in air as he belly-breathes. That isn’t even mentioning the infernal orchestra of Pangoro’s guts, his bubbling belly, burbling bowels…
         You hear a familiar chirp in the blackness ahead of you. “Ah-ha!” Floatzel chirps. “I was almost afraid I left it behind!” A yellow bloom bursts to life as your surroundings are revealed by…
         ...Is that Floatzel’s Light Ball? The one she swallowed? Mesprit’s Misery, you’re afraid to ask if it’s the same one…
         Irregardless of where she procured the glowing orb, the darkness of your surrounds is stripped away, unveiling the state of Pangoro’s bowels…
11411112121211211322212221122221.title: Up the Panda Express

choices: Go for the hard stuff: long-term
11411112121211211322212221123.content:
At times like these you really shouldn’t be thinking in anything that isn’t turning back to normal, but something about the sound of ruins in the swamp kind of appeals to you. If you had to hazard a guess, it was because your companion Floatzel’s adventurous side was influencing you. Admitting that would be a bad idea, though, it’d make you look like you didn’t care about your current size, and if you did that you feared Floatzel would stop taking seriously your plight. That was why instead you said, mustering as much confidence as you could: “I don’t know much about temples but they’re supposed to be filled with mysteries. There could be something about this mystery I’m in right now”

That was all Floatzel needed to hear. She immediately dove into her pile of treasures, digging around for stuff that could be of use in the swamp. “Great! We’ll leave in the morning. I warn you, it’s all full of slime and marsh water so you better not get separated from me!”

“Trust me, I won’t” Not when it meant being in danger, that was for sure. You weren’t a bad swimmer, but being in dense marsh water would be very dangerous for you at your current size. After some light discussion, the both of you fell asleep, you feeling satisfied for the first time in a while.

-----

The swamp was unexpectedly dense. Even Floatzel, who was used to swimming through any kind of water, was having trouble. Thankfully you were holding onto her flotation device, behind her head, so you didn’t have any problem surviving.

In the depths of the swamp, where the trees covered everything in a darkness that surprised you, stood what seemed to be a half-submerged tower. Part of it was crumbling, but from what Floatzel could see there was a clear pathway. Even though it was going downwards, under the level of the water, the stone stairway was completely dry. “I feel so excited! I had seen this place from outside, and now this will be the first time I’ll sneak in!”

“What’s this tower?”

“I dunno! I heard it’s a place where a legendary Pokemon used to be venerated by humans but these days it’s just a place for Pokemon to live. I can’t blame them” Floatzel commented, sneaking through a crack in the tower. The inside of the building was musty, humid. She took a deep breath, enjoying it – the smell of places to explore! “Look at the torches, there’s Pokemon here, definitely” Indeed, many of the torches had fire.

“Let’s hope they’re friendly”

Floatzel awkwardly tried to pet your head. Given the place you’re at, the only thing she could do was press on you slightly, not much of a petting. “We won’t talk with anyone! This will be like a stealth mission, so hold tight onto me and let’s see what wonders are in this place!” it was hard not to be excited when she said it with so much excitement.

The mustelid descended the stairs quickly, going down on all fours for more speed. It was exhilarating, like you were on a train. Floatzel descended for what seemed like an hour, getting deep into the swamp, until she came to a bifurcation. “Uh, left or right?” she asked you.

“Right”

“That’s a good choice” she complimented, bouncing a little on her hind legs. “Let’s go!” You were ready to hold onto her again when you felt someone grabbing you, someone who definitely wasn’t Floatzel. Fingers plucked you off her flotation device so lightly she didn’t notice, and you didn’t even have the time to call for her before she ran away, unaware you were left behind in someone’s hand. By the time you got the time to call for her, a dizziness overtook you.

Almost immediately the surroundings changed. You undoubtedly still were in the tower in the swamp, the stone walls, slime and moss proved it. “Let me go!” you shouted, turning around to face your captor.

It was an Abra. So that was why it could teleport so fast. Abra excelled at that, after all.

“This is new. I like this. Why are you here?” without giving you a minute to answer, they put a finger to your forehead. In your mind a series of images flashed by in a second, all the memories of these last couple days condensed in a shorter span of time. “Ah, so you weren’t this size all along. Interesting. It’s almost sad, if you ask me” Abra said with sly expression.

“Yeah...? Great, then can you help me?”

Abra petted you on the head. She – you were pretty sure it was she -- she didn’t seem to mean any harm? You sure hoped so. “Maybe I can, maybe I can’t...”

“I’m not really in mood for riddles. You took me away from my friend and I really don’t appreciate that”

“I’ll tell you something: if you play a game or two with me I’ll see what I can do to help you. Or maybe instead of games you could call them challenges. It’s more like challenges to see what you’re made of”

Challenges by a Pokemon you were getting warier of by the second? That didn’t sound appealing at all, especially because you were separated from Floatzel. As much as you hated to admit it, you were at the Abra’s mercy. Annoyed, you sigh. “What kind of challenges are they?”

“Let’s say seeing your recent experiences gave me ideas”

That could only mean you were going to get eaten again. At least by now you were more confident about your capacity to survive anything, so you weren’t afraid. You just hoped it wouldn’t be too bad. “If you’ll eat me then do it quick”

Abra gasped. “Me? No, I won’t do that! I don’t want humans crawling around in my insides”

You didn’t expect that response. “No? Not that I’m complaining, but if it isn’t that, what kind of challenges are they?”

“I have a couple friends, they’re the ones who will have a human crawling around inside them,” she said, teleporting to another area of the tower. When you were able to look at your surroundings from between Abra’s fingers you saw everything was much darker, many other torches were needed to keep the environment lighted up.

You and your current captor likely were deep into the swamp, possibly way underground by now. Part of the tower had crumbled so much the water was seeping through, forming a small lake of a deep green color. The rest of the room was furnished with many things; you’d even think it was comfortable. Did Pokemon live here?
You got your answer after taking a better look. In the lake there was a cyan form. It took you a moment to realize it was a Feraligatr, a rather large one. It was lazing around in the water, floating, perhaps asleep? On the other side of the room, a Vaporeon was running around, a tad anxiously, bringing objects all over the room, reorganizing everything. “These are my friends. Don’t bother saying hello,” Abra explained with telepathy.

Alright, you had decided: you didn’t like Abra at all. No explanation about what the challenges entailed had been given yet, though.

“I’ll give you two options: one is short-term, the other is long-term. I’m not promising you’ll have to do only one of them, but make a choice anyway. Then I’ll explain. How much time do you want to spend in the challenge?”

That wasn’t something you expected either. Going for anything that wouldn’t last long would be great and definitely was your first idea, but then you thought: what if anything short wasn’t enough to satisfy Abra and she decided to mess with you more? Accepting something longer could be better, then.

It was also rather likely your decision would impact which Pokemon you’d find yourself into. You weren’t sure which one would be what choice, though.

After a moment of thought, you took your decision.

114111121212112113222122211231.content:
The sooner this Abra leaves you alone once and for all the better, you decided. “Let’s just go for the short option,” you said. Abra didn’t seem to mind your choice.

“Good one,” her telepathy said in your head. “Now be as quiet as you can. Don’t forget if necessary I can shut you up for good,” she threatened. As if you needed the reminder, as long as you were in her hand you just couldn’t do anything.

“Wait, what am I supposed to do? You said it’d be a challenge! What’s the challenge?”

“It’s simple: you have to escape Vaporeon’s body without being noticed”

That didn’t sound entirely bad. You had literally escaped Noibat’s body unnoticed, doing the same in that Vaporeon wasn’t going to be difficult, you figured. Although...part of you wondered why Abra had chosen Vaporeon for this particular challenge. Was something about that Pokemon that would make the goal difficult for you?

“Okay, I’m prepared,” you said. “I’ll escape in no time”

“Are you sure? You’re so confident I wonder if you already have a plan,” one of Abra’s fingers folded, striking you on the back of your head. It seemed she had tried to pat you on the head again, and once again it had been such a graceless move it was more painful than endearing. “I see, I see now. Right, I remember seeing a glimpse of your trip inside a certain bat Pokemon’s innards. So that’s why you’re so confident...”

“Shouldn’t I be?” you weren’t sure how comfortable you were with Abra being aware that was why you felt so cocky. You didn’t get a response. Instead the laugh that was the response was the only reply, and it was one that got the Vaporeon’s attention.

Vaporeon’s ear fins stood up straight when they noticed their friend’s presence. “Oh! Oh, you’re here again! Did you forget something?”

“You could say that,” Abra said, floating over, with a hand behind her back – the hand that was holding you. All you could do was listen, waiting for the moment you’d be fed to Vaporeon. You did wonder how it’d be, you don’t remember seeing any food where you could be hidden, and given how the point of the challenge was escape Vaporeon’s body without being noticed, it was likely they’d stay unaware of your presence. It wasn’t like Abra could tell them to open their jaws and toss you inside to be swallowed.

Vaporeon trotted over, their tail swishing behind them. “Tell me what it is. I’ll help you and then you can leave”

“Are you saying I’m not welcome here?” Abra sounded falsely saddened. Vaporeon, noticing how that may have been rude, shook their head.

“No, that’s not it! Feraligatr is sleeping. You know how Feraligatr is like if you wake him up. We really have to let him sleep,” you had to agree with Vaporeon. You didn’t want to be near an angry alligator, especially not one as large as that one.

Abra nodded, deciding to get done with placing you inside who would be the embodiment of your challenge. “Then I’ll come back later. I’m sorry for bothering you, so...bye”

“Bye, Abra.” That was all you heard before a sensation of freefalling overtook you. While you tried to keep yourself from freaking out, you focused on rationalizing what was happening: Abra must have used her teleporting ability on you, and only on you. You didn’t feel Abra holding you anymore. Then what had happened?

A humidity that surprised you enveloped you, you fell down on a spongy surface. Agh! You crashed down, holding onto the ground. It was all wet, there was a strange smell in the air. With your eyes closed, you didn’t recognize it at all. It didn’t smell acidic, so you definitely weren’t in a stomach, and – much to your relief – it also didn’t smell earthy, which indicated you likely weren’t in the intestines. But then where were you? Where could Abra have placed you into? Holding onto the ground, you took a bearing of your surroundings.

That’s when you realized how exactly Abra had planned to make this difficult for you. She hadn’t placed you in any place of Vaporeon’s digestive system. “How am I supposed to get out of here?!” you yelled, having noticed where you were.

Abra, that tricky Pokemon, had teleported you right into...

Also you couldn't know how long Vaporeon would wait or if they would avoid urinating even if the bladder got full, and the thought of drowning in there if you couldnt' stay afloat was terrifying. There it was, just below the surface, a muscular opening, currently closed.
