There are many things you'd like to do in your life, so many you can't even count them. Travel, have fun, have a nice life. In your opinion, fate knew all that, and decided to balance your happy goals with cold, unpleasant and real events. It was like the universe had decided you needed some humbling down after having made such grand plans.

You just couldn't think of any other explanation. You'd be fine with it if it wasn't because fate went out of its way to kick you while you're down.

Your heart had plummeted when you heard the Vaporeon calling to Feraligatr. "Hey, Feraligatr..." he had said, with a tone you didn't like at all. Just in case, you tried to wiggle forward, still finding you were very stuck.

----------

Vaporeon lazily floated over to the large alligator. He had seen Feraligatr's eyes flutter open, he knew the big guy wasn't sleeping anymore! Yet he was still pretending he was. "I know you can hear me"

For a moment Feraligatr didn't want to acknowledge he had been caught, but it was pointless, Vaporeon was staring at him sharply. A rumble shook the pond while the big Pokemon raised his head above the water. "What...have I told you about waking me up?"

"Sorry, sorry. But need I remind you you have been sleeping for almost an entire day?"

"I deserve that sleep. You know that."

"Sure, you do. It just would have been great if it had been any other day that wasn't today," Vaporeon swatted Feraligatr, barely felt by the larger one. "Look at yourself, then look at me. You're almost nine feet tall and I barely can reach your hips. You know how much easier this all would have been if you had been the one to move the furniture?"

"You're the one with the eye for that kinda thing"

"It's called teamwork, ever heard of that? You..." Vaporeon clumsily climbed on top of Feraligatr's back, even though he'd have liked to go sleep, there was something about Feraligatr that just made him feel giddy. "...you move things, I tell you how. But no, this time I did all the work while you slept for an entire day"

Vaporeon could feel Feraligatr's skin vibrate with his voice, he was actually chuckling. Vaporeon could be a handful to deal with, but he meant well. Usually when he got all touchy and started climbing on him, the message was rather clear: he was feeling frisky. Slowly, Feraligatr crawled out of the pond, carrying Vaporeon on his back, until he was on dry terrain. "Fine, I get the point. I owe you"

"You're much more fun when you're well-rested" Vaporeon was happy he was the one starting things this time. Usually it was the other way. The anticipation was making him quiver, he was glad he hadn't decided to try to go back to sleep. "How are we going to do it this time?"

------------

You had stayed still, listening to every bit of the conversation outside. With every word, your dread increased. It was plainly obvious what was going to happen, and judging by the way the walls around you were contracting and expanding, Vaporeon was really eager to get started. You had tried all along to dislodge yourself, sending sensations that undoubtedly must have spurred Vaporeon to pursue such urges further. Nothing you could have done would stopped this!

That thought didn't make you feel any better.

How far were you from the end? Would you be able to escape before things started getting heated all around you? You didn't know, but that sure wouldn't stop you from trying your hardest, anything to not be caught in the crossfire of those two's...activities. Screw being seen by Vaporeon, you also didn't care if Abra got upset with you, you just wanted to get out. Now. Struggling, you crawled forward, taking advantage of the times the tunnel ahead of you widened. You saw it happen, the flesh parting and opening just a little further.

It was little consolation that Vaporeon's eagerness was expanding the tunnel a little. You were being shaken around, clearly Vaporeon was moving around a lot. He and Feraligatr were getting ready, no doubt. Soon it was clear to you: you wouldn't be getting out in time.

Laughing, you let yourself fall on the spongy floor. It was a bitter laugh of defeat, your fighting spirit had left you. "Of course this is happening! I have finally reached rock bottom!" So much had happened in the last few days, and there were no signs of improvement anytime soon. Your laughter stopped, replaced with silence. While outside Vaporeon asked a question, slowly you raised your head.

Things couldn't get any worse. That meant the only way now was up. Humans weren't prone to giving up just like that. You made a promise quietly: you'd keep fighting. No matter what else fate tried to throw your way, you'd take it with bravery and face it head on. So what if your near future indicated you were likely to be in the middle of a sex session between two Pokemon?

You'll be fine, you told yourself. You knew you'd be fine.

------------

The size difference usually meant Feraligatr was on the receiving end. As such, normally he was the one who decided how things would proceed. At Vaporeon's question, Feraligatr only had to do one thing to convey his response.

The great member above you gives a few last thrusts as it empties its payload. Once he's finished, the reptile's tongue lifts up and licks the Vaporeon's cock, smearing you against it in a messy goodbye kiss.

         Wasting not a moment longer, Feraligatr takes out Vaporeon's dick from his mouth and tilts his head up—displaying his thick throat in front of the fish-cat. He swallows.

         Powerful neck meat drag you down to the lizard's belly as you kick and holler. A great tightening and the following blissful shudder impart to you that Feraligatr just came. You slap your hands against the esophageal muscles, hoping to stop your descent. But as always, it's in vain.
You're dumped into the lizard's belly accompanied by gator spittle and Vaporeon's load. The Feraligatr's belly isn't full, thank goodness. However, a waist-high slop of foodstuff slorshes about like borscht in an unsteady pot. A pungent, meaty smell haunts the area. Strangely enough, you detect the faint aroma of sugary sweets broiling along with the rest of his stomach soup.

         What does Feraligatr, panting and high in the afterglow, do next?
11411112121211211322212221123121132.title: Gator Aid

choices: You talk to Feraligatr. May as well let him know you're there
You decide to stay silent. This would be rather awkward
114111121212112113222122211231211321.content:
It was just too enjoyable of a moment for both Pokemon, even if it wasn't for you. Vaporeon staggers away, satisfied, his legs trembling, until he reaches the edge of the pond. With a last sigh of exhaustion, he falls forward, crashing into the water and being carried by the water in a rather good dead man's float. It'd be worrying if he wasn't a Water-type. Bubbles burst onto the surface, Vaporeon was snoring.

It was hard for Feraligatr not to feel pride at the results. He idly wondered if Vaporeon would sleep nearly as long as he had done. Sleeping for an entire day was a sacred time for the alligator, and now that his quota for sleep had been fulfilled, he was feeling rather energized! Standing on his hind legs, he steps away from the pond, walking towards the entrance of the room they resided in.

Inside him, in his stomach, you felt every single movement. The steps made waves in the soup you were in, waves that carried you around like some sort of waterpark pool. You touch one of the walls, and then the thick liquid carries you towards the other end of the stomach, taking several seconds to get there. The mixture surrounding you is only waist-high, but the unstable floor beneath you makes it hard to have a footing.

"Okay, now what?" you briefly wondered. That was all you managed to hear before you heard something from above you. It sounded like...munching.

Feraligatr's destination had been the sizable stash of food he and Vaporeon had accumulated. The swamp the tower was in was near a commercial route, trucks and boats passed nearby with various products for the cities. It wasn't uncommon for the Pokemon in the area to get some of the merchandise with ease, and it wasn't like the humans cared. Feraligatr, thanks to his size and strength, had carried almost everything in the storage. Boxes of raw meats, soups, and even candy were stacked one over another.

It all would last them like four days, thanks to a certain glutton. Feraligatr wasted no time, tackling one of the boxes with enthusiasm, clamping his jaws over one of the crates full of meat. With a powerful twist of his neck, he ripped off the wooden cover, and greedily took out the contents. He was already salivating at the prospect of eating it all. Without hesitation, Feraligatr ripped off the plastic covering the meat, and tossed the food into his mouth.

It didn't take long for you to see the confirmation of what you had heard. Thanks to the ability to see in the dark, you didn't miss any detail. Above you, from a hole you knew you had came from, splattered down a pink and white mush. Gristle and meat poured rather quickly, forming a hill on the opposite end of the stomach. He's eating?! That meant soon the place you were in would be filled with acids. You really hoped you still were as resistant to acids as you had seemed to be before!

The stomach wasted no time dealing with the meat, Feraligatr would soon start shoving more and more, so of course it had to process it as soon as possible. While you heard the sounds of masticating and more meat entering Feraligatr's voracious maw, the stomach contracted, shoving the mountain of chewed meat and spreading it all over the stoamch. Soon it reached you, forcing you to get onto it to avoid getting buried under meat and into the resting liquids that had received you. You grab the meat, feeling the wetness in it, and thanking whatever little luck you had Feraligatr wasn't eating live prey. Knowing your luck you'd have been eaten by prey if that had happened.

It was some of the longest ten minutes in your life, and it was all while Feraligatr just kept eating, not stopping at all. The level of the food in the stomach kept rising, distending the sac and giving you more space to crawl around. You were looking for stable ground to weather the meat storm, but the stomach kept throwing everything everywhere, you were at its mercy. More and more ground meat kept entering, completely soaked in acids and liquids you didn't want to think about. How much could Feraligatr eat?

Then the munching above stopped. You sighed with relief.

Feraligatr licked his chops. "That was the stuff. Now where's the good sugar..." he talked to himself. You heard that. Wasn't he full already? The stomach was already pretty full, if he kept eating you'd be able to touch the ceiling with your hand!

The good sugar, as Feraligatr had called it, was in a corner of their stash. Tearing apart the crate, he found assorted candy inside. Taffy, mints, jawbreakers. He wouldn't ever tell Vaporeon, but he really, really liked candy, even though most of it never stayed in his mouth for long enough for him to taste properly. Taking a package of mints, he poured it into his jaw, half of it falling into the throat already.

A barrage of mints fell into the stomach, helping just a little with the meaty stench that filled the place. The candy bounced around, sinking into the meat and pelting you with pieces. You stepped back, trying your hardest to not be touched by them. Above you, you heard a curious noise, and looked up just in time to see a while, round jawbreaker enter the stomach and fall towards you.

-----------

When you woke up, you knew you could add 'knocked out by a jawbreaker' to the list of misfortune you had experienced in a while. You touched your face, it ached. You were sure you had a bruise from the jawbreaker hitting you. Touching your cheek to count your teeth and make sure you hadn't lost any, you looked around to assess the situation.

It must have been a while since you had fallen unconscious. Everything still looked rather cramped, a consequence of Feraligatr's eating. Still, there was something different...the smell was different. You examined the area. The walls didn't have the wrinkled texture you remembered the stomach had, instead it had more of a bumpy, hairy texture. Villi.

"...ah." You must have been unconscious for hours, if you were in the intestines already.

The meat and candy all around you clearly had been quite a while stewing inside Feraligatr's stomach and intestines. It all and you were covered in all sorts of liquids, and beneath you it felt like a lazy river was carrying you. Ahead you saw what looked like an endless field of food being processed, and looking behind you you saw the same thing. In both directions the food just kept going further than the bends of the small intestine. It was like you were on a conveyor belt, efficiently carrying the digestive process, and you were a stowaway.

You try to move forward, but you can't. Looking down you find you're embedded chest-deep into the slop holding you. Tugging and trying to get out showed how difficult the effort was. "...alright then." you muttered. So there you were, stranded in the middle of Feraligatr's food, getting carried deeper while the body performed the digestion, and thanks to your eyesight, you would be witness of how it worked.

At least you'd be able to tell Feraligatr how his guts worked, you'd be able to give all sorts of details--wait. Feraligatr.

He wouldn't be able to change your situation, but you wondered if you could talk to him. Now that you thought about it...you had won. You overcame Abra's challenge. You escaped from Vaporeon's body and he was none the wiser. She never said anything about Feraligatr not finding out! For a moment the thought of explaining how you were eaten brought you dread, it'd be just too awkward to say where you were right before Feraligatr swallowed you, but then you realized you had a decent excuse surrounding you. All that food...

Oh well. You look up. You can feel Feraligatr is awake, you can feel him moving. But should you get his attention?
114111121212112113222122211231211321.title: Munchies

choices: The remnants of Feraligatr's past meal. This won't be pleasant.
The dimly lit, surprisingly clean, cavernous cave of the gator's colon.
1141111212121121132221222112312113211.content:
For a moment, you sit there in silence. A tremor shakes all around as Feraligatr stomps about, sending ripples through the gluck and the muck you're mired in. Sounds of busy digestion fill the air with an incessant grumbling. The slow-moving river you soak in slops along, barely flowing. You sigh. His body gurgles back. It's at that moment you decide: you're not going to sit here, marinating in an unholy mixture of meats and sweets, in silence. If you're gonna go all the way through again, you're going to at least try to spark some conversation—even if it's with your devouree. What's the worst that could happen? Eat you again? After your exit—fat chance.
         "Hey!" You shout. You're almost expecting your words to echo back in Feraligatr's cave-like digestive tract. Alas, your only response is the burbles and swashes of the intestines' food-river.
         You wriggle and twist your arm out of the slop. It exits with a pop and comes out looking like you took a dip in a pool filled with Grimer. Ah, you say as it hits you. You're swamped in a swamp in a Pokemon in the swamp. Sweet irony. Swamp doesn't feel like a real word anymore.
         You take your smudge covered arm and rub the villi-laden walls. It's like wringing your hands through the strings of a mop!

         Outside, Feraligatr feels a peculiar tickle in his belly. Moments ago he was patrolling the halls of the old ruin. Not that he needed to, anyway. But a couple minutes stomping about the crumbling corridors does wonder in scaring away pesky Rattata. They will ravage Feraligatr's stockpile if left unchecked. Granted, he could eat them. But Rattata don't taste that good. And contrary to what Feraligatr expected, a Rattata gorged on sugar does not taste sweeter.
         But back in the present, Feraligatr's attention snaps to his belly. That oh-so-strange tickling feeling feels… strange. Feraligatr knows no other way to describe it. It's like… a tiny, tiny bug is twittering about inside him. Also, Feraligatr is pretty sure he doesn't eat bugs. At least intentionally…
         "Urgh," Feraligatr grumbles as he took a claw and pressed in on his lower belly. His ivory claws scritched across his scales as he scratched the funny feeling into submission. "Quit it."

         Walls crumpling, gluck squelching, goop rising—everything is thrown into disarray as the small intestines squeeze in as Feraligatr's claw pushes forth. Like a crumpled water bottle, the slop level upsurges as villi-coated walls close together. After your head momentarily dunks beneath the surface in a gloppy baptism, you just about had it. Fueled by frustration, you unleash a shout so loud it could rouse a slumbering Snorlax.
         "Stop that you dolt!"

         Feraligatr froze. Did a tiny angry voice just erupt from his tummy?
         Oh Juniper, the squirming is getting worse! The surprise of it all causes Feraligatr to reactively suck in his belly. The struggles that continue after he relaxes indicate that, whatever that is, it did not like that.

         "Stop dunking me like a breakfast tea biscuit!"

         Feraligatr feels his head go hot with confusion and embarrassment. Dear Arceus, the thing in his belly really is talking! And it's angry. And fond of unusual insults.
         All Feraligatr can muster out is an unsure, "OK…"

         Things quiet down as the meat-sweet stew sloughs off the walls and settles back into the river below. Covered in the residue, you're looking like a thing from the swamp yourself.
         "Thank you!" You shout. Surprisingly sincere. The gut passage tilts and wobbles as you assume Feraligatr inspects his talking belly.
         "You a bug?" He asks. "Like… a tiny, tiny Joltik or something?" You hear the great boom of his heart quicken its pace as things shift again, slop sloshing to-and-fro. "Don't shock me! Please, I'm sorry! Electricity really hurts!"
         After finding some stability, you shout back, "I'm not a bug! I'm a human. I… lost a few inches."
         "A few?"
         "I don't understand it either!"
         You hear a soft pat from outside as a firm shockwave bounces through the Pokemon's interior. "How in the world did you get inside me?"
         You answer simply. "You ate me!"
         "Mmm," the Feraligatr gruffs, "'spose that was a dumb question." Feraligatr clears his throat to relieve a bit of his fluster, jostling you up a bit. "Guessing you were chilling in my stash?"
         "You… know it."
         "Why the weird pause?"
         "It's pretty hard keeping a steady tone while swimming in your half-digested dinner!"
         "...Got it." Feraligatr replies. Great save.
         Things get quiet for a bit. Feraligatr looks meekly to the left and right before resuming his patrol like nothing ever happened—no tells besides the vaguely unsettled look upon his mug. The stream of foodstuff (and you) are steadily carried deeper into his depths. The groans and burbles of gator innards hard at work acquaint your ears with the unique soundscape of a giant lizard's internals. A great rumble buzzes around you as Feraligatr breaks the silence.
         "You new here?"
         "Nah, I've got a condo in your intestines—three bends back."
         "I meant here—like—in the swamp."
         "No, I'm just passing through."
         "...Of course you are."
         "No! Not like that! Well, like that too, I guess. But, like, on the outside." You groan. "But Abra comes along and plops me in—yeah. Your friend is a real jerk."
         "...This another game of hers?"
         "Yup. And a rotten one, that's for sure."

◓ ◓ ◓


         You're given a front row seat, witnessing nature take its course. The foodstuff around you is beyond recognition. Anything of use was sapped away by the greedy villi and what's left—the dreck—is quite unsightful. The color has molded to a vague ugly brown-ish color. Not quite yet the abominable stuff you are dreading crossing paths with. But given you are trapped in the middle of a meal, you're afraid it's inevitable.
         You spot a puckered valve of muscle ahead: the duodenum. The end of the small intestine and entrance to the large. Ho boy, here you go again…
         The gluck-stream drags you closer to the ring of flesh. The valve opens at random, swallowing the liquid muck then closing tight—patiently waiting to do so again. Soon you find yourself pressed up against it. Your cheekbone presses against the warm flesh as you detect a foul smell wafting from deeper within. Moments later, it's your turn as the duodenum opens once more and you pass through.

         What awaits you on the other side?
1141111212121121132221222112312113211.title: Gab With the Gator That Gobbled You

choices: You complete the voyage without further problems
11411112121211211322212221123121132111.content:
It's only when you're at your lowest that you appreciate how nice things were before. That's an undeniable truth many experience throughout all their lives, and now it was your turn. You had been inside Pokemon a few times before, and although you never had a good time, now you can say it could have been worse.

You think that now because, now that you look upwards to the path ahead of you, you see much lining the walls. It's not much, just a few patches staining the walls, but it's a foreboding omen: you're likely to stumble upon Feraligatr's meal before you. "...Feraligatr, tell me you don't usually eat as much as you ate a few hours ago"

"Why do you ask?"

"Just wondering"

A pleased growl erupted from way above you, from Feraligatr's throat. "Of course I do. I love food. You don't think the same?" You did like food, but certainly not to the amounts Feraligatr ate, if his latest showing was any hint. It was confirmation, though: you weren't going to enjoy your stay here. The smell was bad enough, making the air so heavy you were forced to cough, and you weren't looking forward to getting any closer to what's causing it. It was bad enough to have it behind you...

You crawl forward, trying hard to get away from the slop holding you, and only manage to get a couple steps done before you fall to the floor, too weighted down by the muck. It's thick, sticky, like a soup. You sigh, sinking and taking a deep breath that made your lungs burn. Right, you shouldn't breathe the air too deeply. At least you managed to get yourself to the front, that should be of some help.

-------

Time passes. Just like you expected, the situation was as dirty as you feared. The meal holding you onto place was solidifying, turning into what you couldn't deny anymore: you were held down by stool. For a moment you thought you were lucky you were closer to the front, but that didn't mean much when you were stumbling onto growing bits of crap along the way. Stains on the walls turned into particles no bigger than your fist, particles that fell down from the walls and ceiling. You had front row seats to seeing how it all crashed mere inches in front of you. Did that mean the further you went the bigger those pieces would get? How long before you sighted something blocking the way?

At least you had Feraligatr's company, as silly as that was to say when you were in his bowels. He was pretty good conversation, showing interest in you and your life. Thanks to him you know where you were. "You're taking this all better than expected" you said, the gurgles all around you filling the silence while you wait for a response.

"I'm a predator. Pokemon have been inside me, you know. The smallest ones follow the same route than you." So that was why he was taking it relatively well. You were the first human, he had commented. "I thought you'd be protesting more. Are things okay in there?"

"No, it's actually pretty awful. I'm stuck and your colon needs some cleansing!" you protested, annoyed by the question.

"Oh. Um, sorry about that. Guess I should eat less?"

"You should. But I'm not upset with you" that was the only reason why you were taking it as calmly as you were right now. "Abra's the one to blame"

"Right. About that, I have been thinking and I wonder if she knew what she was doing"

"I'm sure she knew very well. She wanted to give me a hard time with one of her games"

"That's what I mean." A large tremor shook the colon, dislodging you somewhat. If there was one good thing happening right now was that the drier the feces holding you got, the more you could move. Feraligatr had just sat down, taking a break. "I met her when she teleported me into this tower. Told me to get out" Does she have no more tricks, seriously?

"But you're still here"

"No, I got out! But I came back because I met...a friend" Feraligatr said. Vaporeon, you supposed. "And that friend is turning into something more. I wouldn't have met him if it wasn't for Abra being a jerk"

"Wait, you're not saying what I think you're saying, right?"

"Psychic types, pal, they're weird. They know a lot but they never say it like you'd want it, straightforward. You'll be grateful to Abra before you know it"

You frowned, shaking your head with disbelief, looking around yourself with disdain. Here you were, riding a crap train, in the depths of an alligator, surrounded by air so bad it felt like it was going to stick with you forever. Hell would freeze over before you thanked Abra for anything! A few minutes later, though, Feraligatr piped up: "So you gonna be small forever?"

"I sure hope not!"

"Listen, at the bottom of the tower there's a way for you to talk with Legendary Pokemon. I can't help you with getting those inches back, but getting a legendary's favor can't hurt. It's under a lot of water, though, you'd drown before you reach there"

You listened carefully. "You think it'll work?"

"You should give it a try" He wasn't wrong about that. "I can't take you because I'm busy, but my friend could. He's fussy but he'll help if I ask him to"

You chuckled nervously. You really doubted you could even look at Vaporeon without thinking where in him you were. "No, I have a water-type friend who can help me"

"Fine. Then I'll make sure you two can pass. You got my word"

None of that had changed your mind. While you watched the walls contract and propel everything forward, you kept repeating to yourself you'd never thank Abra.

------------

It had been a few hours since you had arrived to the colon and you were glad you could say you were close to the end. You were using the refuse you were stumbling upon to deduce how far away the rectum was, and now the stray pieces were starting to fill half of the passageway. Having dislodged yourself from the meal carrying you, you had gotten yourself to the dryest spot you could find -- no way you'd walk by yourself ahead and risk being crushed by the mound you had arrived on.

Ahead of you, you saw the walls contracting almost hypnotically, and an ominous-looking drop was looming ahead. You got off the refuse, approaching the edge, careful not to tumble down. All you could see was quite the fall, and then at the bottom the road evened and went out of sight. Maybe it was better that way. The rectum and its contents could only be over there.

Suddenly, everything around you shook. Jumping back to avoid falling, you crawled back to your crap carriage. "What's going on?!"

What was going on was that Feraligatr had finally found Floatzel. You had told him about her, that she was the friend who'd help you, and he had promised if he saw her he'd tell her you were okay. "Wait! The human!" Feraligatr shouted. Floatzel had been about to dart around the corner and away when she stopped in her tracks, slipping and going back.

"Did you say human? This tall?" she showed how small you were.

"That one"

Floatzel pretty much clung onto Feraligatr, trying and failing to envelope him with a hug. "Thank you thank you thank you! You don't know how worried I have been! When I noticed they weren't with me..." the otter looked all over Feraligatr. "So where's the human?"

You were listening to the conversation. From your position, all you could do was cringe. "They're inside me. My bad"

"Your bad?! They better be okay!" the wall right beside you buckled, shaking everything. "Can you hear me? Are you okay?"

"I'm fine!" you shouted as loudly as you could, trying to be heard over the gurgling of Feraligatr's system. "I'm...on my way out"

"On your way out? Wait, does that mean you're...um..." she couldn't bring herself to outright say you were on Feraligatr's poop, pretty much. Your affirmative response confirmed her fears. She glared at Feraligatr. "You better be careful!"

"I know, I'll get them out carefully" As carefully as he could, anyway.

You saw some of the things ahead of you fall down the abyss. Great. You hoped it'd have been carried away when it was your turn to fall. Outside, Floatzel grumbled: "I can't believe this...I should stick my paw in there and get them out myself, I can't believe this..."

"It's not like I want to have humans up my ass, you know!"

"Guys, can you stop? This is bad enough already, I don't want to listen to your bickering!" you were teetering on the edge of the turn. Below you, anything that had fallen was already slowly being carried away, towards the rectum. "I think it'll be like twenty minutes before I'm out!"

And you just couldn't wait for that to happen.
11411112121211211322212221123121132111.title: It's Never Easy

choices: You and Floatzel make it there without incident!
Floatzel swims into trouble in the waters…
Floatzel bumps into some misfortune after she surfaces.
114111121212112113222122211231211321111.content:
You try and steel yourself for the awaiting leap of faith ahead of you, but honestly, looking down into the crappy pit isn’t doing you any favors. In good news: you finally know what it means when you stare into the abyss, and the abyss stares back. This abyss was giving you one monumental stink-eye. It’s also trying to push your nostrils into your skull by the sheer force of its stench. Also, most of it is covered in literal dung.
         You turn away—you face very likely green. You can’t know for certain. You can’t see your own face. But you know what you can see? Absolutely everything else! There’s not much else to see, really. The intestines are fleshy, red, writhing, horrible tunnels: a sewage pipe filled with a mudslide of stinking refuse. But there’s a simplicity to that horror that makes it 10x worse. You’re up shit-creek without a paddle.
         You look back. Lurking behind and below you is the regrettably familiar crap-coaster you’ve been cruising on. It rises and falls with the undulation of Feraligatr’s colon. It slopes upward, mounds of crap stacked atop each other until they very nearly reach the ceiling of the cavernous tunnel. The hard truth hits you. You’re coming out dirty either way—but if you don’t take the plunge, you’re going to be buried.
         You face forward. You’re gonna do it. You’re making the dive.
         Before you can stop yourself, you kick off the mushed earthen floor and plummet. You’re in freefall. The humid, hot air whips past, providing you ironic relief to the suffocating environment of Feraligatr’s colon. The ground fast approaches. You aim for the portion of the road not covered in dung. But, as luck would have it, you’re not that lucky.
         Splat!
         You’re sunken up to your armpits. Your legs are entombed below, gripped in a nasty, mushy vice. You blow, breathe, and cough the breath back out. The smell is somehow worse here.
         Looking ahead, it’s no wonder why. You’re not the only tenant here. Portions of Feraligatr’s last meal, and perhaps others as well, got here long before you. The mound of evil mud is mountainous, dwarfing you to such a degree that you feel microscopic. To make matters worse, the way ahead is hemmed away by the wall of crap. Worst of all, you’re stuck. Again.

         “They’re taking a terribly long time…” Floatzel worries, pacing back-and-forth in front of Feraligatr. The giant lizard is simply sitting in silence, waiting for a cue. He risks a glance at Floatzel—which the weasel immediately notices and returns a glower of her own. Feraligatr quickly breaks away does his best to avoid eye contact. When he dares to take another peep in Floatzel’s direction, he finds their snouts practically touching.
         “Something awful better not have happened to them in there!” Floatzel reels back and crosses her arms and tails. “Or I’ll—I’ll…”
         Feraligatr’s belly gurgles. A tiny voice rises from above the noise.
         “I’m fine!” You holler, your voice faintly carrying past Feraligatr’s scaled hide. “Just—” You choke and sputter on the noxious fumes for a moment. You hope Floatzel didn’t hear that. “Just… fine!”
         Floatzel didn’t buy it. “You’ve been in there forever! Something’s gone wrong, I know it!”
         Feraligatr softly says, “it’s just been ten minutes—”
         “Forever.” Floatzel glares.
         “Yup. Forever, got it. Hey, uh, little fella,” Feraligatr mutters and pokes his lower belly. “Can you speed things along? No offense, but your friend is one hitch away from doing the paw-up-the-bum thing she was talking about…”
         You shout back, quieter this time. Just loud enough for Feraligatr to hear you.
         “Things are going to… well, you know. It’s going to take a while. Distract her!”
         “Distract her?” Feraligatr hisses. “She practically wants to skin me! How am I going to ‘distract her?’”
         “What are you whispering about?” Floatzel is practically steaming.
         You take a second to respond. “...Take her for a walk?”
         Feraligatr’s reply is blunt. “That’ll never work!”

◓ ◓ ◓


         Thirty minutes later, Feraligatr is walking alongside a very angry weasel. While they’re taking their swamp tour, you’re taking a tour of your own. But of course, your’s is much worse. But not by much. Given that it seems Feraligatr’s bowels’ thermostat turned up a few degrees, he’s probably sweating bullets while dealing with Floatzel’s ire. That is, if he can even sweat. You don’t know if he can or not. But it’s mulling over thoughts like these that help you survive the slow, hellish trip through the twilight of your journey in the land where the sun never shines. Two mounds of crap surround you in a phalanx formation, a pocket of air mercifully spares you the fate of having to be in a log as opposed to being surrounded by it. The natural peristalsis of the intestines moves you forward at a snail’s pace. You don’t have much else to do besides to listen to the bodily noises of the gator, the sticky movement of the feces being pushed towards its final destination, and Feraligatr’s awkward attempts at small talk. Not any of it is all that engaging and you slowly find yourself daydreaming, gazing off into nothing.
         The monotony is abruptly broken when you realize you’re falling. Before you can process what’s happening, the clump of stool you’re stuck in plaps onto a similarly disgusting space. You’re in a vertical tube, you remain un-entombed, but sadly still stuck. The good news: you’re just about free!
         ...Wait. There’s still the crap behind you.
         “Feraligatr!” You yell with a ferocity and urgency you never knew you possessed. “Shit now!”

         Your words are loud and clear. Floatzel blanches. Feraligatr stares at the ghost-white weasel, coughs nervously, and rushes behind a nearby bush. Floatzel remains petrified.
         Feraligatr squats, takes a deep breath, lifts his tail, and sighs. “Well, buddy. Here goes nothing…”
         The flesh walls of the fetid chamber you’re in clamp in, pushing in-and-out-and-forward in an oscillation that could only mean one thing: Feraligatr is pooping. You feel yourself steadily lowering as the horrid viscid sound of expelling scat sours the air. You hear the bass-enriched grunts of Feraligatr as he tries to free you as fast as he can.
         C’mon, c’mon, c’mon! Looking up, you can already see that other horrible log poking from over the lip of Feraligatr’s bowels. With each rhythmic contraction, you’re pulled deeper. Soon you feel a pressure on the tips of your toes that spreads further up your body as you descend—clenching in time with Feraligatr’s groans. Soon that pressure is around your shoulders. You’re almost free! But the heap of scat teeters on the edge of the rectum—ready to fall at any moment.
         Just as it breaks off, plummeting towards you with frightening speed, Feraligatr gives one last push and expels you. As you’re falling in the (comparatively fresh) air of the swamp outside, you’ve never been happier to see a Pokemon’s butt. You’re less than enthused when you fall amongst the rest of the Pokemon’s former meals.
         “Stop! Stop! STOP!” You clamor. “I’m free, I’m free!” Feraligatr halts immediately. Thank Arceus.
         The Pokemon grins a many-fanged grin of relief. “You’re okay! Th-they’re okay! Floatzel, check it out! They’re okay!”
         Floatzel stiffly approaches, some of her color restored. Her paw quickly reaches for her nose. “This is going to take a lot of Water Guns…”

◓ ◓ ◓


         The next day, you’re clean, well-rested, and singing the praises of the outside world! Feraligatr offered to let you crash at his place, but knowing that was near Abra’s stomping ground, you politely declined. Floatzel, being the expert survivalist she is, was able to find a cozy place to sleep.
         And now that you’re freshened up and reunited with your ol’ pal Floatzel, you’re ready to knock on the door of that legendary Pokemon Feraligatr mentioned earlier. The big guy directed you both to the waterway that lead under the tower: a clear pool amongst the crumbling ruin—whose surface shone like a polished mirror. You and Floatzel are raring to go!
         “Just one thing,” Floatzel said, looking at you standing on her shoulder, “I never ever wanted to carry you in my mouth ever again.” Floatzel gives a sad look, “but it’s looking like we don't got a choice this time. Unless that Abra you were talking about gave you gills.” She sets you down on the stone floor and flops down in front of you. You give an affirmative nod before she creaks open her jaws and allows you to walk right in.
         After you pass by her ivory fangs and wriggle onto her slippery tongue, the weasel wastes no time before shooting off into the crystal-clear pond.
114111121212112113222122211231211321111.title: Better Out Than In! (Even If Exit Isn't Pleasant)

choices: You accept right away. Better not anger Palkia by being nosy.
You demand to know more details. You want to know what you'll do.
1141111212121121132221222112312113211111.content:
You were rather nervous to be inside Floatzel's mouth again, most likely more nervous than she was. You're the one who is small enough to be into her belly, after all. Thankfully, she's being much more careful than before, barely moving her tongue, while you grab what you can and hold onto it. All around you there's an impenetrable wall of teeth and fangs, pointy and scary-looking. It's not the most inspiring landscape, if you had to be honest.

Outside, things were better. The water was clean, pristine, without not even a sign of murkiness despite being in the depths of a swamp. Floatzel could clearly see the stone walls to the side, slowly turning into what rocks and dirt. The pond was going far deeper than she thought it would, had she entered an underground cavern? Sometimes she passed by fish Pokemon. They barely looked at her. She couldn't tell if they lived there or if they were guardians of what laid below.

Twenty minutes later, she found the bottom of the pond. The bottom curved like a bowl, leading towards an opening right to a side, where she could see a passageway decorated with ancient symbols. Behind you you heard a gurgle of delight. This was awesome! She had found some rather amazing things! If only she could stay to take a good look...but no, she had a task to do. Hoping to return someday, she entered the passageway and followed it to the end, surfacing in an underwater chamber.

It was a huge chamber. Statues decorated the place, most of them shattered and broken. There were clear signs of something huge living there -- that was huge bedding, right over there, and the ceiling was so high she could never dream to reach it at all. The Pokemon that resided there was nowhere to be seen. How did they leave? The tunnel she went through was too small for whatever lived in there.

When she saw the large pink orb set to a side, she realized who resided there. Her jaw hung open from how surprised she was. You interpreted it as she trying to let you out, so you crawled to the edge of her mouth, where she felt you and picked you up. "Okay, we're here. Where's the Legendary Pokemon?"

"I thought Palkia's pearls was just a fun thing to say, not that...peals existed out of their body!" she commented. It took you a moment to realize what she meant:

You were in the abode of Palkia, the Spatial Pokemon. That Water and Dragon type was a Pokemon you never thought you'd come close to meet.

Floatzel approached the pearl, mesmerized, and put the paw holding you close enough for you to touch it. "I think this is how we can contact them, since they're not here. Go ahead, touch it"

It was worth a try. You laid a hand on the surface of the smooth pink pearl. Static-y noises emerged from the pearl, like it was having trouble to connect with Palkia, until finally a voice came through.

"...yes? It's unusual for anyone to try to contact me. What do you need?" Palkia said. You couldn't tell their gender at all from the voice.

"I'm sorry for bothering you," you apologized, hoping to invoke pity. "I really, really need your help!"

You explain the situation, making emphasis on everything you had gone through. You wanted to make clear that staying small could only lead to further misfortune, and that you relied on Palkia to be okay again. Floatzel was just bowing her head, like she expected Palkia's face to appear on the pearl at any moment and she feared it'd be disrespectful to look at them. Your story took ten minutes to tell, and Palkia didn't interrupt at all.

"...you're the only one who can help me. Please, help!" you finished. Should you get on your knees, you pondered for a moment.

Palkia's voice replied. You couldn't deduce what they thought of you and your adventures so far. "I see. Indeed, that'd be under my purview. You did well in coming to see me"

You felt so much elation when you heard that. Finally...! The return to a normal life--!

"I will get in contact with you in three hundred years. Please have some patience"

"Three hundred years?!" Floatzel and you shouted. You got closer to the pearl. "I won't live for not even half of that time!" As soon as you said those words, a strange tingle coursed through your body. "W-Wait, what was..."

"Now you will"

Floatzel raised her head up, politeness be damned. "You can't extend someone's lifespan like that! They need help right now!"

That seemed to have been a bad idea. From the pearl Palkia's voice raised its intensity, turning so loud you felt it in your bones. "I believe I made myself clear! Since when is the human so important they deserve to be placed ahead of the millions of Pokemon that desire my favor? Don't they deserve my help as well?!" Oh. So that was what was going on. That was why they didn't want to help you right way, even though they very clearly could. Palkia wanted to take their duties in order, and since millions of Pokemon asked for help before you...

You conked your head against the pearl. "Please, there has to be a way for me--"

"...I have a proposal for you." they said almost immediately. Oh, that manipulative dragon...they must have felt for desperate you were.

You raised your head. Behind you, Floatzel's ears perked up. "Yes? What's the proposal?"

"Human, there's a favor I'd like to ask of you. Let's say your current size would be quite advantageous for you, for the completion of such favor. Perhaps even favors in plural, now that I think about it."

You held onto the pearl like it was a lifesaver in a stormy sea, although you didn't like the inflection of the word 'favor'. It sounded like a foreboding omen. "What do I have to do?"

"I'm not claiming if you complete my request or requests you will be taken to the top of the waiting list, but I may speed things along for you to not have to wait three hundred years. I imagine moving you up the list a few years a time for every favor you make would be welcome"

"Yes, definitely! But what do I have to do?"

"Will you accept or not, human?"

They were pressing an answer out of you. You peered deep into the pearl. Like images of a movie, moments of your time shrunken flashed in your head.

You had been eaten by a Noibat, almost died in their stomach, had to travel through the intestines to leave, met Honchkrow, was shoved into his bottom because of his perverted desires, trekked through a ruined manor, met Floatzel, got swallowed by her while you got as far as possible from the manor, was taken up her throat, went to a swamp, was stolen by Abra, got teleported into Vaporeon's bladder, crawled through his dick, was a third wheel in two Pokemon's lust-filled urges, and saw in more detail than you'd have liked how Feraligatr digested his food.

And all that had happened in three or four days. If you had to wait three hundred years, you were sure by then you'd have been inside every Pokemon species in existence's bodies. Twice.

The same fire of determination that had been sparked within you the day before swelled up. There was absolutely no way you'd let such a fate happen to you.

"I don't like this," said Floatzel, bringing you down to earth for a moment. She had stepped back, eyeing the pearl warily. The excitement she had felt before was gone. "Why aren't they explaining what they want? Why do they want you to accept before you even know what you'll be doing?"

"It's..." you had no rebuttal. You also had a feeling once you said yes there'd be no way back. Floatzel sighed.

"I never thought I'd say this, but Palkia seems to be a jerk."

"I believe you have no say in any of this, Floatzel. Stay silent." Palkia said. Definitely a jerk. "Human, my patience has a limit. I want a response. Right now."

You crossed your arms. Floatzel was right, something was going on. As you saw it, Palkia's request -- or requests, apparently they were mulling asking you for multiple favors -- was going to be something you wouldn't like at all, or would get you in trouble. Or both. You wouldn't be surprised if it was both. That she had mentioned your size also bothered you a lot. Just what was Palkia thinking right now...?

Finally, you respond.
1141111212121121132221222112312113211111.title: Legendary Contact

choices: “...infiltrate a Legend’s domain in an act of subterfuge.”
“...retrieve one of my pearls from the innards of a giant Pokemon.”
1141111212121121132221222112312113211111.content:
“I accept!” You proclaim, the sound of your voice echoes, reverberating across the cold stone chamber for an uncomfortable amount of time. Floatzel flashes you an unsure glance.
         “Not sure what you’re plan—”
         And then she’s gone. More accurately, you’re gone. In a blink of an eye, you were blinked away and found yourself in a new, alien environment. You’re floating in a dark void. Pinpricks of light—white stars—surround you from every which way. Great colorful billows of cosmic gas are brushed across the galactic sky, dotted with spiraling galaxies and distant planets.
         But consuming your vision is the godlike form of Palkia. Their bipedal, dinosaur-like is marble-white and streaked with lines of fuschia. You float at chest height, forcing you to crane your neck upward, daring to look the legendary in their crimson eyes. Palkia harrumphs.
         “You possess quite the nerve to look a Legend in the eye.” They say, staring you down with unfamothable gravity. You swallow hard and breathe celestial air.
         “I’m sorry—”
         “Silence your jabbering. I will overlook your dereliction. Just this once.” An invisible hand pulls you upwards, dangling you at eye-level with the dragon. You quickly break your gaze. But Palkia’s leer only strengthens.
         “Something wrong, human? You did wish for us to speak eye-to-eye, yes?”
         You creak your head towards the giant, not yet ready to look them in the eye once more. “I’m just… afraid.” Palkia exhales when you say that.
         “Ah, yes. Fear. An appropriate emotion for a mortal to have.” You feel the psionic tug you backward, granting you some space from Palkia’s scowling face and maw. “Do you fear that I will consume you?” Palkia asks.
         You answer truthfully. “A little bit…”
         Palkia’s expression lays still as stone. “A reasonable fear.” They answer, bearing no hint of emotion in their voice. “You will stow it, however. I will not consume you. You are too valuable to waste.” You remain on edge. Something about the Dragon-type’s answer doesn’t quite sit right…
         Suddenly, a sharp pop rings out in the empty void. A familiar face reappears in front of you: Floatzel. Disoriented, the mustelid flicks her muzzle around, stopping when she spots the enormous dragon—shaking in a mix of fear and excitement.
         “W-wow…” Her whisper barely leaves her mouth before Palkia speaks again, not even acknowledging her presence.
         “This is your friend, correct?”
         You nod, afraid that saying anything at all might put the both of you in danger. The monumental Legend rumbles deep in their chest.
         “She has accepted my proposal as well. Sadly, her size is a detriment. Quite useless.”
         Floatzel looks like she’s been slapped. “Useless?? I’m an adventurer! And the only reason I gave your pact a go was to help out my little buddy!” She gestures her paws toward you. “I know I’m useful for something!”
         “Quite so.” Palkia replies without breaking their laser-sharp gaze. “Listen very closely, human. Your friend will be both your motivation and collaborator.” You finally muster up the courage to stare Palkia back.
         “What does that even mean?” You spot what looks to be a wry smirk line the wrinkle of Palkia’s mouth.
         “She will shall share your curse, or be collateral.” You and Floatzel look on in horror as Palkia continues. “She will accompany you in your task, sharing in your diminishment. The effects aren’t permanent of course, should you succeed. Although, if you fail, you will forfeit her to me.” Palkia growls. Perhaps they’re chuckling?
         Either way, Palkia bears their red eyes into you, finishing their speech. “And after 25 years without food, I am ravenous.”
         You’re shaking, but Floatzel isn’t having it. Without a word, she blasts a jet of water toward the Dragon-type. It splashes against his scales, harmless bouncing off before drifting off into the void. At that, Palkia recognizes Floatzel, peering down at her from above.
         “Insubordinate… and churlish. I pray that your friend will fail.” A burst of searing pink energy envelops Floatzel. And when the chaotic sparks die down, you behold Floatzel’s reduced size: same as yours. You watch your otter friend, bravest ‘Mon you’ve known, quiver in fear.
         Palkia dismissively waves a claw, sending Floatzel floating your way. For the first time, you’re able to talk to her without the otter towering over you like a Tyrantrum.
         “Floatzel, are you oka—”
         “Niceties later.” Palkia booms. “You will begin your first task now.”
         “You must…”
1141111212121121132221222112312113211111.title: Cosmic Contract

choices: Do as Palkia says: weaken Xerneas with poison
Make contact with Xerneas and ask them to bestow protection on Floatzel
Betray Palkia and work to hurt them instead
1141111212121121132221222112312113211111.content:
Palkia's order leaves you without breath. You had gone through so much, and got the best lead you could ask for...and the price is being a pawn in the Legendary Pokemon's struggle for power! You exchange a look of disbelief with Floatzel. It's rather amazing to you how much easier you can read her expressions now that she's right in front of you: she can't believe what she just heard, either.

"Wait, how are we going to do that?"

"That is something you must think by yourself. I have given you the order, and it's your duty to complete it."

In other words: Floatzel and you are on your own. For a second you wonder if that's their way of pushing Floatzel closer to her doom. You certainly didn't want her to be digested by that oversized dragon! Swallowing back protests, you ask: "Alright...whose domain will we infiltrate?"

Soon you're being shown in your mind an image of a Pokemon you recall hearing legends about before. It's a rather tall black and blue stag, with an impressive set of antlers. What was its name...Xerneas? With domain over life?

Palkia explains, the image intensifying. "That's Xerneas. For the last few years they have been rather insistent about keeping several of us Dragon-type Legends in check -- in their own words. They're borderline paranoid, and there's not much we can do about it." You imagine it's hard when Xerneas has a decisive type advantage over them. The image transforms, a tree replacing Xerneas' form. "When Xerneas needs time to rest, they are forced to transform into a tree for a thousand years. That's your mission:

You must make it so Xerneas transforms into a tree."

Pretty tall order for a pair of beings not even tall enough to reach over Xerneas' hooves. You don't even know how to get started. Floatzel looks as much at a loss as you.

"You have a day to do so. If you fail, I'll give good use to your friend, as a morsel," they warned you one last time. You don't even have time to reply to that before you find yourself in a different place.

Palkia had the courtesy of directly transporting you to Xerneas' domain. A bright, blue sky shone way above you. There were countless trees, plants, and flowers all around you, a lush and colorful garden worth admiring. You're currently on a grassy hill, and at the bottom, you see your target: Xerneas.

The stag is right there, legs folded, head held high. They seem to be contemplating something, hopefully deep enough in contemplation not to notice you. Floatzel gets closer to you.

"...we have to think of something," she urges you. You sigh.

"Trust me, I know. I don't want Palkia to eat you."

"I mean, I admit I'm kinda interested on how things are like inside a Pokemon, but definitely not if it means dying..." she says. Giving her a comforting pat on the back, she and you start thinking as hard as possible how to tackle the impossible-looking task you have been given.

Luckily for you both, it seems Xerneas is in no hurry to move somewhere else, they have barely moved their head during the last hour. You sat on a pebble, staring at the stag as if that was going to reveal a weakness you could exploit.

"You said Xerneas is Fairy-type, right? Weak to Poison and Steel?"

"Yeah. Why?"

Floatzel is rather invested in the success of this mission -- obviously, since failing meant she'd be in grave danger. She looks around with expert eye. "There are a lot of plants here. I'm certain we can find a poisonous plant we can use"

Your eyes widen. "That's not going to kill them, right?"

"Of course not! I doubt any plant will be intense enough to kill even you."

"If they grew everything in this place then I doubt they can be fooled into eating poisonous plants," you point out. Floatzel examines the leaves of a nearby bush, liking what they see.

"We just have to get the poison into their body somehow, without them noticing. That should weaken them and force them to transform into a tree."

If a Legendary Pokemon could be defeated by putting poisonous plants inside them then they weren't really that impressive, you thought. You weren't sure the plan would work, but it was the best idea you both had -- for the mission, that is. You had a different idea.

"We also could ask Xerneas for help."

Floatzel shot you a look of disbelief. "Help about how to weaken them?!"

"Of course not! Help about saving you," you hurry to explain before Floatzel can think of a rebuttal: "Xerneas has domain over life. What if they can use their powers to keep you alive and safe even if Palkia eats you?"

The otter seems intrigued, although not very convinced. "I...I guess they could do that, but what will we do when Palkia eats me?"

"...we'll think of that later," you say. She was right, you'd both need some sort of plan of action for such a case. You weren't sure you could even stand around and do nothing while Palkia gobbled down your friend.

Floatzel plucked one of the leaves. "We don't even know if Xerneas would want to protect me, and I don't...like the idea of Palkia eating me."

"Sorry, we can think something else."

"We have been thinking for one hour and that's all we have! We have to start doing something or else the time will run out," she said, tearing the leaf into pieces easier to carry. She stops for a moment and adds something, though: "I think you noticed I'd like to proceed with the poisoning Xerneas plan, but...if you insist with your idea...I guess I'll play along."

For a moment you had the rather unkind thought she was pushing a tough responsibility onto you. You stamp down that thought and think carefully your options:

You could do what Palkia asked you to do. To achieve that, Floatzel and you would have to somehow get poisonous leaves into Xerneas' system without them suspecting anything. There wasn't even a guarantee some leaves would be enough to affect the stag that much, even with their weakness.

Or you could make contact with Xerneas and ask them to bestow their protection onto Floatzel, so when the time for Palkia to punish you and her by eating her, she'd survive. There was the problem of making it so Palkia doesn't notice your friend hadn't been digested, though. Getting them out of Palkia safely was a challenge, too. Not only that, you also doubted you do nothing while Palkia ate your friend, and there was a chance the dragon would lose their patience and eat you too. Also, there was no guarantee Xerneas would protect Floatzel.

A third option crossed your mind: rebel. Plot against Palkia somehow, to weaken them. It'd mean surrendering any chance of a return to normalcy, but...you really didn't like Palkia. Not when they were making you take such hard choices.

Either way it seemed that both the subterfuge option and the mission failure option had rather high chances of you paying a visit to a Legend's insides. Two drastically different bodies, and neither could really be classified as the lesser evil.

Having considered your options, you tell Floatzel what needed to be done.
1141111212121121132221222112312113211111.title: Agent of Subterfuge

choices: Xerneas raised her tail and presented her rear—she chanced upon a mate.
Xerneas can't hold it anymore. She moans as her crotch grows tight…
You feel a pressure on the top of your head. Is that... her cervix? Oh no...
1141111212121121132221222112312113211111.content:
Floatzel's arms go a little slack as she looks at you with smattering of a weariness, looking like some of her wind was swept from her sails. "Look. I know I said I'd go along with whatever you said…" Floatzel trails off to snatch a glance at the contemplating Xerneas, swiveling her head over and back again. She turns back to you. "...But can you please reconsider!" The weasel-otter shakes her armful of leaves for emphasis.
         "Floatzel, what are the chances we can really poison a legendary?" The stare she's giving you tells you she remains unconvinced.
         "Look," you say, trying a different approach, "even if—and that's a big if—we successfully poison Xerneas, do you remember what happens next?"
         "I get taken off the menu?"
         "Xerneas becomes a tree! We'll be in them!" Floatzel is shocked still. Bits of leaves slip through her paws and begin to flutter to the floor.
         You continue. "You've got to trust me Floatzel! I'm not gonna let you be gobbled up by that jerk!" Floatzel bites her lip, looking away for a moment before popping her face back to you; an unsteady grin on her muzzle.
         "Then let's get a move-on." She says, dropping her armful of poisonous foliage. "And thank you."
         You both find your way down the hill with relative ease—slipping and speeding between blades of grass, shoots, and flowers. Honestly, it's a lot of fun! And when you find yourself beside the great blue stag, with their golden antlers, black underbelly, and blue coat—you find yourself lifted with a bit of a runner's high.
         You walk along the side of the great beast. Looking up at their towering head, high as a skyscraper—staring off into the sky—you feel the first pang of doubt. As you go past their tucked in hooves, you hope you've made the right choice.
         And soon you and Floatzel stand directly below Xerneas's head, held high and proud. Floatzel doesn't wait before greeting the Fairy with her best shout.
         "HEEEY!" She hollers. Xerneas doesn't even flinch in surprise. They simply slowly tilt their head down, looking right at your orange friend.
         "Curious." Xerneas muses. Her voice is distinctly feminine.
         "CAN YOU HEAR ME?"
         "It's unnecessary to shout." The doe states calmly. She huffs a puff of air from her nostrils.
         "Sorry about that…" Floatzel rubs the back of her head. "So, uh, how you doing?"
         "I contemplate the meaning of the cosmos. Life is serendipitous in its serenity. Can you not espy nature's celestial wonder?"
         Floatzel looks on blankly. "I haven't a clue of half the words you just said, lady— I mean ma'am." You decide to try and salvage things.
         "Look," you begin, "we don't mean to trouble you Xerneas. We need your help." Xerneas' face doesn't show any flicker of emotion. What is it with Legendaries and their cool looks??
         "You are quite brave." Xerneas says with a hint of… admiration, possibly? "It must've been arduous to journey here. You've braved the grove's fearsome traps: the fearsome forest of Trevanant, the eternal watching eyes of the Decidueye, the bone-quaking guard of—"
         "It was really hard. Yeah." Floatzel interrupts. "Sorry for rushing things along, but we've got a ticking clock above our heads."
         "You clearly do not. I see nothing. And my eyesight is peerless."
         "...It's metaphorical. But anyway, Palkia wants us—specifically me—gone. And by us, I mean you and me, just so we're clear." Floatzel's looking more and more nervous by the second. And greater her fear grows, the more she begins talking with her paws. Xerneas watches it all with an unflinching eye. "...and so we need your help, great Xerneas!" Floatzel finishes dramatically.
         Xerneas hums. "It ails my heart to see such frail creatures troubled so." With her next words, you feel her water-blue iris pierce through your soul. "I will assist you."
         Floatzel is ecstatic. Her two tails spin wildly, thumping on the ground as they try to make a full rotation.          "Awesome! Thank you, thank you!" Floatzel bounces up with revitalized energy. "What do we gotta do, Mrs. Doe?"
         Xerneas inspects the both of you before looking cooly back toward Floatzel. "Hm. To ensure your safe ingress, embrace your friend."
         "No clue what you're saying, but I know what I've gotta do!" Floatzel beams as she springs over to you, smashing you into her chest and hugging you tight. She closes her eyes as your face is stuffed in her fur. It smells kinda nice, you guess…
         But your Spinarak-senses begin tingling when feel the pleasant warmth of the sun's touch snuff out. You look down. The ground is eclipsed in shadow. You look up. Xerneas is lining up her rear above your head.
         You sputter an ugly gasp. "What are you doing!?"
         Floatzel opens her eyes just in time to see the doe's rear come crashing down.
         Immediately things become tight, wet, and hot. You and Floatzel are pressed up together as Xerneas groans, her grousings traveling through her cramped walls in a rumbling earthquake.
